statement: In the Wisconsin health insurance exchange, "the Society of Actuaries points out that there'll be, according to them, an 82 percent increase in individual premiums over the next couple years under Obamacare."

statement: "I’ve got the spending down, I’ve got the debt down a little bit, I’ve got the reserves up."

statement: Women in the United States are paid about 70 percent of what men earn for the same work.

statement: "We're already seeing bakers and florists and photographers forced to participate in same-sex marriages under the threat of law and in some cases even jail."

statement: "In New Hampshire, 93 percent of Democrats, 79 percent of Republicans, 82 percent of gun owners and 60 percent of NRA households support background checks."

statement: Says Ken Cuccinelli "attacked churches for helping the poor."

statement: "It is against the law for the NSA to record or monitor Americans’ phone calls without getting a specific FISA warrant to do so."

statement: "Currently, it takes up to 25 years to obtain U.S. citizenship legally" but the Senate bill "would allow immigrants who came to the United States illegally to obtain citizenship in just 13 years."

statement: Rhode Island's graduated driving license "has saved hundreds of lives."

statement: Says Florida "rubber-stamped phony horse racing."

statement: "Abortion is the second-most conducted surgical procedure in this country."

statement: "About 95 percent of (Ohio’s) electricity comes from burning coal."

statement: Says President Obama has cracked down "on employers who are attracting undocumented immigrants and hiring them more than any previous president."

statement: In South Florida, "we've had nine inches of sea-level rise since the 1920s."

statement: Bob Barr has changed his position on the Defense of Marriage Act over the years.

statement: "Nearly 70 percent of all federal spending will go towards Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid" in fiscal year 2014.

statement: "President Obama has the most border patrols and border security deployed at the border of any previous president."

title: This shot hits the target

statement: In 2008, "only 54 percent of Latinos in Texas were registered to vote and only 35 percent actually turned out."
title: Dividing estimates into estimates

statement: "The hole in the earth that’s going to be dug (for the proposed Gogebic mine) is bigger than my entire district."
title: Small district, big hole

statement: Georgia loses "millions of dollars of revenue because people go out of state to buy fireworks."
title: Kaboom!

statement: "Under Gov. Kasich, Ohio wages have increased by $10.3 billion."
title: On the money

statement: "We have a federal government that thinks they have the authority to regulate our toilet seats."
title: Big Brother in the bathroom

statement: "In the last two years, we have reduced the deficit by $2.5 trillion."
title: Future cuts, and over 10 years, not two

statement: Says Houston is "home to more doctors, more nurses, more researchers than any other place in the world."
title: Compared to what?

statement: Said the year before he took office, the state lost 119,000 private-sector jobs, labeling them "Corzine jobs losses of 2009."
title: Same ol' blame game

statement: Says bag litter increased after San Francisco banned single-use shopping bags.
title: Two-bag spike?

statement: "Scientists tell us that we could have a cure in 10 years for Alzheimer's" were it not for "overzealous regulators, excessive taxation and greedy litigators."
title: Scientists tell us this is nonsense

statement: "Seven of the 10 highest-income counties in the country ring the city" of Washington D.C.
title: It's a well-off capital

statement: Wall Street megabanks that received bailouts in 2009 now get taxpayer-funded advantages not available to community banks in Ohio.
title: Government guarantee but no money changing hands now

statement: Says Virginia, Florida and Georgia are the three states that are the principal source for gun trafficking.
title: Correct when considering size; changes with population

statement: Says we will pay the new chancellor "a basic salary of nearly $300,000 a year ... an amount that does not include the costs of this public employee’s benefits, perks and living expenses for a lavish house, an upscale car, a spending allowance, and fine dining almost every day on the taxpayer dollar."
title: She does get gas, entertaining allowance

statement: "In the United States, 50 percent of social services are provided by the Catholic church."
title: Catholic charity is big, but not that big

statement: Of every "three dollars in food stamps for the needy, seven dollars in salaries and pensions (go to) the bureaucrats who are supposed to be taking care of the poor."
title: Overhead is 5 percent at most, not 70 percent

statement: "Nearly 25 percent of all automobile accidents are caused by texting while driving."
title: Should have said 'distracted driving'

statement: U.S. Rep. Scott Rigell "wants gun owners in a federal registration system."
title: No ammo

statement: "The incidents of threats against (President Barack Obama) are greater than for any other president in modern times."
title: No different than Clinton or George W. Bush

statement: "Taxes and fees amount to about 20 percent of a typical $300 round-trip domestic ticket. That’s higher than taxes on products like alcohol, tobacco and firearms."
title: More like 15%

statement: "DEP has 2,812 employees, the lowest level since the mid-’80s."
title: Numbers are off

statement: "There is no clinical evidence that vaccinating healthcare workers protects patients."
title: Researchers found evidence; others dispute it

statement: Says indoor workers get "less UV than outdoor workers, but they get more melanomas."
title: They get too much bad UVA, not enough good UVB

statement: "In the period from 2007 to 2011, the Office of Health Insurance Commissioner reported an 18 percent decline in the state’s total medical spending."
title: Per-capita spending is up

statement: Rhode Island is the last state still using the Optech III P voting machines and they don’t meet suggested federal standards.
title: Split vote

statement: "Our debt is already bigger than our economy."
title: Which debt?

statement: "The Chinese government provides their people no access to the Internet."
title: Millions use internet in China but censorship is rampant

statement: Says the federal government is supporting a study in Hawaii to "develop a menu for when we colonize Mars."
title: Study is more Mars than Maui

statement: Says president is ‘spending $2.2 billion to give away "ObamaPhones." ’
title: Program predates Obama, doesn’t hand out phones

statement: The transportation package passed by the General Assembly would impose the "largest tax increase in Virginia’s history."
title: Not when inflation is considered

statement: Eighty-five percent of Floridians who will benefit from expanding Medicaid are "single, childless adults."
title: He messed his numbers up

statement: The fiscal cliff agreement was "the largest tax increase in history."
title: Not when using the best measuring stick

statement: Cobb is one of the largest school systems (in the nation) that is debt free.
title: System is in the black

statement: "There are 3 million jobs available in America that are not filled because too many of our people don’t have the skills for those jobs."
title: Not all are unfilled due to skill shortage

statement: "Raising taxes on investment income has actually lowered the revenue received from the tax, while cutting capital gains tax rates has increased revenue."
title: A temporary spike, not a long-term phenomenon

statement: "Super Bowl L by everybody's estimation is a $500 million economic impact to the state of Florida."
title: Study commissioned by Host Committee does not equal "everybody"

statement: "There are 3.6 million jobs sitting vacant, in part because there aren’t enough qualified applicants to fill them."
title: Right diagnosis, wrong evidence

statement: Ohio Republicans made significant gains during [Chris McNulty’s] time at the ORP, including the extremely successful re-election of President Bush in Ohio."
title: McNulty didn’t exactly leave on a high note

statement: "More than 64 percent of minimum-wage earners are women."
title: She's on target

statement: "The majority of my contributions have been from private individuals" giving $125 on average, "not from PACs, not from groups."
title: Individual gifts outpace union PAC money

statement: Georgia has the most lax gun laws in the nation.
title: Many states far lax than Georgia.

statement: "When (John) Brennan ... was asked directly … ‘Is there any geographic limitation to your drone strike program?’ Brennan responded and said, ‘no, there is no limitation.’"
title: That's what he said

statement: Says Jennifer Horn, chairwoman of the N.H. Republican Party, owes $92,000 in back taxes.
title: IRS tax lien speaks volumes

statement: "More than 80 percent of Americans believe we need to have universal background checks."
title: Greater than 90 percent in most cases.

statement: "Over the last 20 years, the world has changed. It used to be that one could make a career out of working for one company. Today, the average worker stays at his or her job for barely four years."
title: Employment tenure has increased

statement: Says, "I-205, six miles of which runs through my district, already carries more traffic than I-5."
title: 11 percent more traffic

statement: "We have no regulation of drones in the United States in their commercial use."
title: No regulation? In fact, a ban

statement: Says 100,000 are on waiting list to attend Texas charter schools.
title: 101,000 students, charter advocacy group says

statement: The Legislature needs to spend $500 million to "shore up" the pension fund this year and the next 28 years to keep it "afloat."
title: Figure right, context off

statement: Research found that "over the course of the existence of the Brady Bill ban, the use of assault weapons in crimes decreased by two thirds."
title: Best number available, but laden with caveats

statement: The Georgia Senate ethics resolution "doesn't define cap."
title: $100 a week? A month?

statement: "There have been literally hundreds of new tax preferences and loopholes added to the code since 1986, last time we did this."
title: Exact number elusive, but hundreds at least

statement: A proposed ban on hollow-point bullets and bullets that expand upon impact "essentially bans deer hunting."
title: It's tough to shoot a deer without a bullet

statement: "Governor Christie, his idea of jumpstarting the economy is to propose a trickle-down income tax cut last year and in his budget address this year, he stated his support for it again."
title: Similar story, similar concerns

statement: Says "Kurt Schrader supports Obama’s sequester … but won’t cut $1.6 million to fund new video games."
title: A time warp leap in logic

statement: "In 32 other states and Washington D.C., they [voters] can avoid the wait by voting before Election Day."
title: Vote early but not often

statement: Florida is "second in the nation in the uninsured."
title: Actually, No. 3

statement: Says Jeb Bush "flip-flop-flip(ped) on immigration."
title: Fair amount of flipping

statement: "In Wisconsin, only half of all the adults with serious psychological distress received mental health treatment or medication."
title: But serious mental illness is different

statement: Says the Georgia Dome would need up to $350 million in work over the next five to seven years.
title: Cost depends on level of work

statement: "The president is advocating a drone strike program in America."
title: No advocacy we could find

statement: "When the president's spokesman was asked about (Anwar) al-Awlaki's son, … he said he should have chosen a more responsible father."
title: Robert Gibbs said it when pressed by activist group

statement: Under Gov. John Kasich’s budget proposal, "the top one percent in Ohio will pay $10,000 less in income tax each year, but Ohio’s working and middle class families will pay more."
title: Some, but not all

statement: "For the first time in eight years, our budget also increases funding for persons with disabilities by $36 million to help more disabled people receive community-based services."
title: Yes, but 21,000 will remain on waiting list

statement: "We have over 300,000,000 weapons, firearms in this country. That’s almost as big as the population."
title: Statistic's on target

statement: "Rhode Island could tell you who has a camper, but we couldn't figure out who has a gun."
title: On target

statement: Of $60 billion Congress approved in response to Hurricane Sandy, "only 10 percent was for disaster relief."
title: Even by narrow definition, he's off

statement: Says if Oregon had limited its budget growth to the rate of population growth plus the rate of inflation, the state’s all-funds budget would be about $27 billion today, not $60 billion.
title: His source got the math wrong, but he has a point

statement: Says Texas has the most uninsured people of any state -- 6 million.
title: Highest rate, not highest number

statement: The United States gives $8 million a day to Israel and gives that country a blank check.
title: Numbers right, "blank check" disputed

statement: A "legacy of taxing and borrowing … crippled the economy we inherited two years ago."
title: The real problem was real estate, real estate, real estate

statement: Says Gov. Rick Scott cut more government jobs than were created in the private sector in Florida in 2012.
title: Only if you stop counting in August

statement: Says Rick Scott called education not a "core function" of the state.
title: Evidence by omission

statement: "Do you know which state has the worst ratio of white voter turnout to African-American voter turnout? Massachusetts. Do you know what has the best, where African-American turnout actually exceeds white turnout? Mississippi."
title: Massachusetts data seems unreliable, but Mississippi is pretty spot on

statement: Says his proposed education spending "is the highest state funding level in Florida history."
title: Not the whole picture

statement: The majority of public funding for the Marlins stadium "came from hotel taxes, the burden of which is incurred by tourists who are visiting our city, NOT the resident taxpayers."
title: It's still public money

statement: "In Atlanta, since 1994 when the ‘Seven Deadly Sins’ (mandatory minimum sentences) took effect, the violent crime rate has dropped 62 percent."
title: Hard to tie crime drop to one reason

statement: "There's no plan from Senate Democrats or the White House to replace the sequester."
title: Start by clicking "PLAN" on White House website

statement: Two-thirds of Wisconsinites receiving unemployment checks "are not required to search for work due to current work search exemptions."
title: Yes, but why is important

statement: New Hampshire is currently the only state in the nation that does not have a full-service veterans hospital or equivalent access.
title: Oft repeated, still half true

statement: Under Gov. Scott Walker’s public-school budgets, "a student entering kindergarten will not enjoy the same state investment in his or her education as those that came before them until they are graduating from high school."
title: Off by several grades

statement: "Since January 2010, New Jersey has added 103,000 new private sector jobs. The last two years -- 2011 and 2012 -- have been the best two years of private sector job growth since 1999."
title: Slow and steady growth

statement: "There's a tax credit of $2,400 to bond [former inmates] that an employer would get for hiring a convicted felon. There's a federal bonding program -- you can get $5,000 to $25,000 in federal money to hire a convicted felon. And there's federal grants for felons to set up their own small businesses."
title: Claim needs rehabilitation

statement: Says "Studies show the average age of entry into prostitution is 12 to 14 years old."
title: Some studies back this up, for juveniles only

statement: Says a majority of Americans -- and Republicans -- support his approach for deficit reduction.
title: Tax increases and spending cuts

statement: Says that since 1975, redistricting by Texas lawmakers has always been found in violation of Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act.
title: One way yes, the other no

statement: Due to the sequester, "people are going to be unsafe. Homes are going to burn."
title: Sequester probably won't be burning down the house

statement: Virginia is "the only state" that has a tradition of attorneys general resigning if they run for governor.
title: A unique custom

statement: "There are literally teachers now who are getting pink slips" because of sequestration.
title: Literally, not really

statement: Says the "last non-partisan commission to improve the voting experience in America concluded that #VoterID was necessary."
title: Envisioned free IDs for needy

statement: "Of the 18 stadiums built from 2004 to 2013, 47 percent of the total cost came from public sources."
title: Close to the mark

statement: In annual surveys of Rhode Island communities that receive Drug Free community grants, many report that more than 50 percent of youth surveyed do not think daily marijuana use poses any serious risk of harm.
title: No reefer madness here

statement: Says the federal government is earning more tax revenue now "than any other time."
title: Not what the best measure shows

statement: "Property taxes had increased 70 percent in the previous 10 years."
title: Depends on use of tax rebates

statement: "About two-thirds of all consumption is services. . . It was just the opposite" when the sales tax was enacted in the '30s.
title: A service economy

statement: "There's going to be a slowdown and delays in flights" as a result of the sequester.
title: Prepare to wait

statement: Says "Did you know that the #KeystoneXL project is expected to create 20,000 American jobs, including more than 800 in Oregon?"
title: This pipeline is pumping some slippery claims

statement: Comic strip says government study shows Head Start "has little or no impact on the children it’s supposed to help."
title: Gains made, then lost

statement: "This is a test of the fact-checking widget."
title: Just another test

statement: "When I ran against incumbent President Gerald Ford, you know how much money we raised? None."
title: For his campaign, no, but for other groups, yes

statement: Felony crimes in the city of Atlanta are the lowest they have been since 1969.
title: It's been a long time

statement: In a budget deal struck in 2011 "a trillion dollars of cuts went into effect immediately, and then a special committee was set up ... to get agreement on another $3 trillion of cuts."
title: Cuts not immediate, for one thing

statement: Says that except for foreign policy, Ron Paul’s voting record and his voting record are virtually identical.
title: Paul, Broun: ballot buddies

statement: "You can't bring an iPad or a piece of paper and a pencil in the (Wisconsin Assembly) gallery to take notes of what's going on," but "you can bring a gun up there."
title: Right on guns, iPad; but pencil and paper?

statement: "New Jersey has lost over half of our pharmaceutical jobs to states you know, not low-tax states like in the South, but high-tax states like New York."
title: A bitter pill

statement: Of six Rhode Island tax-credit programs worth about $35 million, "three companies got 90 percent of that -- CVS and two companies not even located in the state of Rhode Island."
title: CVS got 59 percent of the total

statement: Knopp says he upheld a campaign promise not to join the Public Employees Retirement System (PERS).
title: After he cashed out his account in 2010

statement: If the sequester hits, federal prosecutors will have to "let criminals go."
title: Scare tactic

statement: "Kewpie burgers are delicious. An Ohio institution. And they'll cost less thanks to John Kasich's tax cut."
title: For here, or to go?

statement: "In other jurisdictions where (a domestic partnership registry) has been enacted, we have seen that fewer people enter into marriage."
title: Marriage is down all over

statement: Says if Congress doesn’t avoid the sequester, "tens of thousands of parents will have to scramble to find child care for their kids."
title: Could be tens of thousands — or not

statement: "The National Science Foundation spent $1.2 million paying seniors to play World of Warcraft to study the impact it had on their brain."
title: Pure fantasy

statement: "What concerns me is there is only two sentences that have been written about minority business."
title: Devil in the details, and those aren't done yet

statement: "More than 9,000 Rhode Island voters used the Moderate Party master lever mechanism and they didn't have a single Moderate on their ballot."
title: Voters can't master the master lever

statement: Without a Medicaid expansion, 275,000 more Ohioans could be getting their primary care in emergency rooms, costing "everybody a lot of money."
title: Costly care

statement: If the sequester hits, "hundreds of thousands of Americans will lose access to primary care and preventive care like flu vaccinations and cancer screenings."
title: Sequester offers little flexibility

statement: The sequester "won’t consider whether we’re cutting some bloated program that has outlived its usefulness, or a vital service that Americans depend on every single day. It doesn’t make those distinctions."
title: Some discretion in cutting, but not much

statement: Says Travis County's unemployment rate is below the national average while its poverty rate exceeds the national average--and local poverty is rising.
title: UPDATED: Poverty up since 2000, but local rate sometimes goes down

statement: "There’s more murders with hammers last year than...shotguns and pistols and AK-47s."
title: Upon further review

statement: Says, "when this governor came to office, he had (an) 11 billion dollar  - I call it mismanagement – deficit."
title: A theoretical deficit

statement: Says Chuck Hagel’s nomination as defense secretary "has been publicly celebrated by the Iranian government."
title: One man hoping

statement: Federal spending on entitlements "is projected to consume all revenue by 2045."
title: A projection, not a certainty

statement: "The only time in our history when the debt has been higher than this was the end of World War II."
title: Debt is at a 60-year high

statement: Says after Hurricane Sandy, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg "refused to allow the National Guard into the city to restore civil order because Guardsmen carry guns!"
title: Guard was already there without guns

statement: "The president flagrantly defies the 2006 federal law ordering the construction of a secure border fence along the entire Mexican border."
title: There. Is. A. Fence.

statement: "The group that supported the president’s health care bill the most? Latinos."
title: Blacks also supported it strongly

statement: "Nobody in total is proposing cutting anything. We’re trying to reduce the rate of growth in government."
title: Plenty of cuts, but growth overall

statement: "There are more people killed with baseball bats and hammers than are killed with guns."
title: More than rifles? Yes. More than all guns? No.

statement: Says "If Oregon’s Legislature simply authorizes $450 million for the CRC, it will … leave Oregon holding the bag for a great deal more cost responsibility."
title: Interstate agreement calls for costs to be split 50-50

statement: "Phoenix is already one of the kidnapping capitals of the world."
title: Scary stat still wrong

statement: "The majority of (the American people) voted for a Democratic House."
title: An odd occurrence

statement: "There are 3 million jobs that go vacant each month in this country."
title: Help wanted

statement: Says Austin is the largest city in the U.S. without nonstop flights to Europe.
title: Except for 4 bigger cities

statement: "Collectively states are spending more on Medicaid than they do on K-12 education."
title: But U.S. picks up most of the Medicaid tab for states

statement: "Every dollar we invested in high-quality, early education programs can save more than $7 later on by boosting graduation rates, reducing teen pregnancy, even reducing crime."
title: It's complicated

statement: Says wrestling was a favorite sport of Abraham Lincoln.
title: Abe could put you in a half nelson

statement: Says of a failed cloture vote on nominating Chuck Hagel for defense secretary: "This is not a filibuster."
title: 60 votes usually means filibuster

statement: "Agriculture has always required a significant workforce from abroad."
title: In some cases and places, not always

statement: The United States does "not have a system through which growers and dairies can bring a workforce legally into the U.S."
title: There is a program, but no one likes it

statement: Wisconsin's Supreme Court justices are "deciding fewer opinions in civil and criminal cases than they used to."
title: Numbers steady amid conflicts

statement: In Virginia "there has been a billion dollars in surplus over the last three years. The legislature has spent less than 1 percent of that on roads."
title: Wrong number

statement: Says she heard more than 2,400 cases as a Wisconsin appeals court judge
title: Decides a lot, authors fewer

statement: Says 2012 was the "first year in American history that more minorities are being born than people in the majority."
title: Wrong year, mayor

statement: Employers and schools have no right to conduct "surveillance of a dorm room or a worker’s cubicle."
title: Employers CAN watch you work

statement: Says, "Statistics indicate that one in eight children, and one in 18 adults in Oregon suffers from mental illness."
title: One in eight is on the high end of estimates

statement: "Lots of studies seem to indicate that minors find it very easy to get marijuana, easier than to get alcohol."
title: Marijuana not easier to get than alcohol among youth

statement: Says he "has repeatedly praised Chuck Hagel’s character, patriotism, bravery, and personal service defending our nation."
title: Smile, then swing

statement: "The 12 hottest years on record have come in the last 15 years."
title: It's even worse than he says

statement: Wisconsin’s laws "ranked the worst in the world for mining investment."
title: Ranking outdated, misleading

statement: "I was the first member of Congress to call him (Barack Obama) a socialist..."
title: Ohio senator takes the title

statement: Says Texas is last in workers' compensation coverage.
title: Texas law unique

statement: "Ohio companies export more goods and services globally than 41 other states."
title: We're Number 9

statement: "Already, the Affordable Care Act is helping to slow the growth of (Medicare’s) health care costs."
title: Grabbing credit before it's proven

statement: Says he and Mitt Romney agreed on tying minimum wage increases to inflation.
title: Romney, Obama on same side

statement: "I still live in the same working-class neighborhood I grew up in."
title: You mean the house that's for sale?

statement: "We have doubled the distance our cars will go on a gallon of gas."
title: Doubled ... in 2025

statement: "We have a governor who's vetoed measures like increasing our minimum wage and restoring the earned income tax cut."
title: Vetoed and proposed

statement: Says Texas ranks first among the states in the amount of carbon dioxide emitted and toxic chemicals released into water.
title: Aye one way, nay other ways

statement: "Throughout, we have kept Congress fully informed of our efforts" to create a legal framework on counterterrorism.
title: Lots of Members of Congress don't think so

statement: Says Texas has the nation’s most uninsured residents.
title: A million more live in the Golden State

statement: Says he was the first local official to endorse Barack Obama
title: If Fitz endorses but no one’s around, does he make a noise?

statement: "I was never against same-sex marriage."
title: Claim not an open-and-shut case

statement: Says "overwhelming majorities of Americans" support gun legislation "like background checks."
title: True of background checks -- but other proposals?

statement: Military spending cuts, known as the sequester, were President Barack Obama’s idea.
title: Obama opposes the cuts

statement: Says his administration has made "progress" on border enforcement by "putting more boots on the southern border than at any time in our history and reducing illegal crossings to their lowest levels in 40 years."
title: The facts are accurate; the credit is less clear

statement: "Our economy actually shrank during the last three months of 2012."
title: It shrank slightly, but it did shrink

statement: "After shedding jobs for more than 10 years, our manufacturers have added about 500,000 jobs over the past three."
title: Yes, but new jobs just a fraction of those lost

statement: Says abortions are decreasing.
title: Down by thousands

statement: State support for local schools per pupil has decreased by at least 25 percent over the past decade.
title: Math correct, but needs more context

statement: Says, "Since 1994 when VAWA was first passed, incidents of domestic violence have dropped more than 50 percent."
title: A number of sources agree

statement: "When the Affordable Care Act was signed, 17 million American children" had a pre-existing condition and were "uninsurable."
title: Few lacked insurance because of condition

statement: Says Texas high school "graduation rates are at an all-time high—the third-highest in the nation—which represents a significant turnaround from just a few short years ago."
title: Behind three other states

statement: "Three in four low-income workers don’t have any paid sick days available."
title: Double trouble: Low pay and don't get sick

statement: There are twice as many gun shops as McDonald’s in the United States.
title: Will that rifle complete your order?

statement: Except for Virginia, "the other 49 states keep raising their gas tax."
title: Fueless statement

statement: Says U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wisconsin, was elected in a "very low turnout" race.
title: Only compared to presidential years

statement: Says "right now, we have more military spending than the next 10, 11, 12 countries combined."
title: Leader of the pack

statement: More than 40 percent of sales nationally are made without background checks.
title: Figure is 15 years old

statement: Says Austin trains are "full" at rush hour and "packed" for special events.
title: Standing room only

statement: "With the exception of slavery and the Chinese Exclusion Act, our laws have never barred persons from becoming citizens."
title: Other Asian immigrants affected too

statement: Says Texas is "last in mental health expenditures."
title: But for Idaho

statement: "The brutal fact is, when it comes to education, America is slipping" behind other nations.
title: Doesn't add up

statement: Says Texas ranks first in executions among the states.
title: For last year and over the years

statement: Says Texas ranks last in the percentage of residents with high school diplomas.
title: Tied with California, Mississippi in 2011

statement: Florida has "the second-lowest (campaign) contribution limit in the entire country."
title: Not so $imple

statement: "When total Sandy spending is added up, it's more than the annual budget for the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. And it's more than twice the annual budget of the U.S. Energy Department."
title: Numbers are pretty close

statement: "This is the first time since Roe was decided in 1973 that a court has granted personhood status to the preborn."
title: Issue has already had its day in court

statement: Says each year approximately 30,000 people in the United States die as a result of gunfire, and about 80,000 people are wounded.
title: Numbers haven't changed much

statement: Tide gauges measuring sea level in Rhode Island since 1930 have risen "maybe about 10 inches since that time."
title: True for Newport, less so for Providence

statement: "We’re taxing our small businesses now at rates higher than corporations."
title: Not true for most

statement: Says the pension and health benefits reform "eliminated collective bargaining for health benefits."
title: Not eliminated forever

statement: Says Gov. John Kasich can remove the president of the State Board of Education.
title: He's got the bully pulpit

statement: "Washington, D.C., now has greater population than Wyoming and Vermont, more active duty military than 29 states, more tax revenue than 29 states (and) a larger domestic product than 27 states."
title: Stats are a mixed bag

statement: Says his budget provides "the highest state funding level in history" for education.
title: Not the whole story

statement: Wisconsin state lawmakers worked seven days in 2012 but got "paid for a whole year."
title: Mighty narrow definition of worked

statement: Says "in Katrina, they approved $60 billion within 10 days of the storm on a voice vote."
title: Roll call on Katrina

statement: Says out-of-state abortion clinics "have marketed their services to minors" in states with parental consent laws.
title: Fits the definition

statement: Says "MAX carries 30 percent of evening rush-hour commuters traveling from Downtown on the Sunset and Banfield freeways."
title: They did the math, and they did it right.

statement: "A majority of Americans agree with" a ban on assault weapons. "And by the way, so did Ronald Reagan."
title: History, polling support claim

statement: "One-third of the gasoline is purchased by out-of-state people" in Virginia
title: No fuel for this claim

statement: 40 percent of U.S. gun sales "are occurring outside of" licensed gun dealers.
title: Dated data

statement: "Forty-seven percent of (members of Congress) are millionaires."
title: No disputing this 47 percent claim.

statement: "Ohio is doing better right now than the national average on all the (economic) numbers."
title: A little word that means a lot

statement: Says the claim that 40 percent of guns are sold without background checks traces to information gathered before background checks were even required.
title: Wrong on timing, right on weaknesses

statement: In 2009, the FBI "referred more than 71,000" cases of people failing background checks when trying to buy a gun to another federal agency, "but U.S. attorneys ultimately prosecuted only 77 of them."
title: Many can't be prosecuted

statement: Says "on the state level, we spend less today than Jon Corzine spent in fiscal year 2008, five years later."
title: Recent spending is up

statement: "Eighty percent of those who have applied for licenses have no cancer, no Parkinson's disease or glaucoma. They have nothing you would associate [with] the use of medical marijuana."
title: Laws allow use for many conditions

statement: "Statistics show one male cat can father 420,000 kittens in five years."
title: Cat-agorically untrue

statement: Says ending the direct payment farm subsidy program "could save up to $28.4 billion over ten years that could be used to reduce the deficit."
title: More than just peanuts; cutting crop subsidies could save $$$$

statement: Says that 9 million to 50 million undocumented immigrants live in the United States.
title: Around 11 million, experts say

statement: Says his plan to raise car registration to $56 would still leave Virginia with a fee that’s "equal to or lower than most states."
title: Wrong and without basis

statement: "As a result of National Rifle Association and other private-sector (safety-education) programs, fatal firearms accidents are at the lowest level in 100 years."
title: Bottomed out in 2009, up slightly since

statement: Says "the jurisdictions with the strictest gun control laws, almost without exception … have the highest crime rates and the highest murder rates."
title: Contradictions aren’t hard to find

statement: Odds of winning the Monopoly Millionaire instant win game are 1 in 3.27.
title: A free ticket is beating the odds

statement: "States have cumulatively cut over $1.8 billion from their mental health services between 2009 and 2011. This is the largest reduction in state mental health services in half a century."
title: Cuts were largest in decades

statement: Research shows that "a vast majority of arriving immigrants today come here because they believe that government is the source of prosperity, and that's what they support."
title: What research?

statement: Says since Australia passed tough gun laws, "homicides by firearm have declined almost 60 percent."
title: It's no horror story

statement: "I had to lay off 48 people last year," which has exacerbated the lack of law enforcement officers in the county that respond quickly to crime calls.
title: Sheriff’s Office responds to few crime calls

statement: Says "the area damaged by Hurricane Sandy represents roughly 10 percent of our nation's economy."
title: Sandy hit Buffalo?

statement: Says the New Year’s Day "fiscal cliff" deal "reduces the deficit."

statement: "Approximately 43 percent of all college grades today are A's, an increase of 28 percentage points since 1960."

statement: Says according to the FBI, more people are killed each year with hammers and clubs than rifles.

statement: "Today, about 40 percent of guns are purchased without a background check."

statement: Says Chuck Hagel has called for "an end to our nuclear program."

statement: "State revenue projections have missed the mark month after month."

statement: "When George Bush became president of the United States, 17 million people were in poverty. When he left, 30 million people were in poverty."

statement: Says Oak Grove is "one of the largest cities in Oregon" and is "the biggest city in Clackamas County and it's not a city."

statement: Driving with a dog in your lap is dangerous, in part, because it could fly forward in a crash. "An 80-pound dog at only 30 mph packs a 2,400-pound punch."

statement: "One out of every five law enforcement officers that's killed is killed with an assault weapon."

statement: Says state workers have not had across-the-board raises in six years.

statement: "Since last year’s address, more than 10,000 jobs created -- many on the high end of the employment scale."

statement: "Spending of government money is 17 percent less than it was a decade ago."

statement: Since taking office in January 2011, "the ‘rainy day’ fund has increased by 226 percent."

statement: A Paul Ryan-Scott Walker (or Scott Walker-Paul Ryan) ticket for the White House in 2016 would be unconstitutional because both men live in Wisconsin.

statement: "Washington, D.C., had some of the strictest gun laws in the country. And when they passed them, violence skyrocketed."

statement: "We just had someone last week in Neenah near a school kill someone with a bow and arrow."

statement: The federal government owns 30 percent of the land in the 50 states, or about 650 million acres.

statement: A Republican-sponsored Wisconsin mining bill "will take at least seven years to create jobs."

statement: Says Chris Christie "vetoed" a "jobs package" of "30 bills."

statement: "Religious groups like Knights of Columbus have been forced to allow same-sex marriage ceremonies in their facilities, against their beliefs."

statement: Says "Abortion clinics in Oregon, as in most states, have no state oversight and are not held to basic health or safety standards."

statement: Under President Barack Obama, "8.3 (million) fewer Americans are working today than there were four years ago."

statement: We have the fourth highest in-state tuition for public universities in the country.

statement: "The last time Republicans held hostage a resolution to ensure that our country’s bills were paid cost us more than $1 billion in added interest and slowed the economic recovery."

statement: Says U.S. Rep. John Barrow, D-Ga., celebrates gun ownership even in the face of school shootings.

statement: The tax penalty that the government imposes if you don't buy health insurance "is lower than it would have cost to buy insurance."

statement: Says Virginia economic development officials "decided they didn’t want to bid on" his company's electric automobile plant.

statement: The Milwaukee County Board’s staff grew from four workers to 38 over four decades and now costs taxpayers "a lot more," while the total county workforce was more than cut in half in the same period.

statement: Says Chris Christie’s plan "to kick-start our economy" is to propose an "income tax cut that disproportionately benefits the wealthy, and...he's still proposing it."

statement: Says Ohio’s economic recovery "started in February 2010."

statement: "Even members of the NRA, when they were polled recently, were under the impression that everyone has a criminal background check."

statement: "Poverty levels (are) at an all-time high."

statement: Says Texas will be "majority Hispanic in six years."

statement: "Wind powers nearly 13 million homes across the country."

statement: "The governor does not have any power to veto a referendum [on same-sex marriage] that would be a constitutional amendment."

statement: "It is ironic that (First Energy Corp. is) going to have a name on our (football stadium) where we (Cleveland Public Power) supply the electricity."

statement: Says Rick Scott’s proposal for election reform "only mandates 48 hours of early voting."

statement: Says his elections proposal would allow "a potential of 168 hours (of early voting), which I think is the most we’ve ever had."

statement: Social Security has nothing to do with the federal deficit.

statement: Says "in this next biennium, the cost of primary and secondary education is going to increase by more that $1000 per student. Half of that $1000 – $500 per student – is accounted for by the increased cost of PERS alone."

statement: Says a recent study shows Florida students are second in the world in fourth grade reading, behind Singapore.

statement: "Nearly a quarter of all adults in this state have some college credit without a degree."

statement: Abraham Lincoln "visited and some say even danced in (the Ohio Senate) chamber."

statement: Says Austin’s treated wastewater, put into the Colorado River, is of higher quality than water the city takes from the lake for public use.

statement: Virginia "spends less per student today than we did in 2008."

statement: "Thanks to Washington, nearly everyone will pay more in taxes in 2013. Somehow people think it's just the wealthy. It's not."

statement: "In total, we have added nearly 75,000 private sector jobs in New Jersey since we took office in January 2010."

statement: "The average age of first marijuana use is 12."

statement: Kohl’s Department Stores in 2012 "announced the creation of 3,000 new jobs."

statement: "It costs $10,000 a year to keep a child in school; it costs $30,000 a year to keep someone in prison."

statement: Since 1968, "more Americans have died from gunfire than died in … all the wars of this country's history."

statement: In 2011, more people were murdered with knives, "hands or feet" or "clubs and hammers" than with any type of rifle.

statement: "I am now the No. 2 member of this House in terms of length of service."

statement: In 2010, 2,694 young people were killed by gunfire. 1,773 were victims of homicide; 67 were elementary school-age children.

statement: The state budget proposal has been submitted "on time and [it's] the earliest that a governor has done so in over two decades."

statement: "Gross income tax receipts are exceeding the Administration’s projections for this fiscal year prior to Sandy."

statement: "Unlike the gridlock in Washington, more than 80 percent of the bills we passed during this General Assembly had bipartisan support."

statement: Says Texas public school funding grew three times the rate of enrollment from 2002 to 2012.

statement: The United States has "an immigration system where only 6.5 percent of people who come here, come here based on labor and skill."

statement: "In Minnesota, well over 6,200 election-day registrations from 2008 proved fraudulent."

statement: Members of Congress "specifically exempted themselves from many of the laws they have passed, such as being exempt from any fear of prosecution for sexual harassment" ... (and) from the healthcare reform."

statement: U.S. Senate candidate Todd Akin was "partly right" that a woman's body has a way of shutting down so that a pregnancy doesn't occur if she's raped.

statement: "Semi-automatic weapons, whether pistol or rifle, were designed for use by the military on the battlefield."

statement: "I sponsored the amendment that expanded the hours of early voting so that people who have irregular work schedules could vote."

statement: Says in "our region," 2011 was worst drought year ever recorded.

statement: The fiscal cliff deal "increased spending."

statement: "Even if you took literally every single ounce of platinum in the world, it still wouldn’t add up to enough needed to pay down our nation’s debt."

statement: "200 consumer laws were destroyed" in 2011 when Gov. Scott Walker signed Act 92.

statement: Seven of America’s 10 wealthiest counties are in the Washington, D.C., area.

statement: "[W]e see America's prison population exploding, with America having a greater percentage of its people behind bars than any other nation in the world!"

statement: Since the federal Violence Against Women Act was adopted in 1994, "cases of domestic violence have fallen by 67 percent."

statement: Says "how much money the government is collecting from people...in terms of the gross domestic product" is "the lowest in 40, 50 years."

statement: "The amount of money that we put into running our own state legislature is nearly as much as we put into the University of Rhode Island."

statement: Says if you are on your bike in a crosswalk, all you have to do is dip your wheel into the road and cars must legally stop.

statement: Says 11 states have more people on welfare than employed.

statement: The fiscal cliff deal "ultimately raised taxes."

statement: Members of Congress can "retire with the same pay after only one term" in office

statement: Says his transportation plan "would make Virginia the first state in the nation to eliminate the state tax on gasoline."

statement: "A far different picture from the prior eight years, which saw 115 increases in taxes and fees."

statement: "Our numbers are going up at the airport."

statement: "In the four years before I became governor, we increased state debt $5.2 billion. We've paid it down $2 billion."

statement: Says in fiscal year 2011, the state had "a projected $11 billion deficit."

statement: Ohio's judges, "compared to other similar states, are being woefully underpaid."

statement: "While President Obama says all options are on the table for preventing a nuclear Iran, Hagel says military action is not a viable, feasible, responsible option."

statement: "Eleven states complete their [legislative] sessions within three calendar months, and another five only meet biennially."

title: A lode to ponder

statement: "Our pension system is the only one in the country that’s 100 percent funded."

statement: "Hurricane Sandy, the most destructive Atlantic storm ever."

statement: "Report that #GOP insisting on changes to Social Security as part of #fiscalcliff false. BTW those changes are supported by @barackobama."

statement: Says George Washington said a free people should be armed to guard against government tyranny.

statement: "Individuals with mental illnesses die an average of 25 years earlier than those without a mental illness."

statement: "Connecticut has the fifth toughest gun control laws in the country, including an assault weapons ban that bans 35 different weapons."

statement: Says "our economy in New Jersey gets $38 billion from the businesses at the Shore."

statement: "You see 34 people (are) murdered every single day" by gunfire in America.

statement: "Faculty salaries at UW System institutions have now fallen more than 18 percent below the national average."

statement: Says Virginia is the biggest state that does not have a major league sports team.

statement: "The average kid comes out of Virginia colleges with about $25,000-plus in debt."

statement: "One out of every four students fails to earn a high school diploma. In our major cities across America, half of our kids don’t graduate."

statement: "The price tag amounted to nearly $4,200 for every man, woman and child in the state."

statement: "Last year, handguns killed 48 people in Japan, 8 in Great Britain, 34 in Switzerland, 52 in Canada, 58 in Israel, 21 in Sweden, 42 in West Germany and 10,728 in the United States."

statement: "[T]he Georgia Dome has returned $10 billion in economic impact to the state of Georgia."

statement: Says Charlie Crist and Missouri Rep. Todd Akin "hold same abortion views. No exception except the life of the mother."

statement: Northern Virginia is the most "heavily trafficked place in the country."

statement: Says Texas economy is about 30 percent larger than Australia’s.
title: Kangaroo outweighs armadillo

source: The Campaign to Fix the Debt
statement: "If lawmakers fail to avert the fiscal cliff, 18 percent of the federal money that is sent to the states will be eliminated."
title: Not even close

statement: "I have the experience as Senate Budget Chair of cutting $4.5 billion in spending -- to close the deficit while protecting education and health care."
title: There's no I in team

statement: Says the Senate will have a record number of female senators in 2013.

statement: Thanks to actions by the Milwaukee County Board on the 2013 budget, the amount of county taxes on the average home in the city of Milwaukee "would be a $19 decrease."
title: Actually, falling home values brought it down

statement: Says the Portland Children’s Levy holds its "administrative expenses to less than 5 percent."
title: It's written into the measure

statement: Says Texas has the 15th largest economy in the world.
title: Presuming California doesn't peel off

statement: "This week the House of Representatives voted to remove the word ‘lunatic’ from federal law."
title: Yes, by a 398-1 vote

statement: Says budget savings by reducing pay and benefits for federal employees total $103 billion over 10 years -- more than $50,000 per worker.
title: Lean times

statement: Says Massachusetts has three state-mandated student tests and Finland just one.
title: Finnish finish with at least four tests

statement: "Scott Walker has even removed the 250,000 jobs promise from his website."
title: Uh, it's still there

statement: "In the last 15 years, we've witnessed a dramatic expansion in the jailing of immigrants, from about 70,000 people detained annually to about 400,000."
title: Old data hard to find

statement: President Barack Obama’s Fiscal Year 2013 budget proposal "couldn't get support from either party in the House or the Senate."
title: Dems showed plenty of support

statement: Wisconsin has created "just under 100,000" jobs since he took office.
title: His own administration warned against this math

statement: "Right now one of our highest job growth sectors is Leisure and Hospitality. We've added jobs that mostly fall within the restaurant and bar sector industry. These are not high-paying jobs, as the U.S. Department of Labor estimates this is an industry sector with the lowest average wages and the lowest proportion of its workforce earning minimum or subminimum wage jobs."
title: High job growth, low pay

statement: "If the House of Representatives fails to extend the middle-class tax cuts, 400,000 middle-class Rhode Island families will see their federal income taxes increase."
title: It's households, not families

statement: Says, "In the last four years we’ve cut $36 million in ongoing revenue."
title: Not enough money to bear growth is not the same as a dollar cut

statement: Under Charlie Crist, Florida lost 825,000 jobs and the unemployment rate increased from 3.5 percent to 11.1 percent.

statement: Says personal-injury trial lawyers "have provided over 80 percent of the funding for the Texas Democratic Party for over a decade."
title: Mild exaggeration, if it please the court

statement: "Fourteen million Americans' mortgages are greater than the value of their homes."
title: More than a quarter remain underwater

statement: "In recent years, menhaden numbers along our coast have plummeted by 90 percent."
title: 30 years ago is "recent"?

statement: "More than 50 percent of those people getting minimum wage in this state are high school students."
title: Try less than half

statement: Says Texas passed a state ‘Dream Act’ before any other state.
title: DREAM bigger than Texas law

statement: Says state schools superintendent candidate Don Pridemore "voted for the largest cuts to public education in our state history" and for "$2.3 billion in tax breaks for corporations and the wealthy."
title: Some truth in both parts of the claim

statement: The increase in the current state budget was greater than the inflation rate and the rate of population growth in Georgia.
title: Numbers need context

statement: Agriculture "is the strongest industry in Ohio."
title: Industry has a high yield

statement: Says the Obama administration plans to ban all weapons for U.S. citizens through international treaties.
title: And every man must grow a Fidel Castro beard

statement: Says that "the state spends more money on tax giveaways than it receives in tax collection."
title: The numbers add up - but taxes are complicated

statement: "The Agriculture Department estimates that roughly 42 percent of the corn crop will be used to make ethanol -- more than the amount of corn used to feed livestock and poultry in the United States."

statement: Social Security has not contributed to the debt and the deficits.
title: That's accounting fiction

statement: Milwaukee County government employees pay "much more" for their health care than City of Milwaukee or State of Wisconsin employees.
title: Some will to some extent

statement: "In 2008, tourism brought in $38 billion dollars and supported more than 300,000 jobs in the state of New Jersey."
title: Billion-dollar industry

statement: "The five economic indicators that the federal government tracks - for the first time since August 2006 - were positive this October."
title: A sign of things to come?

statement: November 2012 was "a record year of turnout. More people voted before Election Day using absentee ballots and voting early than ever before in our history."
title: Record in sheer numbers, not turnout percentage

statement: "The city of Atlanta has one of the highest lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender populations per capita, ranking third among major American cities."
title: More proof needed.

statement: "A man using bath salts reported that raccoons had set fire inside his home and stolen his cell phone."

statement: Says real estate taxes were put in place to pay for Obamacare.
title: Investment tax affecting very few

statement: Says Walmart employees represent the largest group of Medicaid and food stamp recipients in many states, costing the taxpayer $1,000 per worker.

statement: Says a new state report "confirms" that red-light cameras "lead to more accidents, more injuries and greater cost."

statement: Says food stamp growth, while high, lagged the rise in unemployment.
title: This claim served with accuracy

statement: Public employees receive "something like 25 percent of the paychecks that are issued in Rhode Island."
title: One in four? More like one in nine.

statement: Says that in 2011, Oregon had "the second fastest growing economy in the nation."
title: He's right -- though you may not feel it

statement: "The poverty level in" the Dallas school district "is one of the highest in the country, higher than New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston, Detroit and Newark."

statement: Democratic Party candidates for the state Assembly "actually received 200,000 more votes statewide" than their Republican counterparts in the 2012 election

statement: Says he has never voted for raising taxes.
title: Read his lips

statement: The Broward Republican Executive Committee "had the liberal League of Women Voters Guide removed from the Broward Supervisor of Election's website."

statement: Says "the number of Americans living at or below the poverty line is at its highest level since" 1964.
title: One of the highest levels

statement: Says he first unveiled his new legislative agenda in Wisconsin, not in California as critics complain

statement: Says in January 1992, George H. W. Bush "probably had a 90 percent or even higher approval rating after the first Gulf War."
title: Rating fell below 50% by January '92

statement: "If you and I fail to defund ObamaCare now, some 16,000 new IRS agents will be begin prying into our private medical records, eyeing each and every one of our treatments and prescriptions for "violations’."
title: Claim suffers from chronic incorrectness

statement: Says legislation supported by gay rights activists would strip "mother" and "father" from future Texas birth certificates.
title: It's a parent!

statement: Says the state is required "pick up 70 percent of the cost" of K-12 education.
title: Only if you're using some selective math

statement: "National studies are already showing the negative effects that the health care law is having on businesses and our economy. Businesses across the country are raising their prices … (or) cutting jobs as a result of the added cost."

statement: "Our race was the closest U.S. Senate race in Ohio in 36 years -- when Howard Metzenbaum defeated Robert Taft in 1976."

statement: A "foreclosure tax" that would take effect in 2013 could mean a high tax bill for those facing foreclosure and millions of families who modified their mortgage or had a short sale through their lender.

statement: "We have more people working in clean and green energy than in oil and gas in this country."
title: Green industries are a gusher for U.S. jobs

statement: Says that in the 1985 election former Gov. Tom Kean had "the largest winning margin for a gubernatorial candidate in Jersey history."
title: Nearly 800k more votes than rival

statement: "In the past year alone, Ohio businesses have created more jobs than almost every other state in the country."
title: Out pacing some larger states

statement: Says veterans’ disability claims backlog doubled in Obama’s first term.
title: Obama broke a promise

statement: Operating a health care exchange would be "illegal" in Georgia and some states because of legislation passed in those states.
title: The other way around, experts say.

statement: "When you look at the number of crashes before the cameras were installed compared to after, they’re virtually the same."
title: Little to slow down this claim.

statement: Says President Barack Obama "did not come into office with the economy in a free fall."
title: Cratered might be a better way of describing it

statement: "For the first time in history, the share of the national popular vote margin is smaller than the Latino vote margin."

statement: "There is no evidence that poor people abuse drugs more frequently than any other socio-economic group."

statement: The "error rates" for the Fulton County elections department are "well below the average."
title: An errant claim

statement: Says the tax code is effectively subsidizing "the marketing efforts of fast food and junk food companies by as much as $19 billion over 10 years."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker has "led people to believe that if Wisconsin doesn’t implement a (health-care) exchange, Obamacare doesn’t happen here."
title: Tea party has promoted that hope; Walker, not really

statement: Says because of Hurricane Sandy in Atlantic City "much of that boardwalk no longer exists -- just the pillars where the boardwalk used to be."

statement: Says Delta Air Lines has "once again broken a promise they made to me and to the people of Memphis."

statement: "Our welfare system now consumes 42 percent of our budget."
title: Even with broad definition of welfare, number is high

statement: "We’ve outdrawn the Super Bowl for a little while now in the arenas and stadiums that we’ve followed them in for the Super Bowl. We’ve gone in after [the NFL] and surpassed their ticket sales."

statement: Says she is "entering in the most diverse class ever," of U.S. Representatives
title: Score one for girl power

statement: Says Fran DeWine’s made-from-scratch dinner rolls are a delicious favorite in a traditional Thanksgiving dinner.
title: We were convinced. Happy Thanksgiving.

statement: Says about 25 Texas cities and 39 states have banned texting while driving.
title: Texas ban vetoed

statement: "Wisconsin is the only state that allows parents or guardians to purchase alcohol for their children – regardless of whether that child is seven or 20 years old – at bars and restaurants."

statement: "Mitt Romney received exactly zero votes in at least 12 Cuyahoga County precincts."

statement: A precinct in the Allen West-Patrick Murphy recount has "7 registered voters in Guatemalan community and the tally showed 900 voted!!!!!"
title: This claim needs a recount

statement: Says the initial Portland plastic bag ban represented "only a modest share of total single-use checkout bag use."
title: A statement without any support.

statement: "In 2011, our state-run lottery funded New Jersey classrooms by over $930 million."

statement: "In one county alone in Ohio, President Obama received 106,258 votes. But there were only 98,213 eligible voters."

statement: "Secular Americans are the fastest-growing religious identification demographic in this country."
title: Secular term goes too far

statement: Says New Jersey is "50th in return of our federal tax dollars."

statement: Says that under the new healthcare law, full- and part-time workers will be required to buy insurance costing $375 to $1,000 a month, starting in 2014.
title: Off two years, missing caveats

statement: "More Tennesseans have hunting and fishing licenses than vote."
title: More voters than sportsmen

statement: Three thousand felons voted in Rhode Island in 2008.
title: Released felons can - and do - vote

statement: Says New Hampshire had the fourth-lowest unemployment rate in the country during Maggie Hassan’s time in the state Senate.

statement: Says the Multnomah County Library system "is the second busiest in the nation."
title: Most recent numbers say "yes."

statement: Says 40 years ago, the U.S. placed Texas under Voting Rights Act for failing to print ballots in Spanish.

statement: Barack Obama is "only the second Democrat in the last 75 years to win Ohio twice with more than 50 percent of the vote."

statement: "There is no reason to allocate 60 percent of bridge space to satisfy two percent of all travelers."

statement: Says that with President Obama's re-election, state and federal income tax rates for some taxpayers will rise "to roughly 65 percent."
title: Experts say maybe around 50 percent

statement: "Every American now is $51,000 in debt. That’s money I owe, that’s money my children owe before they even go to kindergarten, that’s their check to the federal government right now."

statement: Budget analysts say the looming tax hikes and spending cuts would  "take us into a recession and kill jobs."

statement: Says the state of Texas rates as "unacceptable" almost 500 of the state's 8,000 public schools.

statement: When it comes to income taxes, Wisconsin is "one of the best places in the country to be poor" but "top 4 or 5 worst" for middle-income earners.

statement: "Sixty percent of New Jersey doctors do not accept Medicaid patients."

statement: Says a poll shows that "without a name attached, Democrats are just one point behind" Gov. John Kasich.

statement: "Clayton County offers the lowest operating millage rate in Metro Atlanta."

statement: Half the lottery directors across the country had not run a lottery before they were hired.
title: Odds are that your state's lottery director has limited gaming experience

statement: Says under President Barack Obama, the United States has created "five million jobs."
title: Cherry-picking jobs

statement: Says Mike Dovilla supports a plan "that could allow a foreign corporation to take over the Ohio Turnpike" 

statement: "Revenues are 15 percent of GDP — it’s still in the range of the lowest it’s ever been."

statement: Says that over the past 20 years, Texas public school spending rose 142 percent and per-pupil spending more than tripled when adjusted for inflation.

statement: "Wisconsin still ranks first among the 50 states in manufacturing jobs per capita."

statement: Says "I was the first governor in America to endorse Mitt Romney."

statement: Says Tennessee’s higher education funding model "is 100 percent outcomes-based" and "we are already seeing this model changing the way our postsecondary institutions do business."

statement: "Texas’ population is projected to double in the next 50 years or so, but our basic amount of water will remain about where it is now."

statement: Says Jeb Bush "extended early voting" after seeing "long lines."

statement: "Mitt Romney made over a hundred million dollars by shutting down (a Marion, Ind. paper) plant."

statement: "The higher the education level, the more likely they are to vote Democratic."

statement: "We have more hospitals that are children’s hospitals than any other state in the union." 

statement: Says that "Tennessee law requires that schools receive half of proceeds -- $31 million per year" -- from a half-cent increase in the Shelby County sales tax.

statement: Says Ovide Lamontagne wants to eliminate kindergarten.

statement: Gubernatorial candidate Maggie Hassan supported 33 tax and fee increases as Senate Majority Leader.

statement: "Sheldon Whitehouse [got] a secret closed-door briefing, warning of the [2008 economic] crash."

statement: Says U.S. Senate candidate Tommy Thompson "says he’ll do away with Medicare."

statement: Says Mitt Romney "was director of a company that stole millions from Medicare."

statement: "After Patrick Murphy’s charges were dropped, Murphy’s father gave the prosecutor a huge campaign donation."

statement: Says Mitt Romney wants to "get rid of Planned Parenthood."

statement: Says "Romney supported a law that could have made most common forms of birth control illegal."

statement: Says Jim Renacci has "consistently voted" for loopholes that "encourage outsourcing of our jobs."

statement: "The Ryan budget gets rid of Medicare in 10 years and turns it into a voucher program."

statement: "Bill Nelson actually voted in favor of higher taxes 272 times."

statement: "Tommy Thompson made millions from corporations who outsource American jobs and now he's trying to lavish huge tax breaks on them."

statement: Says Connie Mack was "the only member of the Florida delegation that voted against a bill to help NASA."

statement: Says Mark Hass "raised your taxes by $1 billion in a single day."

statement: Says U.S. corporate tax rate is "highest in the world at 35 percent."

statement: Says that Sherrod Brown is an "Obama rubber stamp" for "supporting the job-killing cap and trade plan."

statement: Says opponent Chad Chadwell "wants condom techniques demonstrated to your children."

statement: Says the NAACP's Ohio chapter has endorsed Issue 2.

statement: Sheldon Whitehouse voted for a "$525-billion tax increase on the middle class."

statement: Says Matt Wand has sided with anti-choice activists "to restrict access to reproductive health care services."

statement: An Obama campaign tactic for rallying voters is to "offer them cell phones."

statement: Says Charlie Bass supports Paul Ryan plan that forces seniors to pay $6,400 a year more for health care so millionaires can pay less in taxes.

statement: Says "Mitt Romney’s plan rolls back regulations" on banks.

statement: "There is no war on coal. Period. There are more coal jobs and more coal produced in Ohio than there were five years ago, in spite of the talking points and the yard signs."

statement: Says he "opposed $716 billion cut to Medicare."

statement: Says Bill Young "voted twice for the Ryan budget that ends the current Medicare system."

statement: "There are millions of women all across the country who rely on Planned Parenthood for not just contraceptive care; they rely on it for mammograms."

statement: Says Mitt Romney’s plan makes "catastrophic cuts to education."

statement: "We borrow $4 billion every single day, much of it from China."

statement: Says she voted against the Medicare Part D prescription drug program "because it was unfunded."

statement: Says Democrats first proposed prohibiting the government from negotiating prices for prescription drugs in Medicare Part D and he "had nothing to do with" that provision in the law.

statement: Says Barack Obama "sold Chrysler to Italians who are going to build Jeeps in China" at the cost of American jobs.

statement: "The truth is David Cicilline voted for tougher laws against child abusers, domestic abusers and abusers of the elderly."

statement: Bill Clinton presided over "the biggest expansion of the American economy since World War II."

statement: Says Connie Mack initially said he would have voted "yes" for the Paul Ryan budget plan, and then, "you said it was stupid and you would vote no. And then your folks corrected you, and you changed your position again, yes."

statement: Says Maggie Hassan pays zero property taxes on her $500,000 home.
title: Can't pay taxes when you don't own the home

statement: "Women in Barack Obama's White House are earning less than men."

statement: Says New Jersey lost private-sector jobs between 2000 and 2009 because Democrats increased taxes, fees, regulations and state spending.

statement: Sherrod Brown "voted six times to raise his own pay."

statement: "We’re talking right now about a $12 billion hole in our current, so-called balanced" state "budget."

statement: "New Jersey is the only state in the union that spent less on higher education than it did at the beginning of the decade."

statement: Rhode Island has taken its federal Medicaid funding and shown it can run the program more cost-effectively than the federal government.

statement: Says Multnomah County libraries "are open 44 hours per week … the lowest of any library in the four-county region."

statement: "Under President Obama: $4,000 tax hike on middle-class families."

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tommy Thompson ran Medicare "into the ground" and "nine years closer to bankruptcy."

statement: Says the Central Health district's tax rate is the "lowest among the largest counties in Texas, and it will continue to be the lowest" if voters approve a proposed tax increase.

statement: "One industry in America has increased its employment base in the last four years by 176,000 people: the United States government."

statement: "6,400 Ohioans ... lost manufacturing jobs in the month of September."

statement: "If Buehler were elected, our vote-by-mail system would be at risk."

statement: "We got back every dime used to rescue the banks."

statement: Says GM used taxpayer dollars to prop up operations in China.

statement: Lois Frankel "spent over $13,000 in taxpayer money on a marble shower in a private bathroom with her own toilet."

statement: While she was mayor, Lois Frankel took a "police helicopter ride to go to a dinner party."

statement: "There’s 21 congressmen and senators that have been convicted of felonies that still get their retirement, even in jail. They don’t have to wait until they’re 65."

statement: "Connecticut's take on slot machines is 25 cents on the dollar. And the state's take on table games:  zero."

statement: "The sequester is not something that I've proposed. It is something that Congress has proposed."

statement: "As governor, I cut $5 billion in spending."

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tammy Baldwin supports a "tax increase that President Obama says" would cost middle-class families $3,000 per year.

statement: Says Chris Christie was "behind" in the polls against Jon Corzine during the 2009 governor's race.

statement: Says Jim Renacci "opposed increasing combat bonuses for our troops."

source: Promote Oregon Leadership PAC (Oregon House Republicans)
statement: Says, "Carl proposed a 'windfall' tax on real estate development when he was a Metro Councilor."

statement: Says Romney said "we should ask Pakistan for permission" to take a shot at Osama bin Laden.

statement: Says Barack Obama was silent on Iran "when the students took to the streets in Tehran and the people there protested, (and) the Green Revolution occurred."

statement: "Pakistan has 100 nuclear warheads and they’re rushing to build a lot more. They’ll have more than Great Britain sometime in the relatively near future."

statement: Says Mitt Romney "just gave a speech a few weeks ago" and said "we should still have troops in Iraq."

statement: Elizabeth Townsend runs the elections office that omitted a school board race on a ballot and gave a School Board candidate "faulty advice."

statement: "Latin America’s economy is almost as big as the economy of China."

statement: Says Mitt Romney was clear that he "would not provide government assistance to the U.S. auto companies, even if they went through bankruptcy."

statement: "Veterans’ unemployment is actually now lower than (the) general population. It was higher when I came into office."

statement: "I went to the Olympics that was out of balance, and we got it on balance."

statement: "The president said he was going to create daylight between ourselves and Israel."

statement: "A few months ago when you were asked what's the biggest geopolitical threat facing America, you said Russia."

statement: "Virginia papers called (Scott) Rigell’s campaign ‘Mostly False.’"

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Charles Bass wants to privatize Social Security.

statement: Ann McLane Kuster is "for a government takeover of health care more radical than Obamacare. And she supports a $700 billion cut to Medicare for current retirees."

statement: "Now remember, property taxes went up 70 percent in the 10 years before I became governor."

statement: Virginia’s educational level among whites is higher than Georgia’s.

statement: "Women who have miscarriages could be investigated by police" under legislation supported by Republican state Senate candidate Rick Gudex.

statement: "The poverty rate amongst women is the worst it’s been in 17 years and the extreme poverty rate is the worst it’s ever been."

statement: "There are more oil rigs in operation in the United States than the rest of the world combined."

statement: Says Barack Obama "said when he was running for office four years ago that he would halve the annual deficit by the end of his first term. That simply has not happened."

statement: Says Tammy Baldwin "voted to gut Medicare for seniors."

statement: "While I was mayor of the city of Providence we had the lowest crime rate in 30 years."

statement: Says an arts tax would provide "funding for certified arts and music teachers for every elementary school serving Portland residents."

statement: Says Connie Mack voted to redefine "rape" as "forcible rape."

statement: Says Mitt Romney and George Allen "would overturn Roe v. Wade and allow states to end safe, legal abortion even in cases of rape, incest or when a woman's life is at risk."

statement: "I’ve got a 94 percent" career voting record in Congress while Bill Nelson has "a 92 percent voting record."

statement: "George Bush never suggested that we eliminate funding for Planned Parenthood."

statement: As a Member of Congress, Chris Murphy "was raking in $1 million in salary."

statement: Says fewer than 30 percent of Texas college students graduate in four years and only 58 percent graduate within six years.

statement: Says the University of Texas can afford to build a medical school because it has a $7 billion endowment and its football program had a $50 million profit last year.

statement: "President Barack Obama (is) the first president in history to cut Medicare by $700 billion."

statement: Says he "is the reason we do not pay a toll every time we pass over the bridge at MoPac and William Cannon."

statement: Laurie Monnes Anderson "voted to let violent criminals out of jail early."

statement: Says Connie Mack "is protecting Chevron oil from a multi-billion dollar lawsuit over pollution of rivers and rainforests."

statement: "Regulations have quadrupled. The rate of regulations quadrupled under this president."

statement: Frank Guinta voted to make middle class taxpayers pay over a $1,000 more a year in taxes.

statement: Says Rep. Jon Runyan "voted to redefine rape."

statement: "Sherrod Brown supported President Obama's $453 billion tax increase."

statement: Massachusetts Sen. Scott Brown shows someone can be bipartisan in Congress because he "votes about 66 percent with his own party."

statement: Says Bill Nelson voted "98 percent of the time" with Barack Obama.

statement: Says Connie Mack takes two homestead exemptions, "directly contrary to Florida’s Constitution."

statement: In 2012, Connie Mack missed 178 votes, "one of the worst voting records" in Congress.

statement: "Bill Nelson voted for higher taxes 150 times."

statement: Says Bill Nelson voted to cut $700 billion out of Medicare to pay for Obamacare.

statement: Says Barack Obama has pension investments that include Chinese firms, and "investments through a Caymans trust."

statement: Says his administration put more border patrol agents on the U.S.-Mexico border than at "any time in history, and the flow of undocumented workers across the border is actually lower than it's been in 40 years."

statement: Says his administration has created "5 million jobs … over the last 30 months in the private sector alone."

statement: Says Mitt Romney suggested that "employers should be able to make the decision as to whether or not a woman gets contraception through her insurance coverage."

statement: Says Paul Ryan’s budget plan "ends Medicare."

statement: Sherrod Brown "failed to pay his own taxes three separate times."

statement: Says Mitt Romney "called the Arizona law a model for the nation."

statement: Says Barack Obama began his presidency "with an apology tour."

statement: Says President Obama waited two weeks to call the attack in Libya "terror."

statement: Says Mitt Romney refused to say whether he'd sign the Lilly Ledbetter bill.

statement: When Mitt Romney was governor of Massachusetts, he "stood in front of a coal plant and pointed at it and said, ‘This plant kills.’"

statement: "Oil production is down 14 percent this year on federal land."

statement: Says Obama broke his promise to offer a comprehensive immigration bill in his first year.

statement: Says Patrick Murphy is trying to "hide his drunken assault of a police officer."

statement: An Army report stated Allen West "performed illegal acts, merited court martial, faced 11 years in prison.'"

statement: Paul Ryan "cut embassy security in his budget by $300 million below what we asked for."

statement: The  Georgia Department of Economic Development assisted with the creation of 28,776 jobs, an increase of 29 percent from last fiscal year, and $5.97 billion in investments, a 32 percent increase.
