statement: "Under the Obama administration, we are drilling and producing more domestic energy supplies than we ever had before."

statement: Says Adam Hasner "gives the wealthy tax breaks worth $250,000 a year but hikes middle class taxes $2,000."

statement: Says six studies verify that the math adds up for Mitt Romney’s tax plan.
title: A lot of friendly guesswork in this math.

statement: As governor, "Mitt Romney raised nursing home fees eight times."

statement: Says the Obama administration "watered down sanctions" against Iran, delayed them and tried to stop Congress "from putting the tough sanctions in place."

statement: Says "as Co-Chair of the Joint Ways & Means Committee, I secured the key piece of funding for" the Portland-Milwaukie Light Rail project bridge."
title: It was a group effort but she was 'vital.'

statement: Says economists Harvey Rosen and Martin Feldstein have said that "paying for (Mitt) Romney’s tax cuts would require large tax increases on families making between $100,000 and $200,000."

statement: Says opponent Tammy Baldwin ‘has had not one positive ad’ in the campaign for U.S. Senate.
title: The mud didn't fly until after the primary

statement: Says "when I voted against [an increase in the minimum wage], it was in the 80s."

statement: "The tax burden on Virginia families was lower under Tim Kaine than under George Allen."

statement: " … if the Agreement goes into effect, the millions of Mexican citizens who will become eligible for Social Security benefits may have a far stronger claim to benefits and protection against cuts than U.S. citizens!"

statement: "President Obama has worked to change Medicare for the worse" by "creating an unelected, unaccountable panel with the power to deny coverage of certain treatments."

statement: Signs letter saying Consumer Product Safety Commission is acting "without consultation or input from the company" to stop the sale of Buckyballs.

statement: Signs letter saying Consumer Product Safety Commission is acting "without consultation or input from the company" to stop the sale of Buckyballs.
title: Company shows paper trail

statement: "David Cicilline was the state representative who opposed tough mandatory sentences for those convicted of domestic violence  and child abuse."
title: It's true!

statement: Says the U.S. Senate has passed "a budget" over the last three years "called the Budget Control Act."
title: Not a budget resolution

source: Coalition to Bring Jobs to R.I.
statement: "By voting to approve [Question 1], we can . . . save 900 jobs" at Twin River.
title: Some jobs at risk, but not 900

statement: "Tennessee students now cover about 67 percent of the cost of their education at public universities, and some 60 percent at community colleges."
title: It's on the students

statement: Says Julie Parrish "voted to divert $160 million from public schools to private for-profit schools."
title: For-profit company, public school

statement: Under Maggie Hassan's leadership, "we increased state spending in the middle of the great recession by 24 percent leading up to and following it."
title: By one measure, it's close

statement: Says Joe Biden "went to China and said that he sympathized and wouldn't second-guess their one-child policy of forced abortions and sterilizations."
title: Biden doesn't endorse forced abortions

statement: "There's not one Democrat who endorses" the Romney-Ryan Medicare plan.
title: Wyden worked with Ryan but doesn't endorse latest plan

statement: "The Canadians — they (dropped) their tax rates to 15 percent. The average tax rate on businesses in the industrialized world is 25 percent."

statement: "We weren't told they wanted more security " for diplomatic facilities in Libya.

statement: Says she’s never said "don’t build" Texas 45 Southwest.
title: Actions count too

statement: The Obama administration "called Bashar Assad a reformer when he was turning his Russian-provided guns on his own people."

statement: Says that Josh Mandel voted to let insurance companies deny coverage for autism
title: Voted against a bill to require coverage

statement: Says Obama was in New York City the same day as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu but went on a TV show instead of meeting with him.
title: They were in NYC same week but different days

statement: Says the Obama administration spent taxpayer dollars on electric cars in Finland (and) windmills in China.

statement: On ending the war in Iraq, "Gov. Romney said that was a tragic mistake, we should have left 30,000 troops there."
title: He used that word

statement: Says Obama promised unemployment would never go above 8 percent.
title: Economic prediction, not promise

statement: Says Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan would "eliminate the guarantee of Medicare."

statement: Says his deficit plan "made some adjustments to (Simpson-Bowles), and we're putting it forward before Congress right now, a $4 trillion plan."

statement: "When Congress voted to condemn Iran for sentencing a Christian pastor to death, (U.S. Rep. Lois) Capps was the only member who voted no."

statement: Says Travis County Sheriff Greg Hamilton has accepted $42,000 from strip-club interests and $10,000 from local alcohol distributors.

statement: "$500 billion of the extension of the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy goes to 120,000 families."

statement: Says the Republican Party platform says "pull back even more of the rules on campaign finance reform, get rid of McCain-Feingold" while the Democratic Party platform says "we want to find a way to put more fair rules on campaign finance reform."

statement: Says Charlie Bass forfeits right to equal cost for TV ads under FCC rules
title: Got to know the rules

statement: Says "under Oregon law, girls from 15 years of age and up are given complete control over whether to be sterilized or not."
title: It's not as simple as asking to be sterilized.

statement: Mitt Romney "said it was 'tragic' to end the war in Iraq."
title: Referring to the pace of the drawdown

statement: Says President Barack Obama "gives students the right to repay (federal) loans as a clear, fixed, low percentage of their income for up to 20 years."
title: Not as clear as you'd think

statement: The "Health Care Compact bill would end Medicare's guaranteed benefit for Tennessee's Medicare recipients and shift management of the federal health care plan to the state's TennCare program."
title: Speculation at best

statement: "We've got 7.2 percent unemployment (in Ohio), but when you include the folks who have stopped looking for work, it's actually over 10 percent."
title: Assumes all who aren't looking still would want jobs

statement: Says Romney called Russia our No. 1 enemy.
title: Geopolitical foe = enemy

statement: "I've cut taxes for ... middle-class families, small businesses."
title: See the stimulus, 2010 tax deal and more

statement: Says his budget plan "would cut our deficits by $4 trillion."
title: UPDATE: His number includes last year's cuts

statement: "The auditor [for the city of Providence] was not locked out" of access to the city's finances.
title: Access delayed, access denied.

statement: Providence has "amongst the highest tax rate(s) in the entire country."
title: No debating high taxes

statement: "After a decade of decline, this country created over half a million manufacturing jobs in the last two and a half years."
title: Gains that came after even bigger losses

statement: Says that Mitt Romney's response to the crisis in the auto industry was, "Let Detroit go bankrupt."
title: He didn't write those words

statement: "Jeb Bush recently noted, Reagan himself would have been too moderate, too reasonable for today's GOP."
title: Bush's comments a little murky

statement: When Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid were created, "Republicans stood on the sidelines"
title: Final bills got significant GOP support

statement: Says Mitt Romney asked for a waiver from federal welfare rules.
title: Once supported waivers; never asked for one

statement: Ohio has "created 45,000 new manufacturing jobs since 2010. And that's due in large part to the fact that the auto rescue has helped Ohio."
title: Jobs yes, but unclear if cars were the driver

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s leadership, "since June 2009, (the auto) industry has added a quarter of a million jobs."
title: A key theme of the Democratic convention checks out

statement: Says House Republicans "tried to change the definition of rape."
title: Only for federal abortion funding

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan attacked the president for "the same amount of Medicare savings that (Ryan) had in his own budget."
title: Ryan acknowledged as much in June

statement: Says Charlie Crist "was pro-life, pro-gun and vehemently anti-tax."
title: Strongest on guns, less so on abortion

statement: "In the last 29 months, our economy has produced about 4.5 million private-sector jobs."
title: Number is cherry-picked, but accurately described

statement: Says that like Todd Akin, all Texas Republicans in U.S. House cosponsored a bill "that attempts to distinguish between ‘forcible rape’ and other sexual assaults."
title: Bill targeted abortion funding

statement: "We have more scientists and engineers per square mile than anywhere in the world."
title: New Jersey leads the world

statement: The stimulus program "cut taxes for 95 percent of the American people."
title: UPDATE: 'Making Work Pay' was for workers only

statement: "Since 1961 … our private economy has produced 66 million private-sector jobs. So what's the jobs score? Republicans 24 million, Democrats 42 (million)."
title: For whatever reason, the pattern's correct

statement: Mitt Romney said we should let foreclosures "hit the bottom."
title: He also said it would 'come back up'

statement: Women "receive only 77 cents for every dollar a man earns."
title: One measure, but others valid, too

statement: When it comes to jobless workers, "Mitt Romney says he likes to fire people."
title: Romney was talking about health insurance companies, not workers

statement: "Republicans would give seniors a (Medicare) voucher that limits what's covered, costing seniors as much as $6,400 more a year."

statement: Says Republicans Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan support "massive cuts in Social Security for future generations."
title: Over decades, formula tweak adds up

statement: Says she was misquoted and "didn’t say" that the Israeli ambassador said "what the Republicans are doing is dangerous for Israel."
title: Caught on tape!

statement: Says Bruce Springsteen played in 1975 at Seton Hall University in South Orange at Walsh gym.
title: The gov and the boss

statement: "Seven presidents before (Barack Obama) -- Republicans and Democrats -- tried to expand health care to all Americans."
title: Some tried harder than others

statement: "Under President Bush in eight years, we added $4.9 trillion to the debt. Under President Obama, we've added $5.3 trillion to the debt in the 3.5 years he's been in office."
title: It's been debt-o-rama

statement: Says Mitt Romney told university students in Ohio that to start a business, they should "borrow money if you have to from your parents."
title: Uttered at Otterbein

statement: Says Mitt Romney has put forward a plan "that would cut taxes for millionaires while raising them for the middle class."
title: Romney's vague plans include tax cuts across the board

statement: Says Mitt Romney’s tax plans would "give an additional $250,000 tax cut to millionaires and billionaires" while raising taxes on the middle class.
title: Foggy tax plans leave some impacts unclear

statement: "We will spend $100 billion in Afghanistan this year, fixing roads, building bridges, training police officers, and more, [and] cutting the same things in our own country."
title: Infrastructure only small part of overall spending

statement: "By the time (Mitt Romney) left office, Massachusetts was 47th in the nation in job creation."
title: Governors have limited impact on state economies

statement: Says Milken Institute rated San Antonio as nation’s top-performing local economy.
title: Remember the Alamo City

statement: "The first (state) budget that came out of our Republican leadership slashed funding to Planned Parenthood...It resulted in the reduction of hours, the elimination of days, elimination of access to women in my city and all over my state."
title: Money cut, clinics closed

statement: Says Barack Obama is a Muslim.
title: Daffy and dilly

statement: In 2008, Charlie Crist ‘"applauded the pick of Sarah Palin and said she would do ‘a great job.’"
title: Crist loved Palin in 2008, but that's ancient history now

statement: The GOP platform that seeks further limits on abortion and is silent on an exception for rape "has been there for more than 30 years."
title: Language largely unchanged for last seven conventions

statement: Federal law adopted "under Tommy Thompson's watch" prohibits the government from negotiating for "better prices" on prescription drugs for senior citizens
title: Thompson pushed for law, which includes bargaining ban

statement: Says Chris Christie was the "first governor in America to endorse" Mitt Romney.
title: Two other govs endorsed first

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie has embarked on a tour to "demand that New Jersey’s Democratic legislature approve an immediate tax cut that would disproportionately benefit the wealthiest."
title: Guv backed new plan before tour

statement: Says a federal judge "sanctions Tennessee ‘birther’ lawyer … for bringing a frivolous lawsuit."
title: Tennessee 'birthers' must pay

statement: U.S. military uniforms are manufactured in China.
title: Claim goes AWOL

statement: Says opponents of the health care law  "prevailed on our two main arguments" to the U.S. Supreme Court.
title: Jury says it needs a little more detail

statement: At Bain Capital, "we helped start an early childhood learning company called Bright Horizons that First Lady Michelle Obama rightly praised."
title: Company joined first lady's Let's Move campaign

statement: Under the "Obama economy ... utility bills are higher."
title: A mixed bag

statement: The unemployment rate is declining faster in Tampa "than almost anywhere else."
title: Tampa Bay more like it

statement: Says "Bruce Starr voted to throw 6,000 Oregonians off unemployment."
title: He voted not to extend the program

statement: Says under the Romney-Ryan budget ... "the American Opportunity Tax Credit for college tuition would be eliminated."
title: College tax breaks go down the tubes

statement: "There is an increasing amount of evidence from public polling that the highest number of Americans ever identify themselves as pro-life."
title: Some favor limited legal abortion, though

statement: Says that when Democrats controlled Congress and the White House, federal spending as a share of the Gross Domestic Product leapt from 18.2 percent in 2001 to 25.2 percent in 2009 -- the largest such increase in any eight-year period since World War II.
title: Math solid, but Republicans ruled much of period

statement: "When Tim Kaine was governor, spending soared, blowing holes in the budget every year."
title: Mixing apples and oranges

statement: In his first TV interview as president, Obama said we "should talk to Iran."
title: He said it

statement: Barack Obama began his presidency "with an apology tour."
title: The tour that never was

statement: "The majority of Americans now doubt that our children will have a better future."
title: We are pessimistic, and long have been

statement: "In Massachusetts, Gov. Romney narrowed the gap between students of different races."
title: Not all Romney's doing

statement: President Barack Obama has "weakened the respect for America abroad."
title: Up, mostly

statement: Clackamas County Commissioners "approved a re-negotiated agreement to lower the county’s contribution to TriMet’s Portland-Milwaukie Light Rail project to $19.9 million from $25 million."
title: In-kind services also cost money

statement: President Obama’s education "solution" includes an effort to "nationalize curriculum."
title: Blaming Obama for state-based trend

statement: Says Connie Mack IV co-sponsored a bill to "take a third of the Social Security Trust Fund ... give it in individual accounts to the senior citizens, who then were to invest it in the stock market."
title: No seniors asked to day trade

statement: Says "President Obama and his National Labor Relations Board" sued Boeing over its decision to open a plant in South Carolina.
title: Any influence would be indirect

statement: Says the national health care law puts federal "bureaucrats between an American citizen and her doctor."

statement: Says the United States has "the world’s greatest health care system."
title: Mixed results

statement: Says Sherrod Brown voted "for the $1.17 trillion health care law that adds a new tax on Ohio manufacturers."
title: Wrongly implies all manufacturers are taxed

statement: Says that as Providence’s mayor, David Cicilline said the city had a "world-class … school system. Not only did Providence not have a world-class school system but as measured, was amongst the last school system in the entire country."
title: Claim gets failing grade

statement: "When President Obama took office, we were losing 700,000 jobs a month. Now we've had job growth, I think, for 24 consecutive months."
title: It's 22 months, not 24

statement: In Massachusetts under Mitt Romney, "unemployment went down, household incomes went up," and the state "saw its credit rating upgraded."
title: A mixed bag on statistical accuracy

statement: Says President Barack Obama broke his promise to keep a Wisconsin GM plant from closing.
title: It closed before Obama took office

statement: President Obama "funneled" $716 billion out of Medicare "at the expense of the elderly."
title: Misleading on Medicare

statement: The Obama administration "even proposed banning farm kids from doing basic chores!"
title: A load of manure

statement: Barack Obama has "never even worked in business."
title: Not a lot of experience in business, but some

statement: Says women care most about jobs and the economy
title: Not social issues

statement: When his grandfather arrived in the United States, "there were no government benefits for immigrants."
title: Government benefits were smaller than today, but far from zero

statement: "Mitt Romney’s platform ...won't protect the mortgage interest (tax) deduction for middle-class families."

statement: "Last month, 44 of the 50 states saw an increase in the unemployment rate."

statement: Wealthy taxpayers, not middle-income earners, get "most of the deductions" in the tax code.

statement: "A Gallup report recently said that nearly 50 percent of small business owners aren't hiring because of what they call ‘regulatory uncertainty.’"
title: It ranked sixth on a list of eight obstacles

statement: Says most Texas schools spend 45 out of 180 school days in mandated testing.
title: Total varies, and it’s likely less than 40

statement: "A report just came out that if we continue with President Obama's policies, we're looking at over 9 percent unemployment next year in the fourth quarter."
title: Actually shows rate could drop under Obama

statement: Claims Ohio Gov. John Kasich says climate change is a problem.
title: Ohio governor is a believer

statement: "President Obama is attacking Paul Ryan on Medicare even though it is his administration with the help of Jim Langevin who cut $716 billion from Medicare."
title: Savings not really a cut?

statement: Says "taxes were raised 115 times in the eight years before I became governor" and those increases were part of a "path that led to wealth and jobs and people leaving our state."
title: Taxes and fees

statement: Says they said "it was impossible to balance a budget at the same time, with an $11 billion deficit" and "we did it."
title: Structural deficit that he now dismisses

statement: The health care law imposes a federal mandate requiring middle-class Americans to buy health insurance "whether they can afford it or not."
title: There is a hardship exemption

statement: There has been "$5 trillion in debt added over the last four years."
title: His number is very close

statement: Says President Obama has waived "the work requirement for welfare."
title: That's not what the memo says

statement: Says our national debt is greater than our gross domestic product.
title: Outside debt approaching 75 percent of GDP

statement: Says Paul Ryan "tried to change the whole game" for Social Security
title: Voluntary accounts for younger workers

statement: "Household income in America has gone down for families an average of $4,000 in the last four years" while it " went up $5,000" under Mitt Romney when he was governor of Massachusetts
title: Apples + oranges = inaccurate picture

statement: "If you look at the number of illegal immigrants coming into the country, it is net zero. It's been that way now for almost two years."

statement: Says a portfolio managed by the Texas General Land Office earned 22 percent last year while the state’s emergency reserve account experienced a 1 percent gain.

statement: Says Republicans supported legislation on early voting and in-person voting in 2005.
title: They enacted it and Dems opposed

statement: Mitt Romney "gave away his father's inheritance."
title: An already rich Romney didn't need it

statement: In the past 27 months, President Barack Obama has created more private-sector jobs than "in the Reagan recovery."

statement: "Half the kids coming out of college this year … can't find a job, or a job that's consistent with a college degree."

statement: Says the top 20 percent of income earners pay nearly 70 percent of all federal taxes.

statement: Republicans included "the Akin amendment in the Republican Party platform, which bans abortion, even for rape victims."

statement: Says that Tennessee Gov. Bill Haslam "has made it clear by his repeated actions that he will pursue a policy that promotes the interest of Islamist (sic) and their radical ideology as long as he is governor."

statement: "This year, Eric Cantor has received more money from oil companies than any other member of Congress."

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tommy Thompson "wants to give a new $265,000 tax cut to millionaires like himself while raising taxes on the middle class."
title: Some math checks out, some doesn’t.

statement: "We've got the highest corporate tax rate in the world."
title: Effectively, one of the highest

statement: The state government workforce grew when Tim Kaine was governor.
title: Cherry-picked figures

statement: "Independent voters have a ten-point margin in favor of Mitt Romney right now."

statement: "In 2008, candidate Barack Obama attacked John McCain for proposing cuts to Medicare."

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tammy Baldwin wants a "completely government-controlled" health care system that goes "far beyond 'Obamacare'" and is "a Medicare system for all."

statement: "We have only one person on the (TVA) board, to my knowledge, who even has any corporate board experience."

statement: "For Social Security, which is projected to remain solvent through 2033, Whitehouse has cosponsored [a bill that] . . . would extend the life of the program by an additional 75 years."
title: 75 years from NOW, not 2033.

statement: "His new running mate, Congressman Ryan, put forward a plan that would let Governor Romney pay less than 1 percent in taxes each year."

statement: The Romney-Ryan plan for Medicare "does not affect" benefits for anyone 55 or older.

statement: The Obama administration "willfully leaked the existence of STUXNET (a computer worm used against Iran), allowing our enemies to learn more of our secrets and of our operations."

statement: The price of gasoline was at $1.85 a gallon when President Barack Obama took office and has since nearly doubled because of his policies

statement: Initial efforts to strip airport contractors of their special diversity status "has no effect" on the contracts or the city’s diversity goals.

statement: Says Betty Sutton and House Democrats "gutted" Medicare by $741 billion to pay for Obamacare.

statement: Paul Ryan’s Medicare plan "could raise future retirees’ costs more than $6,000."

statement: Says "cities save an estimated $38 in dental costs for every $1 invested in fluoridation."

statement: "Your Congressman, Charlie Bass, took over $166,000 from Big Oil."

statement: Says Obama puts "15 unelected, unaccountable bureaucrats in charge of Medicare, who are required to cut Medicare ... that will lead to denied care for current seniors."

statement: "Mitt Romney says class sizes don’t matter."

statement: Says 88 Texas constables have died in the line of duty.
title: Undercount

statement: Says U.S. Senate hopeful Tammy Baldwin voted for a $1 trillion stimulus bill that included a wasteful "$800,000 to replace light bulbs."

statement: "I haven't raised taxes in the time I've been the governor of New Jersey."
title: For some, tax burden increased

statement: Says that as Massachusetts governor, Mitt Romney "condemned coal-fired plants, saying they kill people."
title: Broad emissions-cutting program embraced

statement: "In Florida, they're already talking about how the Ryan-Romney plan will end Medicare and replace it with a voucher."

statement: The Obama administration "leaked information, deliberately or otherwise, that led to the identification of the Pakistani doctor that helped us in achieving our goals and killing bin Laden."
title: Pakistan made the connection on its own

statement: Says Congressmen Paul Ryan and Todd Akin co-sponsored legislation "to limit federal funding for abortion to victims of ‘forcible rape.’"
title: 'Forcible rape' in original versions

statement: "I led the fight to require the Coast Guard to buy their engines from us, not foreign companies."
title: No real battle, let alone a battle won

statement:
"Clayton County Public Schools recently achieved a milestone that has eluded other
	metropolitan districts across the state" by meeting federal guidelines for having a highly qualified staff.
title: Who knew?

statement: "A small business in my district" needed "31 different permits and fees just to be able to expand."
title: Yes, but this business is a special case

statement: Tim Kaine supported "higher energy costs for families."
title: Dim evidence

statement: Rep. Peter Petrarca "voted on two pieces of legislation that helped auto body shops ... and at that point I think there is a conflict of interest."
title: Was there a conflict of interest?

statement: Says an appointed board created under Obamacare "will have the ability to come between you and your doctor in determining the best treatment options for you!"
title: Familiarly flawed

statement: Says House Republicans spent $50 million on 33 votes to repeal Obamacare.
title: Congressional researchers warned the calculation can't be made

statement: "Under the president's plan, he cuts Medicare by $716 billion, takes that money out of the Medicare trust fund and uses it to pay for Obamacare."
title: Needs more explanation

statement: "Days after the (Osama bin Laden) raid, Hollywood was invited into the White House so that they could receive a briefing" that revealed intelligence sources and methods.
title: Not pushed by the White House, no sign of secrets revealed

statement: Says Bill Nelson "voted to raise our taxes 150 times."
title: Lot of counting tricks here

statement: Says under Wisconsin law, he cannot remove his name from the ballot for re-election to Congress.
title: To get off you have to be six-feet under

statement: Says Jon Corzine "gave away 14 percent raises over 4 years and he stood on the front steps of the Capitol at a public-sector union rally and said, 'I will fight to get you a great contract.’"

statement: "From a standpoint of the county government, neither school system has received an increase in funding over the past six years."
title: State increases, but not local

statement: Ted Cruz is "unknown to the vast majority of Texans."
title: Name ID high, lacks legislative record

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "raises the pay of inmates, but we don't raise the pay of staff in our correctional institutions."

statement: Says Reps. Rush Holt, Frank Pallone and Bill Pascrell are "willing to jeopardize seniors’ access to coverage by gutting $741 billion from Medicare" to pay for a "big-government healthcare takeover."

statement: "Thirty percent of [Sheldon Whitehouse' campaign] money is coming from special interests."
title: PACs? Yes. Special interests? It's lots more

statement: "Paul Ryan got his start in politics, as a young staffer just out of college, working for then-Congressman John Kasich’s Budget Committee."
title: Kasich? What about Bob? Kasten, that is

statement: Paul Ryan would "outlaw in vitro fertilization."
title: Bill he co-sponsored could hamper IVF, but not "outlaw" it

statement: "While (Barack) Obama preaches ‘we are our brother’s keeper,’ his brother and aunt live in real poverty in Kenya."
title: Close to half of Kenyans in poverty

statement: Says she does the jobs of state auditor, secretary of state and lieutenant governor "for less than the price of one of them" in Washington state.
title: In title but not in practice

statement: Says Texas is 1st in business climate, 49th in education.
title: Study up before you run again, Kinkster

statement: "Austin is the largest city in the U.S. or Texas with no geographic representation" on its city council.
title: Citizen research holds

source: American Civil Liberties Union of Florida
statement: "13,000 Floridians are able to vote -- but their governor won't tell them."
title: The state tried for years to reach these folks

statement: Says "Paul Ryan supports banning all abortions, even in cases of rape or incest."
title: Almost all, but Ryan supports one limited exception

statement: Claims Joe Biden said "coal is more dangerous than terrorists."
title: Distorts comments about coal and air pollution

statement: "NASCAR fans are twice as likely as non fans to serve in the military and 37 percent of active servicemembers and veterans are NASCAR fans."
title: Data is thin, but claim makes sense

statement: "After one year, Tennessee’s students made their biggest single-year jump in achievement ever recorded in the state."
title: Right with an asterisk

statement: Says Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan "want to turn Medicare into a voucher system."
title: A lesson in Washington linguistics

statement: Says Paul Ryan "wants to cut Pell Grant scholarships for nearly 10 million students."
title: Yes, if using Obama assumptions

statement: Says "about 100,000 kids in this country leave their home state and go to another state to be educated. Out of that 100,000 young people, 30,000 of them are from New Jersey, by far the largest amount."
title: Nationwide numbers are way off

statement: Says President Obama said of the national debt, "If I don't have this done in three years, then there's going to be a one-term proposition."
title: Creative editing confuses the issue

statement: Says Barack Obama "robbed Medicare (of) $716 billion to pay for ... Obamacare."
title: Not "robbed"

statement: Says Paul Ryan's budget relies on the same $700 billion in savings from Medicare that Mitt Romney and other Republicans have been attacking Democrats about.
title: Both sides trying to reduce future spending

statement: Says "a Republican hasn't won [an election] for a presidency in New Jersey since 1988."
title: Solidly Democrat since 1992

statement: "(Brendan) Doherty wants to raise the eligibility age for Social Security benefits for anyone born after 1960, with no regard for the challenges it would cause for people working in physically demanding occupations."
title: Where’s the proof?

statement: Florida has "more concealed weapons permits than any other state."
title: By a wide margin

statement: Says Mitt Romney "wants to end tax credits for wind producers."
title: Romney says he would get rid of the tax credit

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Martin Heinrich "spent a trillion of our tax dollars on a stimulus for failed companies here and jobs overseas."
title: Much of the stimulus literally couldn't be spent that way

statement: "Mitt Romney is the first major party candidate for president of the United States in modern times not to release at least 12 years of tax returns."
title: Reagan released one

statement: Voter turnout for some groups in the 2008 presidential general election in Georgia "was far greater than it should have been demographically."
title: Don't forget about Obama

statement: Says Josh Mandel bet against Ohio families
title: Ad invests in a bad bet

statement: Says Ronda Storms voted to fund the 'Taj Mahal' courthouse.
title: Hard to foresee the future

statement: Says Joe Garcia "voted to raise our utility rates."
title: Votes to both raise and cut rates

statement: Says Mitt Romney said at a January 2012 debate that under Paul Ryan’s tax plan, "I’d have paid no taxes in the last two years."
title: Ryan plan didn't come up

statement: "We do know that Romney personally approved over $70 million in fictional losses to the IRS as part of the notorious 'Son of Boss' tax scandal, one of the largest tax avoidance schemes in history."
title: What Romney specifically approved is unclear

source: Floridians for Ethics and Truth in Politics
statement: Says state Senate candidate Aaron Bean voted to give health care subsidies to illegal immigrants.
title: Twisting government jargon

statement: "We actually made history in 2010. We came the closest in 24 years to defeating Frank Pallone."
title: History says otherwise

statement: The Obama administration is "unwinding our nation’s welfare-to-work requirements."
title: Evidence points to opposite conclusion

statement: Sherrod Brown "sent billions of our tax dollars to foreign countries."
title: A ridiculous stretch

statement: Georgia spends fewer tourism advertising dollars than any other state in the South.
title: Show us the money

statement: Says the federal government "mandates transexuals (sic) and homosexuals grabbing children in their stranger-danger zones in the name of airport security."
title: No such policy

statement: "(The Tax Policy Center) found that Romney would raise taxes on the average middle class family by $2,000 to pay for $5 trillion in tax cuts for millionaires and billionaires."
title: Numbers don't match

statement: "I didn’t try to push" a bill to reduce lottery scholarship proceeds for students.
title: Sponsored the bill, argued for it, passed it through Senate

statement: Rhode Island has "the most burdensome level of health-insurance mandates in the nation."
title: Depends on who's counting; "burden" debatable.

statement: Says Texas GOP platform calls for end to teaching "critical thinking" in public schools.
title: Critical omission

statement: Says library district would come "at no direct cost to the city budget."
title: It would cost the city at least $7 million

statement: Says Ron Saunders "made the choice to stand with Rick Scott" on expanding school vouchers, restricting scholarships and giving tax breaks to the wealthy.
title: Saunders good buddies with Scott? Hardly

statement: Says Tommy Thompson favors Obama's health care mandate, was publicly thanked by Obama for health reform support and that Thompson "says we can't repeal 'Obamacare.'"
title: Words right, timing of them twisted

statement: "I have voted every year in Wisconsin."
title: Except when he didn't

statement: Says Barack Obama "has deported more people than any other president in this country's history."
title: 57 percent more deportations per month than under George W. Bush

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tommy Thompson is "a big corporate lobbyist" and has been "lobbying during the middle of the campaign."
title: Not officially a lobbyist

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Eric Hovde "refused to pay his property taxes until he was taken to court."
title: Hovde fought city’s attempt to collect penalties

statement: Art Robinson says "Social Security should be ended through attrition."
title: Robinson has also called to increase Social Security payments

statement: The property appraiser's budget "is $1 million less today than when I took office 16 years ago."
title: Budget lower since 1996

statement: A United Nations arms treaty would "almost certainly force" the U.S. to "create an international gun registry, setting the stage for full-scale gun confiscation."
title: Put a bullet in this claim

statement: Says the Central Ohio Human Trafficking Task Force "is the first task force of its kind in Central Ohio"
title: A task force with teeth

statement: Says Mitt Romney "paid only 14 percent in taxes — probably less than you."
title: Yes with payroll taxes, no without

source: Floridians for Ethics and Truth in Politics
statement: Aaron Bean voted to give illegal immigrants in-state tuition.
title: Bean denies it, then fesses up

statement: "Gov. Romney himself, with 28 other Republican governors, supported policies that would have eliminated the time limits in the welfare reform law and allowed people to stay on welfare forever."
title: A misleading overreach

statement: Says Mitt Romney and Bain Capital are to blame in a woman’s premature death when they closed the plant where her husband worked.
title: Innuendo with no proof

statement: Bill Nelson’s vote for the Affordable Care Act "cuts $500 billion from Medicare to pay for new government programs."
title: Distorting Medicare again

statement: "This ban will only apply to Oregon commercial fishermen. Washington commercial fishermen would still be allowed to use gillnets on the Columbia River."
title: WA dictates what happens in WA; ditto for OR

statement: As Florida secretary of state, Kurt Browning "allowed 1,800 illegal voters to register in Florida."
title: Number is wrong, plus he didn't 'allow'

statement: "One of the key things about Leonard Lance is that in 2008, when you look at [the] Project Vote Smart website, he was not for guns. Now he has gone too far to the right, saying that you can carry concealed weapons in national parks."
title: Not for guns? Nope.

statement: "Thousands of politicians from across Ohio – along with their relatives, employees and friends – are still eligible to serve" on the proposed redistricting commission.

statement: In June 2012 "we actually had more people go on Social Security Disability [85,000] ... than the 80,000 jobs that were created."

statement: "In June, jobless ranks were higher in nearly 90 percent of U.S. cities."

statement: Says Mitt Romney opposes requiring employers to cover contraception and would eliminate funding for Planned Parenthood.

statement: Says he never voted for a "tax increase."

statement: "Ninety percent of the topsoil has inadequate moisture to grow crops."

statement: "We have reduced funding for education the least. They've suffered the least cuts."

statement: "As president, Barack Obama has never visited Israel."

statement: "America used to be the third easiest country to get established in a business. It's now number 17."

statement: The health care law could cost up to $2 trillion, "double what we were promised."

statement: Says "Your kid just ate 16 packs of sugar."

statement: The health care law "imposes the largest tax increase in history on the middle class."

statement: "Bill Nelson was the deciding vote" on the health care law.

statement: President Barack Obama’s health care reform "slashed $500 billion from Medicare."

statement: Says as a result of the national health care reform, "the Congressional Budget Office says we save $250 million over the first 10 years. Over the next 10 years, we save $1.2 trillion in savings in terms of health care."

statement: Cuts in local government and school funding in John Kasich’s budget caused "many communities to seek school levies, local tax increases, layoffs."

statement: The health care law is "the largest tax [increase] in the history of our country"

statement: "Unemployment rate dropped in every state that elected a Republican gov. in 2010"

statement: Gov. Rick Scott "tried to kick 180,000 people off the voter rolls."

statement: "Every one of the 67 supervisors of elections" in Florida refused to carry out the effort to remove noncitizens from the voter rolls.

statement: Says Mitt Romney "has a corporation in Bermuda (but) failed to disclose that on seven different financial disclosures."

statement: Montana Democratic Sen. Jon Tester is "the largest recipient of lobbyist money."

statement: Sixteen thousand new Internal Revenue Service agents will be "empowered to enforce" the new health care legislation.

statement: "I've never supported a payroll tax."

statement: "75 percent of the Obamacare tax falls on the middle class."

statement: " ‘Obamacare’ puts the federal government between you and your doctor."

statement: Toothpaste contains "the poison substance of fluoride."

statement: The federal government has made investments in science and technology inventing the products that led to the creation of Google.

statement: "Two thirds to three quarters of people without [health] insurance in Rhode Island work."

statement: "In the last 10 years, only one piece of legislation has been cosponsored and passed by" John Duncan Jr.

statement: Says cuts by Gov. Rick Perry's administration left "12,000 teachers without a job."

statement: Says "while state leaders have cut funding for our schools and other basic priorities, the amount of money the state is projected to give away through tax breaks increased by a whopping $3.4 billion."

statement: Under the health care law, "everybody will have lower rates, better quality care and better access."

statement: States still face a "mandate" to expand Medicaid coverage under President Obama's health care reform law.

statement: Voter fraud provided "a portion" of the margin of victory of Democrat John Lehman over Republican Sen. Van Wanggaard in a state Senate recall election.

statement: The Supreme Court said the individual mandate "is a tax. So it's a tax."

statement: Says Clackamas County Measure 3-401 "will hurt our county, cripple economic growth, and increase our taxes with excessive special elections."

statement: The United States has "the best health care delivery system in the world."

statement: The Mack Penny Plan for the federal budget  "would balance our budget by 2019" and "continues to gain support."

statement: By eliminating the public intervenor’s office, "I was the first one to fire Kathleen Falk."

statement: "If you look at most of the polls, this is a margin-of-error race on Fourth of July between Mitt Romney and the president."

statement: The Wisconsin Retirement System for public employees is "a self-funded pension plan" and "it’s the money of the workers’ that funds it."

statement: Says "our 12 month job increase was the sixth highest in the nation."

statement: "Fireworks have never been safer, and their use continues to increase each year."

statement: "We’re spending $12,000 bucks a kid a year in the school system."

statement: "In 1950, corporations paid $3 in taxes for every $1 by a worker. Today, they pay 22 cents for every $1 by a worker."

statement: Says he "passed" eight measures, including ones to prevent groping at airport security checks and to bar "sanctuary" cities in Texas.

statement: Says Dow Chemical decided to build a plant in Saudi Arabia rather than Oklahoma due to the impact of environmental regulations on the supply of natural gas.

statement: "Statistics show that more people at this time telecommute than they ride carpools, mass transit, bicycle or walk."

statement: A company with "20 employees" could go "out of business" because of health care law requirements to buy insurance.
title: Blatantly wrong

statement: The Medicaid expansion is "going to cost Florida $1.9 billion a year."
title: Inflates, oversimplifies state estimate

statement: Says the health care law rations care, like systems in Canada and Great Britain.
title: 'Rationing' charge is empty rhetoric

statement: Tim Kaine "made Virginia the best state for business four years in a row."
title: Pro-business traditions predate Kaine

statement: "Before Act 10, the total cost of public sector employees’ employment was 29 percent higher than that in the private sector. After the act, it’s still 22 percent higher."
title: Picture a lot more cloudy than presented

statement: "Just in the past 10 years, college tuition has increased 28 percent."
title: Costs are even higher

statement: Lorain "is the poorest urban school district in the state of Ohio."
title: Poverty is an issue, but several other urban districts are poorer

statement: The transportation tax is regressive, and Emory University is "literally getting its own transit line at virtually no cost to itself."
title: Right on the sales tax, wrong on Emory

statement: "No one in Rhode Island -- not just children, no one in Rhode Island -- should eat more than one serving of freshwater fish caught in our state each month."
title: The facts that got away

statement: As Massachusetts governor, Mitt Romney used a line-item veto to cut "millions of dollars for firefighting equipment," including firefighters' "coats, pants, helmets and boots."
title: Vetoed grants were for fire gear

statement: "New Jersey's citizens are working at the highest rate in three years."
title: Not by any rate

statement: President Obama's health care law is "a government takeover of healthcare."
title: A falsehood that won't die

statement: "People who wash cars at home will use approximately 80 percent more water than they do in a car wash."
title: But claim is all wet

statement: "(Environmentalists) said ‘We’re only going to stop coal mining above 2,000 feet.’ ... Well guess where all the coal in the state of Tennessee is? Above 2,000 feet."
title: Strikes a false vein

statement: President Obama’s health-care law will "add trillions of dollars in debt."
title: Best nonpartisan analysis says it will SAVE money

statement: Says Rep. Charles Bass "supports privatizing Social Security, risking trillions more on Wall Street."
title: The record shows it differently

statement: "Oregon schools receive millions of dollars per year in federal school lunch assistance and yet they are required to spend that money almost anywhere but Oregon."
title: We’re feeding kids cheese from Missouri and Minnesota

statement: Says Ann Kuster said the debate over America’s debt limit is not an important issue of the day.
title: That's not what she said

statement: Says the federal health care law upheld by the Supreme Court "has improved or saved the lives of more than 4,000 Texans" otherwise prevented from obtaining health coverage due to pre-existing conditions.
title: Undercounting

statement: "If you're one of the more than 250 million Americans who already have health insurance, you will keep your health insurance."
title: Americans aren't so lucky today, even before his law is in force

statement: "Obamacare … means that for up to 20 million Americans, they will lose the insurance they currently have, the insurance that they like and they want to keep."
title: Cherry-picked number that lacks key context

statement: "Austin is the biggest city in America with a Tier One research university (UT-Austin) but without a medical school."
title: Meanwhile, in Round Rock

statement: Says "Barack Obama and his team" are "socialists in every respect of the word."
title: Claim fans old flames

statement: Says there are "$500 billion in Medicare cuts required to pay for this flawed [health care law]."
title: A reduction in future growth, not a cut

statement: "Obamacare adds trillions to our deficits and to our national debt."
title: Not supported by evidence

statement: Obama "said (the individual mandate) wasn't a tax."
title: He said it, in one interview

statement: "Obamacare is . . . the largest tax increase in the history of the world."
title: Not even biggest in U.S. history

statement: Says U.S. Senate rival Tommy Thompson said he wants to "do away with Medicare."
title: He said that, more or less

statement: "There is little if any evidence that the use of red light cameras in New Jersey has reduced the number or severity of accidents at the intersections where they are used."
title: Too early to tell

statement: "Over the last few decades, the income of the top 1 percent grew by more than 275 percent -- to an average of $1.3 million a year."
title: They don't all make $1.3 million - range is $352,000 and up

statement: Says "TriMet's own analysis shows that YouthPass does not actually add to the transit agency's costs."
title: Yes, but TriMet says it's not about operating costs

statement: Says the Constitution "specifically states the Congress shall write legislation for immigration policy," so Barack Obama lacks the authority to defer the deportation of young illegal immigrants.
title: Yes, but...

statement: Says because of Texas lawmakers’ choices, "hundreds of thousands of women no longer have access to basic medical care, life-saving cancer screenings and contraception."
title: Estimate: 83,000 have lost state services

statement: "The median income in America has dropped by 10 percent in the last four years."
title: Arguably true at one time, but no longer

statement: "The state's unemployment rate is fifth-highest in the country, a full point above the nationwide rate and higher than all of our...neighboring states."
title: One of the nation's highest

statement: U.S. Rep. Phil Gingrey gave the government the power to electronically spy on Americans without a warrant.
title: We're watching and say Mostly False

statement: Obama has "racked up more debt than any president in history — over $5 trillion."
title: Numbers are right, but is it all Obama's fault?

statement: Says, "Yet in Salem they have traditionally waited until the money is almost gone to pay for the most important things in our state’s budget."
title: That's not how the state budgets

statement: The DREAM Act "was written by members of both parties. When it came up for a vote a year and a half ago, Republicans in Congress blocked it. The bill hadn’t changed. ... The only thing that had changed was politics."
title: More than just a change in politics

statement: Says "a lip-reading instructor at the River School, a Washington, D.C., school for the deaf" has determined that during 9/11 ceremonies, Michelle Obama said, "All this for a damn flag."
title: Read our lips: No truth in this one

statement: Says Josh Mandel’s campaign is under FBI investigation
title: Bearing false witness

statement: Says GOP U.S. Rep. Sean Duffy of Wisconsin "voted twice to end Medicare."
title: Lie of year reprise

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie’s proposed budget is "the biggest spending budget in the history of the state of New Jersey. It is the largest in the nation at this point in time."
title: Big claims, short on facts

statement: Ronald Reagan "raised taxes in 1982, 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1987."
title: Reagan cut tax deals with Congress

statement: Atlanta Tea Party co-founder Debbie Dooley "wants gas taxes raised."
title: That's not the whole story

statement: "Under current law, if you go on a dating website and you say you're 32 and you're actually 42, you've committed a misdemeanor."
title: And a new law changes that.

statement: Federal health care reforms amounted to ‘the government takeover of health care.’
title: An old chestnut, already roasted

statement: Says New Jersey’s job growth in May represents "25 percent of all the jobs created in the country."
title: An invalid comparison

statement: "Three of our cities are among the top five worst cities in the U.S. for asthma."
title: Something in the air?

statement: Women "earn only 77 cents for every dollar earned by men in the same position."
title: 77 cents not based on a job-by-job comparison

statement: "Did you know Wisconsin's AFSCME union has lost 50%+ of its members since no longer requiring membership?"
title: Union disputes, but WSJ stands by its reporting

statement: "Gov. Romney was very clear, he would veto the DREAM Act."
title: No backing off from primary comments

statement: "Now, in the House of Representatives, we have 40 different jobs bills that have passed and almost all of them have been bipartisan."
title: Need more love for bipartisan support

statement: Says a national Coca-Cola study showed Texans love Texas more than residents of any other state love their state; Wisconsinites ranked second.
title: Study's existence unconfirmed, dang it

statement: In 2008, "33.2 percent of those who voted early on the last Sunday before Election Day were African-American, while 23.6 percent were Hispanic."
title: Several groups compared voter turnout with registrations

statement: "70 percent of the people who voted" on June 5, 2012, "just didn’t feel comfortable with the recall of the governor," weakening any idea that Wisconsin is "fully behind this Walker agenda."
title: Recall effect not quite so clear

statement: "As Virginia lost over 65,000 jobs, (Tim) Kaine put partisan ambitions first" by serving as DNC chairman during the last year of his governorship.

statement: "Since the beginning of the economic downturn in FY 2008, the state workforce has been reduced by 12.4 percent as part of overall cost savings measures to balance the budget to reduce revenues."
title: Did they lay off their fact checker?

statement: "My opponent, in 2008, had contributions investigated by the federal government."
title: Contributions claim not on the money

statement: Rhode Island has the "worst maintained bridges in the United States of America . . . and we have the second worst maintained roads [behind] Alaska."
title: No potholes in this argument

statement: "Nearly 60% of all occupants of HUD properties in U.S. are illegals."
title: A tiny fraction of that

statement: "Women (are) paid 77 cents on the dollar for doing the same work as men."
title: A valid number, incorrectly described

statement: "Most of Ted Cruz’s money comes from Washington, from outside the state of Texas."
title: Up to 40 percent

statement: "There’s no wildlife" in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
title: It's called a 'wildlife' refuge for a reason

statement: Since President Barack Obama took office, "you have 1,700 employees just at the Department of Transportation" earning over $170,000.
title: That level actually was reached due to Bush-era policies

statement: "(Assembly Democrats) wanted to raise the gas tax by $2.4 billion. We said no to that....They’re down on the ground. They’re sweating. They’re twitching. It’s ugly, ‘cause I keep saying no."

statement: "Congressman Renacci is under FBI investigation."
title: Contributions, not the congressman, drew FBI scrutiny

statement: Says 97 cents of every dollar played "represents over $500 million dollars that is returned to Oregonians every year to help support job creation, schools, state parks and watersheds."
title: No matter how you dice it, the statement misleads

statement: "Less than 2 percent of illegals are picking crops, but 41 percent are on welfare."
title: Numbers are close but welfare claim is misleading

statement: "A million people a year come into the U.S. legally. No other country even comes close to that figure."
title: He's right, in part because we're such a big country

statement: Says President Obama's new immigration plan "is amnesty."
title: Temporary plan for enforcement isn't amnesty

statement: "The Koch brothers alone gave twice as much money to Scott Walker as the total amount of money raised by Tom Barrett."
title: No evidence it was near that amount

statement: Tim Kaine urged "$500 billion in Medicare cuts."
title: Recycled rubbish

statement: Says that under President Obama, there’s been a substantial increase in federal government jobs.
title: Substantially misleading

statement: "There is no Plan B" if the transportation referendum is not passed by voters.
title: A do over for this claim?

statement: "Vagina. Because apparently, saying that word in the Michigan State House of Representatives can get you a two-day ban from speaking on the floor."
title: The V-word, plus a few others

statement: "More than 43 percent of all food stamps are given to illegals."
title: Mathematically impossible

statement: "In 2011, NJ economy ranked 47th--at the bottom with Alabama, Mississippi & Wyoming. Under Christie, NJ is falling behind."
title: Tweet and blame

statement: Says, "Less than half of all states have legal protections on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, despite the fact that LGBT Americans report employment discrimination and unemployment at much higher rates than the U.S. average."
title: Sexual orientation is not protected under Title VII

statement: Barack Obama has "provided guns to Mexican drug cartels."
title: No confirmed presidential role

statement: "When Mitt Romney was governor, Massachusetts ... (had) more debt per person than any other state in the country."
title: Figure is correct, but lots of context is missing

statement: "Romneycare covers abortion, illegal immigrants and has a public option. Obamacare does not."

statement: "Before I was governor, tuition was skyrocketing and we stopped that. We capped and then we froze college tuition."

statement: The Americans for Tax Reform pledge "relates to new taxes that were going to be initiated by legislative action."
title: A spin too far

statement: Says Mitt Romney has said "we don't need 'more firemen, more policemen, more teachers.' "
title: Clear difference with Obama on cops, teachers, firemen

statement: Says President Barack Obama wants to raise "the lowest (income) tax rate from 10 to 15 percent."
title: Wants to raise taxes on wealthy

statement: Says Joe Kyrillos "voted to raid the state's pension funds by $2.8 billion that is costing New Jersey taxpayers still today to the tune of nearly $15 billion dollars to repay that money."

statement: Says her congressional district has 10,000 medical-device industry jobs and 1,000 will be lost because of health-care law tax.
title: State numbers dubious, too

statement: Decriminalizing marijuana "will save the state anywhere from $4 (million) to $11 million dollars."
title: Claim goes up in smoke

statement: "The latest evidence of Republican success is that since the beginning of the current legislative term, state unemployment has gone down almost 20% to 5% adjusted."

statement: Says he has nearly 200 delegates bound to support his candidacy at the Republican National Convention.
title: Seems about 60 short

statement: Say Portland Public Schools' central administration makes up less than 4 percent of the staff.
title: Central support accounts for 4 percent of district budget

statement: Virginia women earn "only 79 cents to each dollar earned by men..."
title: Many ways to look at pay gap

statement: U.S. Rep. Paul Broun has not authored any legislation that has been adopted by Congress.
title: Broun's batting average on bills not good.

statement: Sherrod Brown "gave huge bonuses to executives."
title: AIG negotiated the bonuses before Congress acted

statement: Says Barack "Obama admits he’s coming for our guns, telling Sarah Brady, ‘We are working on (gun control), but under the radar.’ "
title: Iffy quote, worse interpretation

statement: Says Barack Obama is "trying to slash funding for the Armed Pilots Program designed to prevent terror attacks."
title: House junked Obama's plan

statement: Say "this biennium, liquor sales account for nearly $1 billion in the state budget."
title: Maybe $1 billion in sales -- but it doesn't wind up in the budget

statement: When Mitt Romney was governor, Massachusetts lost 40,000 manufacturing jobs, a rate twice the national average, and fell to 47th in job creation, fourth from the bottom.

statement: U.S. Sen. Bill Nelson was "the deciding vote for the health care law."
title: Only if there were 60 "deciding" votes

statement: Says Robert Menendez is "the king of raising money from Wall Street, over a million dollars, one of the leaders in the United States Senate. I haven’t raised any Wall Street money at all."
title: Wall Street cash gets around

statement: Rob Portman shares "radical, ideological views" toward women.
title: Radical injection of hyperbole

statement: Says "Oregon is one of only three states that allow the use of gillnets on inland waters."
title: Something's fishy

statement: Says Barack Obama’s regulatory adviser Cass Sunstein, "wants to ban hunting and says animals should be represented in court."
title: Walked most of it back in 2009

statement: Says Barack Obama "supported Ted Kennedy’s ammo ban to outlaw all deer-hunting ammunition."
title: Bad news for deer: This isn't true

statement: Says under Mitt Romney, Massachusetts was 47th in job creation.
title: Ranking's right; blame's overstated

statement: Citizens Property Insurance has "over $500 billion worth of risk, with less than $10 billion worth of surplus."
title: Cherry-picking numbers

statement: Says lawyer appointed by Eric Holder to investigate government leaks helped and donated to Obama's campaign, vetting vice presidential prospects.

statement: "Overwhelming Democrat and Republican votes" in 2011 for legislation in two special sessions on jobs demonstrated the bipartisan nature of the Wisconsin Legislature.
title: Rose-colored recollection

statement: "Giving the facts:  73,000 jobs created ... since '11.  Do you know how many direct jobs in the auto industry?  1,800."

statement: Most tips left at Dunkin’ Donuts don’t go to employees.
title: Wake up and smell the facts

statement: "As Governor: Romney did not keep public safety funding in line with inflation."

statement: Under Florida’s voting law, a requirement to turn in voter registrations within 48 hours "makes it impossible to meet the deadline if you’re working right to the end of the week."

statement: Portland, Ore., has "never gotten over 12 to 15 percent ridership" of its public transit system "in the past 12 years."

statement: "Marcy Kaptur voted against a ban which would have prevented the aborting of a baby girl for the sole reason that she's a girl."

statement: Says "only 18 percent of Portland elementary schools have art instruction compared to 83 percent nationally."
title: The numbers are reliable and fairly comparable

statement: "Romney outsourced call center jobs to India."

statement: As governor of Massachusetts, "Romney reduced unemployment to just 4.7 percent."
title: It did fall that far, but Romney doesn't get all the credit

statement: Virginia "is home to more veterans per capita than any state in America."

statement: Says Jeff Wentworth, bending the rules, "has used $211,743.96 in campaign contributions to lease luxury cars."

statement: "Minnesota has passed and Indiana has passed" right to work laws making union membership and dues optional
title: Minnesota started down the road, but stopped

statement: "When I was U.S. Attorney we wound up putting 10 percent of the state Legislature in jail during my seven years."

statement: A new manufacturing plant is slated to create about 3,000 jobs in central and northeast Georgia and "create about a $3 billion infusion" into the economy.

statement: "When I started in Ohio it was terrible. Now, we’re getting bipartisan support for our bills. And that’s called leadership."

statement: The United States has experienced "40 straight months of unemployment at 8 percent or higher."

statement: Says "Tommy Thompson's tax plan amounts to an average tax cut of almost $87,000 for the top 1 percent."
title: In the ballpark as an estimate

statement: Says "we are overcharging students . . . to help pay for the health care law."
title: Health care bill generated more student aid, not less

statement: "Massachusetts is reporting a trend far below the national trend in the escalation of health-care costs in this year."
title: Not this year. Not overall. In 2010? Maybe.

statement: Says combined inflation and unemployment rates in October 2011 were the highest since Ronald Reagan succeeded Jimmy Carter.
title: Disregards Reagan's first two years as president

statement: Says Democratic runoff opponent Grady Yarbrough twice previously ran statewide as a Republican.

statement: "We spend in tax loopholes annually $1.1 trillion. That's more than we spend on our defense budget in a year, on Medicare or Medicaid in a year."

statement: "More Hispanics have fallen into poverty under Obama."
title: Recession, not Obama, mostly to blame

statement: "When Mitt Romney was governor, Massachusetts lost 40,000 manufacturing jobs, a rate twice the national average."
title: A stretch to blame Romney for decades-long manufacturing decline

statement: "In Galveston, Texas, they have allowed people to privatize part of their Social Security. And people are building wealth."
title: Plan works, but some better off with Social Security

statement: Says Barack Obama has played nearly 100 rounds of golf as president.
title: Hole-y so

statement: "It took us four years to balance the budget. Then I gave you four surplus budgets for the first time in more than 70 years, paid $600 billion down on the national debt."
title: A mixed picture on debt

statement: Says Barack Obama is a socialist.
title: Obama is a... vocalist

statement: Says "As Mayor of Wilsonville, I drove TriMet out of town and replaced their bloated transit system with our own local bus line that offers better service and has saved our businesses millions of dollars."
title: Bus service was on its way out before he took office

statement: Says Hawaii Gov. Neil Abercrombie made a late-night visit to Kinko’s to forge President Barack Obama’s birth certificate two days before Obama unveiled it to the media.
title: Gullible people forwarded it after "satire" label got dropped

statement: Florida election officials’ requests to some residents to submit proof of citizenship is a "backdoor poll tax."
title: The cost of a stamp is much less than what poor voters faced under the poll tax

statement: Homosexual behavior "cuts your life by about 20 years."
title: "Gross misrepresentation" of research

statement: Says PolitiFact "listed Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin as the Governor who told the most lies" and "our own ‘untruthful’ Governor Chris Christie made it into Politifact's top five of ‘Lie - en Governors’."
title: Wrong on both counts

statement: "There is no record of congresswoman Betty Sutton ... ever holding a single in-person town hall meeting open to the general public."
title: Better recheck that record

statement: "Right now, I’m polling at about 8 percent" against Barack Obama and Mitt Romney.
title: Most polls haven't offered him as a choice

statement: "District 22 includes about 80% of the district I have represented since 2010. District 20 includes about 20% of the area I have represented since 2010."
title: New maps change Latvala's district

statement: Says PolitiFact issued a True ruling on Paul Krugman calling "Governor Christie a ‘fiscal phony.’"
title: A 'phony' claim

statement: The new Hartsfield-Jackson international terminal was "on time and on budget."
title: Crash and burn

statement: Says he "cut the budget."
title: Doesn't set the budget, but did reduce internal spending

statement: Massachusetts under Gov. Mitt Romney initially ranked last among states in job growth, but by the end of his governorship, "we were in the middle of the pack."
title: Numbers right, but Romney's role was limited

statement: Under Gov. Mitt Romney, Massachusetts ranked "47th in job creation."
title: Right on stats, but bigger forces beyond Romney

statement: Says "TriMet now spends $1.63 in benefits for every $1.00 spent on wages."
title: He's right -- but only if you count retirees

statement: "In the 2000 Florida election, at least 1,100 eligible voters were wrongly dropped from voting rolls in an attempt to purge a list of felons. Many of those who were dropped showed up to vote and were told they could not."

statement: When Mitt Romney was governor, "the fact is that the average income for a family in Massachusetts went up by $5,500."
title: With inflation, incomes declined

statement: Georgia Public Service Commission member Stan Wise "has received about 95 percent of his campaign money from the utilities he is supposed to be regulating."
title: More money. Some problems on the details.

statement: Rob Portman won the fewest votes of all Ohio U. S. Senate victors since 2000.
title: Not all elections are equal

statement: "Scott Walker has a plan to privatize state lands" and "wants to sell our deer to the highest bidder."

statement: "Women have come through the recession worse off than men … the numbers bear that out. We went from a 7 percent unemployment rate for women when he (President Barack Obama) was elected to an 8.1 percent now."
title: Slow recovery for women

statement: President Obama budget request for veterans is "more than double the amount in constant dollars appropriated in 1980, when the veterans population was larger by a third."
title: Bipartisan effort has helped veterans

statement: The last three days of early voting "happen to be the most populated days of voting that we have in early voting."
title: Elections boards got slammed with voters in 2008

statement: "Forty years ago ... about half of congressional districts were genuinely competitive. Today, only about 10 percent of House races on Cook Political Report are listed as ‘toss-ups’ or ‘lean’ to one party."
title: Yes and no

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker made "draconian cuts" to public safety budgets that put police officers at "greater risk of harm."
title: The mayor way overshoots his target

statement: "The U.S. is borrowing approximately $2.52 for every $1 of economic growth so far in 2012."
title: Debt growing faster than economy

statement: Says "city leadership is threatening to lay off police and emergency services personnel to balance the budget."
title: "Last resort" does not = threat

party: Ocean State Tea Party in Action
statement: "We came out against Deepwater and everybody is now paying for [the project] in their electric bills."
title: It has to be built first

statement: The federal government "reviewed and verified" his administration’s numbers showing Wisconsin added 23,608 jobs in 2011.
title: Is the final word in? We'll know June 28

statement: Figures cited by Gov. Scott Walker "are not commonly used" to measure job creation.
title: A rushed release doesn’t discredit the data

statement: Ted Cruz "helps run two national organizations that have been leading the push to give amnesty to illegal immigrants."
title: One group, not leading

statement: Says Tom Barrett plans "to spend $100 million on a trolley that goes barely two miles on the east side of Milwaukee."
title: Barrett backs the plans, but some cost estimates not firm

statement: "We’ve seen property taxes go down for the first time in 12 years on a median valued home."
title: Not lower for everyone, but median-value measure is on target

statement: Says the Affordable Care Act was a federal takeover of the student loan industry and ‘profits’ on the loans go to help pay for the health care law.
title: A big stretch

statement: "No one on my staff has ever been charged with a crime."
title: Receptionist arrested, convicted

statement: Says in the last six months of the Bush administration, the U.S. lost 3.5 million jobs, including 760,000 jobs during January 2009 alone.
title: Not quite

statement: Candidate Bill Byrne used campaign funds for work on his "personal car."
title: Truckin' to a half true

statement: "The legislature was never given the opportunity to debate or vote on loaning $75 million to 38 Studios."
title: They were in the dark

statement: Because of voter fraud, Republican candidates "need to do a point or two better" to win statewide elections in Wisconsin.
title: No evidence of that rate of fraud

statement: "More than 250 (voter registration) groups, ranging across the entire political spectrum, have filed with the state and are registering voters right now."
title: More than half aren't registering voters

statement: Says Amanda Fritz "manages less than 5 percent of city operations."
title: Nolan's right, though it's not Fritz's choice

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "took away $1.6 billion from schools and handed it off as over $2 billion in tax breaks to the rich."
title: Connection dubious; numbers off

statement: Says that from 1992 through 2010, every statewide candidate drawing over 43 percent of the vote in a Republican Texas primary won the resulting runoff.
title: Happened four times

statement: "When it comes to what little bit of job creation was happening in Massachusetts (when Mitt Romney was governor), it was happening in the public sector at six times the rate that it was happening in the private sector."
title: Only true for state government

statement: To help balance the 2011-13 budget, Gov. Scott Walker used "a credit card" approach that "pushed over $500 million in debt onto our children and our grandchildren" costing state taxpayers "more than $150 million in interest."
title: Restructuring debt, yes; but more routine than implied

statement: Thanks to our policies, "for the first time in state history, we have put millions of dollars into our rainy day fund in consecutive years."
title: Payment expected, but not made yet

statement: Says "there have been some job gains in the McMansion State since Mr. Christie took office, but they have lagged gains both in the nation as a whole and in New York and Connecticut, the obvious points of comparison."
title: A better ‘comeback’ elsewhere

statement: Says he "earned the highest possible credit ratings as state treasurer."
title: Preserved the high rating he inherited

statement: An "Obamacare slush fund" paid to spay and neuter dogs and cats, then counted it as an "anti-obesity campaign."
title: UPDATE: Corrected ruling

statement: "Only 2 percent of public high schools in the country offer PE classes."
title: She forgot to add an important word: "daily"

statement: Access for 12,000 women to use Planned Parenthood -- "not for the right to choose," but for "basic health care" -- was "taken away" by Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker and Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch.
title: Funding taken away

statement: "The Republican from Georgia [U.S. Rep. Jack Kingston], he hasn’t even been to a NASCAR race."
title: Strange but true

statement: Says Sen. Sherrod Brown "cast the deciding vote on the government takeover of health care."
title: Accuracy ailing in this health care claim

statement: "According to ATF data, 70 percent of firearms recovered and traced in drug cartel crimes in Mexico originated from the United States."
title: Guns used in crimes but not necessarily drug trafficking

statement: Says Tom Barrett "voted to ban 15 different kinds of guns, even a lot of common deer rifles."
title: Banned guns not widely used for deer hunting (then or now)

statement: "The region I represent, both currently and in the future, has more automotive plants than the entire state of California."
title: No California dreamin' here

statement: A government analysis shows under a proposed transportation tax, "metro Atlanta will create or support an additional 200,000 new jobs, including jobs that are maintained year over year."
title: Don't hold your breath

statement: "In the state of Rhode Island 25 percent of our current physicians are graduates of for-profit medical schools."
title: Grads of foreign schools, yes. For-profit, no

statement: "While Act 10 allowed (Milwaukee County) to save some money, it was millions short of what we needed to fill the hole left by the $28 million cut in state aid."
title: County did come up short, but could have done more, too

statement: Says under President Barack Obama there’s been "the lowest discretionary spending we’ve had in decades in the United States."
title: Highest level in about 20 years

statement: "Water transportation is the most fuel efficient, least polluting, safest, and least expensive means of moving cargo."
title: Clear sailing for this claim

statement: Claims credit for food tax reductions that "previous Democrat regimes refused to make."
title: Short memory

statement: In 2011, Alabama and Massachusetts passed legislation allowing non-citizens who are legal residents to vote in state and local elections.
title: Alabama? No. Massachusetts? No.

statement: Says he "restored prayer and the pledge in our schools."
title: School-led prayer still barred

statement: Says Larry Taylor gave "in-state tuition to illegal immigrants."
title: Mangled flashback

statement: Says the city of Portland has one manager for every six "front-line" workers.

statement: Says "$57,000 is the mean [income] in our state" for a family.

statement: "We don’t allow filming inside of the City Hall unless there is a specific reason."

statement: "The number of new businesses started per year has dropped by 100,000 during this president’s term."

statement: Every time the price of gasoline rises 1 cent, "it's a billion dollars out of our economy that goes to Saudi Arabia."

statement: "Congress as a whole is less popular than it’s been since polling was invented."

statement: Says abortion doctors are "flying into this state, performing abortions and flying out."

statement: Says she balanced a $10 billion budget shortfall without raising taxes.

statement: Says "at the state level we're spending more on tax expenditures than we are on public safety, health care and education combined."

statement: "We were the No. 1 job creator in America in February and we are now the No. 4 job creator in the last year."

statement: Says Romney flip-flopped on abortion.

statement: "(GM and Chrysler) repaid their loans."

statement: "Did you know ObamaCare will cost nearly twice as much as initially expected -- $1.8 TRILLION?"

statement: Despite President Barack Obama's promise to cut healthcare costs, "the average cost of a family policy is up $1,300."

statement: Says Tennessee has some of the lowest beer excise tax rates in the country.

statement: "Every 1 percent increase in the cost of health insurance today causes about 30,000 Georgians to be uninsured."

statement: "Make no mistake -- Sherrod Brown is one of the main D.C. politicians responsible for Ohio jobs moving to China."

statement: "We have $60 billion in 2010 in Medicare fraud."

statement: Says "the No. 2 cause of death in the U.S. (for) women under 50 is being killed by their spouse or domestic partner."

statement: Because of the new health care law, "Americans no longer will see their coverage dropped or capped when illness strikes."

statement: Says "the governor took away a billion dollars of rebates, so in real dollars, our property taxes have gone up 20 percent."

statement: "We also have, in a park that’s not far from here, an ability to build a reservoir that can hold a 30-day water supply for the city of Atlanta."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "didn’t balance the budget" so "we now have a larger state deficit 14 months into (his) term than we did when he was elected."

statement: Says there have been "well over" 54 million abortions since 1973.

statement: "More than 27,000 Rhode Island jobs depend on trade with Canada."

statement: Because of the new health care law, "17 million kids can no longer be denied for a pre-existing condition."

statement: Because of the new health care law, "2.5 million young adults now have coverage."
