statement: "While 9,000 state employees were added to the state’s payroll, Oregon’s revenue forecasts dropped by more than $4 billion."

statement: "In Texas, there are 668 Democratic Hispanic elected officials to the 60 in the Republican Party."

statement: "This (Independent Payment Advisory Board) board can ration care and deny certain Medicare treatments so Washington can fund more wasteful spending."

statement: Says "over 1 million signatures" were submitted in attempt to recall Gov. Scott Walker.

statement: The Wisconsin state Assembly chambers extend to the bathroom and the parlor, and rules allow members to vote for each other if the member is in the chambers.

statement: Says "my plan is a property tax cut."

statement: "The total (state) payroll has gone down. The total amount of the number of workers in the state has gone down. I like the fact that the bulk of that is just by retirements."

statement: "There are a lot of casinos across the country that have gone bankrupt."

statement: Obama's secretary of energy, Dr. Steven Chu, "has said publicly he wants us to pay European levels (for gasoline), and that would be $9 or $10 a gallon."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker cut aid to local schools despite campaigning on trying to restore two-thirds state funding for education

statement: There are "850,000 Ohio jobs tied to the auto industry."

statement: The "Democrat majority in the Senate has failed to submit [a] budget in the past 1,000 days."

statement: Says her accomplishments include "a fiscally responsible budget agreement that controls state spending."

statement: Says there are four super PACs on the Republican side of the Texas U.S. Senate race.

statement: President Barack Obama’s policies have forced "many parts of the country to experience rolling blackouts."

statement: "Ohio is not meeting its obligation to update voter registrations when voters change their address with the BMV."

statement: "In the last two years, super PACs raised more than $180 million -- with roughly half of it coming from fewer than 200 super-rich people and roughly 20 percent from corporations."

statement: "It costs about $40,000 a year for a homeless person to be on the streets."

statement: Says Wisconsin Assembly Republicans voted to repeal a law that ensures "that women cannot get paid less than a man for doing the same job."

statement: "A clear majority of Americans support removing the cost-sharing requirement for prescription contraceptive coverage."
title: Most surveys show support

statement: "Seven out of the 10 states with the lowest unemployment rates (have) Republican governors … That approach that Republicans are using is working."
title: Flimsy statistic

statement: Georgia ranks "last in job growth."
title: Job growth numbers nothing to brag about

statement: Says 94 percent of Wisconsin employers think the state "is heading in the right direction" and a majority say they will "grow their companies in 2012."
title: Friendly sample yields favorable results

statement: "They're paying a less rate of tax -- these richest people in America -- than they have in the last 80 years."
title: Not 80 years, but pretty close

statement: "A hundred percent of all the jobs lost during the recession have been reclaimed in Texas … while the nation is at about 36 percent."
title: Texas bouncing back faster

statement: Giant companies like Toyota will not locate in a state that has not passed a right-to-work law
title: Toyota says otherwise

statement: PIP fraud is "$1 billion in fraud."
title: Hard to say if $1 billion is all fraud

statement: Says "traffic fatalities have fallen dramatically, even as population has risen. You are more likely to stay alive biking, walking and driving around Portland than you were before" he took over the Portland Bureau of Transportation.
title: Walkers aren't much safer these days

statement: Says he "cut taxes by more than $600 million" when he was governor.
title: Right on the money

statement: "If we keep the minimum wage at the current level, then single-parent families earning the minimum wage at a full-time job will live in poverty in New Jersey."
title: Not enough for a family of 2

statement: A socially conservative group sponsored a "prayer vigil" to stop people from buying Girl Scout cookies because it thinks the Girl Scouts are affiliated with Planned Parenthood.
title: Prayer? Yes. Vigil? No.

statement: Says Barack Obama "promised" gasoline at $2.50 a gallon.
title: Newt did, Obama didn't

statement: Says Barack Obama "promised he would cut the deficit in half" but didn’t.
title: Obama now blames the economy

statement: "The fact is 90-percent of Down Syndrome children were aborted in this country."
title: Overly broad claim expands scope of regionalized research

statement: After President Barack Obama’s health care law takes full effect, "100 percent" of Americans will "depend on some form of federal payment, some form of government benefit to help provide for them."
title: At most it would be 60 percent

statement: "A little less than 50 percent of the people in this country depend on some form of federal payment, some form of government benefit to help provide for them."
title: It may even be higher now

statement: Says Obama has "doubled the stock market from where we started when he was sworn into office"
title: Dates are crucial

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker doesn't make his calendar public -- "he's on our dime and we don't know where he is."
title: Mixed bag on what he releases and when

statement: Says the proposed fiscal year 2013 budget "is still below the level of state spending when I took office."
title: It ain’t much, but it’s smaller

statement: "Today, you can't rely on (the retirement fund for public employees), it's not funded."
title: It's funded better than many other states

statement: "Tonight in Ohio, more people came out to vote for Barack Obama in an unopposed race than voted for (Mitt) Romney and (Rick) Santorum combined."
title: Actually, Romney and Santorum won far more

statement: Ronald Reagan’s philosophy of "peace through strength" is why "the Iranians released the hostages on the same day and at the same hour that Reagan was sworn in."
title: Reagan did many things; this wasn't one of them

statement: "If you look up the dictionary definition of happiness at the time of our founders … happiness was not doing what you want to do but doing what you ought to do."
title: Founders' understanding was far more sweeping

statement: Says the federal government "tells health insurance companies how much money they're allowed to keep of what they receive in revenues -- 15 percent."
title: Not all revenue, not for every plan

statement: Says pension contributions under Gov. Chris Christie would represent "75 percent of the total contribution made between the years 1995 and 2010. That's right, in 15 years, total state contribution was only $2.1 billion."
title: This claim’s off by $1.3 billion

statement: Says opponent Beto O’Rourke "wants to legalize drugs."
title: One drug

statement: "Fifty percent of the graduating class of the year 2012 will have smoked marijuana or have done illegal drugs."
title: Candidate not blowing smoke with this claim

statement: "Rhode Island is the only state where officers at state-supported [colleges] carry out their duties unarmed."
title: Not quite a bull's-eye.

statement: "Between 1982 and 2007 the cost of a college education increased 439 percent."
title: College has been getting more expensive for a long time

statement: "When my grandfather came to this country back in 1925, there were no government benefits."
title: Veterans pensions, workers' comp were among programs in place then

statement: Connie Mack's "only real job in the real world" was as "‘events coordinator’ for Hooters!"
title: Will voters give a hoot about Hooters?

statement: "The top 1 percent (of income earners) paid 36.7 percent (of the taxes).  ... The top 50 percent pay 97.7 percent."
title: Those who don't pay are mostly seniors or poor

statement: The Atlanta area’s water planning district "is now the national leader in conservation."
title: We're playing catch-up

statement: Says in the 2012 State of the Union address, President Obama "didn't even mention the deficit or debt."
title: No mentions? Try six.

statement: Wisconsin is called the Badger State because "our ancestors came here with the hopes of living the American dream by mining."
title: And some lived like badgers

statement: Says State Comptroller Matthew Boxer "pointed out that many towns are artificially lowering the real estate values that they report to Trenton" in order to "get hundreds of millions of dollars of additional school aid. This is the kind of fraud that needs to be addressed immediately."
title: Exaggerating the findings

statement: President Obama's "budget would call for about $25 trillion in debt by the end of his term, if he was re-elected."
title: An exaggerated claim

statement: "When (Marcy) Kaptur fought for the Democrats' prescription drug benefit for seniors, (Dennis) Kucinich voted no."
title: Accuracy ailing in this blast from the past

statement: Says Ted Cruz slurred Republican senators including John Cornyn as "graybeards" and "spineless jellyfish."
title: Cruz not naming names

statement: "[E]mployment in Gwinnett is up more than 3 percent over last year, and unemployment is the lowest of the five core metro counties."
title: Rewrite reduces rating a notch

statement: Pasco County "opened 22 new schools over six years to keep pace with growth in student population and implement the class size amendment."
title: Paying fines for missing class size requirements

statement: Pasco County schools have graduation rates "substantially higher than the state average" and dropout rates "below the state average."
title: Beating the state average

statement: While fighting a move to toughen penalties for workplace gender discrimination, state Sen. Glenn Grothman said "he didn’t believe women belonged in the workplace" but belonged "at home, cooking and cleaning and having babies."
title: He fought the law, but not with this argument

statement: Says "we had to cut 13 billion dollars in state spending over two years."
title: Cutting doesn’t mean not spending

statement: "In 2011, there were more than 28,000 new Tennessee jobs created and over $4 billion in capital investment. Our Jobs4TN plan is working."
title: Employment up but can't credit Jobs4TN plan

statement: "One out of four of our young people say they are victims of this (dating) violence."
title: All abuse yes; physical abuse no

statement: "[R]emember, the president proposed eliminating charitable deductions for higher-income taxpayers."
title: No charity for this claim

statement: "In 2010 about 75 percent of child abuse and neglect reports in Oregon were made by those required to report by law."
title: Child abuse reports stack up to truth

source: American Civil Liberties Union of Florida
statement: There are "a larger number of shark attacks in Florida than there are cases of voter fraud."
title: Candidates, stay out of the water

statement: Mitt Romney "left Massachusetts $1 billion in debt."
title: It was the high end of a temporary projection that didn't materialize

statement: "Gingrich supported individual health insurance mandates."
title: Past support is on record

statement: "Under President Obama, U.S. security funding for Israel is at an all-time high."
title: Number is close, but amount was set under George W. Bush

statement: "In some communities, for $10,000 worth of (PIP) coverage it’s $1,500 a year."
title: Depends on the individual, though

statement: "Invested $90 million in traffic fixes without raising taxes."
title: Broadly speaking and didn't do it solo

statement: "We supported the first new nuclear power plant in three decades."
title: He's talking licenses, not plants built

statement: All travelers -- even babies -- arriving in the U.S. by air must have a passport.
title: Right across the plate

statement: Sixteen million jobs were created under Ronald Reagan's presidency.
title: Newt goes back in time

statement: Rhode Island has the "the second-most heavily deployed National Guard in the United States."
title: Answering the call time and again.

statement: President Obama pushed through the stimulus "based on the promise of keeping unemployment under 8 percent."
title: A projection, not a promise

statement: Says he "did the very best" in a recent poll in Iowa matching up each of the major Republican presidential candidates against President Barack Obama.
title: No. 1, with a 7-point lead

statement: Says Ohio Rep. Marcy Kaptur "actually lives" in "a fancy condo in the Washington, D.C.  suburbs."
title: By this rationale, all of Congress could be in trouble

statement: Says Rick Santorum "funded Planned Parenthood."
title: Votes were for large spending bills

statement: The U.S. has a "record number of oil rigs operating right now – more working oil and gas rigs than the rest of the world combined."
title: Strong talking point meets messy reality

statement: Says local Texas chambers of commerce were granted exemptions from paying property taxes on their headquarter properties.
title: One legislator voted "no"

statement: Says Rick Santorum "opposes right-to-work"
title: Santorum voted against it in '96, now supports it

statement: "We've seen in this last year tremendous things happening, including our unemployment rate come down 2 percentage points."
title: Less than 1 point year over year

statement: Says when she "helped get $15 billion more for veterans care, Kucinich voted No."
title: Cited aid was just one part of a large spending bill

statement: "We have 395 inmates pushed into triple-bunked cells intended for two inmates and bunked in classrooms and areas supposed to be designated for inmate labor."
title: AFSCME officials say they can't 'prove' the claim

statement: Says there’s no proven instance where hydraulic fracking has polluted groundwater.
title: By a precise definition

statement: Says Mitt Romney said he does not "line up with the NRA."
title: Old but accurate

statement: "Since President Obama took full control of Washington," every day, 13,000 more people "have been put on food stamps."
title: Numbers are right, but lots more to blame than just Obama

statement: Says "Rick Santorum supported (Arlen) Specter over conservative candidates twice."
title: It happened, however enthusiastically

statement: Says Connie Mack "failed to pay his child support."
title: 12 days late once

statement: Says that Rick Santorum "voted for the unions over FedEx."
title: He was against FedEx provision before he was for it

statement: "The national unemployment rate has been above 8 percent for a record 36 months."
title: Modern record, yes, but Great Depression still rules

statement: Says "half the Americans don't pay any income taxes."
title: No taxing this claim

statement: "The biggest contribution" behind a decrease in U.S. unemployment "was 1.2 million people leaving the workforce"
title: Bad use of data leads to wrong conclusion

statement: "Every time we put a ballot issue on, it costs a million dollars."
title: Two referendums top $1 million, but it's no rule of thumb

statement: About 800 people refused to get a drug screening because they are "out there on drugs."
title: Unsupported speculation

statement: "Since President Obama took full control of Washington … every single day, more than 1,500 of our jobs have been lost."
title: Depends when you start counting

statement: A Dallas proof-of-insurance ordinance resulted in area tow lots mostly filling with the cars of illegal residents.
title: Nobody could know

statement: Claims Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said "she prefers the South African Constitution over the United States Constitution."
title: That's not what she said

statement: "(President Barack Obama) said unemployment was never gonna go over 8 percent if we passed the stimulus plan."
title: An uncertain projection, not a promise

statement: "President Obama once said he wants everybody in America to go to college."
title: In most speeches, Obama's clear that's not what he wants

statement: "Amniocentesis, does, in fact, result more often than not in this country in abortion."
title: Most test results come back normal

statement: "The president gave the (auto) companies to the UAW."
title: No support for giveaway claim

statement: "Florida ranks 45th" in the nation for tuition.
title: We're No. 45! We're No. 45!

statement: After prenatal diagnosis, "90 percent of Down syndrome children in America are aborted."
title: Studies show 80 to 90 percent, but evidence of regional variation

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker is "openly" backing a move to abolish the state retirement system and convert it to a 401(k)-style plan that will reduce pensions "by at least a third" for current and retired public employees
title: Pension moves possible, but scary email goes way too far

statement: Says private-sector job growth in 2011 "places New Jersey in the top third among all of the states."
title: Not true in percentage terms

statement: "It’s going to be harder to vote in Virginia than it is now to buy a gun..."
title: Some truth in a "rhetorical slur"

statement: "Our small staff of 51 is still fewer than we had a decade ago, yet our caseload -- like that of other courts -- has grown."
title: No mistrial for this claim

statement: Says 21,000 Wisconsin residents got jobs in 2011, but "18,000 of them" were in other states.
title: Simple math = bad math

statement: "New Jersey has the second highest rate of institutionalization" of people with developmental disabilities "in America. Only Texas puts more of its citizens -- confines more of its citizens -- to institutions than New Jersey. "
title: Slight differences in rankings

statement: "There are more atheists in the country right now than Jews, Muslims, Hindus and Buddhists combined and doubled."
title: Defies belief

statement: One estimate says there may be "three times as much oil in the United States as there is in Saudi Arabia."
title: Not an apples-to-apples comparison

statement: "The majority of Americans are conservatives."
title: UPDATE: After reader feedback, we reconsider

statement: Says "in Oregon only 41 percent of adults have ever been tested" for HIV.
title: The number is a little old, but it's close.

statement: Without U.S. Senate action, Texas will have more federal judicial vacancies this year than any other state.
title: Two spots shy of No. 1

statement: Florida is "the largest dog-racing state in the country."
title: Dog-gone right!

statement: "Over 40 percent of children born in America are born out of wedlock."
title: Federal data says yes for 2009, the most recent year available

statement: Says "sixty-two percent of small businesses over the last five years went under because they couldn't pay their health care bills."
title: Citing the wrong statistic

statement: "You can’t put a gun rack in a [Chevrolet] Volt."
title: This claim is a lemon

statement: "When Marcy Kaptur brought home $42 million for new manufacturing jobs, Dennis Kucinich voted 'no'."
title: Claim ignores steadfast opposition to Iraq, Afghanistan wars

statement: "This president ... could have gotten crippling sanctions against Iran. He did not."
title: Wrong in a few ways

statement: "Today gasoline hit $6 a gallon in Florida."
title: Only if you're returning the rental car after your Disney vacation

statement: Says "80 percent of the health care dollars are spent by 20 percent of the population."
title: It's all about high-cost patients.

statement: "When I was born, less than 10 percent of the federal budget was entitlement spending. It's now 60 percent of the budget."
title: Wrong figure for 1958, better number for 2011

statement: "When I was born, defense spending was 60 percent of the budget. It's now 17 percent."
title: By the measure he uses, Santorum is pretty close

statement: Says the Tennessee Wildlife Resources Agency brought coyotes into the state "to try to keep the deer population down."
title: A real howler

statement: "Right now, 50 percent of Florida students leaving high school cannot read at grade level."
title: All that testing leads to dismal conclusions

statement: "The governor is trying to take credit for recent actions taken by these companies. The problem is that for all three companies, the decision to move or stay in New Jersey happened before Chris Christie became governor."
title: Credit where credit isn't due

statement: "As Virginia’s governor, Allen cut spending and waste with bipartisan support."
title: Overall spending went up, but some programs were cut

statement: Other states have considered or have sunset advisory commissions; the federal government has the ability, too.
title: Congress doesn't have one oversight commission

statement: Says in the last 20 years, the French have not "stood by" the United States on foreign policy.
title: They have -- time and again

statement: "I have a very conservative voting record."
title: Some conservative groups have dinged Mack for an occasional vote

statement: "For the first time since 1990, American manufacturers are creating new jobs."
title: Better to stick to the script

statement: After Arizona banned smoking in "all public places" in 2007, "admissions for acute myocardial infarction … stroke, asthma, [and] angina decreased following the implementation of the ban."
title: But Arizona's ban doesn't go quite so far.

statement: Says Mitt Romney supports a plan "to slowly and gradually raise the retirement age of Social Security."
title: Yes, but retirees and those near retirement would be unaffected

statement: "[W]hen adjusted for cost of living, Georgia ranks first nationally in teacher salary and benefits."
title: Claim tough to say either way

statement: Says Republican U.S. Senate candidate Ted Cruz "opposes the DREAM Act, which is supported by 85% of Latinos."
title: Latino-focused polls back party's claim

statement: Mitt Romney "supervised a company guilty of massive Medicare fraud."
title: Super PAC's super claim needs some editing

statement: Says he banned texting while driving in Austin.
title: Not doable solo

statement: The cost of a gas tank fill-up has risen $30 since Barack Obama became president.
title: Presidents don't control gas prices

statement: Says the federal government could save $175,587 by eliminating a study of the "connection between cocaine and risky sex habits of the Japanese quail."
title: Yes, but humans are study's purpose

statement: Says "67 percent of marriages now wind up in divorce."
title: Not that high and going down

statement: Says he was "exonerated in every single case" in 1990s ethics violations charges.
title: Um, remember that reprimand?

statement: "'Wrong precinct' rules exacerbate our provisional ballot problems (and) HB 194 does nothing to solve the wrong-precinct problem."
title: She's not wrong

statement: Says Texas legislators in 2011 increased state spending on education.
title: Billions less to schools, overall

statement: "They're saying that 40 percent of the traffic that goes over [the Sakonnet River Bridge is from] out of state."
title: Stat not quite up to speed

statement: "Shelby County donated – I’m sorry, gave – 44 schools to the city of Memphis."
title: Ignores other considerations

statement: Says Scott Walker enacted "the biggest cuts to education in our state’s history."
title: The few others pale in comparison

statement: "The Republicans just voted last year to end Medicare."
title: Debunked yet again

statement: "If you look at states that are right to work, they constantly do not have budget deficits and they have very good business climates."
title: Not necessarily causing economic benefits

statement: Says "there are homes for sale on and around (Oswego Lake) right now for under $150,000 that anyone is welcome to buy."
title: Maybe a condo -- but not on the lake.

statement: Says critics called the original GI Bill "welfare."
title: Not w-eally

statement: Says in his years as a Texas legislator, "we passed three pay increases for teachers and provided them with health insurance."
title: Most already had some insurance

statement: "Fewer than 10 percent of those in the House are what anyone would classify as wealthy."
title: More like 31-42 percent

statement: "We are poised to get rid of over 1,000 more regulations in 2012."
title: A wrath for rulemaking

statement: A 10-year state program that created 202 jobs at a cost of $247,000 per job was approved by former Gov. Jim Doyle.
title: Doyle didn't sign it, but Walker voted for it

statement: Says unemployment would be at 10 percent if people who have quit looking for work were included in federal labor force calculations.
title: Assumes all those not factored in still would want jobs

statement: Says Mitt Romney supports cap and trade.
title: Evidence says he doesn't

statement: "Romney adviser admits Romneycare was blueprint for Obamacare."
title: Add "former" before "Romney adviser," and it would have gotten a True

statement: "Obamacare (hit) Americans with over $500 billion in new taxes."
title: Counts more than taxes, ignores subsidies

statement: Florida "unemployment has dropped more than 2 percentage points, down from 12 percent to 9.9 percent, the second-largest drop in the nation."
title: Still high, but it has dropped

statement: Says a 1915 referendum on women’s right to vote "went down in New Jersey. And it took the Legislature to pass it."
title: Only Ocean County approved

statement: "Obamacare ... will kill jobs across America."
title: No more true now than when we rated it a year ago

statement: Says the Congressional Budget Office said "unemployment could top 9 percent in 2013"
title: Figure cited not a forecast

statement: You may have driven the length of a football field in the five seconds it takes to check a text.
title: If you drive 55

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Tammy Baldwin, a candidate for Senate, supports raising taxes "by $858 billion."
title: Not that much

statement: "Many of the top officials at the Port Authority earn more money than the governors of the states that have jurisdiction over them."
title: A bigger pay day for most

statement: Newt Gingrich "co-sponsored a bill with Nancy Pelosi that would have given $60 million a year to a U.N. program supporting China’s brutal one-child policy."
title: Newt & Nancy together again?

statement: Says abortion is "the most common surgery in our country."
title: Several procedures, including Caesarean, are more prevelant

statement: "The U.S. Census believes that by 2030 the majority of Americans will use Spanish as their first language."
title: We'll sing it gleefully: This claim was out of tune

statement: Says a U.S. Supreme Court justice suggested that some U.S. cases will be decided based on South African law.
title: Distorting for a laugh?

statement: "We aren't the only state cutting back on public television."
title: Cue the fundraising!

statement: Says "if we raise the number of third-graders who read at a third-grade level, we affect everything, from graduation rates to incarceration rates."
title: He's right; there's a connection

statement: Says Barack Obama "endorsed a total ban on the manufacture, sale and possession of all handguns."
title: Not much ammo for this claim

statement: "You can't pass a budget in the Senate of the United States without 60 votes."
title: It's happened with as few as 48 votes

statement: Maryland is "creating jobs at 2 ½ times the rate that Virginia is."
title: Most stats put the states neck and neck

statement: Says Milwaukee blacks have 55 percent male unemployment, 60 percent truancy, a 50 percent graduation rate, the "worst" reading scores and "lead" in infant mortality.
title: A split decision

statement: "Senator Menendez said he would spend our money wisely. But our annual national deficit climbed from $250 billion a year to $1.6 trillion on his watch."
title: Blame game ignores recession

statement: "You're supposed to throw away your shoes" if mercury from a broken CFL light bulb gets on them.
title: A wet wipe will suffice

statement: "[A]t his current rate, President Obama will have added more debt to the United State of America by the end of his first term than each of the previous 43 presidents -- combined!"
title: Debt claim gets cut in half

statement: As Dane County executive, Kathleen Falk raised property taxes by "millions of dollars every year" and approved the second highest increase in the state in 2010.
title: True as far as it goes

statement: "Here's something that people never talk about with coach Schiano: Rutgers had the best graduation rate of any Division I football program in America."
title: Best in conference, not in league

statement: Says a federal judge in San Antonio "issued a ruling that … not only could the students not pray at their graduation, if they used the word ‘benediction,’ the word ‘invocation,’ the word ‘God,’ asked the audience to stand or asked for a moment of silence, he would put the superintendent in jail."
title: Superintendent to hoosegow? Not certain

statement: The polls "show over half of Americans identify themselves as being pro-life."
title: True in one 2009 poll, not since

statement: Oregon House Republicans’ jobs plan could generate more than 50,000 jobs over five years.
title: No arguing with LRO here

statement: "Preventive care … saves money, for families, for businesses, for government, for everybody."
title: Wrong in 2009, and wrong today

statement: Says he signed legislation leading to 12 Texas abortion clinics being closed.
title: Clinics didn't provide abortions

statement: Says that as Wisconsin governor he "never raised taxes."
title: Cut many, but raised some, too

statement: Says "as of November, we were ranked 45th in the nation in terms of job creation, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics."
title: Not as bad as it seems

statement: "The commercial property tax [in Providence] is second highest in the country behind Detroit."
title: A taxing burden.

statement: "Statistics bear out that any time a country, a state, makes more restrictive abortion laws ... fatalities go up and abortions actually increase."
title: Cause-and-effect impact not established

statement: "Twenty-five or 24 million people" are "out of work or stopped looking for work."
title: Needs more revision

statement: David Dewhurst has a "record of promoting an income tax."
title: One remark shortly reconsidered

statement: "This year’s redistricting has been the most open, interactive and transparent redistricting process in Tennessee history."
title: Big claim, scant evidence

statement: "Nationwide tuition at public universities is up almost 300 percent ... in the last 20 years."
title: Doesn't account for inflation

statement: Says Gov. Bob McDonnell's budget would cut pre-kindergarten programs.
title: Pre-K spending would go up

statement: "91 percent of Latinos support the DREAM Act, which allows undocumented youth to attend college," but Marco Rubio opposes it.
title: Numbers make the case

statement: "This year President Obama canceled the 21st annual National Day of Prayer ceremony at the White House under the ruse of ‘not wanting to offend anyone.' BUT … on September 25, 2009 from 4 AM until 7 PM, a National Day of Prayer FOR THE MUSLIM RELIGION was HELD on Capitol Hill, Beside the White House."
title: Little prayer of accuracy

statement: A bill delaying the start of classes until Labor Day would permit school districts "to shave 5 full weeks off the school year."
title: Students could be sprung in spring

statement: The state constitution "clearly says there’s not to be a state income tax in Tennessee."
title: Clearly unclear

statement: President Obama told people "to skip coming here (Las Vegas) for conventions and meetings."
title: Baffling exaggeration

statement: "President Obama is shrinking our military."
title: Bipartisan budget bill tied Obama's hands

statement: "Three years ago, a newly elected President Obama told America that if Congress approved his plan to borrow nearly a trillion dollars, he would hold unemployment below 8 percent."
title: Projection, not a promise

statement: "If you take into account all the people who are struggling for work, or have just stopped looking, the real unemployment rate is over 15 percent."
title: Not the usual measure, but he frames it right

statement: Says Chris Christie "inherited the highest taxes in America and the worst unemployment in the region."
title: Debate over defining tax burden

statement: Says President Barack Obama "has an Environmental Protection Agency proposal that would raise the price of gasoline by 25 cents a gallon."
title: According to a now-outdated study

statement: "Private prisons do not chase escaped inmates past the perimeter like the public prisons do, which means more escaped prisoners in our communities."
title: Do private prisons walk the (property) line?

statement: Newt Gingrich "was fined $300,000 for ethics violations."
title: UPDATED: A fine by any other name....

statement: Public education has been permanently cut "by $1.6 billion through changes in the Standards of Quality funding formula."
title: Number slightly off

statement: In the 2011 legislative session, DEQ's budget was cut 18.5 percent — a disproportionate cut compared to other natural resource agencies.
title: But it's fair to say Natural Resources has been hit hard

statement: Says New Jersey is "down nearly 200,000 jobs from its pre-recession peak" and with Gov. Chris Christie "New Jersey has trailed the rest of America when it comes to unemployment" for 12 consecutive months.
title: Tide is starting to turn

statement: "Ohio has one of the highest provisional ballot rates in the country, and many of them go uncounted each election."
title: Only three states rejected more in 2010

statement: "If you sell your house after 2012 you will pay a 3.8 percent sales tax on it."
title: Another lie that won't die

statement: "No candidate has run more negative ads in American history than Barack Obama did in 2008, especially in the general.’’
title: Because Obama ran the most ads, period

statement: "Most women, including 98 percent of Catholic women, have used contraception."
title: 98 percent of women who've had sex

statement: "Since ObamaCare and the stimulus passed, the unemployment rate in the U.S. has increased."
title: Same rate as when stimulus was signed, and down since health care law passed

statement: "Illegal counterfeiting and piracy costs the U.S. economy $100 billion... every year."
title: Too slippery to pin down?

statement: The Georgia Secretary of State's Office and the Georgia State Elections Board investigate and penalize hundreds of people guilty of election fraud.
title: No voter fraud with this claim.

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker "made more than $70 million in cuts to job training programs through (Wisconsin’s) technical colleges."
title: Only part of the equation

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie’s proposal to reduce state income taxes "would be the second tax cut for the rich by the governor in two years."
title: A veto, but not exactly a tax cut

statement: Says "we brought crime rate down by 30 percent" when he was mayor of Dallas.
title: Leppert presided, wasn’t alone

statement: In just a few decades, Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, other mandatory spending programs, and paying interest due on the debt will eclipse our entire budget.
title: When it comes to federal spending, Schrader’s meaning eclipses his choice of words.

statement: Says Mitt Romney’s campaign "has already spent more on negative ads than John McCain did during his entire presidential run."
title: 2012 more than 2008 already? Nope.

statement: Says she "wiped out" the state Agriculture Department’s inspections of eggs at retail sites like grocery stores.
title: Egg checks reduced but not ended

statement: "The national debt is equal to $48,700 for every American or $128,300 for every U.S. household. It is now equivalent to the size of our entire economy."
title: The numbers add up

statement: "United States of America is twenty-sixth in school performance in the world."
title: Still room for error

statement: "We've seen more anti-women's choice bills introduced in the first half of this session than we've seen in the last three General Assemblies."
title: 2011 total tops previous two-year sessions

statement: "One out of every three automobile fatalities can be attributed to alcohol."
title: Truth touchdown!

statement: "We got [the Quonset Business Park] for free and we’re getting zero dollars out of it into the state coffers … other than the fact that it produces the jobs."
title: What about tax revenue?

statement: AIDS was transmitted to humans because "one guy" had sex with "a monkey" and then started "having sex with men."
title: Completely ridiculous

statement: Congressman Scott DesJarlais "is spending his one year anniversary on vacation -- only working 6 days in all of January."
title: You don't have to be in Washington to get work done

statement: Says U.S. Senate Democrats "have gone without any budget at all" for more than 1,000 days.
title: Number mostly adds up, but political calculations also at work

statement: Says Pennsylvania charges a top income tax rate of 3 percent and Delaware "has no state income tax at all."
title: Livin' ain't that easy in Delaware

statement: "Gov. Romney cut off kosher meals for Jewish senior citizens who were on Medicaid to save $5 a day."
title: Nursing home residents kept kosher

statement: "Today, for the first time in fifteen years, Master Lock’s unionized plant in Milwaukee is running at full capacity."
title: Fewer workers, more efficient

statement: "Unemployment has fallen from 10 percent during the president’s first year in office to 8.5 percent today."
title: Yes, but who deserves the credit?

statement: "A cashier earning $20,000 per year pays the same (Virginia) income tax rate as a hedge fund manager earning $20 million per year."
title: A faulty deduction

statement: Since President Barack Obama took office, "2 million more Americans are out of work."
title: Depends on the data you choose

statement: In 1992, Mitt Romney "gave money to Democrats for Congress."
title: Many GOPers, and three Dems

statement: "The Obama administration ... would impose on every Catholic institution, every Jewish institution, every Protestant institution the Obamacare standard of what you have to buy as insurance."
title: Rule he's speaking of has religious exemption

statement: Says the U.S. federal income tax rate was 0 percent until 1913.
title: Don't forget the Civil War period

statement: Savannah is home to "the fastest-growing port in the nation."
title: A well-anchored claim

statement: "Federal, state and local governments have subsidized the production of the Volt to the tune of estimates between $50,000 and $250,000 per vehicle sold."
title: Average cost to keep dropping with each car sold

statement: "Sheldon Whitehouse's failure of leadership, the adding of almost $8 trillion in debt in his first full term, is shameful..."
title: $8 trillion is a fair projection, but he's just one vote

statement: In July 1996, Mitt Romney helped locate the missing teenage daughter of a partner at Bain Capital.
title: The story checks out

statement: Students today "take more years to get through" college.
title: Actually, four-year completion rates have risen steadily in recent years

statement: A proposed mine in Wisconsin is "about two-thirds the size of Lake Winnebago."
title: Acreage much less

statement: Says with "Gov. Chris Christie and bipartisan reformers" New Jersey had "the most job growth in 11 years."
title: True for private-sector jobs

statement: Siemens has been unable to fill approximately 200 skilled trade positions in metro Atlanta.
title: Almost none are "skilled trade" jobs

statement: "We wiped out a $3.6 billion deficit without raising taxes."
title: Yes and no.

statement: Says the New York Giants "train in New Jersey, they play in New Jersey and most of their players live in New Jersey."
title: Big Blue calls Garden State home

statement: "Chesterfield has eliminated more positions from its general government operations than the Commonwealth has from the entire state government since (fiscal) 2009."
title: Who would have guessed?

statement: "Studies show that if we opened one reserve in Alaska now, in five years, gas prices could be at $2 a gallon."
title: Many factors impact gas prices

statement: "Congressman Phil Roe hands out $1.3M government check" from a federal program that "he voted against."
title: Opposed entirety of 2009 stimulus, not every single part

statement: "Martin Luther King was a Republican."
title: Not tied to any party

statement: "In 2006, I went out and authored a letter with 24 other senators asking for major reform of Freddie and Fannie, warning of a meltdown and a bubble in the housing market."
title: Warning wasn't about a bubble

statement: "This president went before the United Nations and castigated Israel for building settlements. He said nothing about thousands of rockets being rained in on Israel from the Gaza Strip."
title: Obama did mention Israeli fear about rockets

statement: "I've never voted for a Democrat when there was a Republican on the ballot."
title: He chose an all-Democratic ballot instead of a GOP ballot in '92 Mass. primary

statement: "Eric Holder is supportive of the NAACP's efforts to get the United Nations involved in our elections."
title: Ka-blue-y

statement: "Romneycare … is a top-down, government-run health care system."
title: Top down, maybe. Not government run.

statement: "We balanced the budget with the 1997 Balanced Budget Act, and ultimately had four consecutive balanced budgets."
title: Much better phrased than previous versions

statement: "The U.S. gun homicide rate is 20 times the combined rate of other western nations."
title: Numbers are outdated, but close

statement: "Our jobless rate, our unemployment rate, is the lowest of all of the big cities in New Jersey."
title: Jersey City beats Elizabeth

statement: "We have cut crime across every single zone in the city of Atlanta by between 10 percent and 16 percent, depending on the zone."
title: Reed zones out on numbers

statement: Says Ohio has 77 job training programs spread across 13 state agencies.
title: But do they get the job done?

statement: "Romneycare sent costs spiraling out of control" in Massachusetts, "hiking premiums, squeezing household budgets."
title: Health care costs went up nationwide

statement: Republican-leaning states get more in federal dollars than they pay in taxes.
title: Data is generally correct, though dated

statement: Nevada is No. 1 in unemployment, violent crime, car theft, divorce, robberies and foreclosures.
title: On some measures Florida isn't so hot either

statement: Says Steve Jobs was responsible for creating more jobs than the stimulus bill.
title: The stimulus was almost certainly bigger

statement: "Before this day is out, 18 more veterans will have taken their own lives.  That is the daily average, it is intolerable, and it has to stop."
title: Sad statistic

statement: Gov. McDonnell's proposed budget "is cutting" public education.
title: School funding goes up; so does teachers' pension cost

statement: "For the first time in 13 years, our dependence on foreign oil is below 50 percent."
title: Decline in dependence due to several factors

statement: The InterLink at T.F. Green Airport is the closest air-rail link in the country.
title: Derailed!

statement: Says Mitt Romney "was one of the first national Republican leaders to endorse" Marco Rubio.
title: Once it was obvious Rubio would win

statement: Says Newt Gingrich said "Spanish is the language of the ghetto."
title: Gingrich admitted he could have used different words

statement: The United States is no longer "top nation in the globe on infrastructure," having fallen to 15th.
title: U.S. sliding, by many measures

statement: "Nearly half of all persons under 30 did not go to work today."
title: Because many of them were in school

statement: "(Newt Gingrich) voted in favor of establishing the Department of Education, and yet he gets in a debate and says we should get rid of the Department of Education and send all the education issues back to the states."
title: Voted to create it, didn't recently want to get rid of it

statement: "In the last 22 months, businesses have created more than 3 million jobs. Last year, they created the most jobs since 2005."
title: UPDATED: Right on private-sector job stats, but who gets credit?

statement: Says Wisconsin Democrats during the previous administration adopted "double-digit tax increases."
title: Not widespread, but a variety of hikes that size

statement: "Right now in Georgia, nearly one in three leaving our prisons are re-convicted within three years."
title: Deal claim on the mark

statement: Sherrod Brown "has voted with Barack Obama 95 percent of the time."
title: You'll hear this a lot in 2012

statement: "(After the auto bailout) General Motors is back on top as the world’s No. 1 automaker."
title: Top spot partly GM's luck — and it's contested

statement: "Right now, American oil production is the highest that it’s been in eight years."
title: An accurate statistic, though administration was only one factor of many

statement: Says he eliminated an EPA rule that treated spilled milk like it was oil.
title: Don't cry over it

statement: Rob Cornilles supports privatizing Medicare.
title: Supporting a plan that some consider a move toward privatization is not a call for privatization.

statement: A typical married couple "will contribute $119,000" into Medicare but will "receive $357,000 in Medicare benefits over their lifetimes."
title: That disparity is real

statement: "When I was fighting against cap and trade, the speaker was sitting down with Nancy Pelosi on a sofa encouraging it."
title: A tale of two flips

statement: "The median income in this country has declined 10 percent in the last four years."
title: Using outdated statistics; it's ticked up since then

statement: There are 86 languages spoken at Miami Dade College.
title: Muchos idiomas!

statement: Florida's economy "became a bad economy ... because of a huge spike in oil prices in the summer of 2008."
title: You might remember that housing bubble

statement: "Speaker Gingrich for 20 years supported a federal individual mandate" for health insurance.
title: Several times

statement: Says Texas does not regulate the appearance of some kinds of imitation firearms sold in Texas.
title: But: Airsoft guns federally regulated

statement: "Tennessee’s grocery tax is one of the highest in the nation."
title: An affirmative on this price check

statement: "[N]early one in three primary care doctors are forced to limit the number of Medicare patients they see."
title: Medicare is ailing and this congressman has the diagnosis

statement: "We never had an earthquake in Youngstown until John Kasich was elected Governor,"
title: Quake link to Kasich more than shaky

statement: Says Newt Gingrich’s contract was with "the lobbyists at Freddie Mac."
title: Lobbyists direct "strategic advice"

statement: "We have 25 million Americans out of work."
title: A broader number than the official unemployment level

statement: Newt Gingrich says electric co-ops and credit unions are "government-sponsored enterprises" like Freddie Mac.
title: Freddie's a GSE, credit union's not

statement: "When I was speaker, we had four consecutive balanced budgets."
title: Two during his tenure, two after he was gone

statement: "While Romney was a director of the Damon Corporation, the company was defrauding Medicare of millions."
title: Not a great chapter in the Bain story

statement: Rob Cornilles has been endorsed by 20 local mayors, including Independent, Democratic and Republican.
title: He does NOT have a bonafide Independent on his side

statement: "And by the way, when I was governor, I did make the payment into the pension fund."
title: A payment, not ‘the payment’

statement: Says the D.C. city council passed a law banning lethal rat trapping.
title: No reprieve for common rats

statement: "Eleven states have enacted these pay-to-play reforms."
title: Eight, not 11 is more like it

statement: "More than one in five of veterans aged 20 to 24 can’t find a job to support their family or to ease the transition to civilian life."
title: Rate is high for all young men

statement: "Martin Luther King Jr. was a Republican."
title: False no matter how racist were Jim Crow southern Dems

statement: Says that according to a study, under Obama’s health care initiative, "nearly 90 percent of people" in Wisconsin with health insurance "will have their costs go up by more than 30 percent."
title: Nowhere near 90 percent

statement: "Under this tax cut, middle-class families don't save enough for a week's worth of groceries, while millionaires save enough to go on an exotic vacation."
title: Pay more, save more

statement: Says most states, but not Texas, permit jurors to ask questions of witnesses in trials.
title: Judge's call in Texas civil trials

statement: Rep. David Cicilline is responsible for the federal loan guarantee to Solyndra, the failed solar company
title: Can’t be responsible if you’re not in office

statement: Says 282 Texas school districts have requested emergency waivers to increase elementary school class sizes because of "unprecedented fiscal challenges."
title: Other reasons for waivers at play

statement: Suzanne Bonamici supports a plan that will cut choice for Medicare Advantage seniors.
title: Maybe it will, maybe it won't, one thing's for sure, this is a scare tactic

statement: "I didn't inherit money from my parents."
title: He got inheritance, but gave it away

statement: Rick Santorum says Rick Perry requested 1,200 earmarks as governor of Texas.
title: Number toss

statement: President Obama has "said he is going to cut veterans' benefits."
title: Cuts are not to VA budget

statement: Says Barack Obama "began his presidency going on a worldwide apology tour."
title: Kindling on an old fire

statement: Says Mitt Romney "put Planned Parenthood on a state medical board but failed to put a pro-life group on the same board."
title: Board has no say in abortion

statement: "Many types of fish and shellfish from waters across the state are labeled unsafe to eat."
title: Nothing fishy about claim

statement: Says proposal to boost teacher pension fund "puts no mandate on local government."
title: If it sounds like a duck...

statement: The planned expansion of Savannah’s port is a "jobs creating project."
title: It could be, but research is thin

statement: "One generation ago we led the world in college graduation. We're 16th today."
title: Other nations advancing in studies

statement: "Romney signed government-mandated health care with taxpayer-funded abortions."
title: It wasn't in the law

statement: Says an Obama administration policy prohibits people who work with at-risk youth from promoting marriage as a way to avoid poverty.
title: Mum on marriage?

statement: Says PolitiFact has said he "kept a campaign promise to toughen ethics rules."
title: He kept one promise. Others have lagged

statement: "The top 10 most well-paid CEOs in America received a combined $770 million in 2010, while the average American worker’s wage rose just 2 percent."
title: Big bucks for corporate big shots

statement: "[Mitt] Romney and [Brendan] Doherty certainly have a lot in common, like flip-flopping on abortion -- in Doherty's case, in a little over a week."
title: Consistently "pro-life." But what about Roe vs. Wade?

statement: PolitiFact Oregon gave Rob Cornilles a Pants on Fire for a claim about taxes and fees.
title: Do not take PolitiFact Oregon's name in campaign vain

statement: "In campaigns in the past with Sen. McCain and President George W. Bush and others, they have tended to release tax records in April."
title: Except when they don't

statement: The U.S. military is at risk of losing its "military superiority" because "our Navy is smaller than it's been since 1917. Our Air Force is smaller and older than any time since 1947."
title: Our horse cavalry ain't what it used to be, either

statement: Says she got unions to agree to "about $10 million in reduction" of salaries and health benefits while serving as Dane County executive in Wisconsin.
title: The numbers check out

statement: "When [Mitt Romney] was the governor of Massachusetts, he performed 100 — and I’m not sure this number is right, but my mind says it’s about 180 gay marriages."
title: No wedded bliss for this claim

statement: "[The] ACLU and atheists in Denver are demanding the NFL stop [Tim Tebow] from praying on the sidelines."
title: Waaaay out of bounds

statement: Says Rick Santorum "voted to let convicted felons vote."
title: Ad makers, watch your visuals

statement: U.S. Rep. Stephen Fincher is "the only working farmer currently serving in the House."
title: Others just as comfortable with manure on their boots

statement: Says "we’ve accomplished balancing two budgets without raising taxes. We’ve now created 60,000 new private-sector jobs. We’ve made government smaller."
title: Recycled, and still not completely true

statement: "In 2011, (Debbie) Wasserman Schultz missed 62 congressional votes — one of the worst records of any member of Congress."
title: 45th is "one of the worst"?

statement: "More people have been put on food stamps by Barack Obama than any president in American history."
title: Record numbers, but wrong to focus blame on Obama

statement: "Republicans are attempting to remove Barack Obama from Georgia’s Presidential Ballot in 2012."
title: Not the party, just the party faithful

statement: "More Americans have lost their jobs under Barack Obama than any president in modern history."
title: It depends on when you start counting

statement: Says over the last two years, New Jersey Schools Development Authority employees "have not started or completed one single school project, and I’m not talking about major school renovation. I’m talking about replacing boilers, roofs."
title: Not much, but not nothing

statement: Freshman Rep. Bob Gibbs "is spending his one year anniversary on vacation — only working 6 days in all of January."
title: Discounts any time spent helping constituents, visiting district

statement: Gov. Bob McDonnell’s budget plan takes "money out of our classrooms to pave roads."
title: A tiny loss of school funding

statement: "Mayor Barrett saved Milwaukee $25 million, thanks to Gov. Walker’s reforms."
title: You're welcome, Mr. Mayor

statement: "In 1958, there were 16 states in this country that prohibited -- prohibited -- an African-American and a Caucasian from being married."
title: Two dozen states in 1958

statement: "In Connecticut and New York, students at Achievement First schools consistently outperform city and statewide averages."
title: True for city averages, not so much for state

statement: "My opponent on day one of this campaign attacked me on Medicare and Medicare Advantage and that claim was found to be False."
title: Democrats aren't angels either

statement: Rob Cornilles has disputed for two years a news story that said he said he would cut Social Security and Medicare programs before trimming the U.S. defense budget.
title: We find no evidence of a request for a correction

statement: "I also voted 98 percent of the time with Republicans in the Oregon Legislature."
title: Can't find one, much less plural Republicans

statement: The proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline is a bipartisan proposal.
title: If Democrats are split, is this qua-partisan?

statement: Suzanne Bonamici was the only no vote on a 2009 bill cracking down on drunk drivers.
title: Yes, on this bill

statement: Federal law prohibits the growing of industrial hemp in the United States.
title: No hemp growing for you!

statement: Says up to a quarter of African Americans don’t have government photo ID.
title: Not a lot of data

statement: Says Mitt Romney "runs away from Ronald Reagan."
title: Not anytime recently

statement: Mitt Romney is worth "at least a quarter billion dollars" and the bulk of his wealth "remains in blind trusts and overseas bank accounts."
title: Overseas bank investments aren't overseas bank accounts

statement: "The Republicans have never done anything really to balance the budget."
title: Don't forget about the first President Bush

statement: New energy standards will take away "our freedom of choice and selection in the light bulbs we have in our homes."
title: A low-wattage claim

statement: Says a drug test can be performed for "just $4 or $5."
title: Individual tests can be cheap

statement: The education tax burden for Shelby County -- and Tennessee -- is "one of the lowest in the country."
title: State near bottom; county fares better but pays smaller share

statement: Says Rick Perry cut taxes.
title: Some up, some down

statement: Says Romney and Bain Capital drove KB Toys into bankruptcy by loading it up with debt.
title: Romney didn't lead Bain at time of troubled purchase

statement: Tampa is "the strip club capital of the world."
title: We say it and laugh, but evidence is lacking

statement: Mitt Romney’s and Bain Capital’s profits from KB Toys, which later went out of business, were "described by the Boston Herald as ‘disgusting.’"
title: Not the paper's view; a news story quoted a laid-off worker saying it

statement: Mitt Romney is "tearing down his 3,000-square-foot house to build an 11,000-square-foot house."
title: It won't be happening immediately

statement: "One year today since #GOP took control of the House" and "no new jobs."
title: Wrong in 140 characters or less

statement: "In 1790, the first Congress, which was packed with framers, required all ship owners to provide medical insurance for seamen; in 1798, Congress also required seamen to buy hospital insurance for themselves. In 1792, Congress enacted a law mandating that all able-bodied citizens obtain a firearm."
title: And our Founding Father Presidents approved

statement: Says Newt Gingrich "co-sponsored a bill with Nancy Pelosi that would have given $60 million a year to a U.N. program supporting China’s brutal one-child policy."
title: Distortion after distortion

statement: Mitt Romney has 15 homes.
title: Three in the U.S., one in Canada

statement: "Opinion polls show that the majority of Americans, and the majority of New Jerseyans, favor marriage equality for same sex couples."
title: Majority rules

statement: "Five members of [the Common Cause Georgia] board accepted maximum campaign contributions."
title: Hizzoner's verbal blast needs some more context

statement: "More than a quarter of mortgage borrowers are underwater, and 11 percent of all homes are vacant."
title: Data issues hinder this claim

statement: "Mitt Romney, Rick Perry, and Newt Gingrich all say they would cut foreign aid to Israel — and every other country — to zero."
title: None of them said they wanted zero aid for Israel

statement: Rob Cornilles is a Tea Party candidate.
title: Doesn't sound like one, isn't claimed by Oregon Tea Party

statement: Says that when Republicans held Congress and the presidency, they "doubled the size of the (U.S.) Department of Education."
title: Not so simple

statement: "Since the passage of Obama's stimulus package, over 1 million additional jobs were lost and nearly 25 million Americans are out of work, are stuck in part-time work, or have given up looking."
title: Numbers are right but Obama and stimulus aren't to blame

statement: "What’s clear is (Romney) likes firing people."
title: Romney likes being able to fire service providers, not employees

statement: "President Obama has raised taxes 19 times."
title: At least 13, many narrowly targeted

statement: Barack Obama’s recess appointment of Richard Cordray "is precisely what then-Sen. Obama claimed would be ‘the wrong thing to do.’"
title: Precisely what he said if you ignore some of his words

statement: Says the state tax burden per citizen in New York is twice as high as in Florida.
title: Are low taxes everything?

statement: "In the past year, Floridians, not government, created almost 135,000 new private sector jobs. We netted more than 120,000 total jobs in the first 11 months of 2011; the third most of any state in the nation."
title: No. 3, but we're a large state

statement: "She’s voted for 60 tax increases, hurting the middle class and small businesses."
title: She has voted for many taxes, just not 60

statement: "My recommended budget includes $1 billion in new state funding for education."
title: Doesn't make up for last year's cuts

statement: "At my first ‘Let’s Get to Work Day’ … we sold out;" more than 240 dozen doughnuts by 8:30 a.m.
title: That's a lot of sugar

statement: Says in Newark "we’re paying 80 percent of the school budget from local property taxes."
title: More like 11 percent

statement: When Georgia tightened its voter identification laws, the state sent a van and photographer to the homes of people who needed photo IDs and made them for free.
title: GLOW bus made no house calls

statement: Says that after she declared her candidacy for Congress, "the redistricting process was manipulated to allow incumbent politicians to guarantee their re-election."
title: Initial boundaries for her district unchanged in later-updated map

statement: "[If] you apply for a job, the chances are 1 in 7 that you are going to be denied that job unfairly if everybody is forced to use E-Verify."
title: Claim is De-Verified

statement: "You can hire lots of bureaucrats.  That’s what the president’s done.  He’s added 135,000 people to the government workforce."
title: Are border patrol agents bureaucrats?

statement: As a result of welfare reform, "poverty levels went down to the lowest level ever for ... African-American children."
title: Economy was a big factor too

statement: "We haven't had any legislation which took away one gun in the past 20 years from anybody in this country--not one."
title: Hold your fire

statement: Says federal spending has increased 21 percent over the past three years.
title: Spike in increases hasn't persisted

statement: "Ballistic tests have confirmed that the death of at least one U.S. Border Patrol agent was caused by" weapons that were part of a federal arms trafficking operation.
title: Guns were there, but ballistics report inconclusive

statement: Says President Barack Obama "is a socialist."
title: Ridiculous distortion

statement: The EPA was asked about an environmental citation for the city landfill in Nashua, N.H. but "didn’t know" why it was cited.
title: Listed, not cited, but not clear why

statement: Says President Barack Obama has opened up no new trade relationships with other nations.
title: That omits deals with South Korea, Colombia, and Panama

statement: Paul Ryan’s Medicare plan provides "pretty much" the same coverage that members of Congress receive.
title: Substantial differences between plans

statement: Says the Simpson-Bowles deficit reduction proposal went from President Barack Obama's desk to "the garbage can."
title: Hard to copy ideas you've trashed

statement: "We're only inches away from no longer being a free economy."
title: Pants on Fire once, Pants on Fire twice ...

statement: "I delivered a flat tax for my state. I took my state to No. 1 in job creation. With all due respect to what Rick Perry has said about Texas, we did a little bit better."
title: He enacted a flatter tax, but Utah wasn't No. 1 in job creation by the standard measurement

statement: Eliminating "Obamacare" ... "saves $95 billion a year."
title: Repeal would ultimately increase deficit

statement: Says area near proposed northern Wisconsin iron ore mine is "15 hours away" from where public hearing on mining was held.
title: Only if you take the (very) long way

statement: "Bob Menendez just voted to increase the government's debt ceiling to $1.9 TRILLION! In his 19 years in Congress, Menendez has helped overspend America over $15 TRILLION into debt."
title: Writing in CAPS still don’t make it right

statement: "[Renewable energy] projects . . . get us off foreign oil and away, step by step, from these foreign entanglements that we have to get into to defend our oil supply."
title: Oil rarely used to generate power.

statement: "Oregon’s per capita income is 9 percent below the national average and getting worse. This is a state that’s actually getting poorer."
title: Number's right, meaning's relative

statement: Says taking millionaires off food stamps and unemployment would save $20 million.
title: Unemployment: $20 million. Food stamps: $0.

statement: "Our income, our GDP per capita, is almost 50 percent higher than (it is for) the average European."
title: He's right, but uses what may not be the best measurement

statement: Says he "helped save" the Olympic games.
title: He was key in fixing mess in Salt Lake

statement: Says he’s proposed "the largest employer contribution to the Virginia Retirement System in history."
title: A record setter, indeed

statement: President Barack Obama "put in place historic fuel efficiency standards for cars and trucks to lower costs at the pump and reduce dependence on foreign oil."
title: Some fuel for thought

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker eliminated "cancer screenings for uninsured women" and offered "no alternatives."
title: Contract ended, screenings didn’t

statement: "We are now eighth in the nation in job creation . . . we are No. 1 in the Midwest."
title: Biggest states top new jobs list

statement: Congress gave an unelected board "the power to deny care to seniors."
title: Upon examination, Price claim needs more detail

statement: "I think with the exception of the last year or maybe the last two years, we were at 100 percent" when it came to contributing to the Providence pension fund.
title: Close but no cigar

statement: Says he lived up to a 2008 promise when he "closed corporate tax loopholes that were sending profits overseas."
title: He did sign a bill, but it was fairly limited

statement: Says the National Labor Relations Board told Boeing that it couldn’t build a factory in South Carolina because South Carolina is a right-to-work state.
title: Nothing to do with right-to-work state

statement: Says Milwaukee County buses are no less safe now than a year or two ago.
title: A deeper look suggests otherwise

statement: Says "kids who start in the ninth grade in the city of Newark this past September, 23 percent of them will graduate in four years."
title: Wrong twice before. Still wrong now.

statement: Says Rep. Jim Renacci was "trying to leave town for the holidays without extending your payroll tax cut."
title: Robocall attack lacks facts

statement: Says a new national poll shows "the majority of the American people believe we should have a gold standard" for U.S. currency.
title: If by national, you mean GOP voters in three states

statement: Rick Santorum "reformed welfare."
title: Not all by himself

statement: "We don't take a dime from D.C. lobbyists or special-interest PACs -- never have and never will."
title: A lot depends on definition of "lobbyist"

statement: Wisconsin’s monthly job reports have a "margin of error" of 75 percent and were "way off" in eight of first 10 months of 2011.
title: Month-to-month revisions can be significant

statement: "Taxpayers earning $1 million pay an effective tax rate that is about four times what taxpayers earning $100,000 pay."
title: More money, more taxes

statement: "Eighty percent of all U.S. communities depend solely on trucks to deliver and supply the products sold in stores or ordered online."
title: Big wheels keep the goods flowing

statement: Georgia’s unemployment rate has exceeded the national rate for 50 consecutive months.
title: Nothing to brag about for Georgia

statement: "Santorum also voted for a teapot museum in North Carolina."
title: Yes, but not specifically

statement: Says he has "been able to attract independents and Democrats to win" elections in Pennsylvania.
title: Less and less as time went on

statement: "By the way, I'm not raising tolls 50 percent....Jon Corzine did."
title: Corzine gets the blame

statement: "The Social Security trust fund … is already facing imminent bankruptcy."
title: The sky is darkening, but not falling

statement: Says Rick Santorum voted for the Bridge to Nowhere.
title: No argument from Santorum

statement: "What is the proper collective noun for a group of baboons? Believe it or not . . . a Congress!"
title: Good joke. Don't believe it.

statement: "New Jersey taxpayers … will now face the highest tolls in the country."
title: Highway robbery? Not really.

statement: Says Rep. Betty Sutton supports allowing "welfare fund withdrawals from strip clubs, casinos and liquor stores."
title: An ounce of truth and a ton of overreach

statement: Enacting the Right-to-Carry Act would amount to "expanding the rights of sex offenders, terrorists, child predators, and abusers to carry concealed weapons across state lines.’’
title: Exaggerated to make a point

statement: Says there were only "about eight or 10" inflammatory sentences in his newsletters.
title: We found nearly three dozen

statement: Says constitutional amendment would "help to stop unfair, double taxation on real estate."
title: There’s no double tax to stop -- at least not yet

statement: Small businesses "create 70 percent of the jobs in America."

statement: Under a Wisconsin bill, "minor offenses such as violating pet leash laws, seat belt laws, parking infractions, etc., would now be arrestable offenses."

And they also put in place the Independent Payment Advisory Board, 15 unelected bureaucrats, which will be making decisions about health care for our seniors and for all Americans."

statement: Says he’s "never asked for more" than inflationary budget increases in his 10 budgets as Milwaukee County sheriff

statement: Wisconsin bill "grants drug companies and medical device manufacturers immunity from injuries and deaths caused by their products."

statement: Appalachian Power Company is making "record profits."

statement: "Current projections indicate that Medicare will go bankrupt by 2017, while Social Security will bottom out by 2037."

statement: When George W. Bush was governor of Texas, "the percentage uninsured went down." Under his successor, Rick Perry, "it's gone up."

statement: "Our unemployment rate has been higher than 8 percent for more than two-and-a-half years, far above what the Obama Administration promised with the 'stimulus.' "

statement: "Bryce Reeves chaired a group bankrolled by a New York billionaire who fired hundreds of Virginia workers and sent their jobs to China."

statement: "Our government right now. . . (is) spending 40 percent more than what we take in."

statement: In the early 1960s, all levels of government were "consuming about 27 percent of the U.S. economy," a number that has risen to 37 percent today. With that trendline, "we cease at some point to be a free economy."
