title: Red rhymes with Ted

statement: "The reality is that we have roughly 15,000 undocumented immigrants living in the state..."
title: Ten-year-old numbers

statement: Say the ratio of CEO pay to average worker pay in the U.S. is 475 to 1.
title: Chart from a student paper goes viral

statement: U.S. unemployment among people ages 16 to 24 is "18.4 percent, which is a 60-year high."
title: It's fallen a bit since 2010 number

statement: "Senate Bill 5 makes it harder for nurses to give the patients the quality care they need."
title: Just 4 to 6 nurses of each 100 in Ohio are public employees

statement: Says Rick Perry "supported a guest worker program to help people who would otherwise be illegal aliens."
title: Yes, but it's been awhile

statement: Coca-Cola’s CEO "said he finds it easier to do work in China than in the United States."
title: Rick Perry's Coca-Cola claim fizzes on some details.

statement: Says Vince Polistina is "collecting nearly $70,000 in taxpayer-funded salaries -- plus a government pension."
title: Throwing stones in political glass houses

statement: "We have the highest corporate tax rate in the world. It’s 35 percent."
title: Study, experts agree

statement: "Today, the Social Security system is broke."
title: Checks are in the mail

statement: "Health care is the greatest contribution to spending increases in the state budget."
title: $2 billion increase in 10 years

statement: "Every month, another 50,000 U.S.-born Hispanics turn 18 and become eligible to vote."
title: Bigger numbers of whites, blacks

statement: The Arab Spring … "drove up gas prices."
title: Yes, though prices had already been on long-term upward curve

statement: "Not a single banker, a CEO from Wall Street, anyone from corporate America — nobody, (there was) not one arrest of any of these people who brought down the economy in 2008."
title: Not any names you've heard of

statement: "Legally, it doesn't make any difference" which state district you live in when running for Congress.
title: The Founding Fathers said so

statement: Gains in Atlanta Public Schools scores on a national standardized test lend credence to "dramatic" score increases on state tests.
title: Mixed results, unanswered questions

statement: Says that politicians who approved collective bargaining restrictions for public employees "exploited a loophole exempting themselves from Senate Bill 5."
title: They were exempt under former law, too

statement: Say water fluoridation started in Nazi Germany ghettos and death camps to pacify the Jews.
title: Just one of many conspiracy theories

statement: "Today, you have six financial institutions, the largest six, that have assets that are the equivalent of 60 percent of the GDP of the United States of America."
title: Smaller than some foreign-based banks, but still a sizable share

statement: "We have a $2 trillion to $3 trillion infrastructure deficit. We’ve got work that needs to get done. We’ve got people that want to go to work."
title: Claim on point, but overlooks some change since study was done

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie "cut spending (by) $1 billion" and provided "$850 million in new education funding."
title: What about last year’s education cuts?

statement: "The typical white male worker in this country is making in real terms what he was making in 1973" and "the average worker is making what they were making in 1996."
title: Stuck in time when it comes to earnings

statement: Says Barack Obama is a "hypocrite" for criticizing President George W. Bush’s "drone attack program," then using it aggressively as president.
title: There's a case for an Obama apology, but not over drones

statement: "Republicans enacted the most drastic cuts to K-12 public schools of any state in the nation."
title: Twenty six states short of knowing that

statement: Says that to drive the length of the newly drawn 15th District "you’d find yourself on the road as long as it would take to drive from Columbus to Niagara Falls."
title: Keep the pedal to the metal

statement: An Environmental Protection Agency regulation that goes into effect Jan. 1, 2012, regulates dust.
title: Claim is just dust in the wind

statement: "A family of four can make up to $88,000 a year and still get a subsidy for health insurance" under the new federal health care law.
title: Good coverage on insurance claim

statement: Says "New Jersey's unemployment is significantly lower than it was when I got here. And we've created 50,000 new private sector jobs in the last 20 months after having lost 117,000 in the year before I got here."
title: Numbers hit the mark

statement: Says that in 2001, Rick Perry spoke favorably of binational health insurance between Mexico and Texas.
title: Just that one time

statement: Says the federal government hosted a conference and "ordered 250 muffins at 16 bucks a piece."
title: Muffin-gate unbuttered

statement: When he took office in 2009, President Barack Obama "had the biggest Democratic majorities in Congress since Lyndon Johnson."
title: Carter and Clinton had Democratic majorities as big or bigger

statement: "Last year, Korea sold nearly half a million cars in our country. ... The United States, you know how much we sell to them? Six thousand. What kind of deal is that?"
title: Her numbers are a little off, but the disparity is real

statement: "My home state since June of 2009 created 40 percent of the new jobs in America."
title: Perry job growth claim largely on target

statement: Says David Dewhurst skipped nine candidate forums after announcing his U.S. Senate candidacy.
title: Mostly RSVP'd no

statement:
Chris Christie has not been "effective at creating jobs … (or have) a record of governing for effectiveness. ...
	New Jersey (has) one of the higher unemployment rates in the country at 9.4 percent."
title: Rate is higher than average, but not in the top 10

statement: "When it comes to being effective at creating jobs … (Chris Christie has not had) a record of governing for effectiveness. ... Last year, New Jersey created no net new jobs."
title: True for 2010, but why stop counting there?

statement: Says "Every year air pollution protections are delayed, another 34,000 people will die prematurely."
title: People would die, but maybe not so many

statement: Says Tommy Thompson "pushed such strict laws that abortion providers faced potential life imprisonment and women were forced to cross state lines in order to receive attention for life-threatening issues."
title: First part relates to partial-birth abortion ban, second involves more speculation than strong evidence

statement: "We’re. . . keeping and creating jobs in our state. From American Greetings, to Wendy’s, to Diebold, we’ve gone to their doorsteps to keep jobs right here in Ohio."
title: Specific cases can be cited

statement: "If our recovery were more typical of the postwar era . . . we would have 14 million more jobs today."
title: Jobs are slow to return

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie has "now come up with a new agenda" for ethics reform in September 2011.
title: Nothing new here

statement: Says his administration balanced "two budgets with over $13 billion in deficits without raising taxes."
title: What about this year's deficit?

statement: Wisconsin's new state budget includes "a 15 percent increase for road construction and yet we’ve got local towns tearing up" paved roads and replacing them with gravel.
title: Less spending, little gravel

statement: "[Federal] law says that you can't give in-state tuition to an illegal alien … unless you first offer it to any other student regardless of their state of residence."
title: Court rulings don't support his view

statement: Says she helped lead the launch of curbside recycling.
title: She was the bureau director in charge

statement: Says the private sector in Texas created 1 million jobs over the past decade.
title: That's the total and includes government jobs

statement: "Florida is the first state requiring drug testing to receive welfare!"
title: The first one, since the last one

statement: "President Obama has declared disasters in 48 of 50 states this year."
title: Yes, there's been a disaster almost everywhere

statement: Members of the public are being charged $50 to hear Gov. Scott Walker and a dozen members of his administration talk about jobs and the economy at Lambeau Field.
title: For that event, yes.

statement: "We have had over 40 days this summer where it was unsafe to breathe the air."
title: Claim not hot air.

statement:
Says U.S. Sen Sherrod Brown "promised that the first stimulus bill would fund the
	Brent Spence Bridge."
title: Discussing the project isn't promising it'll get done

statement: Because of Jim Whelan, "the 1990s are the only decade since the 1920s when the population of Atlantic City actually went up."
title: Casino gambling helped a bit

statement: The Postal Service’s financial losses result from "a 2006 law that drains $5 billion a year from post office revenue, while the Postal Service is forced to overpay billions more into federal accounts."
title: That, and a thing called the Internet

statement: "It costs more money to put a person on death row than it does to lock them up for the rest of their lives because of attorney fees."
title: Sometimes, but not always

statement: Says President Barack Obama failed "to stand up for the bipartisan debt solutions of the Simpson-Bowles Commission."
title: Similar measures proposed

statement: Says only four Texas legislators voted against a law giving in-state tuition rates to certain illegal immigrants.
title: Five is close enough

statement: Says Texas wildfires are linked to climate change.
title: Growing scientific sentiment that there's a link

statement: The federal government is spending $46,000 a year per family (or group of four) and could balance its budget by dropping that to $30,000.
title: Clunky, but accurate

statement: The Atlanta Beltline paid nearly $3.5 million for less than a quarter-acre.
title: Land price claim has cracks in foundation.

statement: Says that illegal immigrants get a $100,000 break on University of Texas tuition over four years.
title: A little off about very few beneficiaries

statement: "The Fed created $1.2 trillion out of nothing, gave it to banks, and some of them foreign banks, so that they could stabilize their operations."
title: Poof! Instant assets

statement: "If we had been on 'Obamacare' and a bureaucrat was trying to tell me when I could get that CAT scan, that would have delayed my treatment."
title: No, a bureaucrat won't review individual cases

statement: "A construction worker who’s making $50 or $60 grand a year shouldn’t be paying higher tax rates than the guy who’s making $50 million a year. And that’s how it’s working right now."
title: It can happen, but it's not clear how frequently

statement: "At nearly 19 million people, the population of Florida is larger than all the earlier primary and caucus states combined."
title: Four early states total 12 million

statement: Stimulus money funded a government board that made recommendations that would cost 378,000 jobs and $28.3 billion in sales.
title: Chester the Cheetah's not dead yet

statement: "We have asked public employees to pay 10 percent of the costs of their guaranteed pension and 15 percent of the cost of their health care. ... The leadership of those public employees unions don't want to pay anything."
title: Broad-brush claim paints blame too widely

statement: Despite opposition from national Club for Growth, Club for Growth Wisconsin "has endorsed" him for U.S. Senate.
title: State group doesn’t endorse in federal races

statement: "We have 10,000 baby boomers retiring every day."
title: There's a reason it's called a 'boom'

statement: "This is the worst jobs recovery since the Great Depression."
title: Bad, but not the worst

statement: Says "our taxes have doubled" with Rick Perry in office.
title: Fails to show the way

statement: Says "as a share of the US economy, the government’s support for research and development (R&D) has fallen by nearly two-thirds since the 1960s."
title: Statistic is on the mark

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker "is denying Democrats the right to vote."
title: Photo ID law doesn’t single out Dems

statement: Says Rick Perry is "spending more money than the state takes in, covering his deficits with record borrowing."
title: Cash flows fine

statement: "The water quality in the ocean is perfect. It’s been tested up and down every ocean shore in New Jersey."
title: Not quite perfect

statement: "In the past six years alone, changes to the pension formula … have saved over half a billion dollars."
title: Savings will take decades to achieve

statement: Says Rick Perry wrote a letter "supporting Hillarycare."
title: Don't forget rural folks, letter asked

statement: Says Texas’ unemployment rate has doubled on Rick Perry’s watch.
title: Ups and downs not in Perry's control

statement: Says that Romney touted the Massachusetts health plan for the nation in his hardcover book but then deleted it for the paperback edition.
title: Book changed, message not so much

statement: Says he "got lobbied" by a woman with late-stage cancer about vaccinating Texas girls against a virus that can cause cervical cancer.
title: Support came after action

statement: Says he never said he wanted to move Social Security "back to the states."
title: He went right up to the line twice on national TV

statement: "President Obama has the lowest public approval ratings of any president in modern times."
title: Obama's lows are higher than most presidents' lows

statement: Says the Panhandle has had its highest-ever bed tax collections in 2011.
title: Tens of millions of BP dollars=more visitors

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Tammy Baldwin is backing President Barack Obama’s plan to pass a $1.5 trillion tax increase.
title: Silence doesn't equal support

statement: Toledo Mayor "Mike Bell (once) lost his job as a firefighter because his city ran out of money."
title: Layoffs for firefighters followed city worker impasse, strike

statement: The city of Atlanta has either the highest or second-highest average water bills in the country.
title: Atlanta homeowners may not want to drink to this

statement: Says credit rating agencies realize that our instability stems in large part from Oregon’s kicker system.
title: It stems from a narrow reliance on income taxes

statement: "The federal government has not engaged in (border security) at all."
title: More U.S. agents than ever patrol the border

statement: "We're bankrupt."
title: Our finances aren't great, but we're not bankrupt

statement: Says Rick Perry "provided in-state tuition... for illegal immigrants."
title: Swearing involved

statement: President Obama "went around the world and apologized for America."
title: Repeating false charge doesn't make it true

statement: Says the United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world with 2.3 million inmates, and the majority of Americans are imprisoned because they sold small amounts of drugs.
title: Right about the population, wrong on the crimes

statement: "Wisconsin is broke," and "state government is $3 billion in debt."
title: Didn’t the governor say he fixed all that?

statement: Says Mitt Romney wrote that if Social Security was done "in the private sector, it would be called criminal."
title: Bank shot

statement: Says "New Jersey’s $1 billion horse racing industry … employs 13,000 individuals and ensures the preservation of 176,000 acres of horse farmland."
title: Wrong numbers for horse racing

statement: "In 1976, the first year that Pell Grants were fully funded, a full Pell Grant paid 72 percent of the cost of attendance at a typical four-year public college. Today, a full Pell Grant covers just 34 percent of those costs.
title: Soaring college costs eroded Pell Grant buying power

statement: "In the month of July alone, EU exports to South Korea increased by over 36 percent. A lot of that is our market share. Those are our farmers and our service providers who are suffering."
title: Stats are right, but EU growth was up months before

statement: "Since 1995, the top 400 wealthiest families have seen their incomes go up 400 percent and their tax rates go down 40 percent."
title: Newer data shows smaller (but still big) income jump

statement: "[The state ethics commission] took absolutely the same percent of cuts as most other state agencies. … They were somewhere in the 7 percent range – same as the governor’s office."
title: Cuts same across the board

statement: Says he did not support the October 2008 legislation to rescue Wall Street firms.
title: Giddyap! Whoa!

statement: Says that  in the recent year homeowners across Ohio have signed mineral rights agreements "and I understand that over a billion dollars worth of leases have been signed to date."
title: Potential riches in shale formations spur buying spree

statement: More private-sector jobs were created in the second year of the Obama administration than in the eight years of the Bush administration.
title: Technically true, but period for Obama is cherry-picked

statement: "[Eighty-five percent] of the funds collected in each county will be redistributed elsewhere -- not spent in the county in which it is collected."
title: Not much concrete for this claim.

statement: Says "We do about 300 investigations a year into housing discrimination and in recent years have put about $150,000 of damages into the pockets of individuals who have been treated unfairly."
title: Try over three years

statement: "Poverty among Americans 65 and over is statistically unchanged" in recent years because of Social Security.
title: Older Americans hanging in there

statement: Says that even if you have no children, "under Obamacare, you would still have to carry insurance that covers pediatric, maternity and newborn care even though you do not need it."
title: Basic coverages already bundled in most health plans

statement: One Wisconsin school district "is so worried about losing state funding that it has stopped giving milk to elementary school kids during snack time."
title: Officials say other factors involved

statement: "An amazing 5,400 jobs were lost in the first 12 months of the (smoking) ban’s implementation in Ohio’s hospitality industry alone."
title: The claim goes up in smoke when you look at the actual numbers

statement: Says New Jersey is "losing 50 football fields of open space to development every day and the more we develop upstream the more flooding we have downstream."
title: Penalty on the play

statement: "The Green Bay Packers are a socialist organization."
title: Socialistic traits, but ...

statement: "The average state pension, including managers, is $23,000 a year; and just $14,000 for local government workers."
title: New retirees, larger pensions

statement: Says an amendment specifying when military members may use deadly force "does nothing to change existing rules of engagement for American service members."
title: Military experts say he's right

statement: Says that three of these five Republicans -- Ben Westlund, Rob Patridge, Max Williams, Lane Shetterly, Lynn Lundquist -- later became Democrats.
title: We found one, but not three

statement: "Ten years ago the Austin Water Utility used a total of 240.3 million gallons. Every summer since then our peak day of water use has been lower."

statement: Says the vaccine to prevent HPV can cause mental retardation.
title: The 'I heard it somewhere' standard of evidence

statement: "Two-thirds of Granite Staters oppose the Tea Party" and its agenda on labor unions.
title: Twisting what the polls say

statement: Says CNN's Wolf Blitzer was wrong to say that "the wealthiest Americans, they pay the most in taxes already -- 50 percent of Americans don't even pay any federal income tax."
title: The Rep. who cried wolf

statement: "I asked the unions to pay into their own health care insurance ... and they said I was being unreasonable. I requested that they contribute toward their own pensions ... and they screamed it was unfair."
title: Didn't ask, did tell

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s jobs bill, states would no longer have to lay off teachers, firefighters and police officers.
title: "No longer"? Not really.

statement: Hurricane "Irene was the second-largest storm to hit North America in terms of power outages -- and the first hurricane to make landfall in New Jersey since 1904."
title: Irene, the outage queen?

statement: The jobs bill includes "President Obama's tax on soup kitchens"
title: Rhetoric outstrips reality

statement: Under President Barack Obama’s jobs bill, "you can sue if you are unemployed and don't get the job and think you weren't hired because you are unemployed."
title: It's in the bill

statement: "$360 million of our tax dollars went straight to ... the Taliban."
title: Fraudulent contract spending is kind of his thing

statement: "The majority last quarter of Sherrod Brown's campaign contributions came from outside of the state of Ohio."
title: Ohioans contributed more last quarter and over the long haul

statement: Says "160,000 kids stay home every day because they are afraid to go to school because of bullying."
title: Source doesn’t stand behind statistic

statement: In the New York 9th District, "there is a large number of people who went to the polls tonight who didn't support the president to begin with and don't support Democrats -- and it's nothing more than that."
title: NY-9 ain't Wyoming

statement: The U.S. military "is in 130 countries. We have 900 bases around the world."
title: A plausible number, though coverage is thinner than it seems

statement: "170,000 of the jobs" created in Texas under Gov. Rick Perry "were government jobs."
title: Paul's number is off, but he has a point

statement: Says "Rick Perry doubled spending in a decade."
title: Unusual methodology

statement: Mitt Romney "drove to Canada with the family dog Seamus strapped to the roof of the car."
title: In a carrier with a windshield, plus he got his revenge

statement: "In terms of the wealthiest Americans, we're at the lowest tax rate since the 1950s."
title: Rate only lower from 1988-92

statement: Says Rick Perry and the Republican-controlled Texas Legislature "managed to slash the budget of the volunteer fire departments in our state by 75 percent in the last legislative session," reducing their abilities to fight recent wildfires.
title: Fiery flub

statement: "Gov. Kasich and the Republican-dominated legislature have foregone the popular option of closing tax loopholes that amount to $7 billion annually in this state."
title: New state budget added more credits, exemptions

statement: The premiums on Medicare’s prescription drug program have fallen almost every year since it began.
title: They actually rose

statement: "The first round of stimulus ... it created zero jobs."
title: A ridiculous claim no matter who says it

statement: "We know that President Obama stole over $500 billion out of Medicare to switch it over to Obamacare."
title: Law-making equated with thievery

statement: "Today, when people retire in Galveston County, Texas, they retire making at least 50 percent more than they would ever get out of Social Security."
title: Some do, some don't

statement: Says that in his book, Rick Perry said that "Social Security is unconstitutional."
title: His 2010 book isn't explicit, but strongly suggests it

statement: Social Security is a "Ponzi scheme."
title: Perry's tone has softened, but his comparison is still wrong

statement: "In writing his book, Gov. Perry pointed out that … by any measure Social Security has been a failure."
title: Tough talk straight from Perry's book

statement: "One international flight a day in a wide-bodied jet ... one flight daily generates $150 million a year and approximately 2,300 jobs."
title: Claim loses altitude with cherry-picking, job inflation

statement: Takes credit for "reining in" state spending when he was governor.
title: Bottom line increased 45 percent

statement: "Since the beginning of the year we've created a net increase of 45,000 jobs."
title: Who created them? Jobs have grown steadily more than a year

statement: Ben Bernanke has been the most "inflationary" chairman in the history of the Federal Reserve.
title: Gingrich claim on Bernanke largely inflated

statement: Says 600,000 to 700,000 government workers have been laid off in the last year and a half
title: Out of range

statement: The Republican-controlled Wisconsin Assembly approved "only one out of 376 amendments offered by Assembly Democrats" in 2011.
title: Based on available data, correct

statement: "When you look at what we have done over the last decade, we created 1 million jobs in the state of Texas. At the same time, (the rest of) America lost 2.5 million."
title: Many factored thing

statement: "Over the past 10 years, the number of people living in Lower Manhattan has nearly doubled. In fact, Lower Manhattan has added more people over the last 10 years than Atlanta, Dallas and Philadelphia combined."
title: Moving downtown

statement: "Mike Trainor...still owes $250,000 to the state."
title: The debt was never repaid

statement: The Wisconsin Department of Corrections is considering implementing mandatory physical fitness testing for security staff.
title: Fake story contained a bogus claim

statement: Says "Every time the Legislature 'suspended' the kicker, most recently the corporate kicker in 2007, Salem spent every penny and failed to stabilize the state's revenues."
title: Context is sorely lacking

statement: Thomas Jefferson expressed "strong support" for a balanced budget amendment in 1798.
title: TJ flip-flopped on federal debt

statement: "The academic achievements of our student-athletes are mentioned in the same breath and spirit as Notre Dame and Stanford."
title: We're calling this one a fumble for Shalala

statement: Says Democratic U.S. Senate candidate Tammy Baldwin ranks "as the most liberal member of the House."
title: Many others ranked there with her

statement: "Issue 2 makes it illegal for us to negotiate for enough firefighters to do the job."
title: 'On duty' staffing specifically excluded

statement: "Two days of interest we pay to China is enough to buy one joint strike fighter [jet]."
title: No turbulence on this claim.

statement: The deal to raise the nation’s debt ceiling will "directly link a debt ceiling increase to spending cuts for the first time ever."
title: History repeating itself

statement: "Michael Dukakis created jobs three times faster" than Mitt Romney.
title: Little evidence that guvs' policies were the cause

statement: Since Rick Perry became governor, "Texas has gone from 46th in the country to 50th in the population that graduates from high school."
title: Stats are right, but larger forces at work than just Perry

statement: "The day President Obama took office, gasoline was $1.79 a gallon."
title: She's right: It fell from $4.00 in just six months

statement: Utah was "the No. 1 job creator in this country during my years of service" as governor, with a 5.9 percent increase in jobs.
title: Not when you use the right statistics

statement: Sherrod Brown "has stood side by side" with President Barack Obama, presiding "over the most rapid increase in the debt over the last 2.5 years" and hurtling toward " the worst jobs record in the modern era."
title: Who knew one senator could shoulder so much blame?

statement: Says the U.S. Department of Homeland Security must report to about 100 congressional committees and subcommittees.
title: This is no oversight

statement: "This year, the Blackstone Valley Mayoral Academy became the first public school in Rhode Island history to have 100 percent of its elementary-age students proficient in reading on state assessments."
title: It was just one test that few schools take

statement: The Massachusetts health care plan "dealt with 8 percent of our population," far less than the "100 percent of American people" affected by President Barack Obama’s health care law.
title: Comparing apples and oranges

statement: "Republicans fought to protect tax loopholes for corporations that send our jobs overseas."
title: They opposed anything that looked like a tax increase

statement: "Congressman Bill Young voted to cut taxes for millionaires and end your Medicare."
title: Ryan budget blueprint didn't end Medicare

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan’s budget proposal "eliminates Medicare" in 10 years.
title: Nope. That's still wrong

statement: Rick Perry "was the (campaign) chairman for Al Gore at one time, not too many years ago."
title: CORRECTED: Perry was supporter, not chairman

statement: "Governor (Perry), you were a Democrat, having worked for Al Gore as his campaign manager..."
title: CORRECTED: Perry was supporter, not chairman

statement: "We [the city of Atlanta] are overbuilt on housing."
title: Glut of Property is Not the Only Problem

statement: Says the federal government is "the largest energy user in the country."
title: BTUs to power democracy

statement: Says Jon Huntsman supports changes in Medicare that would deny guaranteed benefits to 980,000 New Hampshire residents.
title: No guarantee about guarantees

statement: A bipartisan payroll tax cut championed by the White House has meant that "the average family has an extra $1,000 in their pocket" this year.
title: It's a bit less than $1,000 (and not every household gets a break)

statement: "(U.S. Reps.) Paul Ryan, Sean Duffy and Reid Ribble are … shutting down town hall meetings, or making their constituents pay to attend them."
title: Many ways to see them: County fairs, coffees, Rotary meetings, and ... town hall meetings

statement: Rail "doesn’t do a great job in lessening traffic."
title: Rogers claim on rail chugs in right direction.

statement: "I became a Republican sooner in my life than" Ronald Reagan did in his.
title: By about a decade

statement: Say Ohio Reps. Marcia Fudge, Marcy Kaptur and Dennis Kucinich are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: Flagrantly false and riddled with errors

statement: The United States "won every major battle" of the Vietnam War. "Every single one."
title: Winning the battles but losing the war?

statement: Say Texas U.S. Reps. Eddie Bernice Johnson and Sheila Jackson Lee are among open Socialists in Congress.
title: Loosey goosey

statement: "Point Pleasant Beach does not own its beaches; they are privately owned and operated by businesses such as Jenkinson’s"
title: Private ownership's a beach

statement: A new college tuition reciprocity agreement with Minnesota "makes college education more affordable for Wisconsin residents."
title: Not when they’re paying more

statement: "Mayor Fung wants to punish our children's education by removing 12 million dollars from current funding to pay for his private charter school. Your taxes would increase by between 6 and 8 percent per year."
title: Robocall does not compute

statement: Says Barack Obama’s "favorability rating in Israel once clocked in at 4 percent."
title: No cigar

statement: Says "New Jersey's public school students have the best Advanced Placement scores in the nation."
title: If you rank ‘em, we’re number 1.

statement: Says that 500,000 federal workers -- one-fourth of the federal workforce -- make more than $100,000 a year.
title: Not quite that many

statement: Says Ron Paul insisted FEMA should be shut down.
title: He's no fan

statement: Takes credit for "substantially reducing the size of the state workforce."
title: Fewer bureaucrats, more private consultants

statement: Says that when President Obama visited El Paso, he "pronounced that the border with Mexico and the United States was safer than it ever was in history."
title: That was the tone, but never said safer than ever

statement: Says Florida U.S. Reps. Corrine Brown, Alcee Hastings and Frederica Wilson are Socialists.
title: Still scratching our heads with a sickle

statement: Says Oregon state employees received a "catch-up" pay raise in 1981 -- just two years after they agreed not to take a raise in exchange for a retirement benefit.
title: Raises were double digit, but so was inflation

statement: "H.B. 194, the Voter Suppression Bill, invalidates a vote where a voter properly marks the ballot in support of a particular candidate, but also writes in the name of that same candidate."
title: Small window open for counting some votes

statement: U.S. Reps. Hank Johnson, John Lewis and other members of the Congressional Progressive Caucus are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: Socialists? Break out the sickle & hammer to tear down this claim.

statement: President Barack Obama "has virtually no one in his cabinet with private-sector experience."
title: Wrong in 2009, and wrong today

statement: Says President Barack Obama delivered $2 billion to Brazil to help with offshore drilling projects.
title: Not $2 billion and not from Obama

statement: "The ratio of corporate profits to wages is now higher than at any time since just before the Great Depression."
title: He's right, though it may be a temporary spike

statement: "In (Sen. Marco) Rubio's state of Florida alone, Social Security lifts more than -- count it -- a million people out of poverty."
title: Liberal think tank looks just at benefits, not taxes

statement: Says that in 2009 ExxonMobil "paid no federal income taxes, received a $156 million rebate."
title: False before, False again

statement: Say New Jersey Reps. Donald Payne and Frank Pallone are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: The socialist charge is neither accurate nor social

statement: A national study of 2,500 charter schools shows that "maybe 20 percent do better than the community public schools, 40 percent or so do worse and the rest are not having any significant difference."
title: Reputable study, quoted accurately

statement: "The United States is the No. 1 country in the world for energy resources. … We are the king daddy dogs when it comes to energy."
title: We are number one -- but not without some qualifications

statement: Says potential GOP U.S. Senate candidate Tommy Thompson supported "Obamacare"
title: He supported pieces -- and opposed pieces

statement: Congressional Budget Office "says 8 (percent) unemployment till 2014!"
title: Unsaid: Better than now

statement: Says there’s not "much evidence to suggest that people have (contributed to global warming) or can do very much to change anything."
title: A bit of hot air

source: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
statement: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals estimates 200 animals will be spared annually as the result of former President Bill Clinton adopting a vegan diet.
title: PETA has a point, as long as some animals are not more equal than others

statement: "The health insurance plan that (members of Congress) have is no different than any other federal employee's in the United States government."
title: He pays up for care

statement: In Afghanistan, "it is very, very rare that someone who is killed in action is not killed by an" improvised explosive device, or IED.
title: IEDs are easily the biggest killer, but they account for 50-60 percent of U.S. deaths

statement: "We've had 11,000 attempts to amend the Constitution since 1789."
title: Only 0.2 percent of tries actually get ratified

statement: Every 1 percent increase in the number of Ohioans with bachelor’s degrees "means economic activity growing the next year and for each year thereafter (by) $2.5 billion dollars."
title: Sorting out dollar estimate requires higher degree

statement: "As governor, [Mitt Romney] balanced the budget without raising taxes and created jobs."
title: Argument for Mitt Romney could use a little fine tuning.

statement: Says the national debt and President Barack Obama's "refusal to control spending led to our nation's credit rating being downgraded for the first time in history."
title: Politics also a factor

statement: Say Oregon Reps. Peter DeFazio and Earl Blumenauer are "socialists who are openly serving in the U.S. Congress."
title: The socialist charge is neither accurate nor social

statement: Gov. Rick Scott "is trying to get a waiver under the federal health care law that would deny consumers in Florida the right to the $60 million in rebates they have from their own HMOs."
title: Scott wants to delay possible rebates, but amount is unclear

statement: Democrats in the Legislature in 2009 voted for various "pork projects" including "a $5 million scoreboard for the Milwaukee Bucks."
title: Airball. Or, maybe: error-ball

statement: "The estimated savings of this (debt ceiling) deal only pay for half of the cost of extending all of the Bush-era tax cuts for another decade."
title: His numbers are solid

statement: "We spend less on defense today as % of GDP than at any time since Pearl Harbor."
title: Gingrich's Defense Claim Indefensible

statement: "Rooting for the Red Sox is like rooting for the drug companies."
title: High, hard one hurled in defense of team honor

statement: Says direct shipment of wine "makes underage drinking as simple as a mouse click."
title: Not that simple

statement: Public-employee unions spent $30 million in Wisconsin unsuccessfully trying to flip the state Senate to Democratic control.
title: All sides spent that much or more combined, but not the unions alone

statement: Rick Perry "has advocated abandoning Social Security, scuttling Medicaid and ending the federal income tax."
title: Rec: Read his book

statement: "As we near the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, we should not forget that some of the hijackers used New Jersey driver’s licenses to board those aircraft."
title: Five states, but not NJ

statement: The Central Falls fire department is "one of the lowest, if not the lowest, paid fire departments in the state and entire region."
title: Low pay offset by overtime, other compensation

statement: Says his hometown of Paint Creek, Texas, "doesn’t even have a ZIP code."
title: ZIP codes everywhere

statement: "The studies have shown us that [drug testing for welfare recipients] will be saving us money"
title: Studies show the opposite.

statement: "The United States death rate is two-and-a-half times higher for those who do not have a high school education."
title: Another reason to be cool, stay in school

statement: Says Texas gained 21,000 doctors due to tort reform.
title: Doctors go where the people are

statement: "Before Medicare, only 51 percent of Americans 65 and older had health care coverage and nearly 30 percent lived below the poverty line. Today, thanks to Medicare ... nearly all seniors have coverage and 75 percent fewer struggle in poverty."
title: Right on the numbers, wrong on the credit

statement: "We rank below Ethiopia, I'm told, in terms of our exports per capita, well below any of the other developed countries we trade with, and well below China and (South) Korea."
title: Slip of the tongue doesn't destroy underlying point

statement: Says enrolling a student in a subsidized lunch program triggers an "at risk" designation, resulting in an extra $6,000 to $7,000 of state school aid per student.
title: Differs by district

statement: "When Social Security first started, there was 16 workers for every retiree. Today there are three workers for every retiree and soon there will be only two for every retiree."
title: Simple stat exposes Social Security's problems

statement: "Over the last four years, 53 percent of black wealth has just disappeared."
title: From 2005 to 2009

statement: The 2009-11 state budget that Democrats approved left Wisconsin taxpayers $3.6 billion in debt.
title: A shortfall is a challenge; a debt is a debt

statement: Says that before Rick Perry became governor, "only 4 percent of our total labor force was a minimum wage job ... Today, that number has more than doubled (to) 9.5 percent."
title: Wrong starting point

statement: "When lenders foreclose on homes, they typically suffer losses that exceed 30 percent of the value of the home."
title: It's not definitive, but evidence points that way

statement: Says "under our current sentencing laws, about 75 percent of all convicted felons in Oregon do not go to prison."
title: Sure, but at least 75 percent spend some time behind bars

statement: "Recent international reports show the United States near the bottom among industrialized nations for k-12 academic achievement."
title: Pol's claim on U.S. students rates half-true. Studies show they still need to hit the books.

statement: "Last year -- actually, this year in May -- we saw New Jersey Transit fares rise anywhere from 25 percent to 47 percent."
title: Year’s wrong, but fares are higher

statement: Says Gov. Rick Scott is "spending a quarter of a million of our tax dollars to robocall people."
title: Hello? Republican Party picked up the tab for Scott's robo-calls

statement: Says Gov. Rick Scott cut state funding for PBS.
title: Gov. Scott vetoed the dollars -- but Elmo wasn't pink-slipped

statement: Scientists are "questioning the original idea that man-made global warming is what is causing the climate to change. … (It is) more and more being put into question."
title: Actually, consensus is solid

statement: The Dodd-Frank financial-reform law’s hundreds of new rules will force small banks and credit unions to burn up "an estimated 2,260,631 labor hours just for compliance."
title: Paperwork’s piling up, but nobody knows how high on the little guy

statement: Says that Wall Street hedge fund managers "pay a lower tax rate than does a sheet metal worker in Parma or a school teacher in Cleveland."
title: Does this count as coddling?

statement: The proposed transportation bill "could be the largest tax increase in Georgia history."
title: Sales tax vote could be historic for many reasons

statement: "Since I introduced my budget -- first budget -- in March of 2010, we've created 50,000 new private-sector jobs for the people of this state."
title: Gov can't take all the credit

statement: Outside of recall elections, "there's never been a public official removed from office" in Wisconsin "for anything but malfeasance in office."
title: Exceedingly rare indeed

statement: "Hair stylists are required to undergo more government scrutiny than foreclosure consultants."
title: New name, new regulations

statement: Providence's port is "200 miles closer to Europe than any other Eastern port."
title: Geography lesson anyone?

statement: Says Texas schools have had "massive increases" in class sizes with Rick Perry as governor.
title: Massive miss

statement: China is or soon will be "the largest English-speaking nation" in the world.
title: Details are lost in translation

statement: There are 500 million Internet users "and 80 million bloggers who are driving discussions in China. … So you’ve got a lot of people voicing frustration and discontent."
title: Millions of bloggers, but more social than political

statement: Says allowing the payroll tax holiday to expire would end up "costing another estimated 900,000 jobs in 2012."
title: Payroll tax holiday puts jobs on holiday, too

statement: Says Rick Perry flip-flopped on gay marriage by first saying it was a state’s rights issue and then saying he was in favor of a federal constitutional amendment banning gay marriage.
title: A change in emphasis

statement: Democrats failed to flip the Wisconsin state Senate because recall elections were in the "deepest red districts in the state."
title: Red, but not the reddest

statement: The results of Atlanta Public School’s 2010 and 2011 CRCT tests "have not been questioned."
title: They've been questioned repeatedly

statement: "In Texas, we teach both creationism and evolution in our public schools."
title: Not law or policy to mix the two

statement: The "mega-rich" pay about 15 percent in taxes, while the middle class "fall into the 15 percent and 25 percent income tax brackets, and then are hit with heavy payroll taxes to boot."
title: You have to be REALLY rich to pay less

statement: "I started with a $3.7 billion budget deficit. Now we are projecting a $1.2 billion surplus."
title: A "surplus" isn't uncommon

statement: Virginia has made "no progress on jobs" since Bob McDonnell took office.
title: State has gained 50,000 jobs during McDonnell's term

statement: Under Gov. Scott Walker, "unemployment is increasing in Wisconsin at twice the rate it is nationally."
title: One-month increase isn’t a trend

statement: U.S. debt is "now equal to 100 percent of the GDP."
title: A little premature, but in the ballpark

statement: Says a Senate resolution would restore $140 in monthly general assistance payments and prevent people from committing crime.
title: Budget leaves payments intact

statement: Thirty-seven percent of Central Falls’ retired police officers and firefighters are out on disability pensions; in most municipalities, about 5 percent of retirees collect disability pensions.
title: Cites national average that isn't

statement: "Our credit rating went up since I've been in office."
title: Florida's been AAA since 2005

statement: Says Rick Perry "wanted to secede from the union."
title: Never said giddyap, let's go

statement: Says that he did "not exactly" say that communities have the right to ban mosques.
title: But he made that exact point

statement: Says he worked with the Democratic legislature to balance spending with revenues so that "at the end of my four-year term, the rainy day fund was established at more than $2 billion."
title: He was ready for a rainy day

statement: Says the government wants to require farm tractor drivers to hold commercial driver’s licenses even if they’re just crossing a single public road.
title: Rural legend

statement: "Josh Mandel used to be pro-choice, now he’s anti-choice. He used to be sympathetic towards gay and lesbians and now he’s [not]."
title: Interviews back his claim on one point

statement: "The governor having a meeting ... isn't covered by the open meetings act."
title: Open meetings law not that open

statement: "Twenty-five states have lower unemployment than Texas" which is "tied with Mississippi for more minimum-wage jobs than anywhere in the United States."
title: Big state, big numbers

statement: "One in four Texans lacks health insurance, the highest proportion in the nation."
title: Poverty is a contributing factor

statement: "Credit agency says Rep. Gibbs recklessly caused downgrade, higher interest rates."
title: You can't blame it all on one guy

statement: Tax increases could "come into play" as a result of the debt ceiling deal.
title: Unlikely, but possible

statement: Says the state’s pension and health benefits reform includes "the destruction of public sector collective bargaining rights."
title: Weakened, not destroyed

statement: Says "of the 2,000 Portland households in the year-long (composting) pilot, 87 percent of participants reported being satisfied with the overall system."
title: Only 20 percent of the participants gave feedback

statement: "The weight of the evidence (on global warming) is that most of it, maybe all of it, is because of natural causes ... it’s fair to say the science is in dispute."
title: Isolated dissenters but no major disagreement

statement: Statistically, law-enforcement officers die 10 years earlier than the general population.
title: 'Cuff that claim!

statement: Says a poll found him the only Republican candidate who could beat Barack Obama in Texas -- and by eight points.
title: Only--not counting three others

statement: "Certainly we're going to be the most restrictive state in the land … in terms of who can get medical marijuana, how it will be prescribed and how it will be achieved in terms of moving it into the marketplace."
title: Tokin' up is hard to do

statement: When Standard & Poor's "dropped our credit rating, what they said is, we don't have an ability to repay our debt. ... I was proved right in my position" that the debt ceiling should not have been raised.
title: S&P said lack of compromise caused downgrade

statement: Says that under President John F. Kennedy, "government took up" 27 percent of the economy, and today it "consumes 37 percent."
title: Technically right, but lacking important context

statement: "President Obama and Democrats' spending addiction has driven our national debt to historic proportions, maxed out our national credit card and has now led to the Democrat Downgrade of our country's AAA credit rating."
title: Fingers point in both directions

statement: Says Republican recall challenger Jonathan Steitz "failed to pay his taxes."
title: He did. Once

statement: Says Democratic state Sen. Jim Holperin "voted against a property tax freeze" in 2009 and then voted for a "$1.5 billion property tax hike."
title: There was no freeze vote, but state budget action set stage for local increases

statement: "The country's bankrupt."
title: We're still paying the bills

statement: "We created a flat tax in the state of Utah."
title: Not perfectly flat, but certainly flatter

statement: Virginia has a responsibility to fund 55 percent of public education and is paying just 41 percent.
title: Mixes apples and oranges

statement: The Republican National Convention "is a Super Bowl times four."
title: More like times one

statement: "We're inches away from no longer having a free economy."
title: Pants on Fire in June, Pants on fire now

statement: "Obamacare was patterned after (Mitt Romney's) plan in Massachusetts."
title: Very similar plans

statement: Says he "helped bring" Uline company to Kenosha area, "creating 800 local jobs."
title: Help cited came after the move

statement: Says GOP recall challenger Kim Simac "was delinquent paying her property taxes eight of the last nine years."
title: Paid up now, but late on eight

statement: There are cities and counties in Georgia that don’t have websites, and where elected officials don’t have email addresses.
title: Snail mail will have to do

statement: High-speed rail would have cost Florida taxpayers $1 billion to build.
title: That's not what state or federal transportation officials said

statement: "Two elections in a row (Waukesha County Clerk Kathy Nickolaus) has screwed up counting the vote"
title: Wrong and wrong

statement: "One in every five families in the state of New Jersey has a loved one with a mental illness, a serious mental illness, and today, we don’t care."
title: Sound statistic

statement: Says that voter identification laws "keep poor people from voting, minorities from voting, the elderly from voting, students from voting."
title: A lot depends on the details

statement: "George LeMieux voted against the majority of Republicans and joined with Democrats to create a 'Task Force For Responsible Fiscal Action' that looks strikingly similar to the 'Super Committee' now being set up in Washington to justify massive tax hikes."
title: Right on vote, less so on committees

statement: "In the '80s, Democrats promised spending cuts, but delivered only tax hikes."
title: Tax hikes without spending cuts?

statement: The Northwest Corridor highway project in Cobb and Cherokee counties "is expected to create over 9,700 jobs statewide."
title: 'Job years' are not actual jobs

statement: "We’re only spending 2 percent of our GDP on our infrastructure, while China and India are spending 10 percent of their GDP reinvesting back into their country."
title: Slightly off, but close enough

statement: Says his Twitter account has 1.3 million followers.
title: Many tweeps not real peeps

statement: "I built the last nuclear plant — not only in the state, but in the country."
title: N.J.? Yes. U.S.? Not by a decade.

statement: The debt-ceiling bill "doesn’t cut the debt. It will add about $7 trillion in new debt over the next 10 years."
title: Bill doesn't add the debt itself, but doesn't stop it from accruing

statement: The United States has "the longest surviving constitution."
title: Older than other single document constitutions

statement: Says Adam Hasner’s record includes "requesting over $92.2 million in earmarks."
title: Most Florida lawmakers asked for even more

statement: "You might be surprised to know that 137 billion gallons flows (into Lake Erie) every day. You might be surprised to know that only 86.3 billion gallons flow out. ... Leaving us a net surplus of approximately 50 billion gallons a day."
title: Incomplete calculation leaves claim all wet

statement: The deal to raise the federal debt limit created the "largest debt ceiling increase in America’s history."
title: Don't forget World War II

statement: "Almost 88,000 United States service members are still missing and unaccounted for, dating back to World War II."
title: Number of unaccounted-for from WWII recently lowered

statement: "Illegal immigration costs state taxpayers over $3 billion every year."
title: Calculating by assumption

statement: Central Falls "schools are overfunded by state money by as much as $8 million."
title: $8 million? Try nearly $13 million.

statement: Says Texas has "the fourth-lowest debt per capita of any state in the nation, and we are the lowest of any of the big states."
title: Seven places off among all states

statement: Says state Sen. Alberta Darling is "allowing mercury to harm our children" because she voted against an electronics recycling bill.
title: Junked electronics loaded with nasty stuff, but no evidence of harm -- yet

statement: Says state Rep. Sandy Pasch "did nothing to stop" people from scamming the Wisconsin Shares child-care subsidy program and voted against funding for fraud investigators.
title: They cherry-picked one vote and ignored several others

statement: "When Nancy Nusbaum was Brown County executive, spending went up nearly 50 percent."
title: Yes, but increase was middle of the pack

statement: "Today we stand as the highest-performing urban school district in America."
title: It's tough to measure "the" best district

statement: Says Obama has never submitted a budget, and Congress has worked for two years without passing one.
title: The president proposes; Congress disposes

statement: Says state Rep. Sandy Pasch, her recall opponent, "voted to allow public school employees to use taxpayer dollars to pick up the tab for…Viagra."
title: There was no vote and the issue predates Pasch’s arrival in office by years

statement: "The government's twice the size it was 10 years ago. It's 30 percent bigger than it was when (Barack) Obama became president."
title: UPDATED: He, and we, should have adjusted for inflation

statement: "As a percentage of our gross domestic product, the defense budget remains just 3.6 percent. This figure is low by all historical standards."
title: But other measures show U.S. defense spending high

statement: "Rick Perry ended full-day Pre-K for 100,000 Texas children."
title: Grants gone, but full-day pre-K not

statement: Atlanta Public Schools’ 2011 CRCT tests were "given under the strictest security possible."

statement: Says Republican Sen. John McCain won more votes for president in Cuyahoga County in the 2008 general election than he did in seven states.
title: Democratic stronghold has some GOP voters, too

statement: Says Sen. Luther Olsen, his recall opponent, supported the sale of state-owned power plants "not to the highest bidder, but to the biggest donors" with no oversight.
title: He didn’t pick winners, but did back no bids

statement: Says Sen. Robert Cowles, her recall opponent, supported the sale of state-owned power plants "not to the highest bidder, but to the biggest donors" with no oversight.
title: Didn’t like it, didn’t vote for it

statement: Tax increases under Michigan Gov. Jennifer Granholm led to state unemployment going from 6.8 percent to 15.3 percent.
title: National recession, carmaker woes a much bigger factor

statement: "I cut more as a percentage out of government than any state in the country this past decade. And where is Michigan in terms of its economic growth? Cutting did not result in economic growth."
title: Yes, though a bigger issue was that a poor economy forced government cuts

statement: "There’s actually 600 abortions done after the 20th week of pregnancy every year in Ohio."
title: State stats back up claim

statement: Says Democrats cut $35 million from the state budget for Information Technology improvements.
title: Number’s off by about $30 million

statement: "There's no money in Social Security."
title: "No money" earned $117.5 billion in interest last year

statement: There was a "loss of eight million jobs during the Bush eight years."
title: Yes, eight million jobs lost, but not during Bush's eight years

statement: "The average Republican voter thinks there should be some revenue as part of this deal."
title: Different polls reach different conclusions

statement: "One of the biggest polluters in our country is the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District."
title: Not even among the highest water polluters in the Great Lakes region

statement: "[T]his breed (of pit bulls) is most often associated with aggressive behavior."
title: Doggone it. Pit bull claim mostly on the mark.

statement: "#Business formation is still on the rise in Ohio! So far in 2011 we’ve assisted w/ 44,443 new business filings."
title: New filings don't mean new hirings

statement: Says more than eight countries lead the United States in the percentage of college graduates.
title: Education systems still differ

statement: The debt ceiling deal will result in "the lowest level of annual domestic spending since Dwight Eisenhower was president."
title: He'd be right if he'd phrased it differently

statement: "If the debt ceiling is surpassed, our nation will not go into default as some suggest."
title: Depends how you define default

statement: "There are no tax increases in this debt limit bill. Period."
title: Not in this bill, but maybe later

statement: "The (State Board of Administration) transparency issue got a great airing the last legislative session."
title: Legislature discussed for a total of 36 minutes

statement: "For the second quarter in a row, my campaign has raised more money than any other challenger in the nation and brought our fundraising total to over $800,000."
title: His potential opponent, Allen West, still has a bigger war chest

source: Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America
statement: A Waushara County school closed because of state budget cuts supported by Republican Wisconsin state Sen. Luther Olsen.
title: Tiny Poy Sippi school was on the chopping block for years.

statement: "Social Security doesn’t contribute a penny to the deficit."
title: Didn't for years, does now

statement: Under last year’s health care reform, "a bunch of bureaucrats decide whether you get care, such as continuing on dialysis or cancer chemotherapy."
title: Truth in critical condition

statement: "Social Security didn’t cause the debt crisis. Social Security had nothing to do with the debt crisis."
title: Trust fund should be flush, but Congress tapped the pot

statement: In contrast to President Barack Obama, who "is not acting presidential," President Ronald Reagan "would never go into the Oval Office without his jacket on — that's how much he revered the presidency."
title: Reagan did dress pretty formally, but times have changed

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Ron Kind’s "stimulus cost taxpayers $278,000 per job."
title: Stimulus bought more than jobs

statement: Medicaid is the primary source of health insurance for 41.7 percent of Hispanic children in Georgia.
title: Health care for Hispanic children becomes part of the Medicaid debate

statement: (Rep. Bob Goodlatte's) balanced budget amendment does not require a balanced budget.
title: Semantic argument ignores the obvious

statement: "Believe it or not, consumer spending is up over the last eight months."
title: Up both in raw numbers and adjusted for inflation

statement: Says New Jersey has fewer jobs since Gov. Chris Christie took office.
title: Job growth is flat, but still up

statement: "The federal government is spending 25 percent of our entire economy versus 100 years ago we spent only 2 percent."
title: The feds delivered the mail back then, but not much else.

statement: "The RI Board of Elections has heard official testimony from Providence residents who claim to have witnessed known illegal aliens voting in local elections."
title: "Residents" means more than one

statement: Says opponent David Dewhurst is a "career politician."
title: Overlooking two thirds of adulthood

statement: "Polls now show a majority of Catholics favor marriage equality."
title: How often you go to mass impacts views

statement: "This is the first time in the history that we've had the raising of a debt limit also with spending cuts."
title: See 1997, Newt Gingrich and Bill Clinton

statement: Since 1965, the United States has spent "untold trillions" yet the poverty rate hasn’t budged.
title: Actually, the poverty rate has fallen, and plummeted for some groups

statement: "Harry Reid’s plan is basically giving the president a blank check."
title: Was speaking metaphorically

statement: "Our government has spent $2.6 million to teach Chinese prostitutes how to drink responsibly."
title: Phillips distorts purpose of study

statement: Says Republican state Sen. Alberta Darling offered "unqualified support" for a plan to end Medicare
title: She had kind words, but the plan doesn’t “end” Medicare

statement: "When I served as City Commissioner, we made great strides …we successfully fought for, and won, adding women and people of color to the Fire Bureau."
title: Hales had oversight and the bureau did diversify

statement: Says that when he was governor of Utah, he worked with the state Legislature to create a flat tax that "cut income taxes by 30 percent."
title: The new tax was flatter, but 30 percent cut is exaggeration

statement: Says Ohio Treasurer Josh Mandel "supports allowing the United States to default on its obligations."
title: Faulty logic lights the matches

statement: Michele Bachmann's legislative record is "offering failed amendments."
title: Failed bills, too

statement: Says "over 50 percent of U.S. job growth in June came" from Wisconsin.
title: The jobs news was good, but feds say adding it for this sort of comparison is bad

statement: Says stores will be barred from selling 100-watt light bulbs as of 2012.
title: Same light more efficiently

statement: "Recently we have seen our government debt grow by $3.4 trillion during the first 29 months of the Obama administration -- the equivalent of about $4 billion per day."
title: How much is Obama to blame?

statement: In Europe, "church attendance rates (are) in the single digits" because churches are supported by taxes.
title: Not a consistent pattern

statement: "The deficit was on track to top $1 trillion the year I took office."
title: Deficit was projected at $1.2 trillion, then Obama added to it

statement: "Thirty-four of the last 44 (debt ceiling increases) have been for less than a year. So, this notion that short-term is somehow the exception, it's actually the rule."
title: Congress has been shy about long-term committments

statement: Says Democratic recall opponent Shelly Moore "opposes any limit on taxes."
title: Moore wanted to avoid increase for poor and some seniors

statement: "The state of Georgia is near the bottom among states for SAT scores and graduation rates."
title: State brings up the rear with SAT scores and graduation rates

statement: Says Tim Pawlenty said in 2006, "The era of small government is over... the government has to be more proactive and more aggressive."
title: He said then that government had to control entrenched interests

statement: "The U.S. won't default, because default means that you don't pay your creditors. And it takes about 10 percent of the money that's coming in right now" to pay interest to bondholders.
title: A solution to the debt ceiling that's not as easy as it looks

statement: "Active duty males in the military are twice as likely to develop prostate cancer than their civilian counterparts."
title: Study examines diagnosis rates, doesn't explain cause

statement: The House passed "cut, cap and balance" with "bipartisan support."
title: Well, five Democratic votes out of 234

statement: "President Reagan did it (raised the debt ceiling) 18 times.  George W. Bush did it seven times."
title: Yes, but Obama opposed Bush

statement: Says state Sen. Randy Hopper, R-Fond du Lac, unlike typical taxpayers, "didn’t pay taxes"
title: When he didn’t pay, he didn’t owe

statement: "If you're from Guatemala and you are found illegally in Mexico, you are automatically jailed."
title: Incorrecto

statement: Says unemployment in Trenton is "twice as much as what we see in every other area of the state" and, as a result, "we have seen an increase in crime."
title: Crime is up, but unemployment’s not as high

statement: "When the Republicans were in charge, they actually expanded government health care with the prescription drug program."
title: Big money, big program -- from the GOP

statement: "Most countries have no debt ceiling."
title: Few countries limit borrowing precisely as the U.S. does

statement: "The nonpartisan CBO, Congressional Budget Office, has said that the No. 1 policy decision that brought us to the need to prevent the nation from defaulting on our debt for the first time in history were the Bush tax cuts in 2001 and 2003."
title: Not the kind of thing the CBO says

statement: The 2011-13 state budget "cuts overall funding for public schools by $1.6 billion"
title: Number far overstates the case, but it’s one way to look at it

statement: The Atlanta streetcar is expected to create 930 jobs during construction, totaling more than 5,600 jobs over the next 20 years.
title: It still won't.

statement: "This past (legislative) session, we passed out of the Legislature a resolution requiring Congress to pass a balanced-budget amendment to the (U.S.) Constitution."
title: Texas can't make Congress do diddly

statement: Says "the most dangerous time for children" is from "3 to 6 p.m., during which time juvenile crime rates triple"
title: Points deducted for use of dated data

statement: Says state Rep. Fred Clark (D-Baraboo) ran a red light and seriously injured a bicyclist.
title: The picture in the ad tells an accurate story

statement: "The average 401(k) in America of a person who's 60 years old is under $100,000."
title: Not just under, WAY under

statement: Says the state budget "doubled property tax credits for seniors and middle class New Jerseyans" and had "no tax increases for any New Jersey family for the second year in a row."
title: Tax credits dropped last year

statement: Says members of the military have sent him more campaign contributions than they’ve sent President Barack Obama and more than twice what they’ve sent other Republican presidential candidates.
title: Defenders for Paul

statement: Says Ronald Reagan "repeatedly talked about how irresponsible it would be to allow the full faith and credit of the United States to be impaired in any kind of way."
title: The Gipper said don't mess with our creditworthiness

statement: "A clause hidden in the Obamacare bill, which is now law, gives Obama the right to form a private army."
title: Only if they fight with tongue depressors

statement: Says "in the Legislature, (Mary Nolan) has been a party-line Democrat, showing a 100% track record in harmony with the American Civil Liberties Union."
title: She broke from party and ACLU very rarely

statement: Says Wisconsin Senate recall candidate Jessica King "voted to increase her pay with taxpayer dollars by 63 percent."
title: No and no

statement: "The only growth sector that we’ve had in the last two years in America is government growth."
title: Private sector saw gains

statement: "Federal law requires that hospitals treat people whether or not they can pay. So someone (who) doesn’t have health insurance --  they can go to the hospital and get free care."
title: Law only requires emergency stabilization

statement: "There’s pretty much no question that [the curfew ordinances] aren’t effective in either reducing crime or preventing harm to young people."
title: Lights out on teen curfews. Curfews popular, but useless, expert claims.

statement: "The firefighter and police officer pension system is not headed for bankruptcy, far from it. That’s because New Jersey first responders -- fire fighters and police officers -- have never missed making payments to the retirement system."
title: Bankruptcy doesn't mean zero balance

statement: Says that U.S. Rep. Allen West is "a constituent of mine."
title: The U.S. Constitution says it's okay

statement: Said his mother had to fight with health insurance companies for treatment because of a pre-existing condition.
title: Biography of Obama's mother reveals new details

statement: Florida Democrats "put my Social Security number and my wife's Employment Identification Number in a mail piece."

statement: Republican redistricting plans cut Democrat Nancy Nusbaum out of  "her state Senate district by a half a block."
title: It's right there on the GOP map

statement: Says the new Dodd-Frank financial law requires a 20 percent down payment to buy a house.
title: No such requirement

statement: Virginia state employees "pay nothing" toward their pensions.
title: He's signed bills that require workers to contribute to pensions

statement: "We jumped 11 places since beginning this year in terms of being job-friendly."
title: A catchier phrase than saying "We're No. 23"

statement: "Every president has raised the debt ceiling."

statement: "Dubious taxpayer-funded" stimulus spending -- Part II.
title: Pig roast goes up in flames

statement: Says this House processed and approved as many bills as previous Legislatures.
title: More like the lowest number in a decade

statement: "Since 2000, nearly 12 million Americans have slipped out of the middle class and into poverty."

statement: "Your tax dollars are not being used to sue you, the people."

statement: "The Florida Legislature has not filed a lawsuit to fight Amendments 5 and 6."

statement: "I did not vote to spend money to fight that (Amendment 6 redistricting) lawsuit."

statement: Says state Senate recall challenger Sandy Pasch voted "to cut school aid by nearly $300 million."
title: Federal stimulus money didn't offset a cut in state aid

statement: During his first year, President Obama said he "was going to visit Kim Jong-ll and Ahmadinejad and Assad and Chavez – the worst actors in the world."

statement: Says President Barack Obama’s "own economists say the stimulus cost $278K per job ‘created.’ "
title: Someone else's bad math

statement: "[L]ess than one-tenth of Atlanta's transportation needs are covered" in a referendum to levy a 1-cent sales tax.

statement: "Every time we've cut the capital gains tax, the economy has grown. Whenever we raise the capital gains tax, it's been damaged."

statement: Says that, unlike the U.S. Senate, "even the Libyan government, in the middle of a civil war, passed a budget on June 15, 2011"
title: Libya did pass a budget in June, but the comparison means little

statement: "I've created over 40,000 jobs."
title: He wasn't always a CEO

statement: "We have not had unemployment this high for this long since the Great Depression."
title: This Great Depression claim is, well, depressing

statement: "The State Election Board has issued nearly $275,000 in fines to violators of absentee ballot laws."
title: Election fines can be costly.

statement: "Fracturing or horizontally fracturing the shale to open up larger pockets of natural gas ... has been used for over 60 years and, as of 2009, over 80,000 wells have been fracked in Ohio."

statement: Says a new report proves the stimulus supported by N.J. Democrats cost $278,000 per job.
title: A popular talking point doesn't add up

statement: "The black unemployment rate (has) increased since the recovery has begun."
title: White, Hispanic, Asian unemployment eased. Black unemployment got worse.

statement: "Under our (2011-’13) budget, the average (Wisconsin) property taxpayer will save $700."
title: Misleading claim based on favorable assumptions

statement: Ninety percent of the job growth in Virginia has been in the private sector.
title: Statistics back his claim

statement: Georgia’s illegal-immigration legislation "simply follows existing federal law."
title: The federal law books don't entirely back up lawmaker's claim.

statement: "Sherrod Brown was just voted two years in a row the most liberal senator in the United States of America" and is more liberal than Sen. Bernie Sanders.
title: There's lots of liberalism to spread around

statement: Says Planned Parenthood provides about 140 visits for prenatal care in each state.
title: Mistaking clients for visits

statement: The $290 million structural surplus in the 2011-’13 Wisconsin budget is not real because it is based on the assumption that Congress will reinstate the estate tax.
title: Same method was used before -- and benefitted Democrats

statement: Says $500 billion in Medicare cuts are coming.
title: Actuary says they're savings

statement: "By any measure, New Jersey has one of the most segregated school systems in the country."
title: Divided, yes; but segregation?

statement: "Some criminals have learned how to spy on Americans, hacking into our home computers and looking out through the video camera attached to the screen."

statement: Says recent polls show Americans agree with Republicans that the federal debt ceiling should not be raised and the debt and deficit should be dealt with mostly by cutting spending.

statement: "The clear majority of Republican voters think that any deficit reduction package should have a balanced approach and should include some revenues."

statement: "Eighty percent of the American people support an approach (to federal budget problems) that includes revenues and includes cuts."
title: Not quite 80 percent, but most

statement: Says the U.S. borrows "42 cents of every dollar Washington spends today and about half of that comes from countries like China."

statement: Says Texas is the only state that exempts jet fuel from its state motor fuels tax.

statement: "95 percent of teachers and principals are not implicated in the [Atlanta Public Schools cheating scandal] report at all."

statement: Under Ryan plan, "those 54 and younger would receive the same kind of healthcare options now enjoyed by members of Congress."

statement: "POTUS’ economists: ‘Stimulus’ Has Cost $278,000 per job."
title: False in 140 characters or less

statement: "New Mexico is the second Hollywood" because of tax incentives for the film industry.
title: More like a supporting actor

statement: "Numerous studies have shown that these so-called right-to-work laws do not generate jobs and economic growth."
title: Research is mixed

statement: "Our country's got this huge debt, and (President Barack) Obama says raise taxes and keep spending more."
title: Ad is right on taxes, but Obama has made historic spending concessions

statement: Says a quote at the top of the redesigned website for the Department of Justice comes from a socialist who wanted to impose global common law.
title: Misinformed outrage over DOJ website

statement: Says state Sen. Sheila Harsdorf wants to "eliminate Medicare" as we know it.
title: Evidence is lacking

statement: "State agencies have not identified one single instance where groundwater has been damaged due to hydraulic fracking."
title: Links to drilling suspected, though

statement: House Bill 2301 never had a public hearing
title: The final bill did not

statement: Says for the first time in the history of the United States, the government cut taxes during wartime

statement: Social Security and other federal checks may not go out on Aug. 3 if the debt ceiling is not increased.

statement: Florida’s proposed Health Care Freedom Act "will allow Floridians to opt out of Obama’s govt. takeover of healthcare!"
title: The chances are slim, and slim

statement: "From now on, we have to pay the Russians $50 million an astronaut to send Americans to the space station"
title: It's even higher: $63 million

statement: Says scientists are "in dispute" over whether being gay is a choice.
title: Most agree that sexual orientation is fixed; it's behavior that's a choice

statement: "There's no scientific conclusion that (being gay) is genetic."
title: Scientists say genetic role in causing homosexuality is murky

statement: Says new GOP Wisconsin Assembly members "voted to take funding away from their public schools in their districts to give it to private Milwaukee voucher schools."
title: Milwaukee Public Schools may be hurt, but studies say not so for out-state districts

statement: "There are 30,000 people that have been killed with seat belts."

statement: Since President Obama took office, "2 million jobs. Gone."
title: But up 1 million over the last year

statement: "The [Georgia] General Assembly took away the Atlanta Board of Education’s oversight of the superintendent."
title: Long's claim short on important details.

statement: "As we've seen that federal support for states diminish, you've seen the biggest job losses in the public sector -- teachers, police officers, firefighters losing their jobs."

statement: "I sponsored and was the co-sponsor of the only legislation that ever passed that had E-Verify provisions in it back in 2010 when I served in the Legislature."

statement: "A recent study revealed that, across the nation, taxes would have to be increased by an average of $1,300 a year just to support the currently unsustainable public employee pension systems. In Florida, that dollar figure translates to $813 a year."
