statement: For people in the top 1 percent for income, "your effective tax burden is in the low 20s, the lowest it’s been in decades and decades and decades -- lower than somebody who might make substantially less money."
title: Low, but not that low

statement: Because of Democratic tax hikes, New Jersey ended a decade with fewer private sector jobs for the first time in recorded history.
title: Don’t forget the recession

statement: Slim Jims "just recently" cost 99 cents but now cost $2.69.
title: Where's the beef on this claim?

statement: "There are actually half a million fewer government employees now than there were when (President Barack) Obama took office."
title: A bump in federal workers was more than cancelled out by losses at state, local levels

statement: "Our crime rate continues to plummet."
title: Dropping, yes; plummeting, no

statement: Says legislative debate of airport pat-down procedures initiated federal changes in security procedures.
title: Grounded

statement: Says U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown is responsible for "over $14 trillion in debt."
title: No one person is responsible for Washington's workings

statement: Former Atlanta Public Schools Superintendent Beverly Hall left the school district "significantly better than she found it."
title: What about that cheating scandal?

statement: "In our proposal, we would have expanded school aid across the board … Governor Christie slashed school aid in this budget, preferring instead to extend a tax break for millionaires over funding in the classroom."
title: Even with cuts, aid is up over last year

statement: Says many public-employee unions falsely told their Wisconsin members his budget-repair bill sought 12 percent to 13 percent of their incomes for health insurance premiums.
title: No evidence unions embellished the impact

statement: "Mitt Romney is the first Massachusetts politician to run for president and not win the New Hampshire primary in a generation."
title: By most definitions of a generation

statement: By the end of his first term, President Obama will have added as much debt as all the prior 43 presidents combined.
title: By most measurements

statement: Says the average government worker won't be impacted in the first two years under the reform of state health benefits.
title: Increases start in year two

statement: "Dubious taxpayer-funded stimulus projects in Rhode Island include … $250,000 to provide digital television to the state’s inmate population."

statement: "We’re losing almost 6,000 state jobs."
title: Say bye-bye to 5,727 positions

statement: "Fifty-one percent -- that is, a majority of American households -- paid no income tax in 2009. Zero. Zip. Nada."
title: No doubt. Nada.

statement: "China owns more of our bonds than do Americans."

statement: Rhode Island spends "52 percent more per capita on human service programs than the national average."

statement: Newt Gingrich’s presidential campaign has "exactly the same" challenges as Ronald Reagan’s successful 1980 bid.

statement: "This governor has cut funding repeatedly for people who have AIDS, who need drugs to save their life."

statement: "Let’s say (Republicans) take away half of our delegates. They’re worth more than Iowa’s, New Hampshire’s and almost South Carolina’s combined."

statement: Says that when President Bill Clinton raised the top tax rates to levels now proposed by Obama, the country experienced significant job growth.
title: Yes, but was it a cause and effect?

statement: "Young veterans have a higher unemployment rate than people who didn’t serve."

statement: "We have provided at least 16 tax cuts to small businesses."
title: He did, though some small companies may also face tax hikes

statement: Forty percent of union members voted Republican in 2008.
title: Historically speaking, McCain did well in union households

statement: "Ohio currently ranks 50th out of all states in income growth."
title: 50 years of slow growth

statement: Says car insurance rates have decreased since about a decade ago because of market-based solutions that attracted more auto insurers to New Jersey.
title: Giving credit where credit is due

statement: Housing prices dropped for the 30 months prior to Barack Obama taking office, "and they have stabilized, they've been about flat since the president came in."
title: Stable compared to the housing freefall, anyway

statement: "Forty percent of the Fortune 500 were started either by immigrants or children of immigrants."

statement: Says Gov. Scott Walker’s budget "includes tax breaks for corporations and the rich that will cost the state of Wisconsin taxpayers $2.3 billion over the next decade."
title: The numbers are on the money, but some facts shaded by loaded language

statement: "Under Gov. Rick Perry’s leadership [Texas] has created more jobs over the last decade than the rest of the states combined."
title: Mislabels a statistic

source: Better Austin Today Political Action Committee
statement: Says that under City Council Member Randi Shade, Austin had the "highest city debt per person in Texas."
title: Off the mark several ways

statement: From 1947 to 1979, family incomes for rich, middle-income and poor Americans grew about the same rate. But since 1979, incomes for rich families have grown much faster.
title: A striking pattern borne out in the statistics

statement: A year since the "Recovery Summer," there has been been "a fall, winter and spring of no recovery."
title: Anemic recovery, but recovery, nonetheless

statement: U.S. Reps. John Barrow and Sanford Bishop and their fellow Democrats "went on a spending spree and now their credit card is maxed out."
title: Congressmen are keeping their eyes on the federal credit card

statement: Says U.S. House opponent Michael Williams does not live in and has never voted in the congressional district he’s seeking to represent.
title: Homestead since '95, voted then too

statement: "Only the State of New York spends more money on Medicaid than the State of New Jersey."
title: Eight states lead NJ in Medicaid spending

statement: Says that President Obama said, "Nobody made these guys go to war. ... Now they whine about bearing the costs of their choice?"
title: Chain e-mail lies to vets

statement: "You see a whole bunch of Korean cars here in the United States, and you don't see any American cars in Korea."
title: Yes, but categories not clear cut

statement: "Voting in the wrong precinct led to over 14,000 registered voters statewide to lose their vote in 2008."

statement: Says $6 billion projected to accumulate in the state’s rainy day fund is already used.
title: Maybe in two years

statement: "One of the reasons that Budweiser stayed in New Jersey is the money they got from RGGI to put solar on their roof to save on their energy costs."
title: This Bud’s not for Jeff Tittel

statement: "Voted the ‘best specialty plate in America’"
title: Taking too much license

statement: Two years ago we had "the largest structural deficit ever in Wisconsin."
title: Wrong by seven years and one political party

statement: Says the 2011-13 state budget eliminates the structural deficit "for the first time in decades."
title: It’s gone, but the record book doesn’t go quite that far back

statement: Says that in 2009, Jon Huntsman "said that the Recovery Act wasn't large enough and as governor he asked for $14.4 billion in federal stimulus funds. Now he's saying that he never supported it."

statement: Gov. Chris Christie owes the state money "for amenities like extra Gorgonzola cheese for his staff on these trips."

statement: "If you look at our tax mix, the share of corporate revenues as a percentage of our overall revenue mix has declined by about half over the last 30 years."
title: True in '09, but not other recent years

statement: "Rick Scott has destroyed over 100,000 jobs."
title: At least not yet

statement: "In May we generated more jobs than all the rest of the country combined: 28,000 jobs in May for the state, 54,000 for the entire country."

statement: "Since I took office, we’ve created 76,800 jobs."
title: But who should get credit?

statement: "My husband and I have never gotten a penny of money from the farm."

statement: "The Federal Register - which houses all Washington regulations - is 34,000 pages in length and weighs in at more than 340 pounds."

statement: Says Wisconsin’s 2011-13 state budget contains "no fee increases"
title: No fee increases – unless you count new fees and the fees that go up

statement: Ethanol reduced gas prices by 89 cents per gallon in 2010, and if ethanol disappeared, gas prices could rise by as much as 92 percent.

statement: Says President Barack Obama’s overturning of the Mexico City Policy means federal tax dollars can be used "to fund abortion all over the world."

statement: Georgia’s illegal immigration crackdown laws should be called the "Brown Codes" because of their similarity to the "Black Codes" governing blacks after the Civil War.

statement: "Creeping defense commitments in (the Middle East) and globally now consume over half the U.S. discretionary budget annually."

statement: Says that as a gubernatorial candidate, Chris Christie "promised no school cuts."

statement: "Protesters caused $7.5 million in damage to the Wisconsin State House"

statement: Says the 2012-13 state budget "leaves $6 billion in a rainy day fund."
title: Punts on $6 billion in costs too

statement: "Only seven of 18 federal food assistance programs have been associated with positive health and nutrition outcomes, while the remaining 11 have not been effective."

statement: Says President Obama "has fired more cruise missiles than all other Peace Prize winners combined."
title: Correct, none fired by the Dalai Lama

statement: Says he can’t release his internal affairs record because there are Attorney General guidelines in place protecting it.
title: He could if he wanted to

statement: "What I have done -- and this is unprecedented ... is I've said to each agency ... 'look at regulations that are already on the books and if they don't make sense, let's get rid of them.'"

statement: "If you're a … wealthy CEO or a … hedge fund manager in America right now, your taxes are … lower than they've been since the 1950s."

statement: Says President Barack Obama said that if he doesn’t turn the economy around after three years in office, he’ll be a one-term president.
title: A frequent talking point with a strong basis in reality

statement: "The American people don't want us to raise taxes."
title: People do like tax increases on the wealthy

statement: "For every dollar we invest in Head Start, we get $5 to $7 back into our economy."

statement: "On the day of the New Hampshire primary in 1980, the top 13 people of Ronald Reagan’s staff quit."

statement: Says states that passed anti-illegal-immigrant legislation also had few Hispanic legislators.
title: Most states have few

statement: "The top 1 percent of income earners pay 40 percent of all state income taxes, and those at the bottom pay little or nothing."

statement: "We do not want to raise anybody's tax rates. That's never been on the table."
title: In April, Clyburn and his caucus voted to end Bush tax cuts for the rich

statement: "There is no $30 million pot of money" for redistricting issues, including defending redistricting lawsuits. "Your tax dollars are not being spent on anything like that."

statement: Gov. Bob McDonnell launched a "raid on public education to pay for roads."

statement: "We've got more revenue than we ever have."

statement: "Rep. Jim Renacci’s plan to end Medicare also puts nursing home care for 3,000 seniors in the district in immediate jeopardy."

statement: "(Birmingham, Ala.) is the cradle of the civil rights movement."
title: Sorry Al, Montgomery has greater civil rights claim, experts say.

statement: "Since 2004, there have been some 1,300 attacks (on rail targets). Four thousand people have died. Thousands of injuries."

statement: "We are one of the most expensive [bus] rides in New England."
title: A pretty fare claim

statement: "Under Barack Obama the last two years, the number of federal limousines for bureaucrats has increased 73 percent."

statement: "If you threw a barbecue yesterday for the Memorial weekend, it was 29 percent more expensive than last year because Barack Obama's policies have led to groceries going up 29 percent."

statement: "The president released all of the oil from the Strategic Oil Reserve."

statement: In the first 24 to 36 hours of the operation in Libya, "you saw $115 million go downrange because a Tomahawk cruise missile is a little over $1 million each."

statement: "Hispanic unemployment has been ticking down from an all-time high of 13.9 percent because of the policies we’ve implemented."
title: It has zig-zagged lower, but not from all-time high

statement: There is a Republican "plan to end Medicare."
title: Is there no end to this False claim?

statement: A "substantial number" of probationers participating in a pilot project to ease the farm labor shortage are able to "finish the work."

statement: Virginia spends $400,000 on abstinence programs while losing $2.5 million in federal funds due to Gov. Bob McDonnell’s "political agenda."

statement: "The state’s tax burden has, according to census figures released today, cost our state another 190,000 residents in 2009."

statement: The WIC program "is an incredibly cost effective program, serving nearly 10 million Americans each year and costing less than $100 per person. In my district, more than 18 percent of residents suffer from food insecurity and depend on WIC to make ends meet."
title: 4 Falses in 46 seconds.

source: Better Austin Today Political Action Committee
statement: "Under Randi Shade," Austin has "had the highest cost of living of any large Texas city."
title: Not lately, not always and not a council member's fault

statement: "Since June 2009, about 48 percent of all the jobs created in America were in Texas."
title: Not counting jobs added in 19 states

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie’s "poll ratings have been going up."
title: Surveys say … ratings aren’t going up

statement: Says Rick Perry of Texas was "the governor who relied most on stimulus funds to close his state’s budget deficit in 2010."

statement: In the Republican presidential debate in New Hampshire, none of the candidates mentioned the "middle class" or "education."
title: Lots of discussion of middle class, but without that term

statement: Says President Barack Obama promised he would cut the deficit in half, but instead will at least double it.
title: He's confusing debt and deficit

statement: Phil Puckett "voted no on sending the EPA a message that they’ve gone too far not once, but twice."
title: An absurd, and wrong, claim

statement: "Vern Buchanan. His old business was caught illegally funneling over $60,000 in campaign donations to Buchanan to influence his election."
title: Did Buchanan know? Who knows!

statement: Vern Buchanan "has been completely exonerated" in a Federal Election Commission action.
title: Not quite what FEC said

statement: Says critics who say he cut Medicaid are wrong; his budget added $1.2 billion to the program
title: A case of subtraction by addition

statement: "Providence is one of the busiest fire departments for its relative size in the country."
title: Ablaze with activity

statement: Every 10th dollar spent by the Social Security Administration on its program for the poor is "waste, or fraud, they can’t validate that the people should have gotten it," totaling about $8 billion a year.

statement: Multnomah County’s food action plan "clearly plans to disrupt the free market system in terms of food choices making it harder and more expensive for many residents to eat their food of choice."
title: Too much to swallow

statement: "Seventy of Ohio's 88 counties now have more than 25 percent of their residents eligible for emergency food."
title: In one county it's more than 50 percent

statement: "(New Jersey Network) is the only news station which covers New Jersey government."
title: More channels are out there

statement: The U.S. is spending "one out of every six Defense Department dollars on Afghanistan."
title: Afghanistan is costly

statement: Says Miami-Dade mayoral candidate Julio Robaina "has the highest salary among Florida mayors. More than $260,000."
title: $260,000 refers to salary and expenses

statement: Says that Sherrod Brown "voted to cut Medicare by over $500 billion in order to fund government-run health care."
title: Oft-repeated, health care claim isn't getting any better

statement: After not having any foreign trade offices overseas for the past decade, New Jersey opened offices in Shanghai and London in the past six months, and has seen an 18 percent increase in exports.

statement: When Mitt Romney was governor, Massachusetts ranked 47th out of 50 states in job creation.

statement: "Two thirds of the people in Wisconsin strongly disagree with this idea of permanently taking away people’s rights to collective bargaining."

statement: "Most of the state budget isn't for state government doing things. ... 85 percent of the state budget is transferred to local communities for delivery of service."

statement: "As the Democrats finally maxed out their government spending credit card Monday, Kurt Schrader continued to stand with his party leaders in failing to offer any viable long-term solution."
title: Not fair and not true

statement: Says a Republican-drawn map of proposed U.S. House districts for Texas "gerrymanders more than nine million Latinos in Texas to make sure that we have no more electoral opportunity than we did in 1991."
title: Same ol' power share

statement: The ACLU didn't call for an investigation (of the Newark police department), they called for an immediate federal monitor.
title: What investigation?

statement: "Almost 10 percent of Canadians came to visit Florida last year ... (Canadians) buy 7.4 percent of our homes in the state."
title: The governor speaks Canadian

statement: "The right-to-work states are creating a lot more jobs today than the heavily unionized states."
title: Newt's numbers right on jobs in right-to-work states

statement: "When the union says I want to eliminate tenure, that’s not true."

statement: "Who are the most consistently misinformed media viewers? … Fox viewers, consistently, every poll."
title: The data is much more contradictory

statement: Says former Miami-Dade Mayor Carlos Alvarez and current mayoral candidate Carlos Gimenez  both drove fancy European cars at taxpayer expense.

statement: "President Obama and liberal former DNC Chairman Tim Kaine’s $787 billion stimulus failed to create jobs."

statement: "Janice Hahn hired hard-core gang members with taxpayer money to be 'gang-intervention specialists.' She even helped them get out of jail, so they could rape and kill again."
title: She supported the program, but didn't hire gang members

statement: State Sen. Alberta Darling "voted to add more than $1 billion in additional spending" while cutting programs such as education and health care
title: Much of the spending was welcomed by Dems, but the charge is on point

statement: Says 11 percent of the nation’s fatal car crashes in 2009 were attributed to distracted driving.
title: 16 percent, according to the U.S. Department of Transportation

statement: Muslims tried to use Sharia law to influence court decisions in New Jersey and Oklahoma
title: Cain in state of confusion

statement: Says tax revenue was lower than expected in May and "that's basically a clear indication the governor's counselors are probably right -- that we are still not out of the woods yet."

statement: Says Ocean Spray is moving its Bordentown processing facility to Pennsylvania largely because of costs associated with the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative.
title: This argument is out of juice

statement: "As soon as Chris Christie was governor, he gave tax cuts to millionaires."

statement: "A couple of hundred American cities are infested by members of the Mexican cartels."
title: The feds say 230 and growing

statement: "The tax on job creating businesses is 35 percent in the United States, second worst in the entire world."
title: He's close, but off by a bit

statement: The Medford Water Commission was fined $279,000 for dumping plain drinking water into a stream.
title: Chlorinated, fish-killing water, that is

statement: Says Allen West violated federal law by scuba diving with U.S. flag.

statement: Says an alternative to Social Security that operates in Galveston County, Texas, has meant that participants will "retire with a whole lot more money" than under Social Security.

statement: "We are number one in the world when it comes to energy resources. ... The Russians are second; Saudi Arabia is number three."
title: Coal makes U.S. king

statement: "Creating 25 jobs in Umatilla County has the same impact as 500 jobs in the metro region."
title: 25 is not 500 but they do have a big effect

statement: "The president came in and campaigned against me 12 times."
title: He keeps saying it, but the Truth-O-Meter isn't budging

statement: Says the state budget includes spending on commercials for Fortune 500 companies.
title: Action!

statement: "Do this research … watch how much crime picks up if you take away [football]."
title: No football = more crime? A penalty on that claim.

statement: Democratic tax hikes led $70 billion of wealth to leave New Jersey between 2004 and 2008, and mainly relocate to Florida, North Carolina, Virginia and Pennsylvania.
title: Higher taxes aren’t chasing everybody away

statement: "Obamacare takes $500 billion out of Medicare and funds Obamacare."
title: Money isn't really moved here

statement: "This is the slowest job recovery since Hoover."
title: It's bad, but several other recoveries were weaker

statement: Milwaukee’s police chief can fire officers "for basically no cause."
title: Actually, state law specifies what reasons are grounds for dismissal

statement: Says George LeMieux "falsely attacked Marco Rubio."
title: Criticized Rubio's tax-swap plan

statement: "The Democrat-led Senate has failed to pass a budget for 750 days ... Senate Democrats have neglected one of their most basic responsibilities."
title: Cookie-cutter sound bite still leaves out important details

statement: Says he's signed a pledge not to raise taxes four times.
title: Five times counting repeats

statement: "The Public Employee Retirement System is making more millionaires than the Oregon state lottery."
title: But for one you have to work 30 years

statement: Gov. Chris Christie caused a 4.1 percent increase in property taxes in 2010, marking the highest increase since 2007.
title: Governor cut state aid, but recession’s not his fault

statement: "It’s just crazy that the government will ... make it illegal to use the old [incandescent] bulbs."
title: Light on the truth

statement: "Anywhere in the world, when someone uses a mobile phone, e-mail, the Internet or GPS, they are enjoying the benefits of the American miracle."
title: Foreign researchers also chipped in

statement: The Medicare drug program "resulted in the program coming in 40 percent under budget. ... And the reason it was, is because the design was right."
title: Under budget, but how much and why are disputed

statement: Says President Barack Obama "has put (up) a stop sign … against oil drilling, against any kind of exploration offshore or in Alaska."
title: At most, a "reduce your speed" sign

statement: "A large number of the uninsured earn $75,000 or more a year."
title: UPDATE: Census numbers aren't clear cut

statement: Says George LeMieux "even compared Marco Rubio to Barack Obama."
title: A hollow attack

statement: "The cost-of-living increase in Social Security is tied to wage inflation."
title: No, it's tied to consumer prices

statement: Protesters "attacked" the group’s headquarters with "graffiti on the sidewalk" and "stenciled images … smeared on the building and statue."
title: Overheated language obscures the fact no permanent damage was done

statement: Says the state’s new collective bargaining law effectively eliminates police unions' ability to negotiate.
title: Management gets the final word

statement: "For a young man or woman who is entering the ninth grade in Newark this year, they have a 29 percent graduation rate."
title: Statistic omits group of students

statement: Then-Sen. Barack Obama "refused to raise the debt ceiling because he said President Bush had failed in leadership."
title: He said it

statement: An amendment inserted by lawmakers into the state budget "exempts scientific researchers from all state animal cruelty laws."
title: That's exactly what amendment does, but federal laws still provide some protection

statement: If today's economy was rebounding at the rate of the "Reagan recovery," it would have created the equivalent of 25 million new jobs and raised federal revenue by $800 billion a year.
title: Right on jobs, wrong on revenues

statement: "China owns about 29 percent of (the U.S.) debt.''
title: U.S. residents and institutions own the majority of U.S. debt

statement: "There was a recent report out that the premiums for Medicare and the payroll withholdings are only paying about half the program. So it is not financially solvent."
title: A stretch to call it insolvent

statement: "The CBO, the Congressional Budget Office has said that Obamacare will kill 800,000 jobs."
title: CBO's take was much more mixed than that

statement: "Earlier this year, the head of the Congressional Budget Office testified before Congress that implementation of Obamacare would cost 800,000 jobs."
title: Not the job cuts you'd think

statement: "Taxpayers pay for roughly 45 percent of all births in Wisconsin! And 60 percent of the births in Milwaukee!!!"
title: Medicaid does pick up the tab in many cases

statement: Rick Perry "has never lost an election and remains the only person to have won the Texas governorship three times in landslide elections."
title: Two others when rock was young

statement: Workers who pick produce in Georgia’s fields can make $12 to $18 an hour.
title: The pay is decent, the work is hard and few make the top pay Black touted

statement: The budget currently being debated "significantly decreases the use of one-time resources."
title: A fraction of what was in the last budget

statement: Says Gov. Chris Christie's decision to close the Elizabeth MVC "saved no money."
title: Dollars and sense

statement: The Obama administration has cut taxes on small businesses 17 times.
title: There were some tax hikes too

statement: "We have unemployment that rivals the Great Depression."
title: It's bad, but not that bad

statement: The average person "will pay $6,000 more a year" under Rep. Paul Ryan's Medicare proposal.
title: This Ryan doubts its a path to prosperity

statement: "We already have $23 billion worth of debt."
title: Scott focused on debt numbers

statement: Says 1,000 World War II veterans die every day.
title: More like 700

statement: "We have the highest per-pupil cost in the country."
title: Jersey goes to head of the (spending) class

statement: An iron ore mine in northern Wisconsin could operate for 100 years and generate billion of dollars in economic activity.
title: There’s plenty of ore to be dug up, if permits are approved and the demand for steel remains high

statement: Says the Austin City Council "may give $4 million a year to subsidize a race track."
title: Banks for bucks

statement: Because Gov. Chris Christie vetoed a 30-bill job creation package, "New Jersey ranks 50th in the nation in job creation."
title: Vetoes occurred after rankings in question

statement: "Ten percent of violent deaths in the U.S. each year are due to strangulation."
title: Only among women; only if suicides are excluded

statement: Says opponent Kathie Tovo "believes that Austin invests too much in the cops, firefighters and paramedics that protect our families and neighborhoods."
title: Contracts unsustainable, Tovo said

statement: Commercial buses in the United States have "a stellar safety record, a safety record that exceeds that of any other commercial mode or surface transportation mode."
title: Safer than trains and automobiles, but not planes

statement: "The average unemployed American has been out of work for almost 40 weeks."
title: However you measure it, joblessness is at or near record lengths

statement: "Obamacare cuts $500 billion in future Medicare funding in order to fund the new constitutionally questionable government mandate, even going so far as to scuttle Medicare's most popular (and successful) part, Medicare Advantage."
title: Overstates impact of the law

statement: Non-defense discretionary spending has increased "by over 80 percent in the last two years."
title: Time to check his math

statement: "When I became president and CEO of Godfather’s Pizza, it was supposed to go bankrupt . . . We turned it around with common-sense business principles."
title: Pizza man makes good

statement: Says U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan promised to "end health care for our seniors."
title: Ryan would change Medicare, not end health care

statement: Roughly 700 Georgians die needlessly each year because they are too far from a trauma center.
title: Numbers too low to be True

statement: Says Rick Perry said there’s an administrator for every teacher in Texas public schools.
title: "Idiocy" equals "Didn't happen"

statement: Says Panasonic stayed in New Jersey because of the Business Retention and Relocation Assistance Grant (BRRAG) program.
title: Not much to BRRAG about

statement: Out of 150,000 tenured teachers in the last 10 years, only 17 have been dismissed for incompetence.
title: State records give gov passing grade

statement: "Every year the state loses 8,000-10,000 acres of land in bear country."
title: Numbers don’t add up in hunting areas

statement: Says six of the state’s 58 family planning centers had to close because of Gov. Chris Christie’s budget cuts.
title: It's six for six

statement: Commerce Secretary nominee John Bryson "appears to endorse world government."
title: Evidence beyond flimsy

statement: By advocating new requirements for voters to show ID cards at the polls, Republicans "want to literally drag us all the way back to Jim Crow laws."
title: Voter ID laws are controversial, but Jim Crow was far worse

statement: "We've seen 115,000 jobs created in the American auto industry since GM and Chrysler emerged from bankruptcy."
title: Numbers add up, but predate GM's emergence

statement: "The (national) debt really added up $75 trillion in 2010 and is on track to hit $99 trillion this year."
title: Not even close

statement: "Rep. Robert Hurt voted again today to end Medicare and raise health care costs for Virginia seniors."
title: Update: Now with new information on costs for current seniors

statement: "Studies show that people that are on welfare are higher users of drugs than people not on welfare."
title: Studies are imperfect, reach different conclusions

statement: "Kasich’s budget increases state spending from $50.5 billion to $55.6 billion. This is the second largest, two-year spending increase in Ohio history."
title: Hey, big spenders!

statement: "Rhode Island continues to have the highest rates of substance abuse in the country."
title: No substantive abuse of the truth

statement: The budget for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau "is only about 1 percent of the amount banks generate just from late fees and overdraft fees."
title: It's even less than 1 percent

statement: Says that Sarah Palin and Craig Huey "would ban a woman's right to choose in every case"
title: Palin and Huey pretty similar on abortion

statement: Says Craig Huey called Planned Parenthood a "murder mill."
title: On his website, he owns it

statement: Says the federal government threatened to impose a no-fly zone in Texas if state legislators bar airport security officials from performing pat-downs.
title: Please check your sovereignty at the gate

statement: "For every $1 spent on mitigation, $4 in post-storm cleanup and rebuilding is saved."
title: True -- for FEMA projects

statement: Assaults on Wisconsin law enforcement officers are up 224 percent statewide since 2005
title: Numbers check out, though the rise isn’t statewide — it’s driven by Milwaukee County

statement: "I did not say that I would not have them [Muslims] in my Cabinet."
title: Oh yes he did. Three times.

statement: Accuses President Barack Obama of making contradictory claims about efforts to kill Osama bin Laden in 2008 and 2011.
title: E-mail is based on six fabricated quotes

statement: Planned Parenthood "raked in more than $300 million in profits over the past four years."
title: A positive balance sheet doesn't equal profit

statement: "We have the best schools in the United States."
title: Nash claim grades incomplete.

statement: Says the Ohio Consumers’ Council office employs 74 lawyers and that the funding them is wasteful duplication.
title: Too many lawyers by five fold

statement: "Part of his ride was to warn the British that were already there that, 'Hey, you're not going to succeed.' "
title: "Warning" came after Revere was captured by British

statement: "Over the last 15 months, we've added more than 2 million jobs in the private sector. That's far in excess of what it was in the comparable period after the last recession."
title: Better than Bush recovery, but middling overall

statement: "Manufacturing is having its best employment year in almost 15 years."
title: Manufacturing jobs have gone up, after a long, steep slide

statement: "We had (a bill) in Florida where we now are prohibiting doctors to talk -- particularly pediatricians -- to talk to their patients about gun safety in the home."
title: This shot misses the target

statement: U.S. Rep. Ron Kind, D-Wis., "and his fellow Democrats went on a spending spree and now their credit card is maxed out"
title: Democrats and Republicans both rang up charges

statement: "We in the Democratic Party had no input into the locations of these hearings, nor did we have input into the process."
title: GOP not playing fair on redistricting? Claim not exactly right.

statement: Says this month’s special session will cost the state $27,300 a day just for legislators’ daily living expenses.
title: $150 for 182 lawmakers every day of the session

statement: "We’re the seventh highest taxed state in America. And that’s not just state, it’s local as well."
title: Out-of-date data taxes this claim's accuracy

statement: Michigan and Massachusetts raised their bottle deposit and "could no longer afford the program because the redemptions were so high there was no profit in there."
title: That's all news to them

statement: Says Wisconsin state Senate President Michael Elllis (R-Neenah) broke Senate rules during debate on a photo ID bill for voters.
title: The debate rules were changed for that day — within the rules — and all knew about it

statement: "Every time you buy an airline ticket, the federal government runs a background check on you."
title: No one's quizzing the neighbors

statement: The Central Falls School system "spent $100,000 on a time clock."
title: Clocked by the facts

statement: Says public education will get more money in 2012-13 though lawmakers cut $15 billion in overall spending.
title: Never mind cost of new students

statement: Oil companies are able to sell oil that costs no more to produce today than it did one year ago.
title: Even ExxonMobil agrees

statement: Virginia is "headed towards another surplus this year, unlike most states."
title: He's not counting missed pension payments

statement: Democratic Reps. Cicilline, Boswell, Carnahan and Critz "demanded that Congress vote to increase the nation’s debt limit without making any spending cuts."
title: Wasn't a vote on spending cuts

statement: "A few months into office, (President Barack Obama) traveled around the globe to apologize for America."
title: Wrong before, and even more wrong now

statement: The 2009 stimulus bill "failed to get people back to work."
title: Although unenmployment is high, the stimulus has created jobs

statement: "No one thought we could get a bipartisan bill (Medicaid) passed. We did in the Florida Senate."
title: It takes two to make a thing bipartisan

statement: "We're going to be looking at $8 billion a day that we're going to be pouring into foreign countries in order to import that make-up fuel that we're going to need to take the place of what we could have gotten out of the gulf."
title: Math doesn't add up

statement: We are looking at "150,000 barrels (of oil) per day less next year, and 200,000 barrels per day less being able to be developed from the gulf the year after" because of the moratorium on new drilling enacted by the Obama administration.
title: Natural decline more of a factor than moratorium

statement: "We have seized more currency, more drugs, more outbound arms in the past year than any year in our country’s history."
title: Recently, yes. But that's not saying much

statement: Says "for the first time ever," Texas lawmakers are not funding student population growth.
title: Endowment aid continuing

statement: "We are only inches away from ceasing to be a free market economy."
title: Marx wouldn't be happy with the U.S., circa 2011

statement: "It is a greater crime to have an untagged alligator than to host an open house party (for kids)."
title: Sobering fact: Illegal gator killing can lead to more prison time than hosting underage drinking party

statement: "Gerry Connolly and his fellow Democrats went on a spending spree and now their credit card is maxed out."
title: Debt spending a rare bipartisan feat

statement: "We went from a $5.6 trillion surplus that George Bush inherited to over ... $11-plus trillion debt when George Bush left office."
title: A talking point that needs more qualifiers

statement: Wisconsin’s technical college graduates "have a higher employment rate and starting salaries" than four-year college graduates nationwide.
title: Apples + oranges leaves just a seed of truth

statement: "Some neighborhood schools are closing."
title: Some is seven

statement: The city’s 30 percent set aside for affordable housing in urban renewal areas is calculated citywide -- not district by district
title: It's the exception, not the rule

statement: Medicare "only has about 50 percent of it paid for by either premiums or payroll taxes, and the rest is deficit spending ... or debt spending."
title: Not necessarily deficit spending

statement: "Look at the debt that has been accumulated in the last two years. It's more debt under this president than all those other presidents combined."
title: Under Obama, debt has piled up, but not that much

statement: Says that PolitiFact Ohio confirms that Betty Sutton "maxed out federal debt"
title: 'Cherry-picking' and 'selective' were our descriptive words

statement: House Republicans required the use of Styrofoam cups in House cafeterias that are "part of Koch Industries."
title: He's whistlin' Dixie

statement: The Medicare proposal by Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis., would "allow insurance companies to deny you coverage and drop you for pre-existing conditions."
title: Budget resolution specifically bars the practice

statement: "Annual water usage in 2010 was actually down more than 18 percent from usage in 2006."
title: Water use claim not all wet

statement: "Betty Sutton and her fellow Democrats went on a spending spree and now their credit card is maxed out."
title: Cherry-picked claim ignores some key purchases

statement: "In the late 1980s, the U.S. was nearly the lowest-taxed nation in the world, and a quarter century later we're nearly the highest."
title: Right on the 1980s, but wrong about today

statement: It is estimated that Arizona "has lost more than $100 million in hospitality industry revenues since passage of the Arizona immigration laws."
title: The estimates are a little different

statement: "If you look at the benefits and wages of recorded federal employees, they far outstrip the market rates of the private sector."
title: Even in same professions, federal workers make more

statement: "Obesity kills 34 children per hour."
title: About 34 adults die per hour, according to an outdated estimate

statement: "Most of your serial killers, most of your people who commit domestic violence, they start off by abusing animals."
title: There is an association, but it's not "most."

statement: "Obama-Nelson economic record: Job creation ... at slowest post-recession rate since Great Depression."
title: Depends if you count recession months

statement: "Abraham Lincoln (once) jumped out of a window in the Illinois Legislature in order to deny a quorum."
title: The records are dusty, but clear

statement: Says the Obama Administration has fulfilled all of Texas’ requests for fire management assisting grants.
title: 27 of 27, but no major disaster declaration

statement: "There's a 1.5 percent to 2 percent overhead in Medicare. The insurance companies have a 20 percent to 30 percent overhead."
title: There's a difference, but not quite that big

statement: Says the Obama administration approved a major disaster declaration for Oklahoma in 2009, when nine of the state’s 77 counties burned for "about three days," while Texas wildfires have been burning for longer without such a declaration.
title: But it granted 27 fire management assistance grants

statement: "We are in the bottom 10 in dollars in the classroom and the top 10 in dollars in the bureaucracy and red tape."
title: Data getting old, but still appears pretty much on point

statement: "Without ethanol, gas prices would be at least 15% higher. With gas at four bucks, that means you’re saving 12 bucks on a 20 gallon fill up."
title: It holds down pump prices, but you also pay up from another pocket

statement: Says that in the last five years, Texas "created more jobs than all other states combined."
title: Perspectives on "job creation" vary

statement: Members of Congress "receive full pay retirement after serving one term."
title: Minimum service: 5 years. Maximum pay: 80 percent.

statement: Under Gov. Bob McDonnell, more jobs have been lost than created in Southside and Southwest Virginia.
title: More people are working both regions

statement: Says Rick Perry is "the guy that tracked" down Democratic legislators who fled Texas in 2003.
title: Credit belongs to a newspaper

statement: Says he vetoed $250,000 from the budget for a program to learn how to catch rainwater.
title: Idea was to save on water costs

statement: The Democratic health care law "added 12 years of solvency to Medicare."
title: A new report reduces that estimate

statement: Says state budget deal between Texas House and Senate leaders "funds nursing homes, our public schools and universities and provides financial aid for college students."
title: Areas mostly getting less state funding

statement: Says the United States is "the Saudi Arabia of coal."
title: Cantor's oil comparison not so slippery.

statement: Says Republican-approved changes to "make it more difficult to participate in Ohio elections include reducing in-person early voting from 35 days to six."
title: Legislation says 10, but then takes four back

statement: "Less than two years ago, we made a commitment to repay the U.S. . . .taxpayers in full, and today we made good on that promise."
title: New Chysler square; Old Chrysler not

statement: Says that Tim Pawlenty eliminated health insurance for 33,000 to 35,000 people when he was governor of Minnesota.
title: Complicated story about the budget

statement: "Sometimes I was the only 'no' vote on the entire board."
title: Brandes stood out on pest control, mobile home bils

statement: One of every two Wisconsin residents are "on some kind of government handout."
title: Aide says he misspoke. But even then, his numbers have issues

statement: "The (health reform) legislation which Washington passed last year has made it more difficult to hire" because it’s increased costs for employers.
title: Real data doesn't back up this perception

statement: Says that several times in the last 15 years, Austin City Council candidates have won seats after trailing by more than 4,000 votes in the election prompting the runoff.
title: Shy of several

statement: The Paul Ryan budget proposal would "privatize Medicare."
title: Still a government role, but Ryan plan would privatize Medicare

statement: The Paul Ryan budget proposal would leave the country "without Medicare."
title: This part of ad is, ahem, over the top

statement: For more than 30 years after World War II, there was a steady reduction in U.S. debt as a percentage of gross domestic product.
title: No disputing this claim

statement: In the U.S. Constitution, "there’s a little section in there that talks about life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness."
title: We read it. It's not there.

statement: "For decades before I was elected, governors tried and failed to get Minnesota out of the top 10 highest-taxed states in the country. I actually did it."
title: He did it -- with an assist from Jesse Ventura

statement: "750 days since Bill Nelson & the Democrats in the Senate passed a budget. How can this be justified?"
title: It has been more than two years, but it's not all Nelson's fault

statement: Says his barehanded catch posted on YouTube is real.
title: Caught red-handed!

statement: Compact fluorescent light bulbs are "toxic" and "not environmentally friendly."
title: Tells only half the story

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry has been "begging" for the federal government to send the Coast Guard to patrol two lakes on the U.S.-Mexico border.
title: No request to feds, no one on their knees

statement: "To give a sense of how families are struggling, a record four out of every 10 school kids in Ohio now qualifies for subsidized lunch."
title: Figures for 2010 broke a record set in 2009

statement: The U.S. has "47 million people on food stamps. That’s 14 million more than when the current occupant of the White House took over."
title: Former pizza CEO (almost) delivers on food stamp claim

statement: The Providence teacher contract "is one of the longest in the country."
title: In the nation, no. In Rhode Island, yes.

statement: "Early voting remains at 96 hours."
title: Requirement drops to 48 hours, though counties could keep polls open longer

statement: "Unions don’t have to comply with Obamacare."
title: Long explanation for a whole lot of nothing

statement: "The new light bulbs will cost roughly six times the cost of the light bulbs we now use."
title: Up-front, more expensive; but evergy savings make them cheaper in long term

statement: Deregulation of the state’s telecommunications industry will create 50,000 jobs in Wisconsin.
title: It’s an estimate generated by an old study from another state

statement: The U.S. has "over $62 trillion in unfunded liabilities."
title: Shaky figures, poor terminology

statement: "A gallon (of gasoline) delivered to the front lines for our troops in Afghanistan cost more than $400."
title: Troops in remote areas get the pricey petrol

statement: "The turnout on May 14th was just 7 percent -- the lowest turnout in decades."
title: Same as 2000, though fewer voters this time

statement: "Tommy Thompson wanted to implant data chips in humans."
title: Sure, if they were willing

statement: "Gas prices have gone up $2 since Obama took office."
title: Yup, but no president controls gas prices

statement: "No other Northeastern state has passed a photo ID law"
title: ACLU has right ID

statement: "If you take the population growth here in Virginia, we are net zero on job creation since (Bob McDonnell) became governor."
title: Same could be said of former Gov. Tim Kaine's record

statement: "The Arab and the Muslim nations get twice as much money as Israel."
title: Foreign aid fact straight, but is comparison meaningful?

statement: "We bring in enough tax revenue to service our debt, pay for Medicare and Medicaid and Social Security, and then still have about $300 (billion) or $400 billion left over."
title: The math works, as long as you don't spend a dime on defense

statement: " 'Scary' fact about our national debt. In 1791 it was $75 million. Today, it rises by that amount in about an hour."
title: Debt just keeps growing and growing and...

statement: Next year, "you will be mandated by federal law to get rid of your existing light bulbs."
title: No light bulb police

statement: "The Democrats have already voted to ban our conventional light bulbs ... in favor of dangerous fluorescent light bulbs."
title: Belied by light bulbs now on Home Depot shelves

statement: Department of Education officials investigating Virginia Tech shootings "have not once gotten into the car and driven down to Blacksburg to talk to the police chief or the university president or to anyone else."
title: But other communications occurred

statement: "The health care price tag for childhood obesity in Georgia is $2.4 billion annually and rising."
title: Waist line for Georgia's kids growing. Costs, though, not as bad as Deal says.

statement: Says state lawmakers have voted to "spend virtually all of the Rainy Day Fund four times" since the fund’s creation.
title: Last time was 2005

statement: Promotes a chart saying that Barack Obama has "increased the debt" by 16 percent, compared to George W. Bush, who increased it by 115 percent.
title: Calculations shift responsibility for one debt-heavy year from Obama to Bush

statement: On taxes, President Barack Obama wants to raise "the top rate to 44.8 percent."
title: It's not the usual rate cited, but economists say it's reasonable

statement: "Wisconsin is one of the few states in the country that do not currently require a photographic identification" to vote.
title: Actually, as it stands now, only a few do require one

statement: "The $1.8 billion in [transportation] bonding, we don’t have a repayment mechanism."
title: Let's steamroll this falsehood

statement: Says people who signed recall petitions against Wisconsin state Sen. Jim Holperin received "harassing phone calls from out-of-state telemarketers claiming to represent the Democratic Party and insinuating foul play by petition circulators."
title: This claim checks out

statement: Says there are more federal dollars in Gov. John Kasich's budget plan than in the previous state budget.
title: Yes for the General Revenue Fund but no for the entire budget

statement: "The new beverage tax will increase the cost of sodas, juice drinks, sports drinks, iced teas, and flavored water up to 50%."
title: Claim fizzles under scrutiny

statement: "In the first year of the Obama administration, more jobs were created in the private sector than in the eight years of the Bush administration."
title: An already questionable talking point flubbed

statement: "You can't give a child an aspirin in school without permission. You can't do any kind of medication, but we can secretly take the child off and have an abortion."
title: Over-the-counter or prescription makes little difference to school nurses

statement: "Very, very, very few people get a pat-down" when they go through airport security.
title: It's a small percent but a very large number of people

statement: "The Ohio Democratic Party has raised $1.1 million since the November election. A very small percentage of that has come from organized labor."
title: Only 6 percent, but direct campaigning doesn't count

statement: President Barack Obama deserves to be called "the most successful food stamp president in American history" because "47 million Americans are on food stamps."
title: Food stamp use at record high, but not exclusively Obama's fault

statement: "The (border) fence is now basically complete."
title: Depends on your definition of fence

statement: The Massachusetts health care plan is "wildly unpopular" among state residents.
title: Poll data is scarce, but evidence of wild unpopularity is even scarcer

statement: Failure to raise the debt limit does not force a U.S. default on debt payments.
title: But options to default are also dire

statement: Says the Texas Board of Nursing has a backlog of "3,000 complaints against nurses, many of them sexual assaults, malfeasance."
title: Board says sexual assault is a small percentage of the backlog

statement: "Eighty-seven percent of private insurance plans currently include (abortion) coverage."
title: A high percentage, but data is nearly a decade old

statement: "There are not, nor have there ever been, any boycotts encouraged by our organizations."
title: The anti-Walker boycott effort wears a union label

statement: Says businesses "already pay most of the taxes."
title: Analyses support statement, but businesses pass on tax burden

statement: "Most military experts say there is anywhere between 25 and 30 members of al Qaeda in Afghanistan."
title: Most experts don't say that

statement: If the Sellwood Bridge is not replaced, it will have to be shut down within eight years.
title: Nobody knows that for sure

statement: Says judges are using Shariah law in Dearborn, Mich.
title: Two words: Supremacy Clause

statement: President Obama’s health care law "represents a government takeover of health care."
title: The claim lives on

statement: George Allen "had 40,000 earmarks" while he was a senator.
title: 40,000? That's 18 per day

statement: Says Rick Perry "turned down our invitation to meet" President Barack Obama in El Paso.
title: Perry aide suggested Austin alternative

statement: "We're within 600 miles of 60 percent of America. We're in a perfect location."
title: Well positioned and open for business

statement: Increasing the bottle deposit to 10 cents on a case of water bottles could literally double the price of that product in the store.
title: Maybe if we didn't already have a deposit

statement: "(George) LeMieux never requested a single earmark and pushed to ban them all."
title: Voted for pork requested by his predecessor

statement: "(Bill) Nelson voted for billions in wasteful spending earmarks like the Bridge to Nowhere."
title: Nelson has sought and voted for numerous earmarks

statement: About two-thirds of Medicaid beneficiaries are children, but they account for one-third of the program’s cost, while one-third are elderly, and they account for two-thirds of the cost.
title: Medicaid spending on the elderly is disproportionate, but not that high

statement: Virginia ranked near the bottom of the nation 50 years ago in per capita income but is in the top 10 today. It had a "very low" rate of higher education attainment but is now above the national average.
title: Don't know enough about history (but better with the present)

statement: Says Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker "literally invented a $3.6 billion deficit."
title: We’ve been down this path before — and the view’s the same

statement: "The substitute budget now adds in tax breaks and tax deductions for those who buy these prisons."
title: Purchases at this 'yard sale' might end up tax free

statement: "For four years, we balanced the budget and paid off $405 billion in debt."
title: Only part of these achievements on his watch

statement: During his time as House speaker, "unemployment came down from 5.6 percent to under 4 (percent)."
title: Unemployment fell -- but not that far

statement: Under President Barack Obama, the United States has "doubled our exports."
title: Doubling is a goal -- the U.S. is only a third of the way there

statement: The Bush tax cuts "created about 8 million jobs over the first 10 years that they were in existence. We've lost about 5 million of those jobs during this recession."
title: A grain of truth overwhelmed by multiple problems

statement: The Obama administration increased the deportation of illegal immigrants convicted of crimes by 70 percent.
title: Deportations in general up a bit; deportation of criminals up a lot

statement: "American oil production is at its highest level since 2003."
title: But it may drop soon

statement: "Two-thirds of Wisconsin corporations don't pay state income taxes."
title: Most don’t pay in, but it’s not all because of tax breaks

statement: When "the governor announced his ‘jobs budget,’ 99 folks from the Department of Taxation were let go the next day."
title: State says these jobs weren't needed

statement: "Gwinnett Medical Center is operating in the negative," in part, because of illegal immigrants.
title: Hospital claim could use an infusion of more info

statement: "The people of Rhode Island don't want same-sex marriage."
title: His latest poll says otherwise.

statement: "The Border Patrol has 20,000 agents – more than twice as many as there were in 2004."
title: True, with credit to Bush

statement: "The only people in this town that have voted to cut Medicare spending are the people who voted in favor of Obamacare. That’s a fact."
title: Medicare spending still projected to double over next decade

statement: The "six largest cities in Ohio all have higher rates of violence and crime than every major city along the U.S.-Mexico border."
title: Safer down south

statement: During the Eisenhower Administration, "not a single soldier … died in combat."
title: There were hundreds of combat deaths as Ike wound down the Korean War

statement: "Austin Energy is considering its first rate increase since 1994."
title: Austinites pay less now, considering inflation

statement: Says President Barack Obama’s debt commission recommended converting Medicare "to a system where Medicare participants are given a voucher to purchase insurance in the private market."
title: Discussed? Yes. Recommended? No

statement: "Two million federal workers negotiate zippo, zero. There is no collective bargaining for federal employees."
title: Not 'zippo,' but very limited

statement: Wrote that in 2006, Nancy Pelosi said she didn’t think capturing Osama bin Laden "makes us any safer," but in 2011 called his killing "historic."
title: She said it, though the contrast with 2011 is oversold

statement: There is "a situation in this country where you're nearing 50 percent of people who don't even pay income taxes."
title: Deductions cut liabilities

statement: "Gov. (Scott) Walker has yet to create a job, he gives away millions to his friends, and he raises taxes on working people."
title: If this were baseball, one for three would be great

statement: Georgia is "one of only about seven states in the country" that has a AAA bond rating.
title: Georgia's bond rating is AAA-OK

statement: Says close to 90 percent of the population growth in Texas over the last decade was non-Anglo.
title: 89 percent

statement: Says Milwaukee County spent over $170,000 in salaries in 2010 for employees to "participate in union activities such as collective bargaining."
title: Yep. Under contracts, some government workers are paid by taxpayers to work for their unions

statement: Rick Perry "advocated to liquidate" the state’s rainy day fund in 2007.
title: Perry has approved budgets that spent it all

statement: "I'm well aware that medical marijuana is a recognized, medical, viable treatment for this sort of [pancreas] pain condition."
title: Tokin' out of context

statement: From 2008 to 2011, "the pages in the conforming bills have gone from 400 pages to 2,200."
title: Lots to read, little time

statement: The study that states that more than 70 percent of the traffic on the Sellwood Bridge is to/from Clackamas County has been thoroughly debunked by The Oregonian.
title: That's a bridge too far

statement: Benzene has "never been proven to be harmful."
title: It's a carcinogen

statement: "Prices are going up. Unemployment is continuing to go up."
title: Unemployment had been dropping since November

statement: On the night of the Iowa caucuses, Obama "promised the nation that he would do health care reform focused on cost containment, he opposed an individual mandate, and he said he was going to do it with Republicans."
title: Two out of three, for sure

statement: "We have the highest corporate income tax in the world right now."
title: Not No. 1 by all measures, but pretty high on the list

statement: Says people in Africa "literally walk two and three hundred miles" in order to vote.
title: Talk about an elections gaffe

statement: "I’ve been through four campaigns and have not done any negative campaigning."
title: One past opponent even wants to take him to dinner

statement: "Nearly 2,000 high schools - roughly 12 percent of all secondary schools in the United States - produce about half of the nation’s dropouts."
title: Sad but true

statement: House Republican plan would increase costs for Oregon seniors by $6,000 with health care vouchers instead of Medicare
title: Much is uncertain but that is close to a CBO estimate

statement: According to crime statistics, "riding MARTA has been becoming more and more safe over the years."
title: Fewer pickpockets, more violent attacks

statement: Says one of Austin City Council Member Randi Shade’s biggest contributors is the lobbyist for the Formula 1 racetrack planned outside Austin.
title: 2,500 pennies

statement: "A [bank] surveillance camera capturing a criminal’s face and other identifiable traits would certainly discourage robbery attempts and serve as a deterrent to robbers."
title: Helps catch crooks, doesn't deter them

statement: The federal debt is more than $14 trillion, "almost equal to the size of our entire economy," and "every child born today inherits a $45,000 share of the national debt before they take their first breath."
title: Red ink the new birthright

statement: "Polls show that Floridians don't want to repeal the Affordable Care Act."
title: More Floridians favor repeal in two recent polls

statement: "Bin Laden had declared war against Pakistan."
title: Bin Laden declared holy war against its then-president

statement: "America owns 3 percent of the world’s oil but consumes 25 percent of its global reserves."
title: Both numbers slightly high, but close to the mark

statement: Says he has exposed plans by Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker to push legislation that would allow the state to declare financial martial law and take over municipal governments.
title: The plan was already floated, but not by Walker

statement: Rep. Paul Ryan's budget proposal cuts "nothing" from Medicare, Social Security or defense in the next two to three years, and "in three years, he does not cut one dime from the debt."
title: Ryan's proposals kick in later

statement: "The federal government borrows $4 billion every day."
title: A billion here, a billion there . . .

statement: In a lawsuit between private citizens, a Florida judge "announced the decision was going to be based on Islamic Law."
title: The use of foreign law in U.S. courts not that uncommon

statement: Says although the unemployment rate seems to be improving, it does not reflect real job creation -- it’s caused by a "shrinking of the actual labor force."
title: She overlooks actual job creation, but her point about labor force shrinkage is important

statement: "You’ve got each day 10,000 new seniors, baby boomers, becoming eligible for the entitlement programs."
title: The silver tsunami cometh

statement: Says the Internal Revenue Service estimated it must hire "16,500 agents at a cost of $10 billion to the taxpayer" to enforce the federal health care overhaul.
title: Missive's factoid deserves Dear John letter

statement: "At Texas A&M University, only 49 out of 3,000 faculty members brought in enough money to pay for their salaries and overhead over the past five years."
title: Back-of-envelope? Return to sender

statement: Drilling for oil on the Outer Continental Shelf and in parts of Alaska will  "immediately reduce our dangerous dependence on foreign oil."
title: "Immediately" around 2021

statement: Says that had E-Verify been in place in Florida when 9/11 terrorists lived here, "we might have saved the lives of 3,000 Americans."
title: Florida-based hijackers never held jobs

statement: "China now owns $1.1 trillion of our debt, our trade deficit last year with them was a quarter of a trillion dollars."
title: Made in China, held in China

statement: "We don't have bridges being built" in the United States.
title: Some pretty big "little toys"

statement: Says using E-Verify is "a fair amount of cost," about $20 per person that does not match.
title: Though system technically free, there are costs

statement: "A vast majority of the production in the United States comes from small independent oil and gas companies."
title: A more modest majority, and some of those "small" firms are quite big

statement: "Currently, there is no one from South Austin on the (Austin City) Council!"
title: There were two at start of '08

statement: "State employees are actually going to get a pay raise."
title: No pay raise. More money for more hours of work

statement: "One of three patients hospitalized (is) harmed by the care they receive."
title: One in three claim patients harmed during medical care close to the mark.

statement: "55 percent of the people who cast a provisional ballot (in Florida) in the last presidential election -- their vote did not count."
title: Percentage much lower in 2010

statement: Says "in Canada, the number of CT scan machines per 1,000 people is like one-tenth of what we have here in this country. That's why people have to wait."
title: Cain's CT scan claim needs reexamining

statement: Says it probably costs more than $300,000 to run for a seat on the Pedernales Electric Cooperative board of directors.
title: Sixty times less in 2010

statement: Says that while his plan would narrow the time for early voting, "it still will be one of the most aggressive early voting time frames in America."
title: Ohio's top elections officer not even close

statement: Republicans offered Wisconsin bar patrons "free shots (of alcohol) to sign recall petitions against" Democrats.
title: This claim has a little kick, but it is far from 100-proof

statement: "We just fought a Republican budget that ends Medicare as we know it."
title: Not a budget, not for those over 54

statement: Rep. Paul Ryan’s Medicare plan "lines the pockets of the private insurance companies," increases costs for seniors and does not reduce the deficit.
title: Money goes to deficit and insurers

statement: Says Florida is one of a few or perhaps the only state "that has a statewide review of local land use and zoning decisions."
title: Other states review changes, but Florida's standards more stringent

statement: "There are legitimate and widespread anomalies, and widespread questions about the conduct of (the Wisconsin Supreme Court) election, most visibly in Waukesha County, but also in counties around the state."
title: Most of the issues she cites are minor, normal or already cleared up

statement: The Bush tax cuts "helped to create a substantial part of the deficit."
title: Without them, there would have been a surplus in 2007

statement: Says "we have now more Border Patrol officers … than we’ve had at any time in our history."
title: Obama border patrol claim on target, but forgets one bit of history

statement: "A $250 fine if you're caught with a plastic bag coming out of a store. Plastic bag police anyone?"
title: Not even close

statement: "Texans spend $2.5 billion gambling in our neighboring states every year."
title: Chancy

statement: Says stories about his birth certificate drowned out media coverage of the Republican and White House budget plans the week of April 11.
title: Wrong for the week Obama indicated; right for the following week

statement: "90 percent of babies with Down syndrome are aborted."
title: Of women who receive prenatal diagnosis, studies show

statement: President Obama was "raised Muslim."
title: Repeats a debunked statement

statement: President Barack Obama "took exactly none of his own deficit reduction commission’s ideas. Not one."
title: Lots of proposals in common, though not always identical

statement: "We have created more jobs in this last year than the Bush administration (did) in eight years."
title: It's all in how you slice the data

statement: After the U.S.-led military alliance ejected Saddam Hussein’s forces from Kuwait in 1991, the Kuwaitis "never paid us."
title: Kuwait paid $16 billion in war costs, U.S. paid $7 billion

statement: Says the hospital listed on Barack Obama’s just-publicized long-form birth certificate denies the president was born there.
title: And the "birther" beat goes on

statement: "CNN did a poll recently where Obama and I are statistically tied."
title: One poll (misidentified) conducted before he delved into birth certificate issue

statement: Says "many states" are floundering under crushing deficit spending.
title: 49 of 50 states required to pass balanced budgets

statement: Says Paul Ryan "voted for two wars that were unpaid for, voted for the Bush tax cuts that were unpaid for, voted for the prescription drug bill that cost as much as my health care bill -- but wasn't paid for."
title: Got the votes right, but not all the details

statement: "As far as standing committees, we have 10 fewer standing committees. So we’ve saved the state about a quarter-of-a-million dollars through the reduction of the standing committees."
title: Committees cut, but savings redirected in House budget for spending

statement: "The Georgia Lottery Corp. has only once in the past 16 years paid out the agreed upon 35 percent of proceeds to the account which funds the HOPE scholarship."
title: Numbers provide math lesson for student

statement: In early voting in Miami-Dade County, "there is a trickle of two or three people a day at a very high cost to keep those public libraries and polls open."
title: Early voting numbers continue to increase in Miami-Dade

statement: "Mickey Mouse was registered to vote (in Florida)."
title: He tried but failed in 2008

statement: "Each day our nation pays communist China $73.9 million in interest on our debt."
title: That's one big check

statement: "In Senate Bill 5, there is this new method of evaluating teachers. … You’re also going to be rated on what the parents think of you and they can send questionnaires and surveys home to parents."
title: Parent satisfaction one piece of the evaluation process

statement: "Large majorities" of the public "oppose major changes to Medicare" and favor higher taxes on the wealthy.
title: Most polls support that

statement: "Iraq has the second-largest oilfields in the world (behind) Saudi Arabia."
title: Right for 2002, but other nations have since passed Iraq in proven reserves

statement: "Every person on death row was a foster kid."
title: Hardened killers, yes; all from foster care, no

statement: Says protesters at the Wisconsin state Capitol on the night the state Senate passed collective bargaining changes damaged the windshield of his car.
title: Police told him, at the time, it was from a pebble while driving

statement: "Foreign companies in the United States have a significantly higher unionization rate than other companies overall."
title: It's nearly double the overall private-sector rate

statement: Salaries for Virginia’s teachers are below the national average.
title: An "A" for accuracy

statement: "Over the last 10 years, Georgia's public health has declined."
title: Yes and no

statement: Says salaries and benefits for Wisconsin state employee comprised 8.5 percent of the 2009-2011 state budget.
title: Two ways to look at it … but not right under either

statement: "Gov. (Rick) Perry helped balance his budget with about $6 billion worth of federal help, which he happily took, and then started blaming the members of Congress who had offered that help."
title: Perry repeatedly slammed 'Washington' after stimulus funds were key to balancing budget

statement: "We are the most generous in New England and New England is known for its generosity toward its welfare recipients."
title: Only if you're a "vendor."

statement: Per-student K-12 state funding for Portland Public Schools has dipped from $6,036 in the 2007-2008 school year to $5,644 in the 2010-2011 school year
title: Only if you don't include stimulus money

statement: China holds 26 percent of the U.S. debt.
title: Not if you include debt held domestically

statement: "Right now we are spending at an all-time high, close to 25 percent of our GDP [is] being spent on the federal government. But our revenues are at an almost all-time low of about 15 percent [of GDP]."
title: Only World War II era can compare

statement: Says he couldn't keep a 42-inch redfish he caught because of fishing rules.
title: Ag commish has a fishing story for you

statement: Says Wisconsin state Sen. Randy Hopper, R-Fond du Lac, has already been recalled.
title: Maybe soon, but not at this point in the process

statement: Says Texas routinely gets "a lot more federal spending" than it pays in taxes.
title: In recent years

statement: "It is a fact that it costs more to run the schools in August."
title: Board member's summer vacation claim gets low marks.

statement: Tim Kaine broke a campaign promise not to raise taxes.
title: "No taxes" pledge never existed

statement: "Almost 37 percent of the total income from Planned Parenthood is from abortions."
title: As long as you don't count most of Planned Parenthood's income

statement: Says $38 billion in spending cuts in federal budget compromise is "less than $1 billion in real cuts."
title: Only if you take the short-term view

statement: "For every 33 pregnant women that walk into a Planned Parenthood clinic, 32 receive an abortion."
title: Bad stats make for bad facts

statement: Says that in 41 states, government workers "are better paid than the taxpayers who support them."
title: Cited analysis assumes every job's the same

statement: If we had the same staffing ratio (of officers to residents) as Seattle, we'd have 300 more officers in our department."
title: Book 'em, Danno

statement: Under a proposal by Rep. Paul Ryan, people on Medicare will only have $15,000 from the federal government to spend on their health care.
title: The $15,000 goes toward buying an insurance plan -- it's not a cap on medical spending

statement: "Seniors will have to find $12,500 for health care because Republicans voted to end Medicare."
title: Don't break open the piggy bank!

statement: An Internet sweepstakes cafe is "a legitimate business that has been vetted and found to be completely legal in the state."
title: Murkier than Nehr is letting on

statement: "The facts show that approximately 40 persons on death row have had all of their appellate review completed and await only the governor's signature on a death warrant to end the case."
title: Another reason for a death row backlog

statement: General Electric "hasn't really created any jobs in this country, doesn't  pay any taxes, and they're making historic profits."
title: No new jobs but no historic profits

statement: "America's wealthiest 25 percent pay 86 percent of total income taxes. Wealthiest 5 percent pay 60 percent of total income taxes."
title: Graves math on taxes proves true

statement: According to David Cay Johnston, "the average American pays about 22 percent of their income to federal taxes. The richest 400 Americans … pay about 16 percent of their income to federal taxes."
title: For individuals, but families would likely pay less

statement: "Every time we've cut taxes, revenues have gone up, the economy has grown."
title: Not every time

statement: "[Appalachian Power] wants another 10 percent rate increase. The compensation package for CEO Mike Morris rose 22 percent to $8.7 million in 2010."
title: Another zap for customers

statement: "In this bill that I’ve just signed, we don’t cut anybody’s salary. We don’t take away their pension. And we don’t destroy their health care."
title: Shifting pension, health premiums apt to cut take home pay

statement: Says President Franklin Delano Roosevelt sent his advisers to study socialism with Soviet dictator Josef Stalin so the president could replicate it in the United States.
title: Broun needs to brush up on his history

statement: Says the fluoride Austin is putting in its drinking water is "toxic waste."
title: Not waste and not toxic

statement: (Dennis) Richardson wants to make drastic cuts to services we depend on: schools, home care for seniors, even public safety -- all so Richardson can keep more than $440 million in unspent funds for his political priorities."
title: In this case, it takes three to tango

statement: The Republican budget plan "says that 10 years from now, if you’re a 65-year-old who’s eligible for Medicare, you should have to pay nearly $6,400 more than you would today."
title: About that, according to a CBO analysis

statement: "The top 1 percent of income-earners pay about 40 percent of all taxes into the federal government."
title: Maybe 40 percent of federal income taxes, but not 40 percent of all federal taxes

statement: "Americans will pay more in taxes in 2011 than they will spend on groceries, clothing and shelter combined."
title: In the aggregate, yes -- but more Americans will have the opposite pattern

statement: "Hackers broke into Virginia's prescription-drug database (and) ... obtained more than 8.2 million patient records and a total of nearly 36 million prescriptions."
title: Not clear hacker got the records

statement: Milwaukee is "the most segregated city in America."
title: The accepted measure puts Milwaukee — the metro area — at No. 1

statement: "The costs of cancer and all affiliated issues are over $20 billion a year to this state."
title: Research supports representative's figure

statement: "If you go strictly by the numbers, crime is down across the board. Last year we had a 10 percent decrease in the most serious crimes."
title: The numbers agree

statement: "What we have done with the PATRIOT Act, we've given the government enormous powers. We've given the government the right to reach deeply into people's private lives, into their business affairs, without a court order."
title: Approval from secret federal court replaces traditional warrant

statement: Human error, such as skipping a community in the Wisconsin Supreme Court race, "is common in (the vote-tabulation) process.
title: Small errors not unusual, but rare to see mistakes like this

statement: "Full marriage equality [would provide same-sex couples] with about 1,700 rights."
title: Is the mere mention of marriage a right denied?

statement: Tim Kaine proposed "over $6 billion in tax increases from the time he entered the governor’s mansion until the time he left."
title: Right idea, wrong math

statement: "43,000 people are going to be kicked out of nursing homes or denied nursing home entrance" if the Texas House version of the state budget passes into law.
title: Educated guessing

statement: Multnomah County has faced "11 straight years" of cuts
title: The type of cuts where the budget keeps growing

statement: Says Gov. Rick Scott's approval ratings are up.
title: Not in polls we can find

statement: "Medicare passed with virtually no Republican support."
title: More than half of House Republicans, sizable minority of Senate GOP voted 'yea'

statement: George Allen voted to add $3 trillion to the federal debt, voted to raise the debt ceiling four times and voted for the No Child Left Behind Act while he was a senator.
title: Most of GOP joined him
