statement: "A DWI costs $17,000."
title: Study says costs range widely

statement: "The Republicans have demanded deep cuts in education. They've demanded cuts in cancer research and other research to find cures and treatments to diseases."
title: The GOP would cut lots of other things, but those programs are on the list

statement: To pay for government growth, leaders of both parties "borrowed $4 billion a day, leaving us with today's $14 trillion debt."
title: More annual deficits = larger national debt

statement: "When we lower tax rates, we generate more in revenues. That happened in '86 with the Reagan plan, happened in 2001, following the Bush plan."
title: Chambliss tax claim half true

statement: "For every [coyote] they kill, the population will replace and usually multiply."
title: They're prolific breeders

statement: "In the last decade, the average income of the bottom 90 percent of all working Americans actually declined. The top 1 percent saw their income rise by an average of more than a quarter of a million dollars each."
title: Depends on parameters/years picked

statement: "By the end of this decade, the interest we owe on our debt could rise to nearly $1 trillion."
title: Lots of debt, but most estimates fall well short of $1 trillion

statement: Says "Congressman Eric Cantor wants to eliminate Social Security."
title: Just plain wrong

statement: A space shuttle the National Museum of the United States Air Force near Dayton would be "within a day's drive of 60 percent of the U.S. population."
title: Simplified statement cuts out 40 million people

statement: A Republican proposal changes Medicare for those under age 55 so that they will  "participate in the same kind of health plan that members of Congress do."
title: It's different in several ways

statement: "Foreign aid makes up about 1 percent of our entire budget."
title: He's got it right

statement: President Obama has "stopped using the phrase 'war on terror.' "
title: It's a deliberate, reasoned choice

statement: "Politicians and their corporate lobbyists are trying to take away my right to spend my paycheck how I want."
title: Proposals change method of paying union dues

statement: Says unions "take away" hard-earned money of teachers, firefighters and police officers to play politics.
title: Union membership in Florida is voluntary

statement: Says the federal government borrows "almost $60 billion per week."
title: Broun's off by a factor of two

statement: President Obama has spent over $2 million in legal fees defending lawsuits about his birth certificate.
title: Only if all his legal bills went to birth certificate lawsuits

statement: A cap-and-trade bill would "destroy over 50,000 jobs in Virginia."
title: Claim is mostly hot air

statement: "In 2009, we cut state spending in real terms for the first time in 150 years."
title: Data only goes back to 1960

statement: Says Gov. Rick Scott lost Florida 331,247 jobs.
title: Projected jobs, estimated jobs, proposed budget cuts don't add up

statement: "The benefits that were offered to me as a congressman don’t even compare to the benefits that you get as a state employee. I just experienced that myself. They’re not nearly as good."
title: On target on health care, less so on retirement benefits

statement: There was "some sort of informal commitment to build a (psychiatric) building in downtown Cleveland."
title: Legislature OK'd $83.7 million for this 'informal committment'

statement: "There used to be 16 workers for every one person on Social Security. ... Now it’s three."
title: Fewer workers support more retirees

statement: "For every one ESD superintendent position, we can pay for three speech pathologists, or three special needs instructors, or three classroom teachers."
title: Three for the price of one? A deal too good to be true

statement: "Libya supplies the oil for China. We get no oil from Libya."
title: More to Europe than China

statement: "We have a guy who is going to be speaker of the House in four years, and his name has been on the ballot one time."
title: Years are off, story oversimplified

statement: The newly proposed House Republican budget "abolishes Medicare within 10 years."
title: Changes, yes. Dramatically. But program still exists, and those turning 65 before 2022 would see no change

statement: "Over the past decade, the big five oil companies --- BP, Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil and Shell -- made a total profit of nearly $1 trillion."
title: Close, but no cigar

statement: "Many states without collective bargaining, such as Arizona, Nevada and North Carolina, have far larger budget deficits than many that do, including Ohio."
title: States collectively struggling with budget issues

statement: Says the Beaumont school district’s superintendent is the highest-paid in the state.
title: Highest in salary, not in total compensation

statement: Says "an average of $4 billion is added to the national debt" every day.
title: Daily debt estimate hits close to mark

statement: Austin’s Pease Elementary "is a school that was created as part of the Texas Constitution."
title: School's history doesn't include constitutional roots

statement: ﻿Says JoAnne Kloppenburg’s side had a "3-to-1 money advantage" in the Wisconsin Supreme Court campaign.
title: Actually, the Prosser side spent more

statement: Proposed fees for Rhode Island beaches will still be "less than some of the town beaches."
title: Who can put a price on a day at the beach?

statement: "When I took office last year we faced historic budget deficits of $6 billion here in Virginia.  And we closed those deficits by cutting spending."
title: Guv exaggerates actual cuts

statement: Undocumented students who qualify for in-state Oregon tuition are "actively working toward U.S. citizenship."
title: An affidavit is not an application

statement: "Fifty percent of our students who enter higher education need to take remedial courses because they are not prepared for college-level work."
title: That's just community college students

statement: Abortion services are "well over 90 percent of what Planned Parenthood does."
title: Planned Parenthood says it's 3 percent of services provided

statement: "I have the No. 1 show on NBC."
title: In the previous week, yes; all season long, no

statement: In Florida, it’s not illegal for an immediate family member of state officials to prosper from legislation supported by a spouse.
title: Even with conflicts of interest, state law calls only for disclosure

statement: "A report in Navy Times said that 7.3 percent of Army, Navy and Marines have thought about attempting suicide."
title: Here's why trusting a blog is not always best

statement: Said Planned Parenthood’s early objective was to "help kill black babies before they came into the world."
title: Only if by "genocide" he means "public health project"

statement: "From '05 to '09, we've had 1,100 soldiers commit suicide, one every 36 hours."
title: Actual number of deaths is slightly higher

statement: "We’re paying out-of-state residential facilities hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not more," to house children in state custody
title: Actually, it’s millions

statement: Says President Obama's "grandmother in Kenya said he was born in Kenya and she was there and witnessed the birth."
title: Keep listening to tape, there's an immediate correction

statement: "We’ve introduced a bill that includes $12 billion in cuts over the next week."
title: It has $12 billion in cuts, but also $7.6 billion in added spending

statement: Virginia was named "best managed state, best state for business and best state to raise a child" while I was governor.
title: Opponent Allen can make similar claims

statement: "Across the United States, 25 percent of voting age African Americans do not have the photo ID that this bill would require."
title: Data quoted correctly, but the snapshot isn't from 2011

statement: A government shutdown "could disrupt ... veterans' benefits."
title: It could happen, most likely for new claims

statement: Under a House Republican appropriations bill, "6 million seniors are deprived of meals."
title: Cautious math marred by her misstatement of the results

statement: The ratio of people working for the government and working in manufacturing today is "an almost exact reversal of the situation in 1960."
title: Manufacturing's share fell a whole lot faster than government's grew

statement: Says House Republicans rejected a straightforward measure that would prevent members of Congress and the president from being paid during a government shutdown.
title: Yes, but it may be unconstitutional anyway

statement: "We’ve lost 26 million jobs … since (Obama’s) been president."
title: Off by a factor of 10

statement: For the first time in U.S. history, a personal inaction will be deemed unlawful -- not purchasing a health-insurance plan
title: Let’s see, there’s not buying car insurance, not registering with Selective Service …

statement: "The only segment in the beer market that is growing is the craft beer segment."
title: Cheers

statement: Three courts have found the new health care law constitutional and two have found it unconstitutional.
title: The score is 3-2

statement: "Franklin Roosevelt (was) the last president to come to the Congress to ask for permission to engage into war."
title: None sought permission for war; a number sought support for military force

statement: "Since 1990, in inflation-adjusted dollars, per-student funding of the (Florida) state university system from general revenue has dropped by about $4,000."
title: Tuition increases have kept per-student funding steady

statement: The federal government has "77 different means-tested social welfare programs."
title: A whole lot of welfare going on

statement: Says "some [states] with the largest reductions in crime have also lowered their prison population."
title: Who knew? Some states with large crime drops also have drops in prison rates.

statement: "Corporate taxes will soon be the highest in the industrialized world."
title: He's right about corporate tax rate

statement: "We lost more jobs in this great recession than the last four recessions combined."
title: A "great recession" that earned its nickname

statement: "Every child born today inherits a $30,000 share in a national debt that stands at more than $13 trillion."
title: Generally right, though his numbers are a bit mixed up

statement: "Some of the colleges, including A&M, have already guaranteed that they will not increase their tuition."
title: A&M proposing a tuition hike for some students

statement: A majority of the American people opposed the health care law when it was signed and still oppose it today.
title: Polls more mixed than Allen says

statement: Says a photo ID voting law in Georgia didn't dissuade black voters from participating in voting. "It hasn't, it doesn't, and apparently, if you do cause and effect in that state, it's been helpful."
title: Correlation or causation?

statement: "In three years we could find close to 50 million gallons per day through a toilet replacement program."
title: Toilet claim overflows with optimism

statement: When you compare our state pension system "to other systems throughout the country, our benefits are not gold-plated. They are not rich. They are actually average or below average."
title: It's all about longevity

statement: Milwaukee lost the headquarters for MillerCoors because the area lacks good transit.
title: The company said from the start it was looking for a neutral city

statement: Since Oregon’s prescription-only law took effect, meth lab incidents have dropped by 96 percent and meth-related arrests by 32 percent.
title: The data support him

statement: "Ninety percent of Texans say they do not want the nursing homes to close. It polls higher than anything else."
title: 90 percent don't want state funding for nursing homes cut

statement: South Korea doesn't pay the United States for U.S. troops that protect their country.
title: South Korea pays nearly $700 million a year

statement: Says Chris Abele, opponent in Milwaukee County executive race, "failed to finish 3 separate colleges, dropping out all 3 times."
title: Some details lacking on one — but lack of clarity is due to Abele as well

statement: Says Wisconsin Supreme Court candidate JoAnne Kloppenburg "put an 80-year-old farmer in jail for refusing to plant native vegetation on his farm."
title: Judge says Kloppenburg didn’t ask for jail time. He ordered it — eventually — for contempt of court

statement: Tallahassee is "the ninth-rainiest (city) in the nation."
title: A dreary fact

statement: Discretionary spending has "increased over 20-some percent in two years if you don’t include the stimulus. If you put in the stimulus, it’s over 80 percent."
title: Cantor's math not quite right

statement: "From 1960, the year I was born, until the time I became Governor in 2003, the average two-year increase in Minnesota state spending was 21 percent. … we brought that down dramatically, to about 1.7 percent per year."
title: Thanks to one-time spending delays

statement: Says Majority Leader Eric Cantor called for "abolishing Social Security and Medicare."
title: Cherry-picking a quote; ignoring other comments

statement: Says the Southwest Florida Water Management District has $850 million in reserves, enough money in savings to run without levying taxes for more than two years.
title: District's money is mostly tied up

statement: PolitiFact Wisconsin "concluded that the charge that Justice Prosser prejudges matters that come before the court is True."
title: Umm. We remember the original ruling as Barely True

statement: Says Supreme Court candidate JoAnne Kloppenburg’s record as a state Justice Department lawyer consists only of the prosecution of cases regarding regulation of docks.
title: Some of the many other types of cases were argued at the high court in front of Prosser himself

statement: Says that during the first 19 months of the Obama administration, the U.S. detained people from nations designated as state sponsors of terrorism on the southwestern border.
title: Yes, but more occurred in other areas of country

statement: "There has never been a death caused by a [commercial nuclear] reactor in the United States, even when Three Mile Island failed in the 1970s."
title: No one's died - as far as we know

statement: "Originally, Democrats promised that if you liked your health care plan, you could keep it. One year later we know that you need a waiver to keep your plan."
title: Waivers are few, far between

statement: "A third of all the young people in America are not in America today because of abortion, because one in three pregnancies end in abortion."
title: Flawed math and a questionable leap of logic

statement: "Before this (federal health care) law was enacted, Florida parents ... were able to purchase inexpensive 'child-only' coverage for their children. The law’s 'consumer protections' have now eliminated that choice in Florida."
title: Child-only policies still being sold; in fact, state program sells them

statement: Says David Prosser = Scott Walker.
title: Evidence cited is a mixed bag, though even Prosser acknowledges similarities

statement: Says the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act adopted last year contains "a series of slush funds, set up to stay on the books automatically, with little or no oversight."
title: Illicit and unregulated? Hardly

statement: "Public sentiment in favor of collective bargaining and in favor of the unions has actually gone up as these governors, I think, have overreached and gone too far and tried to destroy the labor movement."
title: There’s support for unions, but is it growing?

statement: "Ultimately, after an exhaustive investigation," the National Transportation Safety Board concluded that a Minneapolis bridge collapsed in 2007 "because of an original design flaw dating back to the 1960s."
title: Old design flaws were ruled the primary cause

statement: Says new EPA water regulations would force the state to make drainage canals every bit as clean as pristine Florida river systems.
title: Proposal subject to change/caveats

statement: Since Corey Stewart became chairman in November 2006, unemployment is up 150% and average home price sales are down $150,000.
title: Accurate numbers, inaccurate blame

statement: Says Jeff Stone = Scott Walker.
title: Even Stone has made the comparison ... but he does it in a positive way

statement: Georgia public sector employees do not have a say in the conditions of their employment, do not have bargaining rights or a say in their working conditions.
title: Claim on union bargaining rights gets muddy in the details.

statement: The "House-passed budget proposal could cut funding for programs that help keep local neighborhoods safe, slash more than $1.7 million in anti-terror funds for Ohio."
title: Careful selection of programs, words bolsters truth

statement: "One. That's the number of new drilling permits under the Obama administration since they came into office."
title: One wrong statement

statement: "Regime change (in Iraq) took eight years"
title: It depends on your definition of "regime change"

statement: "American troops have never been under the formal control of another nation."
title: It's happened repeatedly for over a century

statement: "We don't need a separate (prescription drug) database ... Pharmacies already have a database in place."
title: Pharmacy databases aren't interconnected

statement: As a prosecutor, Wisconsin Supreme Court Justice David Prosser did not investigate or file charges in a case involving 30-year pedophile priest, then participated in cover-up.
title: Ad suggests Prosser knew at the time information that surfaced years later

statement: "Every taxpayer owes about $130,000 to pay off the national debt."
title: National debt estimate may make you want to hold wallet tight

statement: Says Milwaukee County Parks director Sue Black has not received a pay raise in five years.
title: True for much of the campaign, but she got one recently.

statement: The hour of sleep you lose during the change to daylight saving time might initially pose some health risks.
title: Daylight Saving claim dead on

statement: Says none of the government programs targeted for elimination or severe cutback in House Republican spending plans "appeared on the GAO's list of government programs at high risk of waste, fraud and abuse."
title: Risk-list areas escape House GOP budget ax

statement: "Oregon is the only state out of the 50 states in the USA that continues to pay 100% of the medical benefits for its employees and their families."
title: The list is shrinking but it's not that short

statement: Says a Lubbock terror suspect’s alleged plan "to use baby dolls to conceal chemical explosives" is similar to a 1995 plot "to blow up 12 jumbo jets over the Pacific Ocean."
title: Baby-doll connection

statement: Says Wisconsin Supreme Court Justice David Prosser "has prejudged matters that are likely to come before the court."
title: Candidate points only to general statements, no specific cases or issues

statement: Woonsocket needs a garbage-burning power plant because "residents are paying through the nose for electricity that’s fueled by foreign oil, at prices that are skyrocketing."
title: But we don't burn oil to generate electricity

statement: Ending federal funding for National Public Radio would jeopardize 9,000 jobs.
title: Wouldn't cost local stations a dime

statement: Central Health "is the only hospital district in Texas that spends taxpayer dollars on abortions."
title: As far as we can tell

statement: Oregon concealed gun applications include "home phone numbers, home address, Social Security numbers, what kinds of guns you have in the house … whether you were dishonorably discharged from the military, what controlled substances you are taking and  were you ever accused of -- accused, mind you -- of stalking."
title: Not quite a bulls-eye

statement: "A U.S. Government Accountability Office report says Planned Parenthood Federation of America cannot find some $1.3 billion given to it by the federal government from 2002 through 2008."
title: GAO found nothing of the sort

statement: "Withheld union dues fund half of Dem (Democratic) campaigns in Florida."
title: Not even close

statement: Says "legislation pending in the House would effectively limit or eliminate ‘time-and-a-half’ for people who work overtime."
title: Proposed compensatory-time wouldn't apply to all workers

statement: The HOPE scholarship "has helped turn our University System into one of the best in the Southeast, with two institutions ranked in the top 20 of public universities in the country."
title: Our flagship schools are more selective

statement: "About 22 percent of adults in Rhode Island and approximately 30 percent of youth (ages 10-17) are considered obese."
title: Claim is more bloated than our youth

statement: "Most Americans live within 50 miles of a nuclear power plant."
title: Most Americans live under the 50 mile shadow; but relatively few within 10 miles

statement: "The entire state of Florida led the nation last year with the most prison inmates committing tax fraud."
title: Even from behind bars, prisoners are scamming the system

statement: Wisconsin was embroiled in a "constitutional crisis" brought on by the Democratic senators fleeing the state for Illinois to block Gov. Scott Walker's budget-repair bill.
title: Unprecedented departure stymied action, but GOP had the tools to break the logjam. And did.

statement: "Due to a flaw in the 1995 Outer Continental Shelf Deep Water Royalty Relief Act numerous oil companies are now drilling in the Gulf of Mexico in federal lands and paying no royalties to the federal government."
title: Faulty leases the culprit that lets Big Oil off the hook

statement: Says Allen West helped thwart a terrorist plot by shooting a gun in the direction of an Iraqi detainee, then reported the incident to his superior and said it was wrong.
title: An interesting story about West's past

statement: The U.S. gives foreign aid to Cuba and Venezuela, even though those countries are our enemies.
title: Money is likelier to undercut ruling regimes, not bolster them

statement: "Since 1980, over 145 incidents have been documented of suction entrapment in swimming pools and spas, including 36 deaths of children."
title: At least 154 incidents since 1985 and more than 36 children

statement: "Since President Obama took office, gas prices have gone up 67 percent."
title: Higher gas prices under Obama. Context blaming him veers off course.

statement: Ohio Director of Job Creation "Mark Kvamme just clawed back about $900,000 from companies that made promises and they didn't keep them."
title: Claw back process underway but no money yet recovered

statement: "Not even expensive bottled water, like Perrier and Evian, are of good enough quality to pump out of mines in Southwest Virginia, according to the EPA regulation."
title: Confusing the issue with irrelevant claim

statement: "There is a growing body of evidence that radiation in excess of what the government says are the minimum amounts you should be exposed to are actually good for you and reduce cases of cancer."
title: Not the mainstream opinion

statement: Says taxpayer resources are being used "to facilitate private political agendas" through automatic payroll deduction of union dues.
title: Cost so small no one can quantify

statement: The coalition of Arab states against Libya’s Moammar Gadhafi is the biggest coalition against a fellow Arab leader since the Persian Gulf War in 1990-1991.
title: For now, anyway

statement: Says the state’s budget shortfall is "not that much different" than it was in 2003.
title: Notably bigger any way it's sliced

statement: "Eleven years ago, the city of Detroit lifted the residency requirement for police officers and today, 53 percent of officers live outside of the city. If we want the tax base of Milwaukee to resemble the tax base of Detroit, this is the way to go."
title: Number’s on target, but other factors are also involved in declining tax base

statement: Studies have shown that in the absence of federal reproductive health funds, we are going to see the level of abortion in Georgia increase by about 44 percent.
title: "Study" not "studies"

statement: "The Congressional Budget Office has this economic model where they measure the economy going forward, and they are now telling us that the entire economy crashes in the year 2037 because their computer simulation can't conceive of any way in which the U.S. economy can continue."
title: Some models do go haywire, but not all, and the timing isn't clear

statement: "According to 2009 estimates, an agreement with Panama could result in almost 1,900 Florida jobs in the first year – and about 15,000 jobs after five years."
title: A man a plan Panama!

statement: Says a "rather extraordinary amount of non-classroom employees" were added by Texas school districts over the last decade.
title: Highest growth in support and administrative posts

statement: Senate Democrats who left the state for weeks to delay a vote on union bargaining power exercised a "Wisconsin filibuster" provided by the state’s constitution.
title: The constitution left room for the maneuver, but doesn’t enshrine it as a “filibuster” tactic

statement: The GOP budget plan "would cut nearly a million jobs."
title: Depends on which economist you ask

statement: Says Oregon is "near the top or at the top of the list" when it comes to capital gains tax
title: Tied with Hawaii

statement: "If you look at the jobs lost in the private sector as opposed to the job gains in the public sector, it's out of whack. The government's growing and the private economy's shrinking."
title: Private sector jobs on the rise for the last year

statement: "What we have now is the most generous, in my opinion, 'good time' bill in the entire United States."
title: Most generous in New England, but not in U.S.

statement: The state of Wisconsin pays plumbers, engineers and other attorneys "much, much more" than it pays attorneys to represent poor people.
title: On the money with most, but off a bit with some contract plumbers

statement: "When I took office in 2003, we had very little reserves."
title: $10 million is more than "very little"

statement: Says "for the equivalent cost of a single mile of freeway, we have a bike infrastructure."
title: Points off for precision, but close

statement: The Texas Constitution "still contains Jim Crow provisions about the poll tax and restrictions on women having the right to vote."
title: Constitution may sprawl, but not these ways

statement: Says the majority of Americans support gay marriage.
title: Some polls agree, others say not quite yet

statement: The House budget plan proposes "the largest discretionary spending cut in history."
title: A case can be made for post World War II

statement: "Florida is one of only three states that require licenses for commercial interior designers."
title: Lawmakers targeting regulations

statement: Says it has offered $12 million in savings through 2011 and $184 million in savings over the next 25 years in contract negotiations with the City of Milwaukee.
title: The proposals would save money, but assumptions behind the math show the bottom line is off

statement: Says the state’s rainy day fund is "our insurance policy against a major natural disaster."
title: It's for anything lawmakers agree on (including disasters)

statement: Say easing restrictions on selling alcohol on Sundays will result in more traffic crashes and fatalities.
title: Sunday alcohol sales claim seems all wet

statement: "Lake Erie supports nearly 10 percent of Ohio's jobs and generates $750 million in state and local taxes."
title: Tax revenue is on the money, but jobs figure is overstated

statement: Says his bill, HB 97, would prevent the use of taxpayer dollars on abortions.
title: Health care law already prevents funding abortions

statement: "We have over 25 million people who live in Texas and less than 2 percent of them have" concealed handgun licenses.
title: Bull's-eye

statement: Says Texas colleges and universities may opt to allow guns on campuses.
title: One school district has done so under the law

statement: A proposed revenue smart cap "gives Floridians a voice, requiring a 60 percent vote by citizens in order to impose a new tax, fee, license, fine, charge or assessment."
title: A less than brilliant claim about smart cap

statement: "Twenty percent of our electricity currently comes from nuclear power plants. I think there are 104 in the United States, two of them around the coast in California."
title: Basically right on all three facts

statement: Says that Republicans "bragged about how every bill was going to be paid for, right from the beginning" and that the first vote, the repeal of health care reform, violated that rule.
title: GOP's new rules for the House gave this vote an exception

statement: Gov. Rick Perry "used $3.2 billion in stimulus dollars for schools to plug other holes in his budget."
title: Stimulus dollars went to education

statement: Building and running the Atlanta Streetcar is projected to create 1,399 jobs.
title: Those aren't actual jobs

statement: "Put simply, less government spending equals more private sector jobs."
title: He presents theory as fact

statement: Federal spending is "all discretionary, other than interest on the national debt. Social Security is discretionary. We have the discretion to change the law. Same is true with Medicare and Medicaid."
title: Laws that set mandatory spending can be changed

statement: "There are corporations in this nation, some of the biggest corporations in this nation, who do not pay taxes."
title: They're not paying and they're not cheating, either

statement: "Oil production from federal waters in the Gulf of Mexico reached an all-time high" in 2010.
title: True, but he ignores a decline that's already begun

statement: "Last year, American oil production reached its highest level since 2003."
title: Yes, but the numbers will get worse over the next two years

statement: "2008: Unions Spent $400 Million to Elect Obama."
title: Too many holes in a big number

statement: "For the first time in more than a decade, imports accounted for less than half of (the oil) we consumed."
title: Do you factor in oil exports or not?

statement: In fighting collective bargaining changes, Democrats are trying to "protect a system that pays unionized government workers 42 percent more than non-union workers."
title: Even the report’s author says the ad takes the number out of context

statement: "Georgia still has one of the richest programs in terms of scholarships for students to go to college."
title: Deal claim on the money

statement: The American Academy of Pediatrics "supports banning guns."
title: Group wants handgun ban

statement: Says that President Obama said in 2008 that his proposed greenhouse gas regulations "will bankrupt" anyone who wants to build a new coal-fired power plant.
title: Candidate Obama's views differ from President Obama's actions

statement: A bill that would halt the EPA from regulating greenhouse gases would help "stop rising gas prices."
title: Forget about the law helping at the pump today

statement: "We now work the longest hours of any people around the world."
title: Americans work longer than most, but not all

statement: "Seven of the 10" school districts with the lowest graduation rate for African-American boys in the country are in Florida.
title: Off on the number, but study shows problems

statement: Says taxes paid by the poorest residents of Texas are above the national average.
title: Close--$60--call

statement: "Democrats have now become the party of the [Atlanta] metro area and of blacks."
title: Are white rural Democrats becoming extinct?

statement: Says four-year terms for City Council members are "the norm in most cities of our size."
title: But cut that Austin to Boston connection

statement: At Twin River, "we're more than competitive" with nearby casinos in slot machine payouts.
title: You can bet on that

statement: Tapping the Strategic Petroleum Reserve would immediately lower gasoline prices
title: The effect on commodity prices is clearer

statement: Texans eat more catfish than residents of all other states combined.
title: Hooked us

statement: On the night of the Wisconsin state Senate vote on the budget package, "a mob showed up and busted down the door and took over the Capitol."
title: The rhetoric overstates the reality, but on some points not by much

statement: "A new ruling by the EPA would force dairy farmers to comply with the Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure Program when dealing with spilt milk -- the same regulations oil and natural gas producers must follow."
title: Udderly absurd

statement: Says Charlotte Nash "pretends to be a chicken farmer" in order to get property tax exemptions.
title: Chicken farmer claim doesn't exactly fly straight

statement: Says Texas school districts are the fifth largest employers in the world.
title: Counting more than 1,000 districts as single entity

statement: Says students who receive free or reduced lunch are "performing just as well" as students who do not.
title: Poorer students perform worse on FCAT, on average

statement: Tampa mayoral opponent Bob Buckhorn "supported forcing police officers to keep their guns locked in the trunks of their cruisers."
title: Police officers and managers came up with the policy

statement: "Our average private sector employee pays 23 percent for their health care. Our average city worker in Ohio pays 9 percent."
title: Government reports back this claim of premium disparity

statement: "Just 400 Americans -- 400 -- have more wealth than half of all Americans combined."
title: Rarely heard comparison rings true

statement: Says it’s a "statistical reality that most single moms are very poor, under-educated, can't get a job, and if it weren't for government assistance, their kids would be starving to death."
title: "Most" aren't on welfare or under-educated, and a big majority work

statement: "Any child born prematurely, according to the president, in his own words, can be killed."
title: Disagreement on abortion taken to an extreme

statement: "We know that every 85 visitors create one Florida job."
title: Tourist dollars help bolster jobs

statement: Says women who need a sonogram in the eighth to 10th week of pregnancy have to get a transvaginal sonogram.
title: To get a clear image, usually true

statement: "Roughly 25% of RI has a criminal record"
title: So wrong it’s almost criminal

statement: Says Rick Scott's proposed budget "would lay off 20,000 teachers."
title: Drawing conclusions on how district would absorb funding cuts

statement: Says iPads and iPhones "are built in the United States of America."
title: Designed in U.S., made in China

statement: Says Sen. Sherrod Brown admitted "that his $787 billion stimulus law failed" and "after specifically attacking Republicans for wanting to lower Americans' taxes, (he) now claims that his stimulus bill 'didn't do enough' to lower taxes."
title: A misquote here, some tweaked facts there ...

statement: "Since 1999, all Virginia Lottery profits have been used for public education in the Commonwealth for kindergarten through 12th grade."
title: No way to be sure before 2008

statement: Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker’s "budget okays disposing of unclaimed pound dogs to university research facilities."
title: It's a technical change to existing law ... and a practice that in practice does not happen

statement: A bill before the Georgia General Assembly would make presidential candidates meet citizenship requirements that are not in the U.S. Constitution.
title: Bill sponsor's theory on citizenship a natural-born dud

statement: "I have asked the Division of Emergency Management to report directly to me."
title: It already does

statement: Says Florida Gov. Rick Scott’s cuts to education are the same as his proposed corporate income tax rate reduction.
title: Numbers don't add up like Grayson said

statement: Bing Energy said it decided to move to Florida because of Gov. Rick Scott’s "plan to eliminate the corporate tax."
title: Yes, but there's also a high-tech contract with FSU

statement: "I delivered to you a budget that ... cuts taxes by $2 billion."
title: Real number is $1.7 billion

statement: "We ... sold the state airplanes as I had promised."
title: Not that everyone liked how it happened

statement: "On my first day in office, I ordered a review of every regulation in the pipeline and every contract exceeding $1 million."
title: Cabinet agencies said no thanks

statement: "Hitler didn't want unions. Stalin didn't want unions. Mubarak didn't want independent unions. These autocrats in history don't want independent unions."
title: Statement caused a stir, but is historically accurate

statement: "Secretly, unbeknownst to members of Congress, over $105 billion was hidden in the Obamacare legislation."
title: The number is right, but it wasn't secret

statement: Damage by protesters to the Wisconsin state Capitol will cost $7.5 million to repair.
title: Even the officials who used the number didn't believe it for long

statement: In the past decade, K-12 funding has grown six times faster than the rate of enrollment.
title: UPDATE: Adjusted for inflation

statement: State employees will have to pay 100 percent of their pensions and health insurance after 2012.
title: No evidence for this one.

statement: Wisconsin state and local government workers pay "$500, $600 or in some cases, $1,000" per year in union dues.
title: Some pay a little less, but the numbers generally are on target

statement: Says nobody in higher education believes Gov. Rick Perry’s proposal to "serve up $10,000 college degrees" is possible.
title: Not impossible, perhaps unlikely

statement: Says "union bosses" bused protesters to a Central Florida education protest.
title: The wheels on this claim come off and off

statement: "Under the clear letter of the law, (Justice Clarence Thomas) must recuse himself" from the case challenging the constitutionality of the health care law.
title: Legal experts disagree

statement: Says Justice Elena Kagan recused herself in "many cases where she had little role" as solicitor general, simply because of the appearance of a conflict of interest.
title: She's recused often, but because the law demands it

statement: In slashing $1.7 billion from Social Security, "Rep. Jim Renacci may end up forcing the entire agency to ... shut down for a month, causing seniors to not get their benefits on time, halting claims processing, and forcing new retirees and disabled workers into a backlog."
title: Hyper overstatement bolstered with hyperbole

statement: The health care bill has "six years of costs against 10 years of tax revenue."
title: Some benefits, taxes already here

statement: "We closed that plant down. It was a $27 million-dollar plant, operating full steam, and we closed it down."
title: She rallied the students and took them to meetings

statement: Texas "ranks third in teen pregnancies... and it is No. 1 in repeat teen pregnancies."
title: That's how Texas ranks in teen birth rates

statement: Says city of Portland has a one-time $22 million surplus
title: In fact, the surplus likely will be much smaller

source: Georgia Association of Latino Elected Officials
statement: Georgia legislation on immigration is a "copycat" of an Arizona immigration bill.
title: Georgia's bill tries to dodge Arizona law's problems

statement: "Last year it was discovered that Rhode Island's public employees ranked 4th in average pay, while the private sector ranked 23rd."
title: Check your source

statement: Texas would have to increase current state spending by 28 percent just to reach the national average for spending per resident.
title: Might be understatement

statement: Says Sheldon Whitehouse said on Senate floor: "Everybody in Rhode Island who disagrees with me about Obamacare is an Aryan, is a white supremacist."
title: Way over the top

statement: A telephone company will no longer have to provide landline service to customers if there is an alternative provider, including wireless.
title: Landlines no longer guaranteed

statement: A telecom bill could keep the State Corporation Commission from getting rate-of-return information from electric utilities.
title: Bad data feeds bellicosity

statement: Says broken compact fluorescent light bulbs "allegedly cause migraines and epilepsy attacks."
title: Flicker of science

statement: Says Oregon recyclers can't recycle plastic bags
title: They can be recycled but it's a pain

statement: "Thirty-five states have accepted high-speed intercity rail money."
title: This train claim is off the tracks

statement: Under Gov. Scott Walker’s proposals, "Money is being taken away from workers, and the tax breaks given to major corporations. "
title: Smaller paychecks for workers, tax breaks for employers

statement: "The average (public school) teacher in Wisconsin’s making $89,000 a year" in salary and benefits.
title: The correct average is actually 16 percent less

statement: In 2011, "the average annual compensation for a teacher in the Milwaukee Public Schools system will exceed $100,000."
title: The number is accurate. The same holds for several other Milwaukee area districts

statement: As part of efforts to rein in protesters, Republicans in Wisconsin have "bolted windows inside the Capitol shut."
title: Um, they’re actually re-securing the building after damage was done

statement: Says Michelle Obama has 43 people on her staff; Nancy Reagan had just 3.
title: Misinformed outrage

statement: Says neither President Barack Obama nor Mexico President Felipe Calderon "have been on the border to see what's happening to the citizens of Mexico, and for that matter the citizens of Texas."
title: Obama si, Calderon no

statement: "We have lost 600,000 jobs over the period of the last 10 years. Only Michigan and California have done worse."
title: Net loss was even greater from the peak in May 2000

statement: DeKalb County has cut more money from its general fund budget "than any local government in the Atlanta metro region."
title: Is DeKalb's CEO a big spender?

statement: "We've seen local union after local union rush to their school boards, their city councils, their technical school boards and rush through contracts in the past two weeks that had no contributions to the pension and no contribution to health care."
title: Some accelerated a bit, but all were in the works and some are sticking to regular meeting schedule

statement: Says the Army is spending $7 million to sponsor a NASCAR team.
title: It's a billboard on wheels

statement: Says Rep. Paul Ryan’s budget "roadmap … doesn't balance the budget until the 2060s and … adds an unthinkable $62 trillion to the national debt between now and then."
title: Correct up to 2063. By 2080, the debt disappears

statement: Gov. Bob McDonnell in 2010 "did not even create enough jobs to keep pace with population growth" in Virginia.
title: A blend of truth and misleading figures

statement: "For every $10,000 invested in business incubators, up to nearly 70 local jobs are generated."
title: Job creation numbers outpace other federal programs

statement: Says many local governments in Wisconsin already require employees to pay 20 percent, 30 percent or even 40 percent of their health insurance premiums.
title: A few examples in her area, but it's far from common

statement: Says the state share of Texas public education spending increased 82 percent over the past decade, reaching $20 billion in 2009.
title: More spending, but less state support

statement: Says the high-speed rail project provides "short-term jobs."
title: Most jobs only last two years

statement: "We’re broke. We don’t have any more money."
title: As a political argument, it may work. But as a financial one? Experts say not so much

statement: "There are nearly 500,000 registered sex offenders across the country and at any one time about 100,000 are unaccounted for."
title: He got one number wrong, the other is questionable

statement: The high-speed rail project would create "60,000-plus jobs for Floridians."
title: Jobs? Yes. 60,000? Not close.

statement: The 2006 Massachusetts health care law has "added (only) about 1 percent to our state budget."
title: The feds kicked in money, though.

statement: Says Barack Obama grew up in Kenya.
title: Even Huckabee said it wasn't right

statement: Says Wendy’s founder "Dave Thomas left the state literally on his deathbed to avoid the estate tax."
title: Where's the beef? No meat in this claim

statement: "Most federal employees do not have collective bargaining for benefits, nor for pay."
title: Some exceptions, but most federal employees can only negotiate working conditions

statement: "We’ve now gained private sector jobs 12 months in a row."
title: Kaine close on job numbers

statement: Under a proposed Georgia law, "women who miscarry could become felons."
title: Bill's vague language makes it possible

statement: Says Tri-Rail shows the potential problems with investing in high-speed rail.

statement: "Unfortunately we have documented instances where people defecated in the (Statehouse) building."

statement: "A miscarriage is considered an abortion."

statement: "The right-to-work states have much lower level of unemployment than the union states do."

statement: The stimulus bill "promised to keep unemployment under 8%."

statement: "From 2003 to 2006, 'Sesame Street' made more than $211 million from toy and consumer product sales."

statement: "The American people have endured 21 consecutive months of 9% or higher unemployment [and] 2.6 million jobs have been lost," since the stimulus bill was signed.

statement: An illegal immigrant who gains admission at a public college takes class space away from students who are legal residents.

statement: The law has not established whether Rhode Island public employees have property rights to their pensions.

statement: Under former President George W. Bush’s administration "while the population in that period grew by 10 percent, the number of jobs in the nation grew by 1 percent."

statement: "Twelve percent of the garbage collected in those SOLV cleanups, by volume, is plastic bags."

statement: "We don’t have bars on campus in Texas. It’s against the law... no alcohol allowed."

statement: If public employees don’t pay more for benefits starting April 1, 2011, "the equivalent" is 1,500 state employee layoffs by June 30, 2011 and 10,000 to 12,000 state and local government employee layoffs in the next two years.

statement: Says Florida's pension plan faces the same long-term funding problems as Social Security.

statement: Tim Kaine wants to thwart "right-to-work reform measures in Midwest battleground states."

statement: One half of federal spending goes to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid while the other half goes to other programs funded with money "borrowed from a foreign land."

statement: If there’s a government shutdown, "people don’t get their Social Security checks."

statement: Gov. Rick Scott's sale of the state planes was "not proper."

statement: When it comes to protesters in Madison, "almost all" are now from outside of Wisconsin.

statement: "The (Wisconsin) governor has proposed tax giveaways to corporations."

statement: "State employees haven't received a raise in five or six years."

statement: The president’s proposed budget "will help reduce the deficit by $400 billion over the next decade to the lowest level since Dwight Eisenhower was president."

statement: Hitler "abolished unions and that’s what" Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker is "doing today."

statement: The House of Delegates budget bill "cuts $50 million from education."

statement: When it comes to urgency on passing a budget repair bill, "there’s no rush on this thing" because the fiscal year doesn’t end until June 30, 2011.

statement: Says families now pay out 40 percent of their income to taxes.

source: Distilled Spirits Council of the United States

statement: A 2005 gay pride vote "had nothing to do with discrimination."

statement: Oregon Health Plan rations "covered procedures under certain circumstances"

statement:
Says his state budget will "provide an increase in state funding

statement: "Six institutions in our country now control two thirds of the capital."
title: Two-thirds of something, but it's not capital

statement: "We're borrowing 40 cents of every dollar we spend."
title: Living beyond our means, yep

statement: "The American people say, don't touch Social Security, don't touch Medicare, don't cut defense. That's 84 percent of the federal budget."
title: That includes a few other entitlements, too

statement: Says required state septic inspections would cost septic tank owners $100 to $150 every five years.
title: People say the cost stinks

statement: "Since taking office, President Obama has signed into law spending increases of nearly 25 percent for domestic government agencies, an 84 percent increase when you include the failed stimulus."
title: Closer ... but no cigar

statement: The health care law "is accelerating our country toward bankruptcy."
title: May depend on Congress' stomach for proposed Medicare cuts

statement: "While the government grew, we lost more than 2 million jobs."
title: Conflicting data, time frames undercut claim

statement: "Of the top five cities for staged automobile accidents, three are in Florida. … We rank No. 1 in the country in staged auto accidents."
title: But not all suspected staging is actual staging

statement: Says he "helped lead an outside audit that’ll save (Milwaukee County) taxpayers over $200 million."
title: The idea was already on the table. And that savings could end up a loss

statement: The federal government "now tells us which light bulbs to buy."
title: A low-voltage notion

statement: "The Interior Department is in charge of salmon while they're in fresh water, but the Commerce Department handles them when they're in saltwater."
title: The fish swim free across regulatory surf

statement: The federal government "may put 16,500 IRS agents in charge of policing President Obama's health care bill."
title: That number is speculative at best

statement: "The White House promised us that all the spending would keep unemployment under 8 percent."
title: Projection, not a promise

statement: "Republican (small business tax cut) bill spends $80 million for better Google searches, not job creation"
title: It’s a tax cut bill, not an increase – but, as we’ve noted, amount per business is very small

statement: Says a "Canadian provincial prime minister came to Ohio for his medical treatment because of the delay in Canadian health care which would have endangered his life."
title: O Canada! Accuracy missing in this tale of the True North

statement: Says that 98,184 Texans are now driving with temporary driver’s licenses lacking their photos.
title: Cited number reflects DWI arrests last year

statement: "The debt will soon eclipse our entire economy."
title: He's right: A landmark is looming

statement: The United States has "one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world."
title: Obama uses GOP talking point, and gets it right

statement: "We are living with a legacy of deficit-spending that began almost a decade ago."
title: A much longer legacy than that.

statement: "As many as a quarter of our students aren’t even finishing high school."
title: A dicey statistic, but prefaced with needed caution

statement: "Two years after the worst recession most of us have ever known ... corporate profits are up."
title: In fact, profits are on pace to set an all-time record

statement: "The number of inmates since 2000 on death row dying of natural causes has now surpassed the number of inmates executed."
title: Cannon makes his case for court reform

statement: A national organization says Georgia has one of America’s toughest ethics laws.
title: State lawmaker's ethics claim lacks greater context

statement: Poll results from the past 35 years show that State of the Union speeches "do not move" presidential approval numbers.
title: Actually, presidents are likelier to lose ground after speech

statement: More people die from "medical misadventures" than firearm accidents nationally and in Florida.
title: Should you fear an accidental slip of the scalpel more than a firearm?

statement: Texas leads "the nation in the percentage of residents without health insurance."
title: We're No. 1!

statement: "We’ve saved over $100 million of (health care) costs" in Milwaukee County. "I did that."
title: Costs are higher, but not as high as they would otherwise be, and Holloway played a key role

statement: Says the Defense Department shrink-wrapped $10.8 billion in American money, loaded it on 175 pallets and put it on a transport plane to Iraq where they passed out $100 bills and no one has any receipts.
title: Yes to shrink-wrapped bundles, but no to taxpayer bucks

statement: George Allen voted for budgets that increased the national debt by $16,400 for every second he served in the U.S. Senate.
title: She actually underestimated the total

statement: "Despite the administration telling us (health care reform) was going to reduce health care costs, they now acknowledge it's going to dramatically increase health care costs."
title: We missed that stump speech

statement: Says a Portland school gives Muslim students "their own school provided prayer room, prayer rugs," and lets them "out of class five times a day to pray to Allah."
title: We couldn’t find a prayer room anywhere

statement: "New England already has access to ample supplies of natural gas."
title: Enough is enough

statement: A test last month at the MAX station at 162nd Avenue and East Burnside saw crime down 41 percent compared with December 2009
title: The early numbers are intriguing

statement: "It is estimated that every $100 million spent on construction generates 3,000 new jobs."
title: Governor's numbers don't add up

statement: Says the first word spoken from the moon was "Houston."
title: Governor, we have a problem

statement: "There was no panhandling when I left office."
title: Oh, you mean THOSE panhandlers?

statement: The health care law includes tort reform.
title: No limits on medical lawsuits

statement: The governor has made a "commitment to billions of dollars in debt and new spending without any explanation of how he plans to pay that money back."
title: He voted for the missing plan...twice

statement: The financial regulatory bill "will kill jobs."
title: What about jobs saved by the new regulations?

statement: Says that "data from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities suggest that the Texas budget gap is worse than New York’s, about as bad as California’s, but not quite up to New Jersey levels."
title: New Jersey reference is off

statement: Gov. Scott Walker hired convicted Assembly Speaker Scott Jensen to oversee a raid on the state employee retirement system to help balance the state budget.
title: It’s based on a fake newspaper article. It’s a hoax. Stop passing it on, people

statement: The impact of the 2010 federal health care legislation will be "huge" on Georgia.
title: Deal healthcare projection needs more detail

statement: "Ben Franklin once quipped that only two things in life were certain: death and taxes. I think even he didn't envision that the tax man would visit on the day of your death."
title: This Founding Father was mistrustful of great wealth

statement: The health care law is "job killing."
title: The GOP cherry-picks its studies

statement: Says 2010 was the "worst year ever for America's doctors" reimbursed by Medicare.
title: Based on rates, not even the worst this decade

statement: "92 percent" of President Barack Obama's administration has "never worked outside government."
title: Repeating an old Glenn Beck line

statement: "We had a debate on whether ‘ObamaCare’ was the way to go to fix up health care and the American voters said no -- emphatically."
title: Recent polls on repeal show a much murkier picture

statement: Under federal law, Jared Loughner "would not have been able to buy a gun" had he been identified as mentally ill.
title: With one caveat, he's right on target

statement: Between 2000 and 2006,  "health insurance company profits quadrupled."
title: Profits soared

statement: "Between the year 2000 and 2006, (insurance) premiums in this country doubled."
title: Pretty close to double

statement: The nation's food supply is "99.99 percent safe."
title: Congressman confuses apples for oranges

statement: Says he’s the first Aggie governor of Texas.
title: Cue the band

statement: If the Stamp Farm wind turbine is built, the "health risk of 'flicker' impact created by shadows of blades of turbines poses real and significant health risks, particularly seizures."
title: A lot of hot air

statement: "The refusal of many federal employees to fly coach costs taxpayers $146 million annually."
title: Slightly overheated but basically correct

statement: In Wisconsin, 98 percent of all small businesses will qualify for income-tax relief under my plan, freeing them to expand and create jobs.
title: With relief for some as low as $1, even small business group leader says it’s no job creator

statement: Under current U.S. immigration policy, "literally one person with a green card" can, in the extreme, bring in more than 270 of his relatives.
title: No huddled masses. More like a party of two.

statement: Says that before health care reform, one of every three health care dollars spent -- more than $800 billion a year -- didn't go for health care.
title: 30 percent plus is the bitter corporate pill

statement: "Some of the men serving in the (Afghan) armed forces have never driven a vehicle before."
title: An army of newbie drivers

statement: Says Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine is hypocritical for challenging the constitutionality of the new health care law.
title: Last we checked, “voluntary” didn't mean "required"

statement: "The incoming Republican freshman class – well, it’s no ordinary group: nearly half of its roughly 80 members have never served in elective office before."
title: Walden’s 50 percent claim falls short

statement: "Martin Luther King Jr. was a Republican!"
title: Evidence not there

statement: "This kind of snowstorm happens every 10 or 15 years."
title: Snowstorm one for the ages? History shows it was rare.

statement: "Recent studies have confirmed that any academic benefits of government funded preschool disappear by the fourth grade."
title: But what about the scores of studies on the other side?

statement: "Every dropout costs us $72,000 for the life of that person."
title: That's one rough estimate

statement: The health care reform law "offset[s] 6 years of benefits with 10 years of tax increases."
title: Some benefits as well as some taxes come early

statement: TriMet is "spending 4.2 million in fed funds to save $168K per year."
title: There’s more to the return than dollars saved

statement: "On average, Americans spend less than 10 percent of their disposable income on food. Compare that to folks in Mexico, who spend 22 percent, China, 28 percent and Russia, 37 percent."
title: Numbers are off, idea is right

statement: Virginia ranked 35th in job creation in 2009 under Gov. Tim Kaine, and moved up to third for 2010, while McDonnell has been in office.
title: Uses statistics that draw the starkest contrast

statement: Says 15,000 IRS employees "have to be added to administer ‘ObamaCare’ and look at the tax implications."
title: The number has not been set, though he may end up in the ballpark

statement: "Whether you like to admit it or not, half our general revenue goes to education."
title: A bad sign for education funding in a bad economy

statement: "A record number of Hispanics were elected to the U.S House of Representatives..."
title: Hispanic Republicans more than doubled in the House

statement: The White House "branded" the memorial service for the Tucson shootings with a "Together We Thrive" logo and slogan.
title: All our idea, says University of Arizona

statement: "When we look at the number of murders in the United States (in) 2009, we had 9,500 people murdered. When we look around the world, we see ... large countries, the U.K., Germany, Japan had 200 or less killed in a year."
title: The differences are dramatic

statement: "I have fought for our shared values without being an ideologue or a partisan"
title: Following the money suggests otherwise when it comes to partisanship

statement: Says she condemned violence at a campaign stop in Arizona in March.
title: Palin defends herself accurately

statement: Ohio taxpayers spent more than $67 million "for the year" on food stamps and Medicaid for Wal-Mart workers
title: Precise figure doesn't exist

statement: Says the claims that Texas faces a $27 billion shortfall "are flat-out false."
title: Based on subset of agency budget requests, actually

statement: "We had an amendment in the health care law that said the federal government is going to take over education."
title: Student loan reform doesn't equal a "takeover"

statement: Members of Congress and their families and staff are exempt from repaying student loans.
title: A new twist on an old favorite

statement: "Saturday's shootings reflect a disturbing trend. Mass shootings have become commonplace since the Virginia Tech massacre in 2007. There have been dozens of incidents where three or more people have been fatally wounded. Hundreds have died."
title: The numbers are right, but trendline isn't clear

statement: Says he "had to impose tougher cost controls on state employees than" any previous Wisconsin governor.
title: Experts tend to agree, but note the tough times dictated the tough measures

statement: Georgia lawmakers fuel up for the session by feasting on "wild" hogs.
title: Peach state lawmakers go hog-wild for feral pig the night before the session starts

statement: "Following the 2009 session," Texas House Speaker Joe Straus "was acknowledged and ‘thanked’ for his ‘tireless efforts’ by Planned Parenthood, the nation’s premier abortion provider."
title: Thanks in absentia

statement: Says the person who Florida U.S. Rep. Allen West first hired as chief of staff told people attending a Tea Party rally that, 'We will use bullets if ballots don't work.'
title: Calls for civility in the wake of the Arizona shooting

statement: Obama’s mid-term approval ratings are similar to other presidents who went on to re-election.
title: Mid-term marks below average but above Reagan's in first term

statement: The City of Milwaukee "uses the building inspection area as a revenue base."
title: State law says fees can’t be put into other parts of the budget

statement: "In my 12 years in the House, I have watched my district go from a solidly Democratic district to a heavily solid Republican district."
title: District was Republican friendly last century

statement: "Our spending has caught up with us, and our debt soon will eclipse the entire size of our national economy."
title: This debt illustration is on the money

statement: Wisconsin’s lawsuit rules are so anti-business that the state’s system is "one of the most promiscuous" in America.
title: The main study cited actually shows the opposite.

statement: Portland spent nearly $1 million in federal stimulus money to install bike path signs where they already existed.
title: Except it didn’t

statement: New provisions of the health care law bar the use of flexible spending accounts and health savings accounts to pay for aspirin and other non-prescription health needs.
title: He's the Bayer of bad news

statement: In preparing a rules package for the 112th Congress, the GOP had no discussions with Democrats.
title: GOP reached out to several House Democrats

statement: The state is able to sharply curtail contract bargaining rights for state employee unions.
title: The state set up the rules, so it can change them

statement: "You’ll find blacks in almost every regiment throughout the South who fought right alongside white Southerners," during the Civil War.
title: No, you can't count Confederate slaves as soldiers

statement: Says the 3C Corridor train would have taken  "an hour and 15 minutes longer" to carry passengers across Ohio "than it would have taken on a New York Central train in 1935."
title: Truth all aboard for this train story

statement: "The richest 1 percent of America will get a bigger tax cut through this bill than the family income of the average family here in Central Texas."
title: What's average?

statement: "There hasn't really been a lot of net growth in the federal workforce when you compare it to say, 1990."
title: But use of government contractors has soared

statement: Says he "led the effort to build a new (University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee) engineering campus in Wauwatosa."
title: Supportive? Yes. The leader? No.

statement: "It's taken more time to complete the Towpath Trail than it did to build the (Ohio & Erie) Canal."
title: Taking longer although the distance is much shorter

statement: Says the state's Medicaid waiver proposal "has languished in a file cabinet at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for more than two years."
title: It was False once. Repeating claim sets meter aflame

statement: "The Democratic majority led the 111th Congress to spend more money in two years than the first 100 congresses before them combined."
title: Close to what got a fellow Young Gun a Pants on Fire

statement: "More than 125 jobs have been created" at the Milwaukee Job Corps Center.
title: The missing context: These are the federally-funded jobs to run the just-opened center

statement: "I stopped requesting earmarks in 2008."
title: Earmark-less

statement: "Ohio has lost more population than every other state in the country except for two."
title: Claim of decline doesn't add up

statement: State governments have little ability to stimulate job growth in the short run.
title: Sorry. There is no free lunch.

statement: "We can save $125 billion in simply not giving out money to Medicare recipients that don't exist for procedures that didn't happen."
title: Medicare's improper payments less than half that

statement: "I never proposed privatizing the (Milwaukee County) airport."
title: Even a county union leader says plan, if passed, would not have fit the definition

statement: "We're worse than a Third World country in terms of water quality and the way we treat our sewage."
title: Experts say he's not just full of it

statement: The city of Atlanta has $56 million in its reserves.
title: Mayor's budget claim shows budget in black

statement: "Rhode Island has the highest percentage of uninsured adults of any state in New England."
title: Compared to U.S., we're not so bad

statement: "In 1998, nearly half of Florida's fourth-graders were functionally illiterate. Today, 72% of them can read."
title: Reading test scores have improved dramatically

statement: "We have the highest (corporate tax rates) in the world right now."
title: Sayonara, Japan. We're No. 1!

statement: "I represent the fourth-poorest (congressional) district" in the nation.
title: Mix-up leaves Moore off by a bunch – 14 spots to be exact

statement: "We are one of only two states to have eight consecutive months of declining unemployment. Twenty-one states had increased unemployment last month. Ours went down."
title: To whom will history give the credit?

statement: Says Texas Railroad Commissioner Michael Williams has attended more than 150 tea party gatherings.
title: Divide by 10

statement: "The Greenest County in America."
title: Sorry DeKalb, there is green grass on the other side

statement: Proposed federal regulations would affect every street sign in the country
title: Not a capital idea, he says

statement: Says one out of three U.S. homeless men is a veteran.
title: Outdated shocker

statement: Says "there is a plan formulated by Chair (Lynn) Peterson and the cities in Clackamas County to further increase this fee in three years and split it up on projects between the county and cities."
title: Not quite yet.

statement: "In the last five years, 28,000 people have been killed along the U.S.-Mexico border."
title: Deaths only in Mexico -- and not only along border

statement: "In 1981, Matagorda, Brazoria, and Galveston Counties all opted out of the Social Security program for their employees. Today, their program is very, very well-funded and there is no question about whether it’s going to be funded in" years to come.
title: Happy history, but employees also had a safety net

statement: The tax-cut deal "adds more than $800 billion to the deficit over two years -- more than the cost of TARP and more than the cost of the Recovery Act" and about the same as health care reform.
title: He's right on two, close on the third

statement: Texas "children may have a teacher who never spent one minute practicing teaching."
title: No law to practice teaching in the classroom, but other training is required

statement: "Over 80 percent of the people want the shot to vote" on whether to approve same-sex marriage, according to polls.
title: Do loaded questions matter?

statement: "All but one of the 50 states already have some form of a balanced budget amendment in their state constitutions."
title: Snappy statement that's not so simple

statement: Portland Public Schools invites "well-paid, well-fed school bureaucrats, administrators, teachers, other staff, non-needy students, affluent parents of students, and other adults, including on the other extreme the adult homeless, illegal aliens, fanatical Muslim terrorists, or drug addicted street people, to enjoy cheap breakfasts in taxpayer-paid school facilities amidst school children."
title: Quite a mouthful but not really right

statement: "The Governor did not consult members of his own party before he released his [transportation] plan."
title: Many Republicans were in the loop

statement: Says Texas Republican leaders "have proposed laying off thousands of teachers."
title: We missed the "calls for layoffs" headline for a reason

statement: House Speaker Dean Cannon says that freshmen lawmakers account for one-third of the 120-member House, and that two-thirds of the chamber have two years or less experience.
title: Term limits = less experienced House

statement: "We continue to see these isolated incidents of people trying to vote five, six times a day."
title: Some cases of double voting, but none of quintuple or sextuple ballots

statement: Says that "all those who do not answer directly to the president, they've said (repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell) is a terrible idea."
title: Split decision

statement: Four out of 10 homicides are committed by gun in this city.
title: Stabbing deaths are second in line

statement: "Sen. Joe Biden, the ranking member of the Foreign Relations Committee, recommended partitioning Iraq into three separate entities."
title: Biden didn't want to turn one country into three

statement: Unemployment and the housing and auto industry crises can be fixed by giving a million dollars to every worker over age 50 to retire.
title: The TARP bailout was a LOT cheaper

statement: "We have dozens of districts that go for 150 to 200 miles, splitting counties, splintering cities and connecting areas that have very little in common."
title: Florida's political map is crawling with salamanders

statement: "You can go to Georgia and make about $6,000 more a year as a teacher."
title: Will Florida's teachers flee for a bigger paycheck in the peach state?

statement: "CEOs now earn 431 times what their workers earn."
title: The old pay gap, it ain't what it used to be.

statement: Says the University of Wisconsin football program is spending almost all of its Bowl Championship Series payout on a Rose Bowl junket for politically connected officials
title: Even Sykes admits his fiery claim burns too hot

statement: Says that "on average, Democratic congressional districts received 81 percent more stimulus funds than Republican districts."
title: Excluding state capitals, figure drops to 29 percent

statement: Those who fail to buy health insurance under "Obamacare" face the threat of jail time.
title: No one is going to the Big House

statement: The Milwaukee business community "did not speak about the facts" -- and in support of train manufacturer Talgo -- as the Milwaukee-Madison rail link was being killed.
title: Divided membership left Talgo at the station

statement: Once people become citizens under the DREAM Act "and turn 21, they can sponsor their illegal immigrant parents for legalization."
title: U.S. citizens 21 and older can sponsor their parents for a visa

statement: Earmarks requested in a federal spending bill included  "$277,000 for potato pest management in Wisconsin."
title: McCain hit this earmark right on the nose

statement: Says Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood will "force you to stop using your cell phone" while driving.
title: This claim is stuck in a dead spot

statement: Teachers "are working their third consecutive year -- some longer than that -- without salary increases."
title: Most got raises for 2008-09 school year

statement: TSA "started off with 16,500 screeners and the agency has mushroomed to 67,000 employees with 3,590 administrative people ... making over $105,000 per year on average."
title: Mica cherry picking his 'started with' figure

statement: Right-to-work states "have higher rates of income growth."
title: The lawmaker’s numbers may be close, but economic experts say the cause-and-effect link is weak

statement: "Every student paying out-of-state tuition actually covers more than the cost of instruction."
title: Out-of-state tuition pays the bills and then some

statement: The Democrats' health care reform law is a "government takeover of health care."
title: Saying it doesn't make it true

statement: "Since January 2008 the private sector has lost nearly 8 million jobs while local, state and federal governments added 590,000."
title: Public-sector number is wrong in at least three ways

statement: "Already, the mayor of Green Bay is having ribbon-cutting after ribbon-cutting for economic development around the new VA center."
title: Um, ground hasn’t even been broken on the clinic itself yet

statement: Says that in his first 17 months as president, the United States doubled its world-leading $500 million a year commitment to fighting global AIDS.
title: A lasting surge

statement: "We are the only state in the country that state employees don't contribute [to their pensions]."
title: More and more, states are asking their employees to pay

statement: "When Social Security was passed, there were all kinds of lawsuits," just as there have been in the legal battle over the new health care law.
title: Some striking similarities

statement: Sen. Jim Webb "persists on negating" Sen. Mark Warner’s votes
title: Webb and Warner in sync on 87 percent of votes

statement: Says Lee Leffingwell has been mayor of Austin, Texas "for about as long as Sarah Palin was governor of Alaska."
title: Look for Leffingwell-Begala ticket in '12

statement: "[State Rep. Doug McKillip’s] donors deserve a refund."
title: A Democrat today, a Republican tomorrow, No refund required

statement: Mt. Hood Community College is No. 1 on average and top faculty pay and benefits.
title: MHCC is No. 1

statement: The tax cut deal is giving "$700 billion to millionaires and billionaires."
title: 10-year estimate used overly broadly on 2-year deal

statement: "On the question on the DREAM Act, no -- no to granting lower tuition to illegals."
title: Tuition rates are left up to states

statement: "One in 19 Americans today get SSDI or SSI. That's one in 19 Americans (who) are disabled."
title: Coburn's number is very close

statement: Under the compromise tax agreement, "99.7% of American families will not pay 1 nickel in an estate tax."
title: Very few would be subject to estate tax

statement: Governor-elect Scott Walker’s opposition to high-speed rail "killed 13,000 Wisconsin jobs"
title: The number is rife with double-counting – even the original source has corrected it to simply “thousands”

statement: "Toledo … is fourth in the nation behind much bigger cities — Miami, Las Vegas, Portland — in number of human trafficking arrests and rescues."
title: Experts say it's more hype than reality

statement: Beaverton "enjoys the most diverse population (by percentage of population) among Oregon cities."
title: A look at newer numbers says otherwise

statement: The Atlanta Braves are "the oldest continuously operating professional sports franchise in America."
title: Braves' origins go back, back, back to 1871

statement: The Obama-GOP compromise "raises taxes, it raises the death tax."
title: Only compared to 2010

statement: "Barack Obama is in an economy that's only worsened since he's been president of the United States."
title: Progress on GDP growth and income, but stubborn problems on jobs

statement: "A 5 percent increase in domestic production would increase the world supply by less than 1 percent and do almost nothing to our dependence on foreign oil. This would also have virtually no effect on the price of gas at the pump."
title: Baby hold off on that drill

statement: "I have always been focused on reining in the deficit."
title: Votes are on both sides and it has hardly been a signature issue during his time in office

statement: Says Joe Straus "was co-author of a bill that would have allowed Planned Parenthood to control public school sex education."
title: The state and local governments control sex ed

statement: Says Jim Renacci ran against the Washington establishment in the election, but is now "hypocritically embracing it with big money, special interest fundraisers."
title: PAC cash accounts for about 15 percent of campaign contributions

statement: "Sixteen [federal] programs exist to fight homelessness" and some of them are duplicative.
title: Kingston claim on federal programs largely on the mark

statement: State employees in Wisconsin earn "about 8 percent less" than if they worked in the private sector.
title: Number cited is national, not state, and what about those benefits costs?

statement: Says federal health care overhaul will cost Texas state government "upwards of $30 billion over the next 10 years."
title: Governor rounding up 10-year figure that doesn't start until 2014

statement: Rhode Island spends less than 10 percent of what the average state spends promoting tourism.
title: Not if you consider population

statement: The Bush-era tax cuts failed to increase employment and "work-force participation fell in 2001 and has never returned to the record level set in 2000."
title: Don't forget, there was a recession

statement: You "can't check out a library book without a photo ID."
title: Yes, you can (with a library card)

statement: "Last year, ExxonMobil made $19 billion in profit. Guess what. They paid zero in taxes. They got a $156 million refund from the IRS."
title: Eye-popping stat that isn't accurate

statement: The state has "less employees this year than we did last year."
title: Barely, but still more than in 2006
