statement: In 2007, "the top 1 percent of all income earners in the United States made 23.5 percent of all income," which is "more than the entire bottom 50 percent."
title: The studies agree, with only slight variations

statement: Eliminating the state tax on health savings accounts will "make it easier for small business owners to provide health insurance to their employees."
title: Would it benefit consumers? Sure. But little evidence it will help businesses provide coverage

statement: Oregonians have an "amazing no-cost way to fight abortion" with free political donations
title: It's better to give when it's free

statement: "An overwhelming majority of Americans support passage of the DREAM Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for undocumented youth willing to work for a college degree or serve in our armed forces."
title: Words matter, especially in polls

statement: "I think [a little] less than half of the people in our prisons are in there for less than a year.  ... We have people who are check kiters and don't pay child support and we are locking them up in the state pen."
title: Plugged system now at 133 percent capacity

statement: In the case of a catastrophic event, the Atlanta-area offices of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will self-destruct.
title: New Zombie Apocalypse myth earns a pickaxe to the head

statement: Sheldon Whitehouse and 18 other senators "voted to censor the internet."
title: That's not what the vote did

statement: "The cost-saving measures we put into place at Columbia/HCA drove down national health care inflation from 18% to 8% in seven years."
title: Scott cites data about employer costs and called that inflation

statement: There are "10 or 20 deaths a year from foodborne illness" in the United States.
title: There are at least 25 times as many

statement: The national debt grew an estimated $15 billion last weekend.
title: The estimate, though accurate, varies from actual numbers

statement: When it comes to the state deficit, Wisconsin is "proportionally in as much trouble as the State of California."
title: By one measure, she’s close – by another not as much

statement: Cities like Seattle have decided to ban food carts.
title: Not outlawed, just heavily regulated

statement: "Ohio is losing over 700 family farms a year, some of them just to pay the inheritance tax."
title: Agriculture remains important to Ohio's economy

statement: "150,000 (oil spill) claims have been filed by Floridians, but only 40 percent of them have been paid."
title: Claims process has been slow going

statement: When President Franklin D. Roosevelt started Social Security, "it only affected widows and orphans," and when Medicare began, "it was a small program."
title: A grain of truth in the big picture, far off on the details

statement: The U.S. "had the opportunity with Israel coming and talking to us about improving our security screening procedures, and we turned them down."
title: Did West mean that the U.S. blew off meeting with Israel or blew off Israel's solutions?

statement: Under the DREAM Act, after two years of higher education or military service "you are eligible for citizenship. Once a citizen, this paves the way to bring the rest of (your) extended family to the United States."
title: Not so easy, and not all your extended family

statement: "They tried to give us $400 million to build a high-speed train that goes 39 miles an hour."
title: Speed figure isn't on board with revised estimates

statement: Says the military accounts for about 10 percent of Florida's economy.
title: Florida is more than just tourism

statement: "There are polls showing right now that the American people for the most part think it's a bad idea to provide tax cuts to the wealthy."
title: A plurality, not a majority, in most polls

statement: Republicans "created a trillion dollar prescription drug entitlement program without paying for it."
title: He's close on the cost for the next decade

statement: "It’s illegal for a state to say we’re simply going to cut off (union contract) negotiations. There’s a legal requirement that you are involved in good faith bargaining."
title: Numerous experts tend to side with Doyle, but it’s not unanimous -- or as clear as the governor suggests

statement: "Understand, this is unemployment insurance. It’s not welfare, as a lot of my Republican colleagues like to suggest it is. You pay into it when you’re working. You get help when you’re not."
title: Generally correct, but extended benefits work differently

statement: The city of Atlanta ranks 25th among U.S. cities with the highest crime rates.
title: Just because your city makes the list doesn't mean you're unsafe

statement: "In Florida, illegal immigration costs taxpayers nearly $4 billion (a year). This amounts to $700 for every household in Florida."
title: A case study in not always trusting studies

statement: "The senior senator from Arizona (John McCain) said he couldn't support repealing 'don't ask, don't tell' because of the economy."
title: McCain's economy argument was about priorities

statement: The Pentagon's survey about the "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy found that 92 percent of service members "agree that they could serve ... in a unit in combat" without compromising "mission readiness."
title: Correct for troops who think they served with someone gay, but not for all troops

statement: The DREAM Act the "would give amnesty to over two million illegal aliens."
title: Potentially eligible not the same as actual

statement: In Wisconsin, "6.2 percent of the population is black yet 24 percent of all state abortions are on African-Americans."
title: Numbers may be accurate, but behind them is a false comparison

statement: "We are giving almost $2 billion of taxpayer money to the junk food and fast food industries every year to make the (childhood obesity) epidemic worse."
title: Dollar number short changes accuracy

statement: A National Football League lockout would cost Atlanta $160 million in lost jobs and revenue.
title: Economic impact claim goes wide right

statement: "In 2009, Jim Doyle and the Democrats rushed through a budget repair bill with billions in tax increases and held no public hearings."
title: Even an aide says the "billions" is off

statement: "Barack Obama's health care bill is nothing new. Mitt Romney signed one just like it four years before."
title: Something Rick Perry and Howard Dean agree on

statement: Measures taken by my administration "have saved taxpayers $1 billion."
title: By our calculations, he comes pretty close

statement: Says more than $3.5 billion in state revenue that is supposed to be dedicated to basic needs and functions is being diverted to "make the books look balanced."
title: Budget balancing for real

statement: Last year, Beaverton School District had the highest number of homeless students ever recorded in Oregon.
title: A record for Beaverton, but sadly not for Oregon

statement: "Refinanced $232.6 million in bonds, resulting in reduced debt service for the City."
title: Some payments went down, but a lot more were added

statement: "There’s talk in Congress now about basically confiscating your private 401(k) or IRA plan and rolling it into Social Security to strengthen Social Security."
title: No need to cash in your retirement savings

statement: Says the CBO estimates that fully extending the Bush tax cuts would add 600,000-1.4 million jobs in 2011 and 900,000-2.7 million jobs in 2012.
title: Yes, but it's missing important context

statement: "I have won more elections than any chairman since 1938."
title: Very good year for GOP, but there have been better

statement: Says he got twice as much money from the sale of County Grounds land than Milwaukee County Executive Scott Walker was willing to accept.
title: Holloway played a role in getting a higher amount, but there’s no evidence Walker was ready to take first offer

statement: Said Republicans made historic gains in state legislatures during last month’s election
title: Democrats looking for good news should not look too closely at the nation's state houses

statement: In "the fall of 2009, only 21 percent of Texas high school graduates enrolled in a four-year public university."
title: Oh Texas, only Texas

statement: "This town (Wilmington, Ohio) hasn’t taken any money from the government. They don’t want any money from the government."
title: Pesky things like facts won't mess up his good story

statement: Providence teachers "can go five or six years without an evaluation."
title: Most agree that's too long to wait

statement: "The American people spoke pretty loudly. They said stop all the looming tax hikes...."
title: Actually, four national polls disagree

statement: Hillsborough's Public Transportation Commission has "a rule that says cabbies have to wear socks. I mean, please. Come on."
title: If the shoe fits...

statement: "Pls refer to Jan.1 tax changes appropriately: they're OBAMA TAX HIKES & they'll slam every American's savings, investments & job opportunity"
title: Palin's tweet forgets tax cut history

statement: "The tuitions in Virginia colleges...have doubled -- 100 percent -- in the last 10 years."
title: With three kids in college, he knows the facts.

statement: In Wisconsin, "deaths from domestic violence are at the highest in 10 years."
title: The approach the group uses inflates the number by including suicides, but even when taken out Moore is on target

statement: Says Sen. Sherrod Brown voted to keep "an extreme, job-killing Internal Revenue Service paperwork mandate."
title: Decision 2012: Just 705 days away

statement: New food safety legislation will regulate backyard gardening.
title: Backyard gardens remain your own bit of paradise.

statement: A ban on earmarks greatly weakens the authority Congress has over spending, to the benefit of the executive branch.
title: Without earmarks, Congress would still have power on spending – even if it has not always used it in the past

statement: Low-flow toilets "can cost homeowners up to $1,000 each."
title: Some of the claim holds water. Some needs to be flushed.

statement: "No family earns too much to qualify" for Oregon Healthy Kids program.
title: You’ll qualify, but it might cost you

statement: "Over half of the foreign-born population in Rhode Island is white."
title: Depends what census data you use

statement: "Historically," Senate ratification of arms control treaties "has been bipartisan."
title: With one exception, the margins have been overwhelming

statement: Obama's position on nuclear arms is a "march toward global zero."
title: That's Obama's stated long-term goal

statement: "The Republican plan for tax cuts is to give each millionaire -- the top 1 percent of income in this country -- $83,347 a year in tax cuts."
title: Enough for 20,000 jars of Grey Poupon

statement: "The Madison-Milwaukee (high-speed) train line is dead."
title: The pulse may be weak, but the project hasn’t yet gone to the great train station in the sky

statement: "[Georgia] Republicans have mismanaged unemployment benefits."
title: Finger in unemployment blame game pointed in wrong direction

statement: "Ohio ranks 46th in the country in putting dollars in the classroom."
title: Just 57 percent looks bad on any grade card

statement: Said the Washington Post argued that a failure to pass the START treaty this year would be "no calamity," and that the Associated Press said "the administration concedes the security risk is not immediate."
title: Kyl left out the portions of the editorial critical of his own approach

statement: Wisconsin’s projected state budget shortfall is now as low as $1.5 billion
title: The number may be “official,” but it builds in iffy money and assumes what the next governor will do

statement: Red light camera installed to "promote public safety."
title: Cameras still don't stop speedy drivers

statement: The payday loan industry "does not exist in a state like Minnesota."
title: Those “usurious vipers” are extinct in some states, but alive and well in Minnesota

statement: "Eighty percent of the oil we're discovering, we're discovering in the deep Gulf" of Mexico.
title: Actually, 80 percent of Gulf oil production comes from deep-water sources

statement: "We were one of the first states in the U.S. to build sewers, to bring the treatment plant on line."
title: Rhode Island should be flush with pride

statement: "Oregon, once again, remains among the top five hungriest states in the nation."
title: It all depends on how you serve the numbers

statement: Says the Texas House has "a record number of new members joining our ranks."
title: On the mark for Republicans but not for entire House

statement: Letting the Bush tax cuts expire would raise taxes on small businesses.
title: But he's misinterpreting data.

statement: "We (Democrats) have made steady progress creating jobs and improving our schools."
title: Programs are real, but can Dems take all the credit?

statement: Says the House Rules Committee is the only panel, other than the Intelligence and Ethics committees, not able to telecast proceedings in its main hearing room.
title: The focus is on transparency

statement: "More people hunt and fish in Texas in a given year than attend the... games of the Dallas Cowboys, the Dallas Mavericks, the Houston Texans and the Houston Rockets combined."
title: Even Da Cowboys outhunted, outfished

statement: "Seven more people will die each and every day until the Legislature ratifies these (pain clinic) rules that are being approved by the Board of Medicine and the Department of Health."
title: But not all the deaths are linked to "pill mills"

statement: Since the Fed was created in 1913, "the U.S. Dollar has lost 98% of its purchasing power."
title: A glaring omission: Wages have gone up dramatically since 1913.

statement: Says President Obama has grown the federal government payroll by 141,000 workers and wants to add 125,000 more.
title: Sometimes being short and 'tweet' leaves out important nuances

statement: "Demand for transportation choice is on the rise, with 14 percent more Ohioans riding passenger trains over the past year."
title: Ridership is up, but numbers are all aboard Amtrak

statement: The health care reform law "reduces the deficit by nearly $1.2 trillion over the next two decades."
title: But his projections get dicey after 10 years

statement: Rebuilding three high schools will benefit 40 percent of Portland Public School students.
title: Maybe in a theoretical world with theoretical enrollment

statement: Regulations are an "endemic weakness in government -- so old that Thomas Jefferson listed this problem among his charges against the King of England in the Declaration of Independence."
title: Jefferson was only talking about King George

statement: More than 10 years of free trade "has brought a $2 billion per day trade deficit."
title: Recession lessened the daily bill, but it's climbing again

statement: "Because of (U.S. Sen.-elect Ron) Johnson’s leadership, Senate Republicans adopted a caucus ban on earmarks."
title: Johnson is a newbie, but he signed on early, which helped force caucus leaders to buckle

statement: "Over the course of one four-year term, it costs taxpayers more than $1 million simply to operate" the governor’s mansion.
title: With a staff of seven, including the “laundress and flower arranger,” it all adds up

statement: Says you can buy four light bulbs for $1.99 at Walmart, while a single compact fluorescent lamp (CFL) costs "$10 a pop."
title: You can find bulbs that price, but CFLs come much cheaper

statement: "The law, right now, permits companies that close down American factories and offices and move those jobs overseas to take a tax deduction for the costs associated with moving the jobs to China or India or wherever."
title: Whether to China or Chattanooga - tax break is the same.

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry's administration has proposed ending immunizations for 113,000 kids.
title: Budget cut proposal estimated to affect 56,000 kids

statement: The U.S. House rule barring members from wearing hats while in session dates back to the 1800s and can be waived by the speaker.
title: Will Wilson's hat-itude get her in trouble in D.C.?

statement: "The (Ohio) economy is on the mend. … It is in better shape than it was when we took office."
title: Guess which half of her statement is way off base

statement: The dollar "has fallen over 44% since Bernanke began pumping money into the system beginning back in 2002."
title: Dollar has fallen, but not that much

statement: Says Oregon ranks 30th in the nation with regard to its incarceration rate.
title: Budgets may be inflated but are prisons?

statement: The economic impact of Atlanta's 2000 Super Bowl was $292 million.
title: Not any more. Try $150 million.

statement: "Rhode Island is one of only six states" to use E-Verify.
title: Thirteen states have some sort of E-Verify mandate

statement: The Florida Supreme Court has "no express authority in the Florida Constitution" to remove questions from the ballot proposed by the Legislature.
title: Who says the Supremes need "express authority"?

statement: "Eliminating earmarks does not reduce spending."
title: At least not the way the budget process is today

statement: The radiation coming from the new TSA body scanners is "equivalent to about three minutes' worth of air travel by anybody, say, at 30,000 feet."
title: Radiation is all around us

statement: "It’s gotten to a point where the average federal worker makes twice as much as the average private sector worker."
title: Two sets of stats say he's wrong twice

statement: In his first meeting with University of Wisconsin System officials, Republican Governor elect Scott Walker told them to prepare for cuts.
title: The tale of the tape: No such hard-line statement was made at the meeting

statement: Texas leads "the country in drunk driving fatalities."
title: Sir, I need you to count backwards from 1,235

statement: "Since the first of the year, 153 businesses at last count had moved out of California to Texas."
title: Business sites, not companies, and 92 of them moved from TX to CA

statement: Small businesses that have "$250,000 in gross sales for the business. They're the ones that are looking at massive tax increases."
title: It's after writing off all your business expenses.

statement: A proposal to reduce the deficit "involved large tax cuts for the top bracket."
title: It says kill the exemptions and lower rates for everyone.

statement: "Congressman Ryan has secured a grand total of $116,838,763 to date (for the Mahoning Valley) and has an additional $27,095,000 pending in FY2010 spending bills."
title: Figure actually understates earmarks for his district

statement: "Nobody has played clips over and over ... of President Obama (saying), 'If they bring a knife to the fight, we'll bring a gun.' "
title: Obama borrows Sean Connery's line from "The Untouchables"

statement: "The (federal) debt is growing by more than $4 billion a day."
title: Slightly less now

statement: "We’ve been able to create about 60,000 net new jobs" in Virginia since February.
title: His figure is close, but who deserves the credit for the new jobs?

statement: Milwaukee’s problems include "52 percent black male unemployment."
title: Like others before him, Pratt overstates the number by citing a study that measures something else

statement: Said they reached a  "power-sharing agreement" with Republican Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle
title: By the time Republican senators finished there wasn't much power left to share

statement: The cap-and-trade bill before Congress "prevents you from selling your home without the permission of the EPA administrator."
title: Wrong a year ago, wrong now

statement: A recent report from the president's deficit commission was "completely empty" on controlling health care costs.
title: Actually, it does have some ideas.

statement: "Re: (Marco) Rubio's support of earmark ban: In 2002 alone, he requested 37 earmarks worth $43 million."
title: Fifth most of any state House member that year

statement: "This is the first time a party has picked up multiple seats during a regular election since the mid 1980s, making this the largest majority of any party in more than 25 years."
title: One by one GOP has been picking up seats to build their majority

statement: President Obama, Sen. Harry Reid and Rep. Nancy Pelosi passed a "$1.2 trillion stimulus bill."
title: Inflates stimulus cost by almost 50 percent

statement: Sewer backups into basements caused the "vast majority of the damage to homes and buildings" in Milwaukee’s July floods, but federal flood insurance doesn’t cover them.
title: There is much disagreement about the source of the flood damage, but the claim about coverage is on dry ground

statement: "We haven’t had control of the House for the last two years and it’s been malfunctioning. We had 109 sessions scheduled and held 49."
title: Lets meet! Oh, let's not!

statement: "Rick Scott got a majority of the Hispanic vote in Florida."
title: The Bushes should know better about trusting exit polls

statement: Federal spending is "the highest it's been as a share of our economy in 60 years (and) revenue is the lowest it's been as a share of our economy in 60 years."
title: Correct on both counts

statement: "We now consume at the federal level 25 percent of the gross domestic product. Historically we were at 20 percent. So we've taken 5 percent away from the private sector."
title: Yes, spending is up as a share of GDP

statement: If the state turns down money for high-speed rail, it will "kill nearly 10,000 permanent Wisconsin jobs."
title: Study is filled with a trainload of assumptions, some of which are already off track

statement: Says Fort Hood near Killeen, Texas, is "the largest military installation in the free world."
title: By population, it's neck-and-neck with Fort Bragg

statement: John Kasich says he won, despite "12 visits by a president, somewhere between $45 (million) and $50 million (spent against him,) 500 paid volunteers in here calling me every name in the book, former presidents, first ladies and God-knows-who-else."
title: Lots of Dems campaigning, but it wasn't all about Kasich

statement: $65 billion "would be added to the deficit if we keep the cuts for people on the highest incomes."
title: Warner's numbers add up

statement: Says Governor-elect Scott Walker’s choice as transition team leader "killed the release of a damaging report on Walker’s record in the days leading up to the election."
title: There may have been means and even motive, but party’s claim lacks key element: Evidence

statement: "Social Security is indeed a Ponzi scheme."
title: Pssst, not fraudulent nor get-rich-quick

statement: Experts say the property tax "is the most harmful to economic growth and . . . the sales tax is least harmful."
title: There is no "expert" consensus

statement: $65 million from ABC privatization will not pay for "even an overpass in Tysons Corner."
title: $65 million would cover it without major complications

statement: Portland Community College serves more students than all of the state’s universities combined.
title: Back to the drawing board

statement: "My debt to GDP was the lowest or one of the lowest of modern presidents. My taxes to GDP was the lowest and my spending to GDP" was too.
title: It depends on how you define "modern"

statement: Has created 60,000 net new jobs since taking office.
title: His number is a tad high, but in the ballpark

statement: "The Republican who was just elected governor of the great state of Florida paid his campaign staffers, not with money, but with American Express gift cards."
title: Just temporary workers, and so did Obama in 2008

statement: "It is a commitment voters take very seriously: The only incumbent in Ohio to break his Pledge and vote for Ted Strickland's income tax hike was defeated soundly on Tuesday."
title: More than 60 percent of the pledge signers lost, too

statement: "Mequon and Milwaukee have the highest disparity of income in the country."
title: The gap is big, but there’s not much methodology to the alderman’s madness

statement: Georgia's high school graduation rate topped 80 percent in 2010.
title: Tons of statistics, but no real answers

statement: Oregon’s budget has grown by 49 percent in just four years.
title: Pieces of the budget did balloon

statement: Says over 25 percent of the Texas budget funds services to non-U.S. citizens.
title: How to begin?

statement: "Pres. Obama's finance team is recommending a . . . 1% tax on all transactions at any financial institution."
title: Zero percent credible

statement: "The average federal employee makes $120,000 a year. The average private employee makes $60,000 a year."
title: For starters, that includes salary plus benefits

statement: Says that the federal gas tax has not been raised since 1993.
title: Last increase predates birth of today's new drivers

statement: Republican plan to extend Bush tax cuts "would double deficit projections going forward for the next couple of decades."
title: Omits one fact: Democrats' plan would also balloon deficit

statement: As mayor, Barrett led efforts to redevelop the Menomonee Valley, "which now supports nearly 4,000 jobs in Wisconsin."
title: Jobs may be down overall, but things are looking up in the oft-overlooked valley

statement: Says he's arrested more criminals, "including thousands of child predators and sex offenders," than any previous Texas attorney general.
title: He's probably set records, but exact data wasn't available

statement: Half of children struck by cars near schools are hit by parents driving children to school.
title: Accuracy takes a detour

statement: "We're the only system of federalism in the world."
title: Oldest, but far from only

statement: Grocery prices "have risen significantly over the past year or so."
title: Palin's wrong, but we see why she thought what she did

statement: Electric utility FirstEnergy's annual revenues are greater "than the GDP of Haiti, Kyrgyzstan, Iceland, or 15 African nations."
title: And lots more countries, too

statement: "One of the interesting things about the Recovery Act was most of the projects came in under budget, faster than expected, because there's just not a lot of work there."
title: Lots of projects under budget, but most?

statement: In 2011, Milwaukee Public Schools "will provide 77 cents in employee benefits for every dollar it spends on wages."
title: The district packs in health care and pensions for retirees, but taxpayers still get a big punch

statement: It’s hard to get people in Portland to vote yes on ballot measures, especially when there’s opposition.
title: PDX says yes, a lot

statement: "Animal abuse is often an indicative trait of future acts of violence against humans."
title: Abusing animals can lead to more severe crimes down the road

statement: "I had five of my citizens that were killed last week" because of border security problems.
title: Six were killed in Mexico, not the U.S.

statement: "Anybody who is familiar with the historical data from the IRS knows that raising income tax rates will likely actually reduce federal revenues."
title: News flash: Raising taxes increases revenues

statement: "The amount of the revenue required by the state (for the construction of high-speed rail) is around 10 percent."
title: So far, but still waiting on about $325m in funding

statement: Says that the new financial services law requires 358 regulatory filings.
title: A lot of regs, but too popular to repeal

statement: The debt is "nearly $6 trillion more than when President Obama was sworn into office."
title: Debt hasn't grown that fast

statement: Georgia and other states with weak gun laws have more crime.
title: Hizzoner fires away at states he says have weak gun laws

statement: "The interest on the debt now is going to approach in the next couple of years ... what we spend in the national defense budget."
title: It probably will, but not as quickly as suggested

statement: About 1 in 10 public school teachers in Wisconsin would have been laid off without federal stimulus funds.
title: Our math: Real number + big assumption - actual result = problematic statement

statement: Says Washington's reach extends to "even telling us what kind of light bulb we can use."
title: Use a candle or the (efficient) bulb of your choice

statement: "Georgia has the second-highest rate of childhood obesity in the United States."
title: Bleak stats weigh heavy on our minds

statement: "The budget submitted by Obama will add more to the debt than the outstanding debt of the previous 43 presidents combined."
title: This time, he's right

statement: "Discretionary spending went up 84 percent in the last two years"
title: The stimulus made some serious budget noise, but this approach amplifies its effect

statement: Says the federal government restricts "how much salt we can put on our food."
title: There's not a grain of salt big enough to make this statement true

statement: Says "6 percent more Republicans across the state voted than Democrats."
title: Take that, Dems!

statement: "If all of the [Bush-era] tax cuts expire on schedule, the budget will be close to being balanced in four years."
title: Ending the tax cuts wouldn’t even cut the deficit in half

statement: When Obama took office "the economy of the United States was actually shrinking for the first time in about 70 years."
title: UPDATE: Readers point out better numbers

statement: The Fulton County vote count will be finished by 11:30 p.m. on election night.
title: Great expectations, nice results

statement: Says Washington state has "consistently ranked in the top five in the Forbes list of best states to do business — ahead of Texas."
title: Evergreen leads Lone Star in three of five rankings

statement: "In fact, 85 percent of Oregonians voted in 2008."
title: If only!

statement: "The president of the United States will be taking a trip over to India that is expected to cost the taxpayers $200 million a day."
title: Based flimsily on anonymous source in India

statement: "Congressman Nye voted against a bill which would have defunded the $5-10 billion" the IRS needed to implement  health care legislation.
title: Nye's vote was on a minor procedural motion, not a bill

statement: "Congresswoman Kathy Castor voted to spend $2.6 million to teach prostitutes in China to drink responsibly."
title: Grant was selected by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, under Bush administration

statement: "Mr. Renacci was registered as a foreign trade lobbyist in the United States government."
title: You can't lobby for clients if you have no clients

statement: Says Russ Feingold voted to give Social Security benefits to illegal immigrants
title: Hot-button 2006 vote has spawned dozens of attack ads. This one is wrong, too

statement: Says "Scott Walker wants to ban common forms of birth control, including the pill."
title: Pro-Life Wisconsin's survey included 'personhood' question, through which it -- like some other groups -- defines the pill as abortion

statement: Says that under Gov. Rick Perry, Texas Department of Public Safety troopers have had "standing orders" not to inquire into the immigration status of people unless they're under arrest.
title: Neither candidate nor state provides the "standing orders"

statement: Says he has a track record of not raising taxes.
title: Levies on cigarettes, fireworks and more

statement: Says Steve Spinnett has court judgments against him for trespass and harassment.
title: No evidence of harassment but he did trespass

statement: Robert Hurt supported a bill that helped the uranium industry after taking contributions from the industry and because his father had a stake in it.
title: Hurt took $2,000 from mining officials but was cleared to vote on bill

statement: Says John Raese said he wants "1,000 laser systems put in the sky, and we need it right now."
title: Cherry-picking quotes for wacky effect

statement: Members of Congress did not have three days to read the bill "when the stimulus was rushed into law."
title: The bill sped through the Capitol

statement: "(John) Kasich was the architect who balanced the budget, cut spending, created a surplus, igniting record job creation."
title: A guy named Clinton, and others, had a role in it, too

statement: "Liberal out-of-state special interests are spending millions on 5 and 6 to change the way Florida draws its congressional and legislative districts."
title: Visuals matter in this TV ad

statement: "Paul Workman wants to raise the sales tax."
title: Only if Texas eliminated property taxes

statement: Says Nick Kahl made it harder for many families to cover basic health care expenses.
title: Just a drop in the bucket

statement: "The Republican leader of the Senate said his main goal after this election is simply to win the next one."
title: McConnell also said he'd meet the president halfway

statement: "Senator Robert Hurt voted for a bill that’s raised your electric rates seven times."
title: Deregulation was not a factor in raising rates

statement: "Congressman Perriello voted in lock step with Nancy Pelosi 90 percent of the time."
title: Perriello votes with Democrats, but not necessarily Pelosi

statement: Patrick Rose "voted to explore a state income tax."
title: Income-affected tax maybe, not income tax

statement: Says four Democratic state senators voted to "raise taxes on Wisconsin workers by another $510 a month so freeloaders can get free state-run health care."
title: Workers wouldn't have picked up the full tab, but plan did propose free benefits to the unemployed

statement: Democratic U.S. House candidate Julie Lassa pushed for a "Canadian-style government takeover of health care."
title: Let's see, Wisconsin proposal had no single payer, relied on private insurance ... need we go on?

statement: Says "Richard Devlin raised your taxes by $1 billion in a single day."
title: It was a special day and he had help

source: Georgia House Democratic Caucus on behalf of Elena Parent
statement: State House incumbent Jill Chambers, R-Atlanta, "personally profits from taxpayer money."
title: All insinuation. No proof.

statement: "Of the states that have a lieutenant governor, many are currently discussing the need for such an obsolete office."
title: There’s discussion, but not official state action

statement: She "led the fight to stop health insurance rate hikes and saved Rhode Island families over $150 million."
title: Narration is correct. Printed words, not so much.

statement: "Rigell's car dealership made over $400,000 off the ‘Cash for Clunkers’ bailout."
title: Rigell's dealerships profited, but they didn't make $400,000

statement: "Dan Gelber: On the record against scholarships to help our needy children attend Jewish private schools."
title: "Toxic" to Jewish education? Oy vey!

statement: Lizbeth Benacquisto's supporters "would make (abortion) illegal in all cases, including rape, incest, even to save a woman's life."
title: Right to life groups that support her have no mention of exceptions

statement: "North Dakota's economy is reeling."
title: Cookie-cutter ad gone bad

statement: "The Recovery Act saved 60,000 jobs among law enforcement officials, firefighters in the state of Florida, plus another 20,000 educators."
title: Crist way off on firefighters, law enforcement

statement: Sen. Harry Reid voted "against declaring English our national language, twice."
title: Reid called the amendment racist and divisive

statement: "Decorated Marine, two-tour Iraq war vet."
title: His medals back up his claim

statement: "Mr. Hurt would re-open that darn (Medicare) doughnut hole."
title: Connecting the dots, Perriello seems right

statement: Blames Mike McIntyre and Nancy Pelosi for the second straight year of no cost-of-living increases for Social Security beneficiaries.
title: Cost-of-living-increase decided by formula, not Congress

statement: Says Republican gubernatorial candidate Scott Walker "increased his own pay by $50,000."
title: With group's upside down math, giving back less means getting paid more

statement: "Of those 850,000 (new Texas) jobs, most were public-sector jobs and minimum-wage jobs."
title: Methodology has major flaw

statement: Vows to keep Georgia's race for governor "civil" and focused on the "positive."
title: Claims to run "civil" campaigns slippery as a bag of snakes

source: Promote Oregon Leadership PAC (Oregon House Republicans)
statement: Says Will Rasmussen falsely claimed he had lived in the West Linn district for about a year.
title: Put a halo on it

statement: Says Peter Kilmartin has "only three years experience in his own law practice."
title: Tax forms suggest otherwise

statement: "We have empowered state insurance commissioners to review the rate hikes that are taking place in states. And in some states like North Carolina, they have already used it and rolled back premium increases by 25 percent."
title: States get money to combat rate hikes

statement: "Before we even passed health care, 4 millions kids got health insurance that didn't have it before, through the Children's Health Insurance Program."
title: Yes, but even this takes time.

statement: Stabilizing the recent financial crisis "will cost less than 1 percent of GDP," which is less than the 2.5 percent to fix the savings and loan crisis of the 1980s.
title: He's using one way to calculate it; there are others

statement: "Most of the jobs that we lost were lost before the economic policies we put in place had any effect."
title: Somewhat better times are here again

statement: Bill Heller "raises taxes. Property taxes. Small business taxes. He even wants to tax the Internet. Mr. Heller said no to balancing the federal budget, that puts more debt on our kids."
title: Tax vote claims are correct but balanced budget vote was symbolic

statement: Company may close, "all because government essentially says if they don't hire a lifeguard to watch their workers, they can't stay open."
title: Violations included other safety and training issues, not just the lifeguard

statement: "Most" of the newspapers that endorsed Alex Sink also endorsed Barack Obama.
title: A slim majority supported both.

statement: "Morgan Griffith fought for a plan that would have taken money away from our schools and given it to Northern Virginia schools instead."
title: No evidence Griffith fought for this

statement: The health care bill "cuts the deficit by over $1 trillion dollars."
title: Highly speculative

statement: Rick Boucher "helped write" the cap-and-trade bill
title: Yes, but to protect SW Virginia and coal industry

statement: "Congressman Kasich wants to use our tax dollars to give secret bonuses to his corporate friends."
title: Selective editing puts all the lines together

statement: Says Republican candidates in key Wisconsin Assembly races "side with those who want to privatize Social Security -- and risk our retirements on Wall Street."
title: It's guilt by association, even when there isn't much association

statement: Says state Senate candidate "Monk Elmer voted to exceed the (school district property tax) spending caps."
title: Attention, geography students: Kimberly, Wisconsin is not in Idaho

statement: "Donna Campbell has called for ending all federal funding for education"
title: She said she would vote to end federal education funding

statement: Says Republican candidates in Oregon are "advocating violence" against gays.
title: Guilt by association?

statement: Tells David Cicilline, "94 percent of the carbon emissions which you so want to get rid of are caused by nature."
title: Claim is mostly hot air

statement: Of the more than 1.3 million temporary mortgage modifications, over half have defaulted.
title: Not all that were canceled were due to default

statement: As CEO of WWE, Linda McMahon "was caught tipping off a ringside physician" about a federal investigation into illegally distributing steroids to wrestlers.
title: Memo: "Clue him in"

statement: "Many of the companies bankrolling the ad campaign against Amendment 4 are recipients of a congressional bailout, in the form of humongous tax refunds earlier this year."
title: 'Many' is tough to confirm

statement: Dan Seals has been running for office "since before there were, like, iPods."
title: We found something fishy about this ad

statement: In the past two years, Democrats have "spent more money than this country has spent in the last 200 years combined."
title: Wrong no matter how you slice it

statement: "As a state representative, David Cicilline argued against Megan's Law and voted against mandatory registration of sex offenders."
title: Voted against it before he voted for it

statement: "I lost my health insurance and my doctor because of Obamacare."
title: The company's business decision was in the works long before Obama was in the White House

statement: Rick Perry is "taking money away from hurricane victims" and diverting it to "remodel the Governor's Mansion."
title: Aid rendered can't be spent twice

statement: "Unfortunately everyone needs to cut back in these tough economic times. That's why I voted to cut my own pay along with the pay of our state employees."
title: Zero pay cut equals zero on accuracy

statement: Roy Barnes voted against a bill in the state Senate that would have made it easier to convict child abusers.
title: No, Barnes isn't pro-evildoer

statement: Says Scott Bruun supports allowing corporations to secretly funnel millions of dollars to front groups to finance attack ads.
title: He opposes the Disclose Act

statement: Rick Scott "has said that he would do away with the Department of Community Affairs."
title: He sure doesn't like the DCA but hasn't said he'll abolish it

statement: Ed Perlmutter voted for "Viagra for rapists" paid for with tax dollars.
title: No such vote.

statement: "Your tellers were paid kickbacks for directing elderly consumers from ... safe deposits to risky ones."
title: Bank employees got a 5 percent commission for referrals

statement: The lawyer who brought the case against NationsBank said "publicly that Alex Sink had nothing to do with the case, had nothing to do with the situation and didn't know about the problems."
title: Scheme largely crafted by the bank's investment arm

statement: "Michael Bennet cast the deciding vote" for the stimulus and the health care bill.
title: One deciding vote, or 60?

statement: "When President, then candidate, Obama was asked to disclose some of his donors because there was suspicion of their being the foreign source of money into his campaign, they refused to do it."
title: Not the same

statement: "In Congress Tom Barrett voted to allow abortions through the ninth month, just moments before the baby is born."
title: Partial birth ban applied to a specific procedure. It's the Supreme Court, not Congress, that voted to allow late-term abortions

statement: Says "Scott Walker wants to make abortion illegal, even in cases of rape, incest or to protect the life of the mother."
title: Even Walker acknowledges the ad accurately states his views

statement: Says Lloyd Doggett voted for the health care, stimulus and cap-and-trade bills.
title: Aye-aye (aye)

statement: Since Rep. John Boccieri’s election, "Ohio has lost 600,000 jobs" and his district’s "unemployment has doubled."
title: Bad facts meet twisted logic

statement: Says Peter DeFazio votes with Nancy Pelosi 86 percent of the time.
title: Bad lapdog!

statement: Darryl Hicks had seven ethics violations and didn't pay most of the fines.
title: Hicks late filing paperwork, but experts say not a real ethics violation

statement: "The Taliban has been there for years and years, I mean, hundreds of thousands of years."
title: Meek admits he was wrong in mid-debate stumble

statement: "More private-sector jobs were created in the first eight months of 2010 than in the eight years of the Bush administration."
title: Accurate, but the comparison is cherry-picked

statement: Says Robert Hurt "supports the tax loopholes that send American jobs overseas."
title: Hurt signed Taxpayer Protection Pledge, not a promise to close loopholes

statement: Says Glenn Nye voted "in lock step with Nancy Pelosi" 83 percent of the time.
title: Many nays for Nye

statement: Says Tom Perriello voted "to give tax breaks to foreign companies creating jobs in China."
title: No connection between manufacturing tax credit in stimulus, Chinese jobs

statement: Says he "voted no on the Wall Street bailouts."
title: He wasn't in Congress when TARP was approved.

source: Citizens for Lower Taxes and a Stronger Economy
statement: Says PolitiFact says Amendment 4 "will force counties and cities across Florida to raise taxes and fees."
title: Did you think we weren't paying attention?

statement: Says "Scott Walker favors cutting up to 350,000 families and children off health care."
title: The mud gets muddled due to Walker's change in position

statement: "Georgia had the worst job losses in state history under GOP watch."
title: Yes, job losses greater under Barnes, but don't forget the Great Recession

statement: "More Texans have new jobs today than the entire population of Fort Worth."
title: Net job gains bigger than Cowtown population

statement: "Matt Patten kicked off his dirty campaign with thousands in dirty cash from guess who? (Frank) Russo and (Jimmy) Dimora."
title: Donations predate corruption probe and didn't amount to "thousands"

statement: Says Julie Parrish is "one of Sarah Palin’s mama grizzlies."
title: She may be a grizzly but she's not Palin's

statement: Charlie Crist "attacks me for positions he held, like, six months ago, (when) he was running in the Republican primary."
title: A complex story in flip flops

statement: "Middle-class families throughout America (would) have to pay $6,000 per year" to pay for tax cuts for the wealthy.
title: Off by a factor of 10

statement: "I am very proud, as governor of Florida, that we signed the first divestment act, as it relates to Iran, divesting any investments in companies that would invest in Iran."
title: Florida took the lead in 2007

statement: Says Marco Rubio said that "people who essentially don't agree with him, ought to leave the country, like Keith Olbermann."
title: A rare double endorsement

statement: "There currently are 825,000 student stations sitting empty across Florida in every district and at every grade level."
title: Yes there are plenty of empty seats, but still some overcrowded schools

statement: "What is the maximum number of students allowed in your classroom? ... 30 or more!"
title: In some cases -- yes

statement: Says Gov. Jim Doyle and the DNR have not put hunters first and mismanaged the deer herd; as a result "the deer population has dwindled."
title: There may be fewer deer in the woods, but it's by design (there are fewer to crash into your car, too)

statement: Lizbeth Benacquisto "broke election law 105 times, hiding special interest contributors."
title: She amended campaign finance reports in 2006 municipal race

statement: Says "John Loughlin voted to let people accused of domestic violence keep their guns."
title: He comes close to the mark

statement: Says Leah "Vukmir supports allowing people to carry concealed weapons into day care centers, churches, health care clinics and playgrounds."
title: Statement suggests anyone could do it, but language included narrow limits

statement: Says he "stood up to his own party by voting against the budget to stop runaway government spending."
title: Cites final vote as evidence of budget hawkishness, but not a single amendment to cut spending?

statement: Says Rick Perry recently said he "wanted another (Texas) business tax."
title: Perry signed changes into law--in 2006.

statement: Says John Kitzhaber wants a sales tax so people without jobs pay taxes.
title: He said no such thing

statement: "In Rhode Island, there were thousands of jobs that were created" by the federal stimulus program
title: Update: Just under 2,000 jobs created in R.I.

statement: The new health care law will "force seniors into Barack Obama's government-run health care program."
title: LBJ's government-run health plan is 45 years old

statement: "Fiorina's plan would mean slashing Social Security and Medicare."
title: There's no there there.

statement: Jerry Brown "gave California state employees collective bargaining powers" and "now, state employees can retire at 55 with much of their salary for life."
title: Brown's tough/love relationship with unions

statement: "There are 100 members of the U.S. Senate. Fifty-seven of them, including Russ Feingold, are lawyers. There are zero manufacturers and one accountant."
title: Some lawyers never practiced, and the accountant's other numbers were slightly off

statement: Says Ron Johnson "likes to say there are too many lawyers in the Senate – 57. He’d be the 70th millionaire."
title: The post-election mix will be different, but there are 69 already

statement: "Rick Perry has become a millionaire on the public payroll."
title: Perry's blind trust leaves us in the dark in measuring his net worth

statement: "Since 2000, when he entered politics, Jon Husted has been on the ballot six times for three different political offices."
title: Pot, meet the kettle

statement: Republican candidate for governor Nathan Deal fought to weaken Georgia's rape shield law.
title: Correct, but Barnes needs to add important context

statement: Bruce Starr was the only senator to vote for stronger ethics laws and greater accountability.
title: Many senators voted for stricter rules

statement: Says Alex Sink's plans for governor include $12.5 billion in new spending.
title: Scott's figure ≠ Sink's plan

statement: "You worked hard for your money and you paid your taxes when you earned it. Now, (Indiana Republican congressional candidate) Todd Young wants to tax it again when you spend it."
title: Double taxation from the "Fair Tax"? Surprise -- it could happen

statement: "Carly Fiorina, she's against banning assault weapons."
title: Wouldn't reinstate Clinton-era ban, at least

statement: Tom Ganley has "two F's from the Better Business Bureau" and "over 160 complaints in just three years."
title: The overall average for Ohio's largest auto dealer is B+

statement: "Scientists have shown us (that) the greater possibilities, the real science movement, has been with adult stem cell research. It has not been with embryonic."
title: While there is a political and moral dispute on the issue, scientists argue research on both types should continue

statement: Says Texas voters are being asked to act this November on a proposed constitutional amendment affecting property taxes.
title: Wrong on topics and election's timing

statement: Says Bruce Starr broke the law by letting lobbyists wine and dine him in Maui.
title: Taking the trip was legal

statement: Says Marco Rubio sold a home to a chiropractor who had been lobbying him on automobile insurance legislation and "once he sold the home, for $380,000 cash, the speaker's position on the issue changed."
title: This claim was a pip

statement: Pat Toomey "still supports privatizing Social Security."
title: Despite ad's focus on seniors, Toomey's proposal would exempt them

statement: Says Maryellen O’Shaughnessy "accepted campaign cash from indicted politician Jimmy Dimora."
title: Donation predates indictment by more than 2 years

statement: The Seattle Times called Patty Murray "a 'prolific sponsor of earmarks.' Patty even defended the 'Bridge to Nowhere.' "
title: Murray likes earmarks

statement: As state treasurer, Alexi Giannoulias "lost $73 million in our kids’ college savings."
title: What did he know, and when?

statement: Says Republican Reid Ribble says stimulus bill failed to jumpstart the economy, but his "roofing company made almost $300,000 off stimulus funded projects."
title: Sloppiness on both sides leaves subject and source both a little muddy

statement: "We refused to balance the budget on the backs of our children."
title: Cagle education ad needs more text

statement: Says the Annie's List political group supports third-trimester abortions on demand.
title: Group denies charge; evidence lacking

statement: Says Tom Hughes supports paving over thousands of acres with over-development and sprawl.
title: Farmers, put down those pitchforks

statement: Under the new health care law, "the first person (a) patient has to go to is a bureaucrat. That is called a panel."
title: Another in the long line of rhetorical excesses by health bill opponents

statement: "Ted Strickland destroyed Ohio jobs when he busted the budget."
title: Might as well call him "Ted the Destroyer"

statement: "Mark Kirk: Lied about going to war. Opposed middle class tax cuts. And said unemployment’s not that big an issue."
title: Devil's in the fine print

statement: Rand Paul wants "to end all federal faith-based initiatives, and even end the deduction for religious charities."
title: We check the part of the ad that wasn't about Aqua Buddha

statement: Says Russ Feingold supported a stimulus plan that allowed a company to create 3,000 jobs in China.
title: Claim centers on a critical news release that actually prompted changes to the project in question

statement: Says Kurt Schrader "cast the deciding vote that failed to extend tax cuts for Oregon’s middle-class families and small businesses."
title: So far as we remember, there was no tax-cut vote

statement: Said U.S. Rep. Jim Marshall, D-Macon, sent nearly $2 billion overseas to build wind turbines and create jobs, mostly in China
title: Turbine claim blows hot air

statement: Says Christopher Little has "a history of working against environmental protection by defending the worst types of corporate polluters"
title: None of the cases he cites supports his claim

statement: Rick Scott "doesn't have any ties to a lobbyist."
title: He wasn't the lobbyist crowd's top pick, but he has ties

statement: "I've also offered a plan that can help (fix Social Security) that's supported by Robert Reich, secretary of labor previously, in a previous administration."
title: Reich has something else in mind

statement: Ken Buck wants to "outlaw abortion, even in cases of rape or incest."
title: Buck hasn't backed off this one

statement: The new health care law crushes small businesses "with billions in penalties."
title: What? It gives tax credits to small business.

statement: "We haven't yet taken out a negative ad."
title: Except the one that paints her opponent as a roving psychopath

statement: "Under Lt. Gov. Lee Fisher, Ohio is 44th in the country in terms of getting money actually into worker retraining."
title: Data predates Fisher taking office

statement: "Pam Bondi told a group of lobbyists she’ll side with corporate special interests as attorney general."
title: Supports anti-union measure, but says she will prosecute big businesses if necessary

statement: Says "Scott Walker tried to pass a law to allow pharmacists to block women’s access to birth control."
title: In labeling Walker extreme, the group goes a bit beyond the facts

statement: "Roy Barnes proclaimed Mexican workers good for Georgia."
title: Does Deal ad mislead voters about Barnes immigration stance?

statement: Says Texas has so few gas-pump inspectors in the field, "the HEBs of this state, the Brookshires of this state, they're calibrating their own gas pumps. The (Texas Department of Agriculture) just sends them the stickers and they calibrate them."
title: Filled up with un-so

statement: Says more Republicans than Democrats voted for the Wall Street bailouts.
title: 2008 was so very, very long ago

statement: Says "Tom Barrett supports a government takeover of our health care"
title: Saying it often -- and loudly -- does not make it more true

statement: His biography says he was the top ROTC officer in the nation.
title: He was Number One in U.S.

statement: "If you want to see the jobs that I've saved and created in this storm he helped create, go anywhere in Ohio."
title: Specific projects show Ohio wasn't just losing jobs

statement: Says he's so bipartisan that "12 of my bills were signed into law by Democratic President Bill Clinton."
title: He's close on his record, and his math

statement: John Kitzhaber created 128,000 new jobs while governor.
title: Or did he just let the good times roll?

statement: Says gas pumps in different parts of Texas are missing state inspection stickers and/or their inspections are out of date--and that's cheating consumers.
title: Stickers missing, though Texans might not be getting cheated

statement: "John Boozman is excited about putting a 23 percent national sales tax on everything you buy."
title: Ad only tells half the story

statement: Marco Rubio says "Solo Ingles" (English only).
title: Stretching Rubio's support for English as official language

statement: "Sharron Angle voted to protect sex offenders."
title: On sex offenders, Reid lands a cleaner punch than Angle

source: Citizens for Lower Taxes and a Stronger Economy
statement: "Amendment 4 will reduce Florida’s economic output by $34 billion annually."
title: May be too soon to get accurate numbers on Amendment 4 impact

statement: Says Scott Walker "eliminated his own office of economic development in the middle of this recession."
title: It hasn't historically been the county's role, but the office did disappear for a year

statement: Says state Rep. Patrick Rose votes 90 percent with liberals, backed the state's largest tax increase, proposed nearly $15 billion in government spending and supported "Obama-style government-run health care system for Texas."
title: Not largest tax hike, not necessarily liberal, not Obama-care

statement: Says Chris Dudley thinks Oregon’s minimum wage is too high.
title: Does Dudley wish he could eat his words?

statement: Georgia lawmakers balanced the budget without raising taxes on residents.
title: Read his lips. Casey Cagle says Georgia didn't raise taxes. We dig in.

statement: Says Tom Ganley has been "sued over 400 times, for fraud, discrimination and more," and "a judge called Tom Ganley's business practices "deceptive and unconscionable."
title: Cases accumulated over 40 years by Ohio's largest dealer

statement: Chris Coons has "Marxist beliefs."
title: Headline of college article was an obvious joke

statement: New Castle County's unemployment rate has not almost doubled in the last two years.
title: In debate dispute, Coons is right

statement: Loranne "Ausley's a financial train wreck for taxpayers -- pushing gas taxes, property taxes, taxes on seniors."
title: Voting against cuts isn't 'pushing'

statement: John Raese's wife "is registered to vote in Florida so she can't even vote for him."
title: Public records tell the tale.

statement: "Boyce gave (a lobbyist’s) wife a sensitive job in the treasurer’s office, a job Boyce admitted he only made available at their mosque."
title: Boyce is not Muslim and has never been to the mosque

statement: "Joe Garcia raised utility rates on families."
title: Rivera mixes two meetings, two different issues

statement: Says Steve Kagen "promised us jobs, voting for the $787 billion stimulus. Cost: another 77,000 jobs lost."
title: Here’s our formula: Twisted logic + lack of evidence = Pants on Fire.

statement: Says Rick Perry told students he couldn't attend a gubernatorial forum due to scheduling conflicts, then on forum day "tweeted that he'd just been running with his dog."
title: Perry won't debate until White makes public more income tax return

statement: Says David Wu has presided over "137 months" in which "Oregon's unemployment rate has been above the national average."
title: One congressman against the whole economy?

statement: Says Lincoln Chafee "settled a union strike by giving the teachers a 19-percent-raise."
title: It was 24.2 percent, but over 6 years

statement: "One man (New Castle, Del., County Executive, Chris Coons) thought property taxes should be hiked almost 50 percent."
title: Property tax hikes proposed by Coons; approved by the County Council

statement: "(Jeff) Atwater's busy helping his friends and wasting our tax dollars -- $48 million for a government building so lavish it's dubbed the 'Taj Mahal,' $100,000 for a golf musuem, and $110 million to build a private prison to help a big contributor."
title: Not much connection between Atwater and expenditures

statement: Delaware Democratic Senate candidate Chris Coons "thought that a 911 call should be taxed."
title: Ad puts the full truth on hold

statement: "(Strickland) raised taxes last year to the tune of $840 million."
title: Republicans also voted for the 'increase'

statement: Says "Sean Duffy was a no-show" as Ashland County District Attorney while he was on the campaign trail
title: Duffy acknowledges difficult balance, but left the job to campaign full time

statement: "Houston suffered $1.7 billion in operating losses under Mayor Bill White."
title: He's talking about changes in net assets ...

statement: John Kitzhaber is the only pro-choice candidate in the race for governor.
title: Dudley says he would not propose new legal restrictions on abortion

statement: Says Illinois gubernatorial candidate Bill Brady's first priority after winning the primary "was to sponsor a bill that would mass-euthanize sheltered dogs and cats in gas chambers."
title: Generally right about bill, off on the timing

statement: Just like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, "the AFL-CIO receives dues from foreign entities associated with it."
title: Some unions have Canadian members

statement: "Never once did they (House Republicans) actually cut spending or reduce the state budget. Even when they cut taxes in 2005, they increased spending.  They never paid for their tax cuts."
title: GOP the party of tax-cut and spend

statement: Taking the Fifth Amendment in a deposition about the Columbia/HCA hospital chain he founded "means a truthful answer to the questions that (Rick Scott) was asked would incriminate him."
title: Depends on the circumstances

statement: Says Rick Scott gave a deposition in which he invoked the Fifth Amendment 75 times about his dealings as head of Columbia/HCA hospital chain
title: Not part of the federal criminal investigation

statement: Shows in a television ad that police took evidence from Solantic, Rick Scott's new health care company, after allegations emerged that the company was engaging in fraud.
title: Embellishing with the imagery

statement: In ad attacking Rick Scott, says three executives of the Columbia/HCA hospital chain he ran were indicted.
title: But none convicted

statement: "According to independent analysis, unfair trade deals have resulted in the loss of over 64,000 jobs in Wisconsin ... But Ron Johnson favors those deals."
title: The number is the best available, but leaves out jobs gained through trade deals

statement: "When Washington liberals wanted to take away our guns, Chet said no."
title: From our cold, dead hands?

statement: Said state insurance commissioner candidate Ralph Hudgens "fights hard" to strip women of life-saving coverage such as mammograms.
title: Yes to "fights", no to "strip"

statement: "Groups that receive foreign money are spending huge sums to influence American elections."
title: Chamber not required to disclose, so it's pure speculation

statement: Since the stimulus package was passed, "Ohio’s lost over 100,000 more jobs."
title: Refined claim gets points for accuracy

statement: "Steve Southerland did not pay his taxes in '05, '06, '07, '08 or '09."
title: Business property taxes late, but paid with penalty

statement: "For the first time in history, Wisconsin has more government jobs than manufacturing jobs."
title: It's a month-to-month thing, but the overall point stands

statement: In 2009, "the state Legislature passed more than $5 billion in tax increases."
title: It was wrong the first time we heard it -- and still is

statement: Said he "opposed every budget Republican and Democrat."
title: Voting against a "budget resolution" gives you plenty of wiggle room to spend taxpayer dollars

statement: Say Matt Wand cut Troutdale police, created a slush fund for himself.
title: Not a stretch, just flat-out false

statement: Says the Texas Department of Agriculture seeks to purchase up to 300,000 promotional stress balls.
title: Battle obesity, squeeze "grapes"

statement: Says "Scott Walker says he would ban stem cell research"
title: The adult-embryonic distinction is important in science -- and politics

statement: Debbie Jackow "unlike her opponent ... WILL NOT de-fund the 20/20 land program."
title: But county commission opponent has always voted for the program

statement: Says James Langevin voted to spend "$3 billion for a jet engine no one wants."
title: This claim doesn't fly

statement: Says Republican opponent Jason Isaac is peddling a plan meaning Texans "would pay the highest sales taxes in America, up to 14.5 percent."
title: No plan, but he likes the idea of subbing in sales taxes for property taxes

statement: Harry Reid "voted to use taxpayer dollars to pay for Viagra for convicted child molesters and sex offenders."
title: He did vote that way, but not because he favors the policy

statement: "The years that I was speaker, the Florida House consistently offered leaner budgets than the governor offered."
title: One year much leaner than the other

statement: Rand Paul "wants us to pay $2,000 just to get Medicare."
title: He's been caught on tape saying it several times

statement: Sen. Barbara Boxer "voted against immigration reform to permit (Hispanic immigrants) people to come here legally to work."
title: Boxer voted against a guest worker provision that she felt exploited immigrant workers

statement: Says "Russ Feingold cut Medicare by $523 billion."
title: Growth in the program may slow, but it's still increasing

statement: Says campaign contributions to her rival for a state House seat was money intended for schoolchildren.
title: What's next? Taking candy from babies?

statement: Says that "93 percent of the time John Boccieri voted with Nancy Pelosi."
title: He can't vote with her if she doesn't vote

statement: Says "Rep. Jim Weidner proposed a bill taking away health care for 80,000 of Oregon's children."
title: It’s not that he hates children or anything ...

statement: "I said no to these big bank bailouts."
title: No and "heck no"

statement: Dan Webster "would force victims of rape and incest to bear their attacker's child."
title: The difference between believing and legislating

statement: "O’Shaughnessy even voted for her own personal stimulus package -- a taxpayer-funded pay raise for herself."
title: Voters gave her a raise when they re-elected her

statement: "Since Debbie Halvorson has been in politics, Illinois has lost hundreds of thousands of jobs."
title: A guided tour through a zig-zagging fact-check

statement: "It’s coming. Nobody can stop this train."
title: Excuse us, Mr. Secretary, but won't the voters have a say in this Nov. 2?

statement: Says "the Texas unemployment rate has even grown more than the nation's as a whole."
title: Numbers check, but different time periods yield different results

statement: Says Oregon ranks 43rd in education.
title: Dudley gets a passing grade

statement: Says Peter Kilmartin voted "in favor of expanding the 'good behavior' statute to sex offenders."
title: The bill specifically excluded sex offenders

statement: Daniel Webster "is an advocate for a group that teaches that mothers should not work outside the home."
title: The institute may preach it, but Webster doesn't practice it

statement: "Webster sponsored a bill to create a form of marriage that would trap women in abusive relationships."
title: Only out was adultery

statement: Marco Rubio "wants to raise the Social Security retirement age," and "cut benefits."
title: No changes for current beneficiaries or those nearing retirement

statement: "Newspapers say Florida made bad investments, lost hundreds of millions of dollars, billions in pension funds lost. Who was in charge of Florida's investments? Alex Sink."
title: McCollum and Crist were in charge, too.

statement: "Tom Ganley supports a 23 percent national sales tax that would raise taxes on the middle class while giving a huge tax break to millionaires like himself."
title: It's one of the options he says should be considered

statement: Arkansas Democratic congressional candidate Chad Causey "was a Washington, D.C. bureaucrat."
title: An epithet, not a job description

statement: In most Muslim countries, "We can't have a church. We're not able to build synagogues. It's forbidden."
title: Conversions are off limits, not churches

statement: Since being elected in 2002, Scott Walker has "given back over $370,000 of his salary to the county."
title: That's a lot of change ... and it's in the county coffers, not Walker's wallet

statement: Says Sal Esquivel wants a 5 percent state sales tax on groceries.
title: He doesn't

statement: "Rhode Island has a very generous unemployment compensation rate compared to most other states."
title: We rank 6th or higher

statement: Says Lee Fisher "wanted a $1.1 billion tax increase which could have driven countless jobs out of state."
title: A statewide ballot issue that had bipartisan support

statement: Says Roy Blunt "secretly inserts language to benefit tobacco giant Philip Morris" into a national security bill while "Blunt's girlfriend and son are lobbyists for the cigarette company, and just days earlier, 26 Philip Morris executives wrote checks to Blunt totaling $23,000."
title: Provision added hours before scheduled vote

statement: "Alex Sink funneled three quarters of a million dollars in no-bid contracts to Bank of America."
title: Ad overplays Sink's role

statement: Ron Klein "sponsored an amendment that specifically allows price gouging."
title: Full of hot air? PAC took down its video

statement: "A majority of Wisconsinites opposed the government takeover of health care. But Russ Feingold voted for it anyway."
title: In using loaded language, Johnson overshoots his target

statement: "More lives have been lost because of the war with the drug cartels in Juarez alone, just a few blocks from the United States of America, than have been lost in the war in Afghanistan."
title: Only true if you look at the war in Afghanistan since 2008

statement: Said that his batting average with Congress is higher than every other president since Dwight D. Eisenhower except Lyndon Johnson.
title: Not that good, but better than people think

source: Promote Oregon Leadership PAC (Oregon House Republicans)
statement: Says Will Rasmussen supported a sales tax as recently as last spring.
title: One sales tax accusation deserves another?

statement: "Barbara Boxer voted to cut spending on Medicare benefits by $500 billion, cuts so costly to hospitals and nursing homes that they could stop taking Medicare altogether."
title: Hospitals are unlikely to stop taking Medicare

statement: The Chilean "privatization scheme" that Sharron Angle supports "has resulted in hidden fees, fewer benefits, and millions of people with no coverage."
title: Tying Angle to goose-stepping Chilean soldiers?

statement: "Rick Scott's prison plan would cut Florida's prison budget in half, close prisons, and release tens of thousands of prisoners early -- murderers, rapists, sex offenders, armed robbers, drug dealers."
title: Scott proposes cuts, but says he won't release prisoners

statement: Says Wisconsin Attorney General J.B. Van Hollen "knew about (the Ken Kratz sexting) case for nearly a year and did nothing about it."
title: What about that criminal investigation and pressure on Kratz to turn himself in to regulators?

statement: Says Scott Bruun supports "cutting the Department of Commerce and eliminating NOAA."
title: NOAA can rest easy

statement: The federal government can tell General Motors what to charge for its automobiles.
title: Gingrey's GM claim veers off-course

statement: "Exit polls indicate that Democrats get over 70 percent of LGBT votes in federal elections."
title: From Clinton (71 percent) to Kerry (77 percent)

statement: Says "the headlines … tell the story" of how Walker has "mismanaged" Milwaukee County
title: If this were the art world instead of politics, it would be considered forgery

statement: "Perry pushed for a law that lets insurance companies raise homeowners’ rates without having to justify the increase."
title: No evidence Perry threw weight behind 'file-and-use' regulatory system

statement: Jobs incentive program "created over 1,200 high-wage jobs since 2009."
title: But the number is wrong, and other programs were used

statement: "Social Security is a Ponzi scheme."
title: Not without intent to deceive

statement: Says Kurt Schrader voted to cut $500 billion from Medicare, threatening "thousands of Oregon seniors and their access to their current coverage."
title: Don’t worry about the seniors

statement: Says Scott Bruun "still believes in the same old direction that George Bush had before, which is to privatize Social Security."
title: Well, a little bit of it anyway

statement: PolitiFact Texas says "Congressman Edwards' attacks on Bill Flores are false."
title: Well, we rated ONE attack ad False...

statement: "The Republican candidate [John Loughlin] has talked about privatizing Social Security ... so we know where he stands on the issue."
title: He's talked about voluntary accounts

statement: As Milwaukee County executive, Scott Walker "eliminated the waiting list for long-term care for older adults through the Family Care program."
title: It did disappear within weeks of Walker taking office ... but due to things already in place

statement: Rick Perry thinks "injecting 11- and 12-year-old girls with a controversial drug (the HPV vaccine), without a parent's consent, is a good idea."
title: Parents, your right to consent was never in question

statement: U.S. Sen. Johnny Isakson "has never proposed, nor voted in favor of, a substantial cut in federal spending" and has voted for "many substantial increases in federal spending."
title: Be careful what you wish for. Candidate challenges us to check out attack on Isakson.

statement: A bill to save teacher jobs is completely paid for by closing corporate tax loopholes.
title: Food stamp amnesia is contagious

statement: Peter DeFazio "will sneak in a 1 percent tax on all banking transactions."
title: That part about Obama isn't true either

statement: The Republican election platform "was actually written with the help of a former lobbyist for AIG and a former lobbyist for Exxon-Mobil."
title: One former lobbyist, and the type of help is unclear

statement: When Tallahassee politicians and bureaucrats tried to run our schools, "I've stood up to them to protect local control."
title: A lot of others had already stood up

statement: "An organized crime syndicate was extorting money from his (Tom Ganley’s) business, threatening his family, but he fought back and won the FBI's highest civilian award"
title: Aided probe, despite dangers

statement: Texas has "a higher unemployment rate than neighboring states."
title: Not New Mexico

statement: "Twice as much (federal) money is going back to Hawaii, Virginia and Alaska than is coming home to Oregon."
title: This Republican wants more pork?

statement: "We now have our kids go to school about a month less than most other advanced countries."
title: Summer school for all?

statement: Says the Feingold garage ad "is a fake: He’s not standing in front of his house."
title: No proof ... just an off-base hunch

statement: Rep. Paul Hodes, D-N.H., "voted for the pork-filled stimulus bill -- $1.9 million to study ants in Africa, $39 million for office upgrades for politicians."
title: Voted for the stimulus; other details a stretch

statement: When each faced a pension funding crisis, Tom Barrett made tough choices and smart cuts while Scott Walker passed $400 million in pension debt to the next generation.
title: It could cost more over time ... or it could save money, too

statement: Says "$30 million gap" in stadium funding forced the Portland Beavers to leave.
title: Swing and a miss?

statement: "Pepper ... kicked off a jock tax, imposing a levy on the sports and entertainment industry."
title: Pepper's legislation got Cincinnati into the game

statement: Says Joe Sestak "voted to gut Medicare ... reducing benefits for 854,489 seniors" and jeopardizing "access to care for millions."
title: A grain of truth, but overheated language leaves out nuances

statement: "It takes as much energy to make a solar panel as it likely generates in its entire life."
title: Solar panels have long earned their keep

statement: Independent groups behind ads attacking Democratic candidates are "front groups for foreign-controlled companies."
title: Possible...maybe...but not known

statement: Says Daniel Webster wants to make divorce illegal, even for abused wives.
title: Webster proposed an optional pre-nuptial agreement that would make divorce much more difficult

statement: Says he took down the mob in Northeast Ohio
title: Overstates genuinely noble actions

statement: Says Daniel Webster thinks wives should submit to their husbands.
title: Video clip distorts Webster's point

statement: "The Wisconsin Legislature raised taxes more than $5 billion in 2009."
title: Off by nearly $2 billion. That's no rounding error

statement: Says with the ongoing economic downturn, child abuse is on the rise.
title: Children are abused in good times, too.

statement: Says the U.S. Constitution provides for just compensation when land is taken under eminent domain.
title: It's in the Bill of Rights.

statement: The GOP's "Pledge to America" includes "a 20 percent cut ... for education. ... Eight million kids would have their college aid slashed under this budget."
title: Technically not in the Pledge, but close to a John Boehner proposal

statement: "Florida seniors are exempt" from losing Medicare Advantage under the federal health care bill.
title: Sen. Bill Nelson tried to add it, but the provision was rejected

statement: "Over the past year ... our 16 counties have hemorrhaged more than 6,000 jobs with no apparent end in sight."
title: Inflates job losses by using wrong statistic

statement: On Lee Fisher’s watch, "almost nine out of 10" jobs that Ohio lost were lost to other states, "not to other countries."
title: Yes, but data set doesn't include job losses at smaller companies

statement: Says Rand Paul thinks drug-dealing, theft, burglary and prostitution should be decriminalized.
title: More "gotcha" than substance

statement: Says Zack Space voted for budgets and debt, energy taxes and the stimulus, and "we still lost more than 2.5 million jobs."
title: Broke your shoelace? Blame the Dems!

statement: "Politician Reid Ribble wants to phase out Social Security, forcing Wisconsin seniors to fend for themselves."
title: When splicing and dicing, please include at least the full sentence

statement: "The size of our federal government has more than doubled since the year 2000."
title: Only if you don't do the math

statement: A defense bill "includes language that would require military hospitals to provide abortions on demand."
title: No requirement, and realistically, not "on demand"
