statement: A $300 million stimulus allocation to Wisconsin "has led to the creation of tens of thousands of jobs in every corner of this state."
title: In this stimulus math mashup 1,200 = 20,000-plus

statement: Kilmartin has helped pass laws to "create a witness protection program."
title: He helped strengthen a weak program

statement: "Austin politicians want to cram more kids into classrooms so they don't have to make the tough decisions to balance the budget."
title: Texas legislators have to cram 'fore such a push gels

statement: "The downsizing of Pinellas County government resulted in about 1,200 people being laid off in a 12 percent unemployment market. … I can tell you that every one of them was hired from the time that Ms. Latvala went into office in 2000."
title: Sometimes they laid off an empty chair

statement: "One of the other inaccuracies ... is that we have raised taxes multiple times and run up the budget. Absolutely not true. One tax increase since I’ve been in office. It was a quarter mill tax in the unincorporated area only."
title: Oh yes, it's all coming back now.

statement: "If you look at the application for a security clearance, I have a clearance that even the president of the United States cannot obtain because of my background."
title: No way he outranks the commander in chief

statement: State government spending will be increase 10.7 percent this year.
title: Compares apples to oranges to get the desired result

statement: Says John Boehner "admits 'we are not going to be any different than we’ve been' " by returning to "the same failed economic policies" that "wrecked our economy."
title: Boehner was talking about social issues, not economics

statement: A bill by Earl Blumenauer would "mandate GPS tracking devices on all our vehicles."
title: Blumenauer as Big Brother? Not so much

statement: Says more than 2 million Oregonians have received important medical services because of his health plan.
title: Except for more than a million who would have been covered anyway

statement: "Under Gov. Kitzhaber, unemployment rose 65 percent, state spending went up 57 percent and personal incomes declined compared to the rest of the country."
title: His numbers are accurate, but was Kitzhaber at fault?

statement: Says Ron Wyden spent $2 million "to study exotic ants."
title: Do we need an ants on fire rating?

statement: Says Julie Parrish wants to add a sales tax to everything we need to buy including food, clothing, medicine and school supplies.
title: Only if Oregon overhauls its entire tax system

statement: "Our county now has the fastest growing airport in America, attracting nearly 1,000 new private sector jobs."
title: Passenger traffic is soaring, but not all the jobs have landed yet

statement: Marco Rubio tried to insert "$1.5 million for a rowing institute" into the state budget.
title: Crist is paddling up the wrong creek

statement: Candidate for governor Roy Barnes has been "fighting hard" to let illegal immigrants vote.
title: Republican governors say 'adios' to the truth

statement: "We've created more than 850,000 jobs, more than all the other states combined."
title: While California lost some 800,000 jobs

statement: State pension fund staffers "lost billions. Then Sink gave them bonuses."
title: The number is wrong, and the money isn't gone

statement: Children born today will carry a $30,000 share of the national debt.
title: Count one for the Gipper's heirs

statement: "We paid down the debt for four years -- paid down $600 billion on the national debt."
title: It depends on what the definition of "national debt" is

statement: It's "not true" that since he's been the president, executions in Iran have increased by four times.
title: Human rights reports say executions in Iran are up

statement: "Under Lee Fisher Ohio has lost nearly 400,000 jobs."
title: Overstates Ohio's job losses while Fisher was development director

statement: Washington politicians "run Social Security like a Ponzi scheme."
title: A superficial similarity, but comparison misses the mark

statement: "More people were killed in the United States last year by tainted food than U.S. troops killed in Iraq and Afghanistan since the wars began."
title: No idea what he ate before launching e-mail blast

statement: Sakineh Mohammadi Ashtiani "was never sentenced to stoning."
title: Court documents say stoning

statement: "The total number of dollars that passes through the Department of Development is like $900 million and like $650 (million) of it has nothing to do with development, which is breathtaking when you think about it."
title: Claim ignores that the department has broad duties

statement: The Bush administration had been "giving (auto companies) billions of dollars and just asking nothing in return."
title: It's called a term sheet and we linked to it

statement: Marco Rubio "opposes extending unemployment benefits."
title: Rubio opposes not finding a way to pay for it

statement: "Our tax rates are lower now than they were under Ronald Reagan. They're much lower than they were under Dwight Eisenhower."
title: Most of the credit lies elsewhere, but he's basically right

statement: "There's a big chunk of the country that thinks that I have been too soft on Wall Street."
title: Poll shows people think Wall Street has too much influence.

statement: "Under Tom Barrett’s leadership, violent crime in Milwaukee has decreased by over 20% -- to its lowest levels in more than 20 years."
title: Only if down is up, and homicide is the only violent crime

statement: "I have given $30,000 of my unused travel expenses over the years to supplement the school system's general budget."
title: School board member gets "half-true" grade on travel spending

statement: "Florida spends more than $300 million a year just on children repeating pre-K through 3rd grade."
title: Big numbers, simple math, claim mostly adds up

statement: "Kasich’s trade deals cost Ohio thousands of jobs - 49,000 jobs to Mexico, 91,000 to China."
title: Other people, like President Clinton, also favored these deals

statement: "Speaker Pelosi ... has been busy sticking the taxpayer with her $100,000 bar tab for alcohol on the military jets that she's flying."
title: A small fraction of that amount was for alcohol

statement: "Julie Lassa willingly took a hefty pay raise at a time when people throughout her district and the state were losing their jobs."
title: She took it for a while, but started giving back months before the attack

statement: Says Bill White "didn't pay taxes while earning $133,600 annual salary as deputy secretary of energy."
title: He paid in -- and got some out

statement: Roy Barnes "made Georgia dead last in education" and Georgia "led the nation in job losses."
title: Grumpy old men debate the Barnes record. Some details left on cutting room floor

statement: The new health care law "will cut $500 billion from Medicare. That will hurt the quality of our care."
title: Major ad buy against Democratic incumbents.

statement: Loranne Ausley "voted six times to tax your savings."
title: A vague and distorted claim

statement: "Ganley said that if elected, he wants to ‘cut the dickens’ out of Social Security, Medicare and Veterans’ benefits."
title: He's not the Scrooge he's made out to be

statement: "I've been outspent by my opponents every time I've run for U.S. Senate."
title: With this new math, everyone would be outspent by everyone

statement: "Barnes opposed the creation of the HOPE Scholarship and campaigned against Zell Miller on the issue."
title: Barnes bet against a proposed state lottery, but not HOPE

statement: Says the Austin chapter of the League of Women Voters has no Republicans among elected officers or on its debate committee.
title: Board member voted in 2010 and 2004 GOP primaries

statement: "Wisconsin is one of the highest taxed states in the nation."
title: If Walker was running a decade ago, he'd be right on target

statement: After Hurricane Katrina, "Dallas and San Antonio took in 5,000 to 10,000 refugees each, but (Bill) White brought in 250,000 and put them up in his 'buddies' empty apartment buildings and let the federal government pay their rents for over two years. They did not return to New Orleans, most of them are on welfare."
title: Anonymous should have checked the facts with "buddies"

statement: Rhode Island gives undocumented pregnant women health insurance, plus a cash card "with $400 a month on it" and "$250 a month or $275 a month to spend on food."
title: Health care, yes. Money, no.

statement: Says Ron Johnson’s company got government loans and a grant to help expand his business
title: Behind all the misleading splicing and dicing, there is some truth

statement: Ron Klein "repeatedly voted in favor of amnesty for illegal immigrants."
title: West admits he was wrong

statement: "Do you know that we have pipes carrying natural gas in this country that are made of wood? I'm not joking."
title: Not joking, but no firm proof, either

statement: "As the CEO of HP, Carly Fiorina laid off 30,000 workers."
title: Layoffs happened

statement: Harry Reid has voted "to give special tax breaks to illegal aliens."
title: Candidate takes some liberties with the votes she cites

statement: Harry Reid has voted "to give illegals Social Security benefits even for the time they were here illegally."
title: He did (sort of) and then he didn't

statement: About $4.89 billion in one-time money was used to balance the current state general revenue fund budget.
title: Count is at least $1 billion short

statement: "The stimulus has not created one private sector job."
title: State and federal reports list thousands of private sector stimulus jobs here

statement: "Taxes went down under Jerry Brown."
title: Bill Clinton's involved in this one.

statement: Tom Barrett "voted for the largest tax increase in history ... raising taxes on gas and Social Security."
title: Economists and experts use a different measuring stick than political opponents do

statement: Says he created more than 500 American jobs.
title: The companies where he worked as a CFO added at least that many to the payroll

statement: Horse racing could boost Georgia's economy by $1 billion a year and create 10,000 to 20,000 jobs.
title: Candidate bets on the ponies, but research needs to go back to starting gate

statement: "Deepwater's own testimony . . . is they said they'll create six jobs."
title: True for long-term, not short-term

statement: Ed Schultz said Alan Grayson is "what it's all about."
title: Line from a flashy TV ad checks out

statement: "700 jobs (were) lost because Allen Boyd" voted for the health care bill.
title: Much more to the story

statement: "She created the Waste, Fraud and Mismanagement Hotline.... (that) has saved Wisconsin taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars."
title: Hotline may be ringing up some savings, but even state auditor can't say how much

statement: Says a "Pro-Stimulus economist admits it is not working … "
title: He admits nothing of the sort

statement: Allen West called Social Security a "Ponzi scheme" and said "this country's got to get on sound footing by destroying it."
title: Klein relied on a second-hand source

statement: "You can’t raise taxes in Ohio. We are one of the highest taxed states in the country."
title: How to best rank states a taxing dilemma

statement: Taxpayers pay $18,000 a month for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's district office in downtown San Francisco.
title: At $18,000 per month, you're definitely not in Kansas anymore

statement: Roy Barnes is like Barack Obama because they're both doing a lot of apologizing.
title: Barnes "sorry" like Obama

statement: "Over 22,000 unique Internet Protocol addresses -- in Wisconsin alone -- have downloaded child pornography."
title: Van Hollen cites Van Hollen, but our checks show his numebrs seem to add up

statement: Says opponent Bill Flores helped run a company that laid off over 3,000 workers and paid off executives with millions.
title: Flores lost his job too

statement: "Over 10 years, (extending tax cuts for the wealthy) would add less to the deficit than Obama added with the stimulus in one year."
title: Stimulus wasn't spent in just one year

statement: "Florida ranks last in the ratio of employees to residents... And Florida is dead last in the nation in state employee payroll expenditures per resident."
title: We tie with Illinois in one category

statement: DeWine "took $1.9 million from big banks," "supported legislation that helped Bernie Madoff make millions" and "protected predatory lenders while families lost their homes."
title: Charge has some bark, but this dog won’t hunt

statement: Russ Feingold "has not worked anywhere outside of politics."
title: This time the branding iron is a little too hot

statement: Says Texas U.S. Rep. Pete Sessions said the GOP's goal is to "go back to the same exact policies that were in place before this president took office... policies that crashed the economy."
title: Exact same words, almost

statement: Clayton County has employed 1,300 people over the past seven months through the Neighborhood Stabilization Program.
title: Clayton officials claim on program's economic impact sounds right, but needs more back up

statement: John Boehner has called for "repealing the rest of the stimulus, which would raise taxes on 110 million middle class people."
title: Wants to cancel unspent stimulus, excluding tax credits

statement: Extending current tax rates would "average more than $100,000 a year to millionaires and even billionaires."
title: Yes, but tax increases hit non-millionaires too.

statement: Says John Boehner changed his position on extending Bush tax cuts.
title: Some change, but a lot of consistency

statement: "We will be the first party to elect a bald guy to governor."
title: Thrasher's off by a hair

statement: John Boehner wants to reopen a tax loophole "that actually rewarded corporations for shipping jobs and profits overseas."
title: Jobs connection is weak.

statement: "I don’t understand what Republicans are doing against this. It was their idea. John McCain introduced cap and trade legislation three times."
title: Is cap and trade a Republican idea?

statement: "Senator Jeff Plale saved my job" -- and some 300 others at Bucyrus International.
title: Now that would be high-level constituent service

statement: "While many of his colleagues turned down a $2,500 pay raise ... (Jeff) Plale pocketed the extra money."
title: After a late start, some is going back to the state

statement: Federal stimulus money went to a Georgia Tech project that will "apparently involve the professor jamming with 'world-renowned musicians' to 'hopefully also create satisfying works of art.'"
title: Report gives us the truthiness blues

statement: "Walker says he’s for lower taxes. But Milwaukee County spending has gone up by $349 million."
title: Apples + oranges = bad math

statement: Jeff Weems' "legal record is one of defending BP, Enron and just about every big oil company against the working man."
title: BP is one big oil company

statement: Scott Walker supported the same transportation bill he’s attacking me for. He said at the time it would save the taxpayers money.
title: You reach in your ad, I'll reach in mine

statement: Like me, Scott Walker opposed the 1998 transportation bill and the $9 billion of wasteful spending.
title: The only statements in the record are supportive ones

statement: Due to the war in Iraq, "4,400 Americans are dead, 30,000 severely wounded and more than 100,000 are suffering from serious health problems related to post traumatic stress syndrome."
title: Counting troops that served in Afghanistan, for one stat

statement: "He's the only candidate who's balanced budgets and brought jobs to Providence."
title: He did. For the most part, his opponents didn't.

statement: "There have been more terrorist attacks on U.S. soil by ... Muslims in Obama's first 18 months in office than in the six years under Bush after he invaded Iraq."
title: She's right, but its relevance is less clear

statement: "We've got to find 2 billion gallons (of water per day) between now and 2025."
title: Yes, though the state has already 'found' some of it

statement: "I’m the only one who's fought against developers draining the Everglades!"
title: Charlie Crist, Marco Rubio stake their own claims on restoration

statement: Proposed tax changes are a "handout" to BP.
title: It depends on what your definition of "handout" is

statement: "Sean Duffy backed plan to privatize Social Security."
title: Such attacks are almost as old as the program itself

statement: "It's factually correct to say" that Jennifer Brunner inherited at least 18 lawsuits when she came into the office that were a result of Ken Blackwell’s "mismanagement of the 2004 election."
title: Factually incorrect is more like it

statement: "I can put 10,000 people to work. Electricians, plumbers, sheet metal workers -- by retrofitting all of the state buildings for energy independence or efficiency."
title: Need a job? Barnes ad says he can help.

statement: Says state Rep. Diana Maldonado of Round Rock uses Craigslist to hire campaign block walkers.
title: $10.11 per hour, offered the ad

statement: "When the mayor of Providence's brother wrote over 100 grand in bad checks to the city, Joe Fernandez didn't have the guts to prosecute him. He let him off the hook."
title: But he was following the law

statement: I "kicked crooked cops and government officials off the public pension rolls."
title: Footloose with the facts

statement: "When these same Republicans –- including Mr. Boehner –- were in charge, the number of earmarks and pet projects went up, not down."
title: Earmarks sky-rocketed under Republican control

statement: "For every dollar a county gets in taxes from new development, it costs us 40 to 50 percent more to provide services."
title: Some studies, for some types of development

statement: The Richardson-Denish administration "gave" 50,000 driver's licenses to illegal immigrants in New Mexico.
title: There's more to the story

statement: "On (Rob Portman's) watch as Bush's trade czar, our deficit with China exploded" and "as Bush's budget chief, Portman oversaw a spending spree that doubled the deficit."
title: Not totally his fault, but the charge is pretty close

statement: Says Mark Neumann = Nancy Pelosi
title: Ideological opposites don't always attract

statement: Says State Rep. Kristi Thibaut was an ACORN lobbyist.
title: Lobbied the lege for lower utility rates

statement: "Our law enforcement agencies have found bodies in the desert, either buried or just lying out there, that have been beheaded."
title: Some skulls; no beheadings

statement: John Boehner said the jobs of "teachers and nurses and police officers and firefighters" are "'government jobs' that weren't worth saving."
title: Government jobs, yes. Not worth saving, no.

statement: "By the year 2015 (Medicaid will) take up half our budget."
title: Medicaid will likely grow but by how much?

statement: Lindsey Graham endorsed Charlie Crist for U.S. Senate.
title: A reposted endorsement from 2009

statement: "Boccieri voted to spend a billion dollars an hour, every hour, for his first 50 days in office"
title: Clever use of math subtracts from accuracy

statement: "Close to 30% of our federal prison population consists of  illegal immigrants."
title: The border between fact and fiction can be a thin one

statement: By releasing only basic tax information, former U.S. Congressman Nathan Deal is "hiding more than he's disclosed" about his business dealing with the state.
title: Barnes says Deal tax returns gives "incomplete picture." Is it fuzzy math?

statement: "The president's party always gets shellacked in midterms. It's only twice, 1934 and 2002, that the president's party actually gained in both the House and the Senate."
title: Presidents can lose seats without being "shellacked"

statement: Likens Obama's predicament to 1982, saying, "when Reagan just started out, (unemployment was at) exactly the same point. He was two years into his term. The unemployment was well over 10 percent, and it did come out of it."
title: Much similarity, a bit of difference

statement: "Our most important work has been creating and retaining almost 55,000 Ohio jobs."
title: These calculations just don't work

statement: "My supporters aren't special interest groups in Madison and Milwaukee."
title: Aside from his own millions, not much cash at all

statement: Georgia's U.S. senators voted for legislation that would "gut clean air protections and increase oil dependence."
title: Oil stained attack gets slippery on facts

statement: "It costs us, logistically, three times more to fight in Afghanistan than it does in any other place."
title: Not even double

statement: Ohio today has the "fewest number of state employees since the Reagan administration."
title: Layoffs are part of the picture

statement: Jim Dunnam "has not lived in the district he represents for years now."
title: Member owns two houses back home

statement: After Ronald Reagan cut taxes in 1981 the U.S. enjoyed "exponential growth."
title: Exponential? And what about Reagan's tax INCREASES?

statement: Says the federal agency in charge of Medicare and Medicaid will disburse $803 billion in benefits this year, making "it larger than all but 15 of the world's economies."
title: Apples to countries

statement: "I asked (then-Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice) how many people had died and she did not know the answer to that question."
title: Wasn't asked. Wasn't answered.

statement: Jennifer Carroll's an "outsider."
title: An outsider who's sure loved politics for the last decade

statement: Jennifer Carroll is the "first African-American Republican woman to be part of a statewide ticket in Florida."
title: She'd be just the second woman LG

statement: Ron Johnson is "willing to hand over the Great Lakes to the oil companies."
title: When drilling for an advantage, make sure you're on target

statement: "Both the state and federal governments make more per gallon in gas taxes than the oil companies make themselves for doing all the work."
title: Sometimes yes, sometimes no. It depends on the year and the price of crude.

statement: "Since being elected, (Tom Barrett) has dumped 8.2 billion gallons of raw sewage into Lake Michigan."
title: That's a lot of flushing! And all by one guy?

statement: Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett "has held the line on property taxes."
title: But residents are now taxed by higher fees

statement: "When Pepper’s tax was finally voted down, Pepper laid off cops and closed jails and let criminals run free in the streets."
title: He forgets Pepper tried to fix the problem

statement: Says Rick Perry is a 25-year incumbent.
title: Decades of service -- but not all as governor

statement: "80 to 85 percent of my campaign funds go to donations to various organizations throughout the City of Providence."
title: Mr. Lombardi needs a calculator

statement: "Charlie Crist has six different positions on ObamaCare."
title: Crist sure changes his story a lot, but 'six different positions' is an exaggeration

statement: "Buck wants to privatize Social Security."
title: Definitions are everything

statement: John Boozman supports "privatizing Social Security"
title: Exaggerating his words

statement: Dan Webster supports "privatization of Social Security, deep cuts in Social Security."
title: He said something at a forum that he later took back.

statement: Alex Sink wants to "cut Medicare."
title: Based on an oversimplified reading of a health care bill Sink mildly supported

statement: "More than half of our unemployed Ohioans have been out of work for six months or more."
title: Various gauges vary, but all say times are tough

statement: "The states that actually have lots of teachers in teacher unions tend to be the states that have done the best in terms of academic success in this country."
title: Current academic research is inconclusive

statement: Sharron Angle "would eliminate the Department of Education."
title: She's described her rationale in some detail

statement: "Florida is enjoying its lowest crime rate in 39 years."
title: Crime rate dropped below '71 level before Crist was governor

statement: Charlie Crist's "personal approval numbers are plummeting."
title: The sky isn't falling for Crist

statement: "Pat Toomey thinks corporations shouldn't pay any taxes."
title: The difference between thinking and advocating

statement: "The Great Lakes Compact has a loophole. And the loophole is that while you cannot remove the water in a big transport, you can remove it in containers of 5.7 gallons or less."
title: Experts skeptical of its impact

statement: "Congress and President Obama have accumulated more debt since he took office than the total amount of debt accumulated during the first 200 years of the United States existence."
title: The facts are right. But the interpretation? Not so much.

statement: Says a highway was closed in El Paso because of bullets flying across the border.
title: Gunbattle in Juárez prompted street closure in El Paso

statement: McDonald's in England only sells organic milk and free-range eggs, which provides more nutritious offerings than in the U.S.
title: Policies differ under Golden Arches across the pond

statement: "When career politician Daniel Webster became speaker of the House, he wasted $32,000 of our money on a spiral staircase for his office."
title: It's not a fancy spiral staircase

statement: "Florida is 49th in per capita spending on mental health care."

statement: "Early census returns are showing that conservatives have been measurably less likely than liberals to return their census forms."
title: Claim is based on flimsy evidence

statement: "The most private question on this year’s form asks for an individual’s race, and that question has been asked by every census since the 1790 census conducted under then-President George Washington."
title: Not always as simple as "Check race here"

statement: "The path to ObamaCare becoming law all started with Charlie Crist supporting President Obama's $787 billion stimulus."
title: Yeah, and Crist caused Y2K too

statement: "This census is also the shortest and least intrusive count in modern history."
title: It's 10 questions, and there's no long form

statement: The proposed education changes "will not cut one teacher's pay."
title: Future earnings would be impacted, though

statement: On financial reform, there is "a million dollars being spent, per congressman, in lobbying expenses on this issue. (The) industry has four lobbyists per member of the House and Senate working on this."
title: Public documents strongly indicate it

statement: "Teachers will not be able to return to work after raising their children."
title: A provision exists, but it's not spelled out

statement: "I never considered myself a maverick."
title: Except for all those times he called himself a maverick

statement: "An audit of the last census found that over 370,000  people living in  Texas were not counted, and our state lost an  estimated $1 billion in  federal funds as a result."
title: Outdated report based on figures retracted long ago

statement: "If every house in Florida had a solar-heated water tank, that would eliminate consumption by 17 percent."
title: The sun can't do it all

statement: "The number of uninsured people in Massachusetts is about the same as it was when the mandates were passed in 2006."
title: Reduction by at least 300,000 is not "about the same"

statement: "Snitker has been virtually ignored by the major media."
title: Numbers back him up

statement: The Senate Republican education plan is an unfunded mandate for local school districts.
title: No new source of money yet

statement: "More people are driving under the influence of drugs than are driving under the influence of alcohol. A recent roadside survey showed that 16 percent of the people tested, tested positive for illicit or licit drugs. That's significantly higher than alcohol."
title: Scientific uncertainty complicates drug czar's claim

statement: "With this reform, every insured American gets valuable consumer protections, and every uninsured American can become insured."
title: Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses

statement: The Florida House is "holding the FINAL public hearing" of a controversial education bill in the middle of spring break..."when they hope (teachers) are not watching or listening."
title: The House isn't hiding anything

statement: ''Both Democrats and Republicans are advocating for the use of student test scores to measure teacher effectiveness.''
title: Not in the Florida Legislature

statement: "As a state rep, I was considered the fourth-most conservative in the Legislature.”
title: For one of his two terms

statement: "A lot of the ideas in terms of the (health insurance) exchange, just being able to pool and improve the purchasing power of individuals in the insurance market, that originated from the Heritage Foundation."
title: UPDATED: An unwanted shout-out that's still partly right

statement: "Farouk is on fire."
title: Guilty

statement: "Cuba wants to let the Chinese drill in some of the very parts of the gulf that American producers are currently forbidden to touch, as close as 45 miles off the Florida coast."
title: Not the 'very same' waters

statement: “This week liberal Bill White faced an ethics  complaint about more than $83,000 he failed to report to the state  Ethics Commission.”
title: White says he reported holdings; law silent on if he must do more

statement: "On the day that (the Republican) state leader resigned in disgrace, a ‘Shred-It' truck rolled up to Republican headquarters."
title: And he didn't even have to call anyone names

statement: "Actually, Reagan was a Democrat before he was a Republican."
title: He was not a lifelong Republican

statement: "The average student will be spending $1,700 to $1,800 more during the life of their loan because of this surcharge."
title: No change to student loan rate

statement: "An attack on a healthy 22-year-old homosexual man would be more protected under the law than an attack on an eight-year-old child."
title: That could happen, under certain circumstances

statement: Charlie Crist "worked with Acorn" to give felons voting rights.
title: ACORN isn't near this tree

statement: "The New England Journal of Medicine released a survey the week that President Obama signed Obamacare stating that over 30 percent of American physicians would leave the profession if the government took over health care."
title: Not exactly a peer-reviewed scientific survey

statement: Marco Rubio controlled funds that "out of the $600,000 that were raised,  only $4,000 went to candidates to try to improve their chances to be  elected to office."
title: Crist exaggerates the funds available

statement: "According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, the IRS would need to hire over 16,000 people ... to audit the American people and impose the new taxes and mandates" of the health care bill.
title: It comes from a GOP analysis of a CBO estimate

statement: "The average cost for health insurance in Florida went from about $600 a month for an individual to about $150 a month."
title: Cherry-picking to the max

statement: “The bill also provides full federal  funding for abortions…”
title: Nope--and insurers could drop existing abortion coverage

statement: Rubio's tax swap proposal "would have been a massive tax increase."
title: Overall, Floridians would have paid less taxes

statement: "Since that famous day in February where the governor campaigned with  Barack Obama on behalf of the stimulus program, 211,000 Floridians have  lost their jobs."
title: Very close on target

statement: "Just this week we received the news that for the first time Social  Security is now paying out more in benefits than it's taking in. That  was something that was supposed to happen in 2016."
title: Fresh off the news, he's right

statement: Did not vote for tax increases as a member of the West Miami City Commission.
title: Not what the record shows

statement: "The spillover violence (from Mexico) in Texas is real and it is escalating."
title: Mixed reviews, but so far violence seems sporadic

statement: The federal health care plan "costs Texas taxpayers $2.4 billion per year."
title: Cost estimate based on old information

statement: "The American people will be appalled to learn the health care bill exempts (congressional) leadership and committee staff."
title: Be careful what you ask for

statement: "Marco Rubio thinks that government shouldn't be in the health care business at all."
title: Bashing "ObamaCare" doesn't equal ditching health care biz entirely

statement: Marco Rubio's "income skyrocketed while his power increased."
title: 2004 was a good year

statement: "Our national debt ... is on track to exceed the size of our entire economy ... in just two more years."
title: He's right: A major milestone is looming

statement: The health care reform bill "is the largest tax increase in U.S. history."
title: Significant, but not record-breaking

statement: "Joe, I keep hearing you every morning talking about the biggest tax increase in history, but you don't mention it's also the biggest tax cut in history.''
title: Others have slashed the tax rate more

statement: In Cover Florida "thousands already enrolled and climbing."
title: But that's barely a dent of the uninsured

statement: The Associated Press called Charlie Crist's attacks "over the top," "out of context," and "not true."
title: Back to the back wax

statement: Says she was the “the only Democrat who voted against the Wall Street bailout."
title: Yes, the only Florida Democrat

statement: "War for the soul of the TxDems: 57% of  Dem incumbents for Tx House LOST their primary."
title: Most Dem incumbents had free rides to re-nomination

statement: The cost to implement Florida's class size amendment so far has been "$16 billion."
title: $15.8 billion since 2003

statement: Marco Rubio "supported $800,000 for AstroTurf for a field where he played flag football."
title: A field goal, not a touchdown

statement: The health care bill will subsidize families of four that make more than $80,000 a year.
title: Newly signed bill assists families earning up to $88,200

statement: "Last week the Texas State Board of Education (SBOE), led by Rick Perry's appointee, voted to remove Thomas Jefferson from social studies textbook standards. That's right. Thomas Jefferson... was deleted from a list of historical figures who inspired political change."
title: The SBOE removed Jefferson from the list, but there's more to the story

statement: Florida's cost for the Medicaid expansion will be $1.6 billion a year or  more.
title: McCollum cites highest number possible

statement: "There will be no public funding for abortion in this legislation."
title: We agreed, even when Stupak didn't

statement: Florida's legal challenge of the federal health care bill is "bipartisan."
title: 12 Rs + 1 D = bipartisan?

statement: The Iraq war has been "our longest war."
title: Longest? Not yet

statement: "Hospitals, doctors, MRIs, surgeries and so forth are more extensively used and far more expensive in this country than they are in many other countries.''
title: Pay this bill and call me in the morning

statement: Marco Rubio is a "Miami lobbyist."
title: He hasn't been a lobbyist in years

statement: "The Federal Reserve system has presided over about a 95... percent decline in the U.S. dollar."
title: Inflation takes the blame

statement: "For years now, we have spent more money than we have taken in."
title: Less than two fiscal years

statement: "In Texas, schools do not even have to teach sex education."
title: The law isn't clear

statement: The Democratic health care bill will "collect higher taxes for 10 years  and provide health care for only six years."
title: He's overlooking some immediate programs

statement: "Americans who get their insurance through the workplace, cost savings could be as much as $3,000 less per employee than if we do nothing."
title: Best case scenario, according to one report

statement: The Democratic health care plan is a "government takeover of nearly 20 percent of our economy."
title: Once again, a  ridiculous exaggeration

statement: “Rick Perry had planned to retire from the legislature  until his best friend, David Weeks, and I talked him into switching  parties and running for the GOP nomination for agriculture  commissioner.”
title: Perry silent as Weeks says Rove wasn't only Perry cheerleader

statement: "Kay Bailey Hutchison was elected state treasurer,  succeeding Ann Richards. Democrats then abolished the position ...  Hutchison later became a U.S. senator."
title: Treasury shut down years after Hutchison elected to Senate

source: Citizens for Lower Taxes and a Stronger Economy
statement: St. Pete Beach's experiences are a "fair example" of what could happen if Amendment 4 passes.
title: Not completely fair

statement: A national poll found that among people who oppose the Democratic health care reform bill, "almost 40 percent" opposed it not because it goes too far, but because "they don’t think it goes far enough. ... They will not be unhappy when we pass health care reform."
title: The number's right; the meaning is fuzzier

statement: The Congressional Budget Office analysis of the health insurance reform legislation says the bill "cuts the deficit by $1.2 trillion in the second 10 years."
title: CBO didn't put a dollar figure on deficit cuts beyond 10 years

statement: "The Massachusetts Supreme Court...defined marriage as simply, quote, the establishment of intimacy ... I guess that would mean if you really had affection for your horse, I guess you could marry your horse."
title: Mr. and Mrs. Ed?

statement: "As Florida's CFO, I shut down Krakow's scam and refunded more than $1.2 million to Josephine and other victims of this con man."
title: Yes, Sink returned even more than what she actually said

statement: "There is no precedent for what the Democrats are doing with this deception. ... We have never written a reconciliation bill to amend a law that does not exist."
title: Democratic heath care strategy not unique

source: Citizens for Lower Taxes and a Stronger Economy
statement: Because of a local version of Amendment 4, "the taxpayers of St. Pete Beach have had to pay hundreds of thousands in legal bills."
title: Tab over $700k, city says

statement: "Under the ruling of the Supreme Court, any lobbyist could go into any legislator and say, if you don't vote our way on this bill, we're going to run a million-dollar campaign against you in your district."
title: Actually, you could do that before the court's ruling, too

statement: People "can't go fishing anymore because of Obama."
title: Obama isn't confiscating rods and reels

statement: My "border security efforts have led to a 60 percent  decrease in border crime."
title: Claim omits El Paso, Laredo, Brownsville and other burgs where most people live

source: Citizens for Lower Taxes and a Stronger Economy
statement: St. Pete Beach's local version of Amendment 4 resulted in "seemingly endless lawsuits (that) decimated the city's legal budget and forced the city to raise the property tax rate."
title: Tax rate rose for a variety of reasons

statement: "A government panel that didn't include cancer specialists says women shouldn't  receive mammograms until age 50...If government takes over health care,  recommendations like these could become the law for all kinds of diseases."
title: Amendments assure mammogram coverage for women over 40

statement: Rubio admitted he "would have accepted the stimulus money."
title: Pot, meet kettle

statement: "The economy began its nose dive when Democrats took control of Congress in January 2007."
title: Is it a nose dive if it's delayed by a full year?

statement: "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said this  week that the Democrats have to pass their terrible health care bill so  that the American people can actually find out what's in it."
title: Terrible? Nope, Pelosi said "exciting"

statement: Several times, Obama "has apologized for what he deems to be American arrogance, dismissiveness, and derision; for dictating solutions, for acting unilaterally ... ."
title: Not a sincere apology in the bunch

statement: Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison's  "concession speech came with less than 20 percent of the precincts  having been counted.”
title: Turns out, Hutchison planned to concede even if she squeaked into runoff

statement: "Bill White ... supports the ‘ObamaCare’ socialized medicine plan, as well as ‘Cap and Trade’ legislation that would kill thousands of Texas jobs."
title: Sizzling claims fizzle due to lack of proof

statement: “Bill White ...offered sanctuary to illegal immigrants.”
title: Personally, no, and Houston checks fingerprints against federal databases

statement: "Bill White spent his city billions of dollars into debt (and) saw crime rates soar while he backed gun control."
title: Adams fires a blank on crime rates

statement: Says the Texas State Board of Education is considering eliminating references to Christmas and the Constitution in textbooks.
title: We the people will study the Constitution, and Christmas stays in culture class

statement: The Obama administration "spent more money on the Cash for Clunkers program than the space program."
title: If he means "Constellation," why not say so?

statement: "Crist stays in $2,000 a night luxury hotel suites where he racks up $1,300 in mini-bar charges, and doesn't pay for a dime of it himself."
title: Crist didn't have a mini-bar bender

statement: "House  Appropriations Chair David Obey's partial earmark ban wouldn't apply to 90% of  earmarks."
title: Would address some of worst earmark abuses

statement: "Health insurance companies' costs are only 4 percent of all health care spending."
title: Hospitals and doctors get a bigger piece of the pie

statement: "We are the only industrialized nation that relies heavily on a for-profit medical insurance industry to provide basic health care."
title: Some countries' insurers are for-profit, but are far more highly regulated

statement: "Individuals and small businesses will be hit by increases in health insurance premiums as high as 39 percent."
title: Rates are risin'

statement: "Obama has proposed a 1.4% pay increase for active duty military in 2011. This is THE LOWEST SINCE 1973 ... A LOWER PAY INCREASE THAN WELFARE RECIPIENTS!!!"
title: Military pay raises set via formula

statement: Charges on the Republican Party of Florida credit card were made with "my money."
title: More complex than a two-word soundbite

statement: In the Senate version of the health reform bill, "Every enrollee in the Office of Personnel Management enrolled plan, every enrollee has to pay a minimum of $1 per month towards reproductive rights, which includes abortion."
title: Not everyone; only those that choose a plan that covers abortions

statement: "When we started this health care debate a year ago, 85 percent of the American people had health insurance, and 95 percent of the 85 percent were happy with it."
title: Most polls are slightly lower, but still a remarkable degree of satisfaction

statement: "If we just froze spending at 2007 levels ... by 2013 we would balance the budget ... and by 2020 we would cut the national debt in half."
title: Yes, and we'll each lose 20 pounds if we just eat lettuce

statement: "Nearly all of the top 50 prescribers of oxycodone in the United States are in Florida."
title: 49 out of 50, DEA says

statement: The Senate version of the health care reform bill "allows taxpayer money to pay directly for abortion in federal community health centers funded in the bill."
title: Not the intent of funding

statement: "Todd Staples recently tried to woo his supporters and right-wing base by suggesting the Agriculture Commission cut programs intended to feed the elderly and disabled, many of whom are veterans."
title: Proposal includes food aid cuts, but program wasn't targeted

statement: George W. Bush was "the least popular president in modern history."
title: Several were equally unpopular, or worse

statement: "The Florida Legislature raised taxes and fees by almost $2 billion" in the 2009 session.
title: Tax hike for cigarettes, increases for driver licenses and car tags

statement: "Florida's new fingerprint identification system is improving our rate of solving cold cases by 300 percent."
title: Matches, not necessarily arrests are up

statement: The health care bill will "create 4 million jobs, 400,000 jobs almost immediately."
title: Pelosi overstates one report

statement: "When Social Security started, age expectancy for the average man was 58. It was 62 -- 62 for women."
title: People didn't live as long back then

statement: Texas is the "fastest growing state" with the "most Fortune 500 companies."
title: Most companies, most new people but not the fastest growing

statement: "There's almost 1 million Texans who are unemployed and that's an all-time record number in our state."
title: But it's not the state's highest unemployment rate

statement: "Texas has installed more wind power than any other state, and all but four countries."
title: He's not blustering

statement: "Nobody has been talking about it (Medicaid fraud), focused on it, or paying attention to it."
title: Plenty have been paying attention

statement: Says Gov. Charlie Crist has called him "a rock star."
title: Yes, Charlie is an Aronberg groupie

statement: Reconciliation was used "for tax cuts for the rich twice under Bush."
title: Some tax cuts were for everyone

statement: "President Obama's bill won't bring down the costs (of health care) for average Americans -- or really for very few Americans, if any."
title: Most will see lower premiums

statement: "Debt has almost doubled in Austin under Gov. Perry."
title: Debt x 2

statement: "Congressman McCollum voted to dismantle Social Security."
title: Would a Florida congressman cross Grandma?

statement: "Washington cannot hide from the fact that Congress hiked the national debt ceiling to $14.3 trillion. They cannot hide from the fact . . . that the budget that they’re going forward with has more than a $5 trillion in debt in it over the next five years."
title: No one's hiding these numbers

statement: "Our graduation rate is the highest it's ever been."
title: 'Ever' is a misleading word

statement: Cover Florida "is available to any Floridian, offering basic coverage for about $150 a month, instead of the typical $600 a month."
title: Cherry-picking the most favorable numbers

statement: "The lifespan of the average American is less than that of people in nations that spend far less (on health care). ... To put it bluntly, we spend more and die sooner."
title: Correct -- we spend a lot more and die a bit sooner

statement: The Democrats' health care bills would end "the denial of ... coverage to those who have a pre-existing condition," while the Republican bill would not.
title: Same goal, two very different approaches

statement: Says she’s "tried over 100 jury cases in Travis County courts."
title: Try try again

statement: "We worked together to enact ... the largest tax cut in Florida history."
title: Based on bad projections

statement: "Due to ... tax cuts and lower (property) values, 2009 property taxes were almost $3 billion below 2007 property taxes."
title: Less taxes coming in

statement: "We are now seeing a decrease in violent crime."
title: Crime stats show a drop

statement: "He (Obama) has done several things well. Most of those things are places where  he changed his view from where he had during the campaign. So, for instance, he's  left our troops in Iraq and they're being more successful there. He boosted our  effort in Afghanistan, which is the right course to take. He did not close  Guantanamo, thank heavens."
title: Obama has stayed pretty close to campaign goals

statement: In 2001, former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan "justified increasing spending and cutting taxes, saying that we didn't really need to pay down the debt."
title: Not what Greenspan said on debt

statement: U.S. Rep. Alan Grayson "compared a former vice president to a vampire ... and compared America's health care system to the Holocaust."
title: Even caught Chris Matthews off guard

statement: Florida "has the second-highest foreclosure rate in the nation."
title: At times it's been third or fourth

statement: "Charlie Crist was the only prominent Republican in the country to campaign with Barack Obama before the stimulus passed, on behalf of the stimulus."
title: Only man hug? Yes. But not only GOP supporter

statement: "The Republicans have repeatedly said that they agree with 80 percent of what's in our bill."
title: They said it, though the degree of harmony may be oversold

statement: The health care bill "dumps 15 to 18 million low-income Americans into a Medicaid program that none of us want to be a part of because 50 percent of doctors won't see new patients."
title: Not that many doctors refuse Medicaid

statement: Gov. Rick Perry "spent over a million dollars on D.C. lobbyists asking for more federal money and lives in a luxury house that costs taxpayers $10,000 a month."
title: Hutchison on the money

statement: "I left the city with $43 million in the bank."
title: 'I don't know where the hell I got the 43 million.'

statement: Challenger Tim Tuggey "is a lobbyist who donated over $41,000 to Democrats who support abortion and same-sex marriage."
title: Solid math, then unsupported conclusions about Democrats

statement: "Her opponent: zero times a judge, zero rulings, zero experience on the bench."
title: Not to say she doesn't have experience in a civil court

statement: "I'm glad for the wording of it (an ethics report on corporate-sponsored Congressional trips) because clearly the wording exonerates me."
title: Not according to our dictionary

statement: Says he "never" donates to Democrats while Paul Workman "contributes to Democrat Kirk Watson and other Democrats running against Republicans."
title: When giving doesn't pay

statement: Says Paul Workman "voted in the Democrat primary, supporting Democrats with his vote."
title: 1994: The year of the Democrat

statement: "Fifty-seven" of  Rubio's 100 ideas "ultimately became law."
title: Here's an idea: Better math next time

statement: "Speaker Rubio supported gun restrictions that included background checks and waiting periods."
title: Yes, he supported "reasonable restrictions"

statement: "The costs for families (in the individual market) for the same type of coverage that they're currently receiving would go down 14 percent to 20 percent."
title: Pay more, get more

statement: The CBO found that the House Republican health care plan would lower premiums by "up to about 10 percent" and, for purchasers in the individual market, "those cost savings could even be higher."
title: On average, CBO expects drop in individual premiums to be smaller

statement: Says one in three Texas children drop out of high school.
title: Lots of numbers, little agreement

statement: "Since 1981, reconciliation has been used 21 times. Most of it's been used by Republicans."
title: Reconciling reconciliation

statement: "I vetoed more than $3 billion in spending. Lawmakers and I cut taxes for 40,000 small businesses. Now Texas is No. 1 in job creation. The nation’s five best housing markets are right here in Texas. We balanced five state budgets and we cut state spending."
title: He's right about jobs and housing, but then come the distortions

statement: "Congresswoman Bachmann actually said we should be  'weaned' off our Social Security and Medicare. She wants to privatize Social  Security and replace Medicare with some kind of voucher system."
title: Radio ad wanders from the facts

statement: The Democratic health care plan is a "government takeover of our health programs."
title: Most people would still have private insurance

statement: Bill McCollum "cost the rest of us billions" as a member of Congress, including a national debt that "skyrocketed" to $4.7 trillion.
title: Right in the details, but lacking context

statement: Bill McCollum voted four times to raise his own pay, by a total of $51,000, and earns a congressional pension worth more than $75,000 a year.
title: The charge is accurate -- even slightly understated

statement: "Bill McCollum said tax cuts don't work."
title: Sink is cherry-picking one quote

statement: "As bank president, Alex Sink eliminated thousands of Florida jobs while taking over $8 million in salary and bonuses."
title: National GOP group's shot at gubernatorial candidate is pretty on-target

statement: "Florida leads the nation in elected officials charged with crimes."
title: Not per capita; and not just elected officials

statement: "One of the most recent polls said 75 percent of the American people have said either don't do anything or start over (on health care reform)."
title: Polls show pessimistic picture

statement: "We were promised (the stimulus) would provide 'green jobs' for Americans, but 80% of the $2 billion they spent on alternative energy went to purchase wind turbines built in China!"
title: Chinese wind turbine companies? Not so much.

statement: "Holly Turner... still takes her homestead (property tax) exemption in Fort Worth."
title: Her husband claimed an exemption for the 2009 tax year

statement: "We have solved the problem. ... Scientists are now saying leave the nuclear waste where it is."
title: Not a closed case -- and experts see Reid's solution as problematic

statement: "Mayor White has major stake in Barnett Shale production company."
title: White's interest not 'major'

statement: Says she "stopped Capital Metro from raising fares for senior and disabled citizens."
title: She voted for raising fares a couple times, too

statement: “In this judicial race, special  interest groups have demanded  money from me, in exchange for  endorsement and support.”
title: Strongly worded question doesn't amount to demand

statement: The stimulus includes  "$219,000 to study  the sex lives of female college freshmen."
title: More New England Journal of Medicine than Penthouse

statement: "$100,000 in  stimulus funds (were) used for a Martini Bar and Brazilian Steakhouse."
title: Brazilian cuisine with some help from taxpayers

statement: The stimulus includes "$7 million to build a bridge in Thedford, Nebraska, to help 168 residents avoid a 30-second wait at a local train crossing. Not one full-time job will be created."
title: Jobs for nearby Colorado workers

statement: "The current (agriculture) commissioner allowed tainted beef to be sent to school cafeterias."
title: Come to think, Staples also let it snow in the Panhandle

statement: In the stimulus, "$15 million dollars  went to 'build a bigger, better airport' for the town of Ouzinkie, Alaska,  population 165."
title: Airport is the island's lifeline

statement: The stimulus bill "didn’t create one new job."
title: Despite grim employment numbers, the stimulus has created jobs

statement: "My opponent... lost 43,000 jobs in Houston since he took over; we are losing jobs."
title: Shami is distorting — and neglecting — some crucial details

statement: "As Houston's mayor, I helped our area lead the nation in job growth."
title: But Houston did enjoy significant job gains when White was mayor

statement: "So far, the Recovery Act is responsible for the jobs of about 2 million Americans who would otherwise be unemployed. ... [And] the Recovery Act is on track to save or create another 1.5 million jobs in 2010."
title: The president highlights the most favorable numbers

statement: "In the three months before the act took  effect, America lost 750,000 jobs a month. In the last three months, we've lost  about 35,000 jobs a month."
title: He's off slightly for the three months prior to signing

statement: During "the recent global warming summit in Copenhagen, Nancy Pelosi and others stayed at a five-star hotel on a trip costing nearly $10,000 per person."
title: Some credit goes to a hotel chain's billing policy

statement: Says state Sen. Steve Ogden was the "driving force behind business income tax hurting small business, crafted the Robin Hood school finance scheme making property taxes skyrocket, wrote a budget that will result in a $14 billion deficit and voted against" gun freedoms.
title: Barrel o' claims, wee slivers of truth

statement: "There have been three people tried and convicted by the last administration in military courts. Two are walking the street right now."
title: Two have been released to foreign countries

statement: Among the money spent on health care in the United States, "46 cents on every dollar spent is through Medicare and Medicaid."
title: He used a valid number, but erred in defining it

statement: President Barack Obama's "initial response when we heard about the Christmas underwear bomber" was to say that "this was the act of an isolated extremist."
title: Obama used the words, but did he mean what Cheney thinks?

statement: Says the Texas Education Agency follows up to make sure undocumented immigrants paying in-state tuition at Texas colleges are applying for permanent residency.
title: TEA: No way

statement: "We have killed lots of innocent people in the state of Texas."
title: Innocents may have been executed, but that's not certain

statement: "We have billions in surplus."
title: Budget shortfall on the horizon

statement: The Bush administration prosecuted 190 suspected terrorists in federal courts.
title: Few of those are on par with Guantanamo detainees

statement: "When we go to vote, they ask for driver's license and verify that you are a voter and a citizen in the state of Texas."
title: No driver's license? Try bringing your electricity bill

statement: Despite touting the economic stimulus as a great triumph, "The very same report, however, notes that unemployment will average 10 percent for the rest of the year."
title: Unemployment rate may stay the same, even as jobs are added

statement: "Taxpayers even footed the bill for Perry’s trip to a bachelor party in Las Vegas."
title: Taxpayers picked up security tab only

statement: Franklin Roosevelt never allocated more than 12 percent of GDP to federal spending, while the percentage for Barack Obama is not projected to drop below 22.8 percent.
title: Only if you eliminate the final third of FDR's presidency

statement: On the new dollar coins, "'In God We Trust' is gone!"
title: God's on every coin

statement: "A Democratic poll operation shows that Fox News is the most trusted news operation in the country."
title: Yes, thanks to popularity with Republicans

statement: One-third of the economic stimulus package was tax cuts.
title: In the ballpark

statement: The House passed a pay-as-you-go rule that said, "If you wanted to have an investment, an entitlement, etc., you had to pay for it."
title: Except for the exemptions and waivers

statement: Says Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison "took 154 private flights all funded by taxpayers" though "commercial flights were readily available at a fraction of the cost."
title: Comes to less than 10 trips a year for senator pressed for time

statement: Vice President Joe Biden's meeting "with the transparency and accountability board . . . was closed to the public."
title: Open government behind closed doors?

statement: Houston is "the third-most toxic city in the United States of America."
title: But not as toxic as Atlanta and Detroit, biz magazine says

statement: "One state even spent a million bucks to put up signs that advertise that they were spending on the federal stimulus projects."
title: Signs advertising stimulus, yes; $1 million, probably not

statement: "Barack Obama had 150 days in the U.S. Senate where he was able to vote quite often 'present.' "
title: Wrong on a couple of counts

statement: "The governor’s not taking his own fiscal advice. ... In the first fiscal quarter of this year, we’ve seen a 13.5 percent increase in spending, double-digit spending out of the executive branch in the State of Texas."
title: Figure is right, but implication is wrong

statement: "Florida still averages more students in its classrooms than any other state in the Southeast."
title: 2 years ago, if you don't include Virginia

statement: Says his executive order requiring young girls to be vaccinated against HPV wasn't mandatory.
title: There's no mandate without the "mandatory"

statement: "The law is very clear! 'The monies recouped from the TARP shall be paid into the general fund of the treasury for the reduction of the public debt.'"
title: That's what the bill says

statement: Some Republicans who voted against the stimulus "have been all too happy to claim credit for Recovery Act projects and the jobs those projects have produced. They come to the ribbon cuttings."
title: We found a few lawmakers who did

statement: "The money supply has doubled in the last year."
title: It depends how you measure it

statement: "Our (Texas) graduation rate ranks 43rd out of 50 states."
title: 43 out of 50 ain't bad... ?

statement: "For the hour after the (Jan. 14) debate, 'Debra Medina' was the No. 1 search on Google and for the remainder of that night No. 3."
title: Texans showed "volcanic" interest, but Medina wasn't nation's top search

statement: "We're also cutting a Forest Service economic development program that strayed so far from any mission that it funded a music festival."
title: $10,000 went to music festival ... in 1997

statement: The Senate-passed health care bill "is identical to the Massachusetts health care plan -- the same thing."
title: Same recipe, with a few differences

statement: Uses headlines to portray Gov. Rick Perry as beholden to special interests.
title: Seven reasons to watch for more political TV ads

statement: Bill White "is discriminating. He's taking jobs from African Americans and giving them to his friends."
title: White has a record; this isn't exactly it

statement: "Federal employees are making twice as much as their private counterparts."
title: Not double -- and not an apples-to-apples comparison

statement: "Thomas Jefferson created the Marines for the Islamic pirates that were happening."
title: Off by one president

statement: "We cut property taxes by one-third."
title: Tax burden didn't lighten

statement: "We passed without, frankly, the help of the Republican caucus, we passed 25 tax cuts last year, mostly aimed at the middle class and small businesses."
title: Stimulus was chock-full of tax cuts

statement: Says a prank phone call caused "400 children to be taken from their parents... without warrant."
title: Spoiler: the punch line isn't "Then you better go catch it"

statement: Health care reform "would bring down the deficit by as much as $1 trillion over the next two decades."
title: Big round number disguises complexity

statement: "The State of Texas does not even use the E-Verify system to determine if someone is legally in our country when they apply for a job."
title: But it still checks whether its job applicants are legal residents

statement: "Bill White has presided over the construction of what may be the world's largest abortion clinic."
title: May be the world's largest illogical leap

statement: "What were the old annual deficits under Republicans have now become the monthly deficits under Democrats."
title: Only if you seriously cherry-pick

statement: Obama came into office "with a $1.3 trillion deficit before I had passed any law. ... We came in with $8 trillion worth of debt over the next decade."
title: Debt has been years in the making

statement: "Mr. President, multiple times from your administration there have come statements that Republicans have no ideas and no solutions" on health care.
title: Yes, they've said that several times

statement: "I have had the challenge during this administration to suspend no less than 37 public officials in about 36 months."
title: Florida's public officials have been bad

statement: “Under (Rick Perry’s) watch as governor, over six million Texans have no health care coverage, including one million children, homeowners suffer from the highest insurance rates in the country, and college tuition has skyrocketed 136 percent.”
title: Two punches land, two slip a bit

statement: The president's health care proposals will cause "most Americans to have their premiums increased, not decreased, and hundreds of millions of people lose their current insurance coverage."
title: Pretending clarity while distorting

statement: "President Obama's proposed 'spending freeze' will only reduce the $42 trillion in government spending proposed between 2011 and 2020 by little more than one-half of 1 percent."
title: Not a panacea to budget woes

statement: "Inequality in Texas is steadily getting worse, with very few rich people, a great many poor people, and fewer and fewer in the middle."
title: Inequality has risen over decades

statement: "President Obama pledged to go through the budget 'line by line,' but on his watch, non-defense spending has spiraled out of control, increasing by 67 percent in the last year alone."
title: Different measurements yield very different results

statement: "A majority of Americans still oppose this health care bill."
title: More Americans oppose it than support it, but not always more than 50 percent

statement: "The amount of debt is on pace to double in five years and triple in 10. The federal debt is now over $100,000 per household."
title: Mixing different debt numbers

statement: "Here in Virginia, we have the opportunity to become the first state on the East Coast to explore for and produce oil and natural gas offshore."
title: He struck the truth

statement: "We cut taxes for 95 percent of working families."
title: The key word is "working"

statement: "Last week, the Supreme Court reversed a century of law that I believe will open the floodgates for special interests – including foreign corporations – to spend without limit in our elections."
title: Why Alito shook his head

statement: "At the beginning of the last decade ... America had a budget surplus of over $200 billion. By the time I took office, we had a one-year deficit of over $1 trillion and projected deficits of $8 trillion over the next decade."
title: Obama (mostly) nails it on the numbers

statement: "We've excluded lobbyists from policymaking jobs."
title: We found at least four

statement: The "pay-as-you-go law ... was a big reason why we had record surpluses in the 1990s."
title: An economic boom and defense cuts were bigger reasons

statement: "Because of the steps we took, there are about 2 million Americans working right now who would otherwise be unemployed."
title: It's a projection, and rosier than most

statement: "For the first time in history, my administration posts our White House visitors online."
title: Obama's transparency boast requires explanation

statement: U.S. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison “voted to continue Roe v. Wade.”
title: His verb's off, but his meaning is clear

statement: U.S. Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison “has voted nine separate times to raise the national debt ceiling.”
title: She's voted no a few times too

statement: "PWNED: House GOP Dominates Twitter, YouTube, Social Media in Congress."
title: Dems, consider yourselves PWNED

statement: "We have over 300 state agencies. Forty-five of those agencies are related to health care."
title: A committee by any other name is not an agency

statement: "Right now the Tea Party polls higher than the Republicans and the Democrats."
title: Armey overstates a recent poll

statement: Democratic presidents "have been considerably more effective at creating private-sector jobs."
title: Even with Obama's doldrums, the postwar pattern is surprisingly durable

statement: "With a stroke of a pen, the (U.S. Supreme Court) decided to overrule the 100-year-old ban on corporate expenditures."
title: Campaign finance law has complicated history

statement: "We lowered the business tax from 4 percent down to 1 percent."
title: Rate dropped, but taxes rose

statement: "As long as I have served . . . This is the first time  every single solitary decision has required 60 senators."
title: Cloture votes more common, but not that common

statement: Members of Congress passed a pay raise for themselves of $10,000 over two years even as they voted not to raise Social Security benefits for 2010 and 2011.
title: A nugget of truth that misstates key details

statement: "The Texas Department of Transportation... misplaced a billion dollars."
title: Double-counted funds crippled road projects

statement: “The largest tax increase that we have ever had in our state is yours – it is the business margins tax that you signed, governor.”
title: Senator's tax argument has holes

statement: The Democrats' health care bills would provide "free health care for illegal immigrants."
title: No accommodations for immigrants

statement: The House health care bill provides for "free abortion services, and probably forced participation in abortions by members of the medical profession."
title: Abortions paid through premiums, no docs forced to perform them

statement: There are "high administrative costs" when you donate to Haiti relief through the White House Web site.
title: No, there's no Pay Pal on White House site

statement: In Massachusetts, Scott Brown's Republican affiliation is "not a secret, but clearly not on display."
title: Candidate made his views clearer than his partisan ties

statement: "The Washington Times ... pointed out that we had succeeded where previous administrations had failed" on spending cuts.
title: But it was a news story, not an editorial

statement: "The No. 1 issue that the American people care about is getting America back to work."
title: Other issues trail in significance

statement: Health care reform: "Everything about it is going to raise costs, raise taxes and lower the quality of health care."
title: Everything or some things?

statement: "Most Texans aren't millionaires."
title: Rest of us can still be proud and loud

statement: Chile ranks third internationally in economic freedom, while the U.S. ranks 17th.
title: Chile's economy has grown, but Beck's rankings are off

statement: "The Trans-Texas Corridor is dead."
title: Not much of a pulse left in the asphalt

statement: "Close to half of the folks in this country illegally entered legally (but) overstayed (their ) visas."
title: Numbers differ based on study

statement: Obama's job approval rating is up.
title: An uptick in the last month

statement: Says Gov. Rick Perry was for Wall Street bailout before he was against it.
title: Perry said giddyup, then whoa!

statement: The Obama administration "raised discretionary spending by 24 percent from President George W. Bush's last full-year budget and will run up more debt by October than Bush did in eight years."
title: Whose debt is whose?

statement: When President Bush took office in 2001, he inherited a $236 billion budget surplus, with a projected 10-year surplus of $5.6 trillion. When he ended his term, he left a $1.3 trillion deficit and a projected 10-year shortfall of $8 trillion.
title: A trip down Memory Lane, when they said the budget future was "bright"

statement: Says Kay Bailey Hutchison voted for sanctuary cities.
title: Truth gets distorted and deported

statement: "We definitely lost way more jobs in Texas this year than we gained — we lost 300,000 jobs in Texas alone this year."
title: She wants guv to join the jobless

statement: "No Democratic campaign for (Fla.) governor has ever had these kinds of resources this early on in an election cycle."
title: Helps that the primary is uncontested

statement: Says Land Commissioner Jerry Patterson threatened to shoot him.
title: Wudda cudda, in a movie only

statement: Says Rick Perry's "Pay to Play" politics led him to send $899 million to an offshore call center in Bermuda, driving down enrollment in children's health insurance
title: The call centers were in Texas, for starters

statement: "Sen. Hutchison abandoned Republicans and stood with Democrats to ensure health care legislation would pass quickly."
title: Democrats cast the crucial votes

statement: During his tenure as mayor, he "saw Houston’s crime rates drop to the lowest levels in more than 25 years."
title: Crime is down across the nation

statement: "More than 1,000 people ... move to Texas every day."
title: Perry may be right, but he's using wrong statistics

statement: A recent Obama executive order could "lead to a number of investigations by Interpol in the United States, potentially aimed at American officials."
title: Interpol just doesn't work that way

statement: "A number of the national publications have put this race in a tossup race between Democrats and Republicans. They don't know who's going to win this race."
title: The number appears to be one

statement: "The attorney general requires that rape victims pay for the rape kit."
title: Victims aren't stuck with the bill

statement: Says she has "quadrupled agents to secure our border."
title: Sure, she and 99 other senators

statement: Says approximately 70 percent of jobs created in the United States in November 2007-2008 were in Texas.
title: Only true by overlooking most of United States

statement: Says a careless attitude and "poor oversight by the Texas Department of Agriculture" led to deaths and illnesses traced to a Texas peanut plant.
title: Challenger overlooked health department role

statement: Says Bill White is for gay marriage.
title: He supports civil unions -- not the same as marriage.

statement: “Illegal immigrants currently occupy 8 million jobs.”
title: He was in the ballpark, but is he now?

statement: Says he "brought 1,200 jobs to Texas by moving his factories here from China."
title: From Korea, actually.

statement: "Texas is LAST (50th) in spending for mental health care."
title: Close ... Texas is second to last

statement: "Why is January 8th an important date in American history? This day in 1835 is the only day in our history when we have not been in debt."
title: Probably more than one day

statement: "We had no domestic attacks under Bush."
title: Did Rudy get amnesia?

statement: "Most of the people that work in finance make $70,000, $80,000 a year."
title: His artful wording includes janitors and receptionists

statement: "I haven't missed a vote since 1993."
title: He's had a perfect track record for 15 years

statement: "President Obama has broken his pledge to the American people to be transparent throughout (health care reform negotiations)."
title: Obama said negotiations would be on TV

statement: "Americans admire Glenn Beck more than they admire the pope."
title: By one measure, Beck beats the pope by a nose

statement: President Obama "doesn't ... want to admit we're at war."
title: Except for all those times he's said we're at war

statement: "In Florida, Sen. Bill Nelson ... got a $25 billion to $30 billion carve-out for Medicare Advantage patients in their state."
title: Changes benefit more than Floridians

statement: A Medicaid provision added to the Senate health care reform bill "is not a special deal for Nebraska."
title: We don't see any other states listed

statement: "I didn't campaign on a public option."
title: It was in his campaign literature

statement: Charlie Crist broke the quarter "record for fundraising in a U.S. Senate race in Florida."
title: By a long ways

statement: When Charlie Crist was elected governor, Florida ranked 31st in K-12 education. "Last year ... we went from 31st to 14. And this year, the top 10 in America."
title: One of these numbers is not like the others

statement: Health care reform plans being consided in Congress "will finally reduce the costs of health care."
title: Health care spending up slightly, rate of growth slowed slightly

statement: President Obama has "the worst ratings of any president at the end of his first year."
title: Almost -- Ronald Reagan had equally mediocre ratings

statement: "Today and every day, an estimated 14,000 Americans will lose their health insurance coverage."
title: Democratic talking point gets a second opinion

statement: "We've created or saved up to 1.6 million jobs, according to the CBO -- the Congressional Budget Office -- through the Recovery Act."
title: That's the top end

statement: The Climatic Research Unit e-mails show that the science behind climate change "has been pretty well debunked."
title: There's lots of other climate change research out there

statement: "President Obama's proposal calls for serious cuts in our own long-term carbon emissions," but China and India will still be allowed to increase their emissions.
title: Emerging economies don't have absolute reductions

statement: A recent drop in the unemployment rate is questionable because it was calculated "over two days of the Thanksgiving week."
title: The numbers reflected what was happening two weeks before Thanksgiving

statement: The "post-Soviet industrial meltdown is responsible for most of the progress in reducing carbon emissions that Europe is able to claim."
title: There's more to this story

statement: "To use money from the TARP fund in the manner that is being discussed by the White House and congressional Democrats would be a violation of the law."
title: Actually, Congress makes the law

statement: "I'm predicting (the Saints) will go not only undefeated, but all the way through the Super Bowl -- something that's never been done before."
title: Hey Guv, some former Dolphins would like a word with you

statement: Labor union president Andy Stern is "the most frequent visitor" at the White House.
title: Only if you use incomplete, outdated data

statement: When Obama was interviewed by American reporters in Asia, "Not one of them asked me about Asia. Not one of them asked me about the economy."
title: More than one did

statement: "In the past year, more than 20 percent of Americans have changed their mind about the war in Afghanistan. They conclude we shouldn't be there."
title: Polls aren't so clear

statement: "We're going to have more troops (in Afghanistan) . . . than the Russians had."
title: Only if you count NATO, too

statement: "In the last few months alone, we have apprehended extremists within our borders who were sent here from the border region of Afghanistan and Pakistan to commit new acts of terror."
title: Accused, but not convicted

statement: Less than 10 percent of Obama's Cabinet appointees "have any experience in the private sector."
title: Most of them do, to varying degrees

statement: The Senate health care bill does not contain limits on medical malpractice lawsuits.
title: He's right: No tort reform here

statement: Under the Democratic health plan, families "will be forced to spend an additional $2,100 a year to keep their current health care."
title: Only true for a small percentage of people

statement: A new Republican litmus test "would have resulted in (the GOP) kicking out Ronald Reagan."
title: Reagan would be on the bubble

statement: "If you want to talk firsts for Bush, this was the first time in American history that a president took us into a war and cut taxes."
title: More often, taxes have gone up during wars
